address: Parque Florestal das Queimadas, Santana, Madeira Portugal
name: Levada Caldeirao Verde
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Caldeirão Verde Levadas Walk in Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Levada Cauldron Green
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Levada do Caldeirão Verde Levada Walk from Funchal
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Walk Green Cauldron - Maze Forest
ranking: #9 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #9 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Another fine example of a levada. Amazing fauna and flora. Only one big down side for me was the amount of toilet tissue tossed at the side of the path. Why do people think it is ok to do this when there is not a speck of other litter left. Sorry rant over.
reviews/1/text: The walk is amazing with lush vegetation and mini waterfalls to walk through (rainjacket with hood recommended). Some interesting tunnels that you will need a torch for (watch your head if tall like me). We were going to walk beyond the end to the Inferno walk but unfortunately that was roped off as the fence to prevent you falling down the mountain had fallen away. You could get past it and some people may have continued, but by that point we'd already had a good time getting to end of Verde and wanted to live to tell the tale, so returned the way we came.
reviews/2/text: I liked that levada becasue theres a huge waterfall and some smaller waterfalls along the way . It was a fun hike because you go under some waterfalls too and I got soaking wet . There are some tunnels to so you need a torch becasue if you use a torch on your phone you could drop it and I need to sell this phone once i get a new one soon so it cant be smashed . But that levada was real pretty and not dangerous at all like a walk in the woods or at a park
reviews/3/text:
If you love trekking this one is fabulous 
Me I started it in Roncho then I joined the beautiful pousada on Queimadas parc
Then I followed the levada, water distribution system , until the waterfall 
If you have time I advice you to continue until the Caldeirao do inferno
View is stunning 
Be aware that you have to go through some tunnel ! Take a light with you
reviews/4/text: For us this has been one of the nicest walks on Madeira so far. I recommend to keep going to Caldeirão do Inferno as this part is even nicer and adventurous 🤩 Bring a lamp 🔦
reviews/4/title: One of the best on Madeira!
reviews/5/text:
The hike "only" to Caldeiro Verde is 6.5 km one-way and the route goes the whole time along a levada (easy in terms of the altitude profile). Even more interesting for us than Caldeiro Verde, was the gorge that is passed shortly before Caldeiro Inferno. It is an extra 2.5 km (one-way) to the Inferno, but -at least for us- with the most strenous passage (300 steps). Once you reach the top, it's not quite obvious where to go next: 2m into the tunnel where it says 'do not enter' and then turn right. In between you cross various tunnels, a headlamp is helpful here (illuminates better than a mobile phone lamp). 
We arrived at the Verde at around 11.30 a.m. and on the way back at around 2 p.m., finally we found the earlier time better because of the light conditions. In comparision to many other hikers parking lots you have to pay here (day ticket 3 €).
reviews/5/title: Only really good in combination with Caldeiro Inferno
reviews/6/text: It was a beautiful walk. The difficulty level is low, the path is very well protected, not recommended for children. We passed through 3 caves, but they are easy to go through, it is advisable to take a flashlight or use the light of the cell phone. As the path is wet, it is necessary to pay attention to the shoes not to slip.
reviews/7/text: Nice walk, beautiful waterfall. Highly adviced to start early in the morning as you have to go back the same way. So it might get really crowded at the waterfall and on the way back. A lot of toilet paper next to the trail.
reviews/7/title: Nice walk, great waterfall and some toilet paper!
reviews/8/text:
This place is indescribable- a world of natural beauty like you’ve never seen. You go up a big long hill, slowly engulfed in the majestic cornucopia of mother natures teet. Then it gets better because it has this awesome car park with a barrier that goes up when you press a button. The more you press it the more bits of paper or gifts you and the more people blow their horns behind you. Weird! Wonderful! Eventually you head along this path along all these massive green trees and there is this irrigation thing constantly going the other direction which I think was water, but it was hard to tell. The path is 8km towards a waterfall. The vibe is very much a humming buzz, like the first lift of adrenaline from acid. You see all these crazy plants and flowers that you only really ever see in films about flowers and plants. It was sort of exciting. 

Anyway, there were a lot of people coming the other way and the path is kind of narrow, so if you’re really obese or American, I’d think twice about going at all. About  halfway along I kind of got bored of plants and flowers and trees and wondered why there were no monkeys or whales or something. Really it’s kind of lame to celebrate it as a cornucopia of nature when the only animal I saw was the part of someone’s sandwich. The views were probably good - I couldn’t really tell because I was too knackered to look at them. After a bit further you really start wondering whether there even is a waterfall. All these glum ungrateful Germans walk the other way looking really unimpressed and barely any of them replied to my greetings and some of them were French, also. Then, god, you have to go through these gross tunnels and it’s dark and there was mud. By the third tunnel I really started hating the place. I mean, just build an escalator up to it or stick some pictures around the place, maybe some music too. The silence bugged me. The trees are all a nasty shade of green. At some point I thought about how pointless nature really is. It doesn’t really do anything and you don’t really get anything off it. I got to the waterfall and it was a massive let down. Actually I got to a sign saying it was another 100m to the waterfall up some stairs and I’d already walked like 7km so I wasn’t doing more. The waterfall has got a nerve and the signage is a con, really, as is nature and so is god. If I wasn’t an atheist I’d probably have asked for my money back but it was free. When I got back some two hours later all the kids were wisely examining their phones to find something better, which may be the smart thing to do come to think of it. Nature sucks. I think they should build a huge open air cinema there to make the most of the awesome car park, then it would get five stars. Other than that, I really loved it.
reviews/9/text: Walking along a levada, is an experience not to be missed in Madeira. It’s quite a trek along sometimes narrow and slippy waterways, you will step through streams, walk under waterfalls and you will get wet! It’s an amazing opportunity to wdd as ok the lush interior of this gorgeous island.
reviews/10/text: One of the best hiking trails in Madeira. It’s flat and relatively easy to do, but bring appropriate shoes and clothing. The trail usually gets muddy and the caves have water spots every now and then. Took us 4h 30min to complete the hike and enjoy the views of the waterfall. It’s all worth it!
reviews/10/title: This hiking trail is a must!
reviews/11/text:
Walked this using no tour guides etc.   This can be easily done at half the cost

Walked it in pouring rain 

Caught no 56 bus at 8.15am from Funchal centre and after a 2 hour bus ride up and over mountains with numerous hairpin bends arrived at Santana. These Madeira bus drivers make the London bus drivers so tame!. Then from Santana took a taxi (cost 10 euros one way) for a 3 mile trip to the start of the walk( No bus avaliable and steep climb up)

Walk was in wet conditions+++ .You need to come well prepared  with proper walking boots, waterproof backpack or items in a plastic bag inside the backpack and whatever the weather take warm waterproof clothing.

Even so we got thoroughly wet through but the waterfalls were magnificent with so much water going over the top etc, walked back through the tunnels using a mobile phone flash light etc . Be careful that you don’t knock your head on the top of the tunnels which can be low in places and also some low overhanging branches.

When finished had a beer/tea/ coffee at one of the cafe’s in Santana ( It had stopped raining then!) and caught the 5.15pm bus back wet but happy that we had achieved this in such bad conditions!
reviews/12/text:
This is an excellent, typical levada walk, taking in several waterfalls and a couple of view points.

It's not a difficult walk in that it's pretty flat,  however, you are walking along the side of the mountain, on narrow, uneven paths and levada walls and through very dark tunnels (where you'll need to walk bent over) so don't forget to take a torch. There are cable fences along the route so you dont feel at all unsafe, although can see a looong way down.

You have to return the way you came so walk is 13km total. You also have the option of continuing on for another 2.2km ew, which we did, to the so called Devils Cauldron. Slightly more difficult in that there are 70m of steps to navigate and a fairly narrow entrance to a tunnel  but will be fine for most people. 

There is a car park at the start which costs 3 euro, toilets (50c coins only) and a cafe.

This is a wet and much cooler area with muddy paths. Plan on it being around 8 degrees lower in temperature than on the coast.
reviews/12/title: Excellent levada week in the mountains
reviews/13/text: Very tame and samey. The last 30 mins are the best but nothing spectacular, the path is pretty well trodden m. If you go aim to arrive before 9 to avoid crowds. Parking costs €3.
reviews/14/text:
Following yesterday’s Rabacal Levada Walk, I went on another one arranged by JB Tours earlier today - Queimadas/Caldeirao Verde.

It is one of the Island’s oldest Levadas located near Santana which receives 5-6 times more rainfall per annum than Funchal. Indeed, today’s Walk started in lovely sunshine but much of the return Walk (6.25 Kms to Caldeirao Verde and 6.25 Kms back) was in light rain so anyone planning to go on this particular Walk should either take rain gear or at least check the weather forecast!

The Walk itself is predominantly flat with relatively few views due to the heavy tree  cover (not dissimilar to a tropical Rainforest) which does involve keeping a watchful eye on both branches and roots (you have been warned!). Tunnels are another feature (there are 4 - two barely 10/15 metres long but the other two are between 100-150 metres and the ceilings are low in places) so don’t forget your mobile phone or - even better - a torch as you won’t regret it!!

Another tip is to make good use of the security wires as - in addition to steep drops - the path is narrow in places which can make it difficult to let other walkers (fortunately no where near as many as yesterday’s Rabacal Walk!) pass!

All in all, a most enjoyable experience - enhanced by having both an excellent guide (Eduardo) and driver (Daniel) - and one I would gladly recommend to others.
reviews/14/title: Flat Walk although attention needs paying to Tree branches/roots as well as the Weather Forecast!
reviews/15/text:
Firstly the car parking. If you put Quaimades car park in Google navigation it  may send you to the second smaller free car park which is known as Pico dos Pedras car park. Beware that this is nearly three KM from the start of the actual Levada walk.  I guess you don't want to add a boring six k to your 13.5 k walk. 
See the photo and put the right car park of the forestry department : Parque Florestal for navigation. 
It's really a flat walk with very few steps. There is practically no view for first half and it only opens up after the tunnels. It's walking through green canopy which is lovely but may be monotonous. Many other levadas even the extremely popular 25 Fontes had better views. 
Some areas are very narrow. You really don't want to stop and let others pass every two minutes. We went at 2-30 and still had to slow down on several occasions on the way in. On the way out hardly any interpretation and much better experience. You really need to keep your eyes on the path as it'd be very easy to stumble. 
The pool as expected is freezing cold. Saw a few birds including the Firecrest. 
Big car park with traditional houses, toilets, cafe and lots of cats. 
Not bad as an introduction but there are better walks.
reviews/15/title: Flat jungle walk, very few view points, choose car parks carefully.
reviews/16/text:
A truly beautiful levada with wonderful nature, views and waterfall at the end. It is not steep at all, on the contrary, but it can get pretty narrow, so you will have to wait for people to pass if there is someone going in the other direction. This levada seems to be fairly popular so I would recommend going early, or late in the afternoon. 
Also the last part is closed with a little wooden fence. I will not say here to ignore it, but if you wont, you will be robbed of the final part with pond and waterfall, so... suite yourself.
reviews/17/text: This is a nice and easy walk to experience the levadas and the greenery around it.  Unfortunately difficult to have good views.  There is a nice waterfall after 3.2 kms from the starting point
reviews/17/title: Nice flat walk with virtually no views
reviews/18/text: The one good thing about Covid19 is the chance to go around with almost no tourist, def recommend visiting Madeira and doing this was flat walk.
reviews/19/text:
The best hiking trip on Madeira! Not to difficult to walk (not to steep) and such a beautiful nature around! Really had the feeling to be in the jungle in Thailand. The views are surprising you and are changing very regularly. It's not about the Nevada at the end of the hike, but about the whole experience! I'm not used to hike at all, but with some good hiking shoes and my fleshlight of my mobile (have to cross 3 tunnels), it was such an amazing experience!
With all the pictures we took (as unexperienced hiker), it took us  about 4h to go & back. 
Parking is only € 3 for a full day.
reviews/19/title: Best hiking tour of Madeira - amazing views!
subcategory_ranking: #9 of 446 things to do in Madeira

name: Cabo Girao

offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Funchal Hop-On Hop-Off Tour 3 in 1
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Madeira Best of the West Day Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Amazing Skywalk, Madeira Wine Tasting and more... in 4x4 Half day Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Full-Day Madeira West Island Small-Group Tour from Funchal
ranking: #23 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #23 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
Fantastic spot where you can enjoy breathtaking views over the coast. Standing on a glass platform overlooking one of the tallest cliffs in the world is a very Adrenalin experienced!
The ticket costs only €2 pp so definitely worth it!
reviews/1/text:
beautiful view!
its really worth it seeing it especially the bottom is made of glass so you can clearly see whats underneath
reviews/2/text:
Cabo Girao is a famous viewpoint on the second highest sea cliff in the world, and the highest in Europe. There is a suspended glass platform offering views of Funchal and ocean, and a second platform with a floor. 

I was very underwhelmed by our whole experience. However, I can't really complain as entrance to the viewing platform is free, we just weren't all that impressed by the views. And the crowds of people detracts from the glass floor thrill factor, which you can actually barely see through (see photos) or else it's looking through a thick metal grid. The early morning views are nice enough and it is only a very short easy walk from the carpark, along good paths, so fine for a pram etc.

There is apparently a cable car to travel down to the bottom of the cliffs and see the black rock beaches. The ride is just 3 minutes, with views towards the East. Located 4kms away from the Skywalk, with a separate small carpark. I read that the cost is €5 each but we did not have time to experience this for ourselves.

Located on the south coast, a short drive from Funchal. The skywalk is free to enter and there are public toilets (take change). Open from 8.30am to 8pm. Spend upto half an hour to look at the views. We visited as part of a very busy action-packed touristy day to Porto Moniz natural swimming pools, Seixel, etc
reviews/2/title: okay views but I was very underwhelmed by the whole experience
reviews/3/text: Went out of season, used the redbus hop on hop off bus (20 euro)  from Funchal centre and the green road train(6.5 euro) at stop 18. Really good round about tour with spectacular views travelling up. This is topped off by the 589 metre glass skywalk at the top. Well worth a visit, as you can sit on the harbour waiting for the return redbus (no hardship, they are every 20 mins) and enjoy a wine and honey cake.
reviews/3/title: Spectacular views, go out of season.
reviews/4/text: Crowds of people visiting Cabo Girao are now completely out of hand.  A mob scene confronts you outside the entrance, with insufficient parking spaces and huge tour buses and taxis manoeuvring around in a dangerous way.   This used to be a highlight of a visit to Madeira but has been ruined since the over-hyped "sky-walk" was introduced and the cruise ship bus crowds descended en-masse.  Save your time and money and visit one of the many other miradouros on the island.
reviews/4/title: Used to be good, now an overcrowded tourist trap
reviews/5/text: A short flat walk from the car park to the skywalk. Huge drop, very impressive but not for the vertiginous! There's also a cafe, shop and toilets nearby.
reviews/6/text: Great views but there is not much else to it. Is great for a short trip but nothing is keeping you around for long. The trip up is also quite hairy.
reviews/7/text:
My wife and I visited Cabo Girao on a cruise ship excursion seeing the sights of Madeira. Access to the viewing platform is free of charge and as we were visiting in the winter months it wasn't too crowded (I gather it can get busy in peak season).
There is a glass floor viewing platform that you can stand on and admire the views if you are brave enough, looking straight down 580 metres to the shore below, although there are plenty of places to admire the coastal views without using the glass floor. It's one of Europe's tallest cliffs and the views of the surrounding area are well worth a short stop. There is a small gift shop near the parking area (I bought a bottle of local rum and a fridge magnet which were good value).
reviews/7/title: Impressive views, glass floor is fun, popular and unique attraction
reviews/8/text: 10 euros each seems expensive for a two minute journey. There’s only a short walk at the base and no benches to sit on.  The cafe at the top was closed and didn’t look like it had been open for months.
reviews/9/text: Came here as part of a 4x4 tour of the island. We were last here in 1998 and it has changed since then with a glass floor and railings,  so it's a lot safer for viewers nowadays. It has amazing coastline views and also the view down the second highest sea cliff in Europe.
reviews/10/text: This is an amazing point to see the sea side view. We came on a Sunday and the entrance was free. There are parking places around.
reviews/11/text:
Amazing place for photos of the cliff and shoreline. 
No entry charge, surprisingly.
Easy to reach by bus
reviews/12/text: Great view from the top, must visit when visiting Madeira, pleasant coffee bar nearby, well worth visiting. Enjoyed the travel from fishing village all the way up. Make sure you have good camera to catch the view. The skywalk is something special.
reviews/13/text:
Looking down to the sea thru the glass is an experience.  A little scary to look down.  I didn't stay on the skywalk long because someone behind me started to jump up and down.  

This sea cliff is the highest vertical cliff in Europe and the second highest in the world, second only to Thor Mountain in Baffin Island, Canada.

FYI,  there is a small gift shop in the area.  Also a restroom that you pay if I recall 50 cents euro to use.
reviews/14/text: The yellow bus tour extension was not cheap but very convenient and a helpful driver warned us how long we had before the n cut return.
reviews/14/title: Came back after 50 yrs for a colour photo
reviews/15/text: Another spectacular seacliff, probably the best one on Madeira. It has the highest cliff skywalk in Europe! It's like the one in the Grand Canyon, made of transparent glass. My friend went on it; I did not. I have acrophobia.
reviews/16/text:
We went there on our way back from Porto Moniz. Very please we did as it was the end of the day and was free👍

Not as frightening as we feared
reviews/17/text: Easy to get to on Rodeste bus number 4, 2.75 euro from lido or Funchal. So no need to pay for a day trip.Busy local route so takes about 40mins. You can bus back or take the green train down to Camara de Lobos. Plenty of taxis touting for business if you are desperate.
reviews/17/title: Cabo girao by local bus, easy and cheap.
reviews/18/text: Visited here on a tour .Found it a challenge to get here on a city bus .Lots of taxis in the parking lot. View was fantastic and washroom facilities available
reviews/19/text:
It is possible to reach Cabo Girao on the bus.  Views are stunning in both directions and the ride from Funchal is also very picturesque.  There were open turnstiles at this attraction so it is possible that at certain times of year a charge is made.  NB  there is a 50c charge to use the toilet.  There is also a cafe.
The viewing platform overhangs the cliff with a glass floor, fun but not for those who suffer from vertigo.
On the return journey (if using the bus) stand near the Yellow Bus stop the bus comes up the hill and does a three-point turn to head back down the way it came.  This is worth your time, but note Cabo Girao is often included in excursions too.  In my humble opinion the open-top buses (yellow and red) are not worth the money, use ordinary buses instead!
subcategory_ranking: #23 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Calheta, Madeira Portugal
name: Levada do Risco
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The Fantastic Waterfalls -Private Service
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Hike 25 Fontes & Risco Levada Self-Guided
ranking: #35 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #35 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Do you want jaw-dropping scenery and don't mind walking a bit? This is definitely the spot. It's a haul with some challenging hills but well worth the trek. Just remember, there is a shuttle to take you back up to the parking area.
reviews/1/text: We were not told how very narrow and high these paths were! We were told it was an easy 3 or 4 km walk. Never having been to Madeira before or heard of Levada walks, we assumed they were a bit like a country hike with some easy slopes. Wrong. Start off with an 800m tunnel anyone over about 5feet 5 will need to duck...if you can see by the light of your phone torch, if you have one...and walk through deep puddles in the dark. Next throw in steep, uneven steps of up to around 200 at once, a narrow path (barely wide enough for one small person) with a sheer drop "fenced off" by a 2 wire fence. The end result is beautiful but having an absolute terror of heights and no way of not carrying on with the walk, I was in no fit state to appreciate it. And we had to retrace the narrow path back! So if you have claustrophobia, difficulty climbing and descending uneven steps or a fear of heights AVOID! This walk would not be deemed safe in the UK!
reviews/2/text: Its a perfect and fresh levada to make on the very hot days on Madera, I definitly recomend it! You wont regret!
reviews/3/text: We did pay a visit to this gorgeous location, the whole party commented what a lovely day we had, we shall be back next year.
reviews/4/text: Trail PR 6.1 goes along Levada do Risco, at 1000m above sea level, taking you to an impressive waterfall, which falls vertically, creating a ridge in the rock.
reviews/5/text: A lovely easy walk that’s cool and quiet. Easy for kids of all ages. There are steps and a little cafe on the way. Beautiful birds and amazing scenery
reviews/6/text: Much more beautiful and bigger falls than 25 Fontes. Recommend going to see this one for sure! Also buy the van driving you up and down from parking, its good value because the walk from parking is not that beautiful.
reviews/7/text: This is a very, very easy levada you can almost do in flipflops. Practically a narrow walk, wide path, ending with a wonderful view at the waterfall. Coupled together  with 25 fontes it is a very pleasant trip.
reviews/8/text: Nice levada walk, in the shadows for most of the part. At the end there a beautiful start of levada with a lagoon and a waterfall. You can turn left halfway to the end, there is another waterfall at the bottom.
reviews/8/title: Walk in the shadow, leads to 2 waterfalls
reviews/9/text:
Lovely walk.  Can take a minibus to rabacal of walk.  

We combined with the 25 fountains walk which made it about 3 hours

Left Calheta in beautiful sunshine but very pleased to have waterproof and fleece for the walk
reviews/9/title: Lovely walk.  Be prepared for the weathet
reviews/10/text: Easy walk along a levada towards the Risco waterfall. The path is mostly flat and the walk does not take very long. We took the shuttle bus from the parking to the forester's house (Casa Rabaçal) and on the way back again because we had more plans for this day. If you don't do this, you have to walk an extra 30-45 minutes (x2) on a fairly steep and boring road. The shuttle bus costs 5 euros for a return trip, 3 euros one way. At the end of the walk you can see the Risco waterfall. We found this more impressive than we thought! After the viewpoint you cannot walk further, you have to go back the same way or you can still choose to take the 25 fontes levada walk.
reviews/11/text: Easy route, almost flat road, but first you need to reach the starting point. The waterfall is high, around a lot of water flows down from the mountains. Very beautiful views, very unusual nature.
reviews/12/text: We came up from the twenty five fountains levada, and hiked to Risco falls, and then over to the Rabacal house, then went back down to the 25 Fontes Levada.this is an amazing and beautiful place. The whole valley that Risco falls are in is a feast for the senses, with a combination of the sound of falling water from multiple sources, being surrounded by amazing views, with a wonderful clean nature smell.
reviews/13/text: We actually wanted to do the Levada do Alecrim. However we misunderstood the signs and after 20 minutes we realize we're doing the Levada do Risco. What a wonderful mistake!! It's so good to feel connected with the nature and in the end you'll find a beautiful waterfall..! And once you leave by car you'll have the best road trip... the nature and the mountains is almost like a Pandora movie.
reviews/13/title: Happiness in Nature and Easy to Walk
reviews/14/text: Easy route but from the route starting point. But from the free parking to the route starting point you will spend extra 30 minutes down and 50 minutes up... Unless you pay 3eur down and 3eur up for doing it in a 12-people-van...I suggest you pay it. The end of the route will reward your small effort with a great scenery.
reviews/15/text: We loved the drive up to the starting point of the hike. The hike itself was short but beautiful. We took the bus back up to the car for 3 euro each. Very much worth it if you are tired or in a rush. (The bus runs several times an hour from behind Casa de Rabacal.)
reviews/16/text:
The walk and the waterfall are pretty nice, but that’s about it. The tunnel and path was closed near the waterfall, and there is no apparent way to get at the bottom of it.

Basically you get to a spot close to it where lots of second hand photographers take the best spots to just take photos of the thing or film it for 30 minutes.

*The walk to that house is definitely not worth it, take the shuttle!
reviews/17/text: Average forest with very poor markings. We spent about 3 hours and were lost as there were some trails going nowhere. Some parts are very dangerous and unsuitable for the kids.
reviews/18/text: This is one of dozen of walks and trails you can have on Madeira. For us it was one of the best, because it has got some part along levada, some part flat and some with a bit of walking up and down. We were with our 12 years old daughter and she also enjoyed this walk. At the end of January we just met a few other tourists. We have stayed for a coffee in a Casa Rabacal, where you can eat and drink and rest for some time. Great thing is that you can also get a bus from this coffee shop and do not need to go up. However we did this. It was really nice day.
reviews/19/text: Nestor our eccentric guide with Pride of Madeira, knows his flora and fauna in the mountains of Madeira. The trek began at 4C so wear a coat and hat. Thankfully Nestor supplied torches for a long cold tunnel section. There is something soothing about walking beside running water all day. That seemed to make the ascents more tolerable. Bring a high-calorie lunch and drink. Wear sturdy high-grip boots. Pay attention to the one-way signs on the trails.
reviews/19/title: Mad Guide added to a wonderful nature experience
subcategory_ranking: #35 of 446 things to do in Madeira

reviews/0/text: We went for a swim for a couple of hours. Entrance is paid (2 euros), there are changing rooms and showers. Water comes from the ocean through the incoming waves. Beautiful views.
reviews/1/text: What a great sight that was design by using the natural surroundings. It was made safe and perfect for swimming or normal visit. Highly recommended and must see
reviews/2/text: We visiting in mid March and stayed a few days in Porto Moniz. I swam a few times in the beautiful lava pools - very few people around - especially good in the late afternoon when visiting trips had left. Had it all to myself at times! A little chilly to get in but gorgeous swimming.
reviews/2/title: Lovely swim in fabulous natural surroundings
reviews/3/text:
There are a number of extremely picturesque rock pools located along the seafront which you can swim in, although the water is cool - 18degrees when we visited in April. These pools are very popular so recommended to visit early on morning or later in afternoon. 

A small fee of €3 each to enter. There are male and female changing areas, with showers and toilets. There are lockers, but as it was very quiet when we visited we just left our bags on one of the large ledges near to the swimming area.

Note: if the sea is particularly wavy the lave pools will be closed, so make sure to go on a calm day. Located on the east of the Island.

I had read that the nearby Aqua Natura Hotel Restaurant is recommended as the views over the volcanic swimming pools and ocean from the balcony seating area are incredible, but we did not have time to visit ourselves.

We had a little stroll through Porto Moniz, which looked like a pleasant tourist town with lots of little shops and cafes and restaurants. There are nice view points overlooking the pools, with the photo frame to take the popular touristy photo.

Mid-April the water was cold at 18degrees, but pleasant enough to swim in for a short while. Then we relaxed in the sun for a while, before continuing on our action packed touristy day -  next stop the black sand beach at Seixel.
reviews/3/title: picturesque natural swimming pools by the sea
reviews/4/text: Hi, I visited Porto Maniz just last week and it's a lovely coastal town at the North Western tip of Madeira, spend a few hours here and take in the natural lava pools which fill up with the rising tide, even in March it was still warm enough for swimming, we had 23° that day & it's a lovely place to look around, plenty of nice bars and restaurants too.
reviews/4/title: Seawater Natural Lava Pools with Views.
reviews/5/text:
The "lava-swimmingpools" are spectacular! Even if you don't intend to go swimming.

Recommend walking around and admiring this beautiful place with great views and picture taking options.

Busy spot which attracts many tourists, even in January some people were swimming in the breathtaking "lava pools" 🤗
reviews/6/text: It was too cold to join the brave souls enjoying the pools but what a great place to watch both people and an incredibly scenic spot.  If anybody gives a lousy review it would be miraculous. This place is worth the drive from Funchal.
reviews/7/text:
This is a beautiful place and magical  to experience. You have to be lucky with the weather, especially twds the end of the year.  We were lucky and the water was not as cold as i thought it might have been.  The natural wave wash over the wall causing waves in the pool is great fun.  The Life Guards keep a close eye on bathers and the pool does not open if High Tide. 3 euros entry. Good changing facility; dont expect a hot shower to rinse under though. 

It can get busy; I hope my next visit is just as good.
reviews/8/text:
We had such a good time here !!! 
My youngest loved the fact the pools move with the waves. The water was pretty cold but as long as we keep swimming it was fine.
After swimming we had some lunch in the on site restaurant and must say the food was great as was the service
reviews/9/text: Wow, what an experience.  We arrived late in the afternoon in October but the water was still warm enough.  The lockers had closed by the time we arrived but it was safe enough to leave your bag and towel on the rocks next to the pools. The waves and views were incredible but in the pools made you feel very safe but at the same time, at one with nature.
reviews/10/text: A bit colder than we expected, but lovely. Lifeguards on duty. Price of sunbeds a bit expensive to rent, so most people sit on the rocks.
reviews/11/text:
We definitely wanted to check out this pool and visited as part of a day tour. We were so disappointed when we arrived to learn that no towels were provided — thought we could rent some. Really too bad the tour company didn’t tell us to bring some. Yes towels were for sale at the adjacent shop but for 33 EUROS each!
   Luckily someone on our tour had an extra hand towel so we both shared it to dry off a bit but could not take a shower.
   The pool and its setting are quite spectacular and not crowded at midday in Oct. Water temp was about 22–refreshing and not too cold. You can rent a locker or take your bag out poolside. Worth a stop …. and, go watch others from the viewing deck if you don’t want to jump in,
reviews/12/text: A fantastic place to visit. Absolutely beautiful and such clear blue water. You can park easily and we paid 5 euros for a day’s parking. We went to the area down towards the helipad but you can also pay to go in the opposite end as well which I think is 3 euros but the website will confirm the prices.
reviews/12/title: A beautiful place with crystal clear water
reviews/13/text: A nice fun time and not expensive like we thought it might be. It was 3€ to get in. It was very busy and I can only imagine in peak season it is hectic. It would be awesome on a flat calm day but it was a bit windy the day we went which meant the waves were making it a little trickier to enjoy but it was nice. There could be more places to sit but otherwise very good.
reviews/14/text:
We made two visits to the natural pools. On the first the sea was calm & all areas of the pools were open, as was access to the sea. On our second visit the waves coming in were massive & all but the main pool area were closed for safety reasons. The smaller area available for swimming & the waves was more than made up by the fun swimming conditions. Also great for photography.
Look after your possessions if you go, or rent a locker. I left my flip-flops in the 
changing room. When I went back to get them they had gone.
You can rent sunbeds & a sun shade or take your own in with you.
reviews/15/text:
If you in Madeira you should check this out !!!
It’s a great place to relax and cool down during hot weather. Is also one of the best natural pools in the world! 
Highly recommended
reviews/16/text: Crisp, clear saltwater pools with beautiful views.  Entrance fee is reasonable.  Large locker-rooms with showers and changing stalls.
reviews/17/text:
Scenic outdoor natural seapool,very busy in summer but still plenty of space,all amenities including lockers male and female changing rooms,onsite restaurants.
I only had a short visit as I was on a tour I could of stayed all day. Some parts of the pool have parts where the waves come crashing over from the Atlantic.very good safe pool really feels your out at sea.
reviews/18/text: Great experience swimming in the natural pools (not the sculpted ones).  Especially cool because you can see the raging ocean just over the wall yet it is perfectly calm inside the enclosure.  Nice cafe/beach bar inside as well.
reviews/19/text: Made betwen the real lava banks, carefully cleaned, equipped and maintained inside. The pool filled with the real Atlantic Ocean water with no danger to swim in the Ocen itself. The posibility to rent the sunbeds and sun umbrellas (may be this year a bit too expensive), the clothes changing rooms, clean toilets and shower rooms, with the Beqch Bar on the territory. The Salvage supervisors are at their place during the working hours. Magnificient experience to be washed away by the ocean wave from the Pool's fence in to the Pool - the most popular entertainment for children and adults.
reviews/19/title: Nice and safety swimming in the Atlantic Ocean water
subcategory_ranking: #13 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rabacal, Madeira 6160-206 Portugal
name: 25 Fontes and Cascada da Risco
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: "25 Fountains" Walk / Lost In The Beautiful Forest
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Rabaçal / 25 Fonts
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Skywalk & Rabacal "25 Fountains Levada Walk" in 4X4 Full Day Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Walk 25 Fonts - No words needed
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Rabaçal 25 Fontes Levada Walk in Small Groups
ranking: #28 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #28 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: This is one of the 'must do' list in any Madeira guide. We  visited on a fairly showery cool day, and walked it not from Rabacal but  from 'Parque de estacionamento Levada 25 Fontes' whch meant that parking etc was easy and the casa de rabacal cafe made for a good halfway stop on a 7 mile walk. The advantage of this route was that the approach is via a fascinating 600 metre tunnel necessitating your phone's camera  in the pitch black (not for those who don't like dark tunnels!)  and then virtually people-free levada paths until you join the throngs of people that join the path from rabacal often in walking parties being led by shouty walking guides and then for 2km you are in a people congestion zone all the way to the waterfalls. The Waterfalls were great but not so amazing that it was worth the throngs of people when the beauty of the levadas to me is getting away from the crowds and into nature. The cafe at Casa de rabacal was nice... pricier than most as you might  expect, but good
reviews/1/text: The only negative was that we were unaware of the minibus shuttle service which runs from the road to the start of the walks (3 euros). So we walked downhill for 30 mins to get to the levadas. Fortunately we got the taxi back up! We went to Levada do Risco, short 2.5km walk total, as we didn't have time to do 25 fontes due to the long walk to the start. Impressive waterfall.
reviews/1/title: Take the minibus taxi to the start of the walk!
reviews/2/text: Great food, hospitality, climate and lovely people. A must visit destination. Only 35 miles long and 9 miles wide but full of surprises. Funchal is a lovely city with quaint lanes, lovely markets and colourful  plants.
reviews/3/text: Windy and misty on top and nowadays you either walk from there, or pay for a minibus.  Warmed up and cleared quickly as we walked down.  Cafe has a toilet, so you don’t need to pay for the one just below it.  Path behind the Risco waterfall is gated and not open.  Walk back up to top is excellent hard exercise!
reviews/3/title: Risco waterfall great - path behind it closed
reviews/4/text:
nice hiking trails - must visit
long walk, to quite a nice waterfall. nice levadas!
there is a large parking spot at the top, come early, it's a crowded place, beware of cows, they walk on the roads.
reviews/5/text: Beautiful scenery and experience walking alongside the water. Strongly recommend going first thing in the morning to avoid tour groups as the paths are narrow and getting past a big group can take a long time - we only got caught in one. The minibus wasn't running when we were there - we would have caught it back as the walk back to the car park is pretty monotonous, and gets harder in the heat. Overall really worth an early morning visit - the car park as well has a lot of spaces in the mornings but you'll have to slot onto the road later in the day. The cafe was a nice break and does tasty coffee
reviews/6/text: The most beautiful lewada and the most crowded. It was the only place actually in the whole island where I spotted crowds. A waterfall in the and of the path is totally worth it though.
reviews/7/text: There is so much more than going to the 25 pontes! It was a long tiring way to get there, together with so many other tourists! We had a little book with Levada walks, we hardly saw any tourist and nature was also at her best. Mystic, quiet, wild flowers, steep slopes, fantastic! I ill certainly go back to Madeira, but not to the 25 pontes 😉
reviews/7/title: Too crowded, too long to get there, beautiful nature
reviews/8/text: Levada do Risco is the reward for walking down PR6.1 route and ending at the waterfall. The route towards the waterfall is steep at places, you'll notice this especially when walking back to the parking. You can use a van instead for the first part of the descent (and back).
reviews/9/text: Our first hike in Madeira.  Parking can be challenging as it can get busy.   There is a shuttle that you can take down (and up) to/from the Rabacal house that is quite steep,  but a paved path. Make sure you have a mask if you plan on using the shuttle.   The complete hike without shuttle for us (2 adults and 2 kids - ages 14/12) took just under 4 hours.  Very nice and would recommend highly.
reviews/10/text:
We parked at Parque de estacionamento (ER 110 15)and were able to find a spot, probably because we arrived at 2 pm. Some cars were parked on the road- I think most people come earlier. We walked to 25 fortes and back. It wasn’t too crowded- most people were returning to lot as we were walking to waterfalls.  If you are reasonably fit, you will work up a light sweat, but it won’t be too difficult. (Context- 3 smokers in 20s, 1 nonsmoker in 40s- none of us athletes). Some down, some up, some flat, some smooth pavement, some cobblestone. Mostly in shade. Take a jacket because weather changes frequently. There are not many grand views but it is still a very pleasant hike- just watch out for those vans driving the tourists who are not doing the full walk. From the parking lot to 25 fortes and back, it took around 3 hours. I recommend using the WC at the Casa do rabacal, which is about 30 min from the parking lot. It costs 50 Eurocent exact change and is surprisingly clean. Unlike many hikes I’ve done, the land is extremely steep on either side of the trail, so there are few opportunities to find a “nature toilet.”

TL;DR- go late in day, not too hard, nowhere to pee on the trail so plan ahead
reviews/10/title: Fewer crowds later in the day
reviews/11/text:
If you have time for only one levada choose this one.
We loved this tour. The nature is incredible, the walk is very easy and makes an amazing hike.
reviews/12/text:
Walking with Emanuel was great. He told us all about the history of the Levadas and pointed out all the plants. A day of low cloud but didn’t matter we were all wrapped up. Obviously beautiful waterfalls. A young couple were brave enough to have a swim. Emanuel called the chaffinches and we fed them. A great day out. Stopped on the way back for poncho.
Drop of and pick up like clockwork. Take a picnic
reviews/12/title: Walking with Emanuel the best guide
reviews/13/text:
Excellent trail. Make sure you use the mini bus, which takes you from the parking to the trail head. It's the best 5 Euros (round trip cost) we ever spent. It saves you at least one hour viewless walk. 

The 25 Fontes trail is easy to moderate with some climbs of stairs. You can combine 25 Fontes and Risco into one hike so you see both the upper and lower falls. Risco is very easy, which takes you only 15 extra minutes at the intersection after your way back from 25 Fontes. 

The Levada is admirable work by ancient Madeirans. Walking along it is quite an enjoyment with soothing water sound and lavish greeneries. If you can only do one Levada, do this trail.
reviews/13/title: This trail has waterfalls, Leveda, and beautiful views!
reviews/14/text: Our new year’s hike. Very much worth every step of the way. You might want to come early, parking could get tricky around noon. Plan enough time for the way back as it is mostly uphill.
reviews/15/text:
A really beautiful walk although popular so start early. When we arrived there was no one around at all and we were feeding the birds from our hands just a few minutes down the path - take bird seed :-) 

The walk down to the actual walk (down the road from the parking spot) is pretty long and when you hit the Rabacal House which is closed before 9/10am the actual walk starts. A very easy few km to Risco waterfall which is stunning but sadly did not have much water yet as theyd had a dry spell but very friendly birds there again to feed! 

Then you go back on yourself and walk down a number of steps towards 25 Fontes which is a canyon with 25 springs running down the walls. It was pretty but the number of people took away from it in our experience as lots of tours come here - it was super busy even in November so goodness knows what its like in peak season. 

An easy walk for the most part but about 600m of ascent and descent if you take the road up and down. I would advise you take the bus back up the road when you get back to Rabacal house, we chose not to, I do not know why but it was a hard walk back up in the heat and nothing to see as its just a tarmacked road but once we committed we just did it. Next time we would get the bus back up though. 

The cafe is nice and has toilets and nice food, cakes and drinks, a welcome treat after the walk.
reviews/16/text: A lovely easy well marked hike. Easy with kids of all ages- there are steep steps. Beautiful views and wildlife to be seen. Take your time and enjoy it.
reviews/17/text:
The Rabacal area is definitely worth a visit although it's very popular so don't expect to be hiking in solitude and it's a real pain when you get stuck behind a group on the nartow levada paths! 

The drive up from Funchal is pretty steep and takes about an hour (rather quicker 45 mins back down). Reasonable amount of car parking but toilets only available by the cafe. 

All the trails are well signposted so you really don't need a guide. Expect the temperature to be around 8 degrees cooler than the coast. 

Most of the trails are pretty easy and vertigo free although there are plenty of steps. We walked for around 4.5 hours total, covering 12 miles and took in 25 Fontes, Risco and Lagos da Vento. The Risco waterfall is the most impressive and the shortest trail if you are time limited.

There is a very nice cafe with sandwiches, great cake and coffee options as well as some hot dishes. If you don't want to walk down (or back up both around 30 mins) there is a minibus service for 3 euro or 5 euro return. 

Good day out to experience the Madeira mountains.
reviews/18/text: This walk is worth it, as the end view is excellent and wonderful and the coolness of the water is a nice extra treat.
reviews/19/text:
Risco is Much more beautiful and bigger falls than 25 Fontes. Dont skip Risco. 
25 fontes are overrated, the falls are quite small and you have avoid people all the time on the way. Risco falls is much bigger, more beautiful and with less people. 
I recommend to buy the 3€ van driving you forth and back from the parking.
reviews/19/title: Beautiful big fall Risco, okey 25 fontes
subcategory_ranking: #28 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Caminho do Monte 174, Funchal, Madeira 9050-288 Portugal
description: Open to the public since 1991, the Monte Palace Madeira occupies an area of 70.000 square meters and houses a huge exotic plant's collection, coming from all over the world, together with swans,duck's and Koi fish. The Monte Palace Museum is an ideal exhibition space nestled within the beautiful surroundings of a tropical garden. There are three floors, two of which are dedicated to sculptures and the third houses a unique mineral collection gathered from the four corners of the world. Monte Palace Madeira, also includes one of the most important tile collections in Portugal. The tiles exhibited amidst the tropical vegetation represent several ages, coming from palaces, churches, chapels and private houses throughout the former Portuguese empire. We are open everyday except 25th of December. Our prices are: Adults - 12,50€ Children younger than 15 years old: Free Entrance as long as they are accompanied by adults. Check our new facebook page montepalacetropicalgarden
name: Monte Palace Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Private Halfday Madeira Garden Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Monte Tropical Garden & Toboggans private Tuk-Tuk tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Tour Cabo Girao Tropical Garden Cable Car Monte Toboggan
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Monte Palace Tropical Garden Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Full Day Madeira Island Private Discovery by Tuk Tuk
ranking: #15 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #15 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: This is a beautiful trip and I fully recommend going if you holiday to Madeira! It’s easy to access from Funchal via the cable car and affordable. However, if you have any physical disability, young children, push chair/crutches or anything that would make stairs difficult then it would be a challenge as the gardens is all on different levels and has a lot of stairs. I think there should be more in place to help those who can’t get around easily enjoy the gardens. However, it is gorgeous, well kept, food is good in the cafe at the entrance and has a variety of different things to see. The gemstone museum was a wonderful surprise!
reviews/0/title: Beautiful Gardens - would recommend if you’re in good shape
reviews/1/text: These gardens are magical. Wind through the stunning flowers, oriental garden, African sculpture, raw gemstone display and enjoy a drink at the bottom with views over the bay below. It’s like a fairytale garden. And if you’re too tired to walk back up, you can always catch a lift on the little shuttle, disguised as a 1920s car….
reviews/1/title: Wondering whether it’s worth paying for? It really is!
reviews/2/text: Absolutely fantastic gardens and a wonderful exhibition of African art. Definitely a full day out. We went up in the cable car, also great. Most bland cheese and ham sandwiches in the world in the cafe, try to avoid that.
reviews/3/text: Loved our visit here. My son and I queued for over 40 minutes to get on the cable car but it was worth the wait. The Monte Palace Gardens is 12.50 for adults, and children 14 and under are free. There are 2 nice cafes, 2 covered exhibitions and so much outdoor space. We stayed for well over 3 hours just walking through the gardens. The views are amazing and the fish ponds were just so relaxing. Half way down the garden there is an area where you can see the people coming down in the baskets. We left the gardens around 4.30 and we got straight on to the cable car, no queues at all. Would love to do it again.
reviews/4/text: This is one of the best scenic attractions ito Gardens. Entrance is 12 euro per person and give you access to 'n beautiful manicured garden. Wine tasting is included, although it is only a very small glass. You need about 3 hours for this attraction. It is not wheelchair friendly, due to many steps.
reviews/5/text:
A very enjoyable and interesting place to visit when staying in Funchal.
This is a very large garden on a steep hillside and if a little infirm on your feet this may prove a little difficult.
Suggest that you use the chairlift from the seafront to Monte for your visit.
There is only limited catering facilities on site and these were very busy on our visit although they are taking steps to improve one of the cafes.
reviews/5/title: Very nice place to visit in Funchal.
reviews/6/text: We travelled up on the cable car from Funchal to see the Palace gardens and take the Toboggan ride down the hill. This is a great combination and needs half a day (3-4 hours). It’s easily accessible by bus 21 if you prefer to avoid the cable car. The gardens are worth a visit and there are two cafes for some lunch. There is also an African sculpture exhibition, that is quite interesting. There is good shade for sunny days and the walking around the gardens is easy.
reviews/6/title: Easy walking in the gardens and shade available
reviews/7/text:
I’ve wanted to come here for years and here I am !

The gardens are at their best at this time of the year and did not disappoint 
It’s tough walking on the paths and you need to be quite agile but worth every step 

The Flamingos were my only disappointment as the pond area was being cleaned and they weren’t at all happy 

The number of staff working to keep the gardens tip top must be huge as we counted over 40 just today

You need at least 4 hours to enjoy it properly 

Don’t hesitate it’s worth it
reviews/8/text: This is a beautiful place to spend the day or half a day. So tranquil and peaceful. Take the cable car ride up for views out over Funchal. We ate in the cafe at the bottoms of the garden which was reasonably priced. Looks of walking but just do it at your own pace.
reviews/9/text: Access the gardens at the top and almost immediately when getting off the cable car. The 12.50 Euros to get in was well worth the money because the gardens are truly vast. Just be warned, there's lots and lots of walking to do and the terrain is very unsettled and, in places, quite slippy. Nevertheless the gardens are magnificent and well worth spending 2 or 3 hours in.
reviews/10/text: Everything about it is stunning and worth the entry price. Busy but not crowded and kept so well compared to other gardens visited.  Cafe was staffed by efficient and helpful people and not overly priced either. Must see on any Madeira itinerary.
reviews/11/text: Beautiful gardens that make you work for the pleasure but well worth the effort. The ride up on the cable car was great and the ride back down on the toboggan even better. Great way to spend a few hours
reviews/12/text:
The Monte Palace is an old hotel with extensive beautiful gardens with many different zones, a central large pond area and also a museum. The museum ​​is housed across three buildings, two of are dedicated to sculptures and the third houses a unique mineral collection. We spent more time that expected in the museums as there was heavy rain when we arrived, but then the day brightened up beautifully.

​​The gardens are located on top of a steep hill, but the paths are good and there are plenty of places to rest. I understand that there is also a golf cart service available to take visitors back up to the entrance/exit at the top of the gardens, but we did not use this.

We spent hours walking along the many paths and admiring the colourful foliage in the gardens. We took a meander around the tranquil pond, visited the beautiful oriental gardens with the koi ponds and many decorative bridges. There are so many amazing little paths and routes to explore, and so many interesting things to discover! From hidden waterfalls, ornate bridges, stepping stones over a pond, water features, hundreds of statues and hidden sculptures, many beautiful decorative tiles. There is sooo much to see I can't possibly describe it to full justice, just take my word for it and go visit yourself! 

Don't forget to pick up your free glass of Madeira from the cafe at the bottom of the gardens (no purchase necessary). Cafe has mixed reviews so we didn't eat here but it is definitely worth a visit just for the little glass of Madeira, that is included with your ticket, we had to try Madeira while in Madeira!

I took soooo many photos, literally hundreds! and could happily have spent most of the day here, wandering around the many little paths and exploring all the little different areas of the gardens.

If I had to choose, my favourite parts might be the Japanese gardens and around the main pond area - there are little pathways you can take to walk all the way around the pond, involving getting splashed by the mini waterfalls and even walking underneath the larger waterfall! and you can also walk out to the little island on the pond.

We visited in May and I don't think the gardens were at their best, as quite a cold and rainy year so not much had flowered. I would love to return again some day in early summer when all the flowers are in bloom.

We visited these gardens on an action packed day; starting with the cable ride up the hill, a wonderful visit to these gardens and then the second cable car ride to the Madeira Botanical Gardens, which fail in comparison but we thought are worthwhile a visit as you are so close. Afterwards we enjoyed the fun touristy toboggan ride, before getting the cable car back down to Funchal and having a walk along the promenade by the sea. A very busy and fun day! The highlight of our day was definitely the Monte Palace Tropical Gardens for us.

The cable car station at the top of the hill is literally right next to the garden entrance. Remember to pick up a map at the entrance, which shows the two different walking routes you can take; a flower walk and an art walk. There is lots of walking involved to see all the garden and some steep areas, so definitely wear comfortable shoes. We spent around 4 hours walking around the gardens, but I could so easily have spent much longer here. Tickets are €12.50 each. Open from 9.30am to 6pm daily.
reviews/12/title: A MUST VISIT - one of my favourite activities that we did in Madeira - and we did a lot!
reviews/13/text: Definitely worth the 25 euros for the 2 of us, and we did enjoy strollilng round. I found the planting a bit 'en masse'. Like they got a few plants in and have propegated them until they have hundreds. Azaleas were in flower, but they were mostly the same colour for instance. Just not the variety I was expecting. The landscaping and water features are nice. Enjoyable, and I'd maybe try going again maybe later in the year, possibly there is more variety then, but in February it didn't have as much as I expected. I saw more flowers when we were out on a Levada walk through some meadows!
reviews/13/title: Nice, but not the wow factor I was expecting
reviews/14/text: We enjoyed our trip to Monte Palace Gardens, the gardens are interesting and the setting is lovely.  We were though saddened to see the flamingos kept in a small enclosure with stagnant water, unable to get very far away from a continuous stream of tourists wanting photographs.
reviews/14/title: Interesting and enjoyable but sorry looking flamingos
reviews/15/text: Lovely place to spend a few hours. Its a bit hilly so wear comfortable shoes.. Easy to get to from Funchal and plenty of free parking quite close by.
reviews/16/text: A must visit destination, although you need to be fit and mobile to cope with the steps and steep gradients. The effort is well worth it, as the gardens are truly spectacular. Would recommend taking a 31 bus to the Botanical Gardens (€1.95) then buying a combined entry ticket plus both cable cars (Botanical to Monte and then Monte to Funchal (€28). Once you get to Monte, you need to pay your entrance fee (€12.50). The gardens combine terrific layout with works of art and are really well laid out and signposted. You should also witness the remarkable wooden toboggans that set off just outside the gardens (huge queues…), and a climb up to the Monte church is also worthwhile. There are good cafes at both gardens. Makes for a full day out!
reviews/16/title: A must visit destination, if you are fit and mobile!
reviews/17/text: Extensive but not especially interesting gardens. Rainy weather didn't help. We much preferred the nearby Jardim Botanico which had more colour, less crowded planting and views over Funchal. It seemed to us that many visitors had come simply to ride down again on the wooden sleds.
reviews/18/text:
Lovely gardens but inaccessible for anyone with mobility issues. Set on a very steep hill with hundreds of steps.
Beautiful plants but couldn’t see most of it.
reviews/19/text:
The views from the garden is the best part - I wasn’t expecting it to be this beautiful but is really is.
The garden is also much bigger than expected so you can spend a long time exploring the plants, wildlife and museums. 
I’d definitely recommend going - I’d love to come back in spring/summer when even more flowers are blooming!
subcategory_ranking: #15 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: E 202, Funchal, Madeira 9000-900 Portugal
description:
At nearly 6,000 feet, Pico do Arieiro is Madeira’s third-highest peak and one of the best spots in town for sunrise views. It gets crowded in the morning—especially since it's also the trailhead for the famous Pico do Arieiro to Pico Ruivo hiking route—so get there early to snag a good spot. On a clear day, you may even be able to see the neighboring island of Porto Santo that's 30 miles away.

Tours typically start from Funchal and will bring you to Pico do Arieiro at sunrise to start the hike to Pico Ruivo. 

– Tripadvisor
name: Pico do Arieiro
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Sunrise Guided Hike PR1 Pico do Areeiro Pico Ruivo small group
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Madeira Peaks - Open 4X4 Full-Day Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Morning Transfer To Pico Do Arieiro, Hike To Pico Ruivo & Return From Teixeira
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: All Madeira In 2 Days Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Pico Arieiro To Pico Ruivo / Highest Peak Challenge
ranking: #6 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #6 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: This hike is not simple; medium to hard level. But very well laid out. You need to be active and have a decent level of fitness to complete it. It’s busy and narrow with lots of up and down steps. You 100% need good footwear, plenty of food and water. Don’t show up in a thin pair of plimsolls and hold up the whole place!! Spectacular views, stunning scenery and a wonderful sense of achievement once completed.
reviews/1/text: I don’t think you can rate an actual mountain…the mountain itself is stunning, as is the walk between here and Pico Ruivo. However, my rating is for the facilities and the actual experience here. It is certainly overcrowded and the bus loads of people from tour operators and coaches really doesn’t help. The air defence station positioned up there is certainly an eyesore and the development of the cafe/canteen and souvenir shop certainly doesn’t help. Whilst the tourist is well catered for, I personally feel the experience and mountain would be a lot better without this.
reviews/1/title: You can’t rate a mountain but it was too developed for me
reviews/2/text:
I've just got back from Madeira and I wanted to see the sunrise at Pico do Arieiro, yes it's an early start but well worth it. I got up around 05.30 and set off around 06.15 to get there around 07.00 just before sunrise & the crowds. Pick your spot and watch the sun come up above the clouds, you have to pick your timing as it's not always clear up there. Once the sun had come up I set off on the PR1 hiking trail to Pico Ruivo, most reviews say give yourself around 6 hours for the round trip, I did it in around 4.5 hours and was back at the car park for a well earned Coffee & Pastel de Nata!
It's not for the feint hearted as the going can get tiring as there's plenty of steps to climb, especially near the end, but you'll get some stunning views of the mountains, so it's well worth it, take plenty of snacks & water + layer up as the wind can hit you when you least expect it. If you come to the island this is a must see & do location.
reviews/3/text: Quite a busy place but the starting point for further adventures. There is free car parking for an hour and its ok to have a wander around
reviews/4/text: I went up 3 times as it's only 40 minutes by road. Though each time the very top was cloud-covered. Best to go early morning. First time I went from 20 degrees on the coast to minus 1 and snowing! Cafe and gift shop at the top, plenty of stop-off points to go to before you hit the cloud cover.
reviews/5/text: We took a Bolt to Pico do Arieiro for the sunrise - got there about 5am (in November, so a tad bit early) but there were already some people around. When the sun started to rise, the views had been just magnificent - the sun rays reflected both on the surrounding mountains and on the ocean in a variety of colours - shades of orange and pink. That view will stay with me for the rest of my life. We were very lucky with the weather as the sky was almost cloudless, so we decided to hike to Pico Ruivo and it was the most amazing hike, with spectacular views all the way. Not at all tiring and not too dangerous in my opinion as there are rails all the way to the other peak. I miss that place and can’t wait to visit it again soon.
reviews/6/text: Absolutely breathtaking scenery. Amazing views. Worth every second of out time, every drop of petrol, or every step we walk. We were lucky the weather was great.
reviews/7/text: I booked a morning transfer from Funchal (they’re called Pico Transfers) to hike up the Pico Ruivo summit.  I was lucky that the area wasn’t crowded when we arrived, and managed to secure a got spot to catch a spectacular view of the sunrise. It was windy and very cold when we got there, so do dress appropriately for the weather. Totally worth the drive up!
reviews/8/text: Lovely place on top of Madeira, with excellent views of the hills and the ocean. A beautiful drive through the countryside, highly recommended for a visa.
reviews/9/text: We drove through the clouds to get to the top. Incredible views, even with the clouds. Not for the faint of heart, though. You're up 6,000 feet!
reviews/9/title: If you have acrophobia, maybe not a good idea.
reviews/10/text: 20 minute stop was not enough to see this area. Lots of cars in the parking lot and although it was cold and windy there the views were awesome .
reviews/11/text: Dropped off at Pico do Arieiro for the start of our walk, the views were stunning and we had not even started walking yet. A tad touristy with a restaurant and shops and very busy with people taking photographs.
reviews/12/text: Great views. Great guide and easy travelling in a minibus. I highly recommend tours of the island. We were collected from our hotel and dropped back to the hotel. Reasonably priced. Sometimes trips booked from the hotel are more expensive but not here. We did the east and west coast.
reviews/13/text: We hired a driver to take us here, as well as afew other places. This stop was good for a short walk, buying a souvenir t-shirt and a bite to eat. The clouds came in as we were there, which made for amazing pictures. Walkers were enveloped in the clouds. Steep drive here, but we were in good hands.
reviews/14/text: Phenomenal views (we had come through a bank of clouds). Quite crowded at the top with everyone scrambling to take their pictures.
reviews/14/title: Feelin on top of the world
reviews/15/text: The drive up from the south is a long and winding road which in some places is a bit frightening but once you get to the top (and find parking) the views are awesome there are several short trails to viewpoints that are really jaw dropping and off course there are the trails for the fit and brave to pico ruivo
reviews/16/text: The journey is worthwhile, as is a long walk out to the viewing spots. Unbelievable panoramic views. Best to visit in the morning as clouds roll in later. The car park was busy but space regularly comes available.
reviews/17/text:
Amazing views! Definitely recommend if you don’t want to hike, but still want to see the views on top of the mountain! You can also see the Nun’s valley from up there!

Since you can get up to the mountain with a car - be ready for a lot of tourists!
reviews/18/text: Love this place for photography, whether sunrise or sunset. The view is awesome. If anyone want some pics to buy do contact me. I have taken some night photography too.
reviews/19/text:
We parked at the lower lot designated for hikers.  The top lot is meant for brief visits under an hour.   The walkway to the starting point is not well illustrated from the bottom, so you may end up walking on the road.

The visitor center at Pico do Arieiro has a clean toilet for 50 cents per person, and a cafe and souvenir shop.  We stopped off before beginning the hike, and our plan was to do a round trip to Pico Ruivo and back.   All in all, it took us about 7 hours, including a 45 min rest at the cafe/toilets near Pico Ruivo.   We are 2 adults and a teenager.   The path for this hike is clear and does not require advanced technical gear.  However, the hike is strenuous, and other than one family with small children, everyone else we saw that day were teenagers or older.   

The path has significant ascents and descents, some on stone stairs, and some on medal stairs close to ladders in steepness.   Most of the path was on dirt or stones.  Part of the hike is in the shade, but much of it is in the open sun so suncream is essential.   The path traverses multiple tunnels, some of which are long enough that light cannot pass through, so a torch is necessary.  One tunnel had a wet floor, so the light was particularly important to avoid stepping in deep puddles or slipping.

The cafe near Pico Ruivo is staffed by people who hike there each day, with no car access, so you need to carry your own rubbish away.  You can buy drinks and small snacks, and they do accept credit cards.   There was just one working toilet and quite a queue for it.  There was also one sink with running water.  People were refilling bottles, although not clear if it was meant to be drinking water.  At one point, the tap ran dry, and needed 30 min to refill the cistern to begin pumping water again.

If you reach that cafe and consider turning around before the final climb to Pico Ruivo, do not turn around!!  The view from Pico Ruivo is a 360-degree view of the mountains including Nun's Valley, and was the highlight of the day.  Totally worth the extra effort to get there.

On the way out, we saw many people on the hike.  On the way back, there were relatively few people.  Many of them must have made arrangements to be picked up on the other side, so just walked one way.  

We were exhausted the next day after this epic hike, but the views were well worth the effort.  Bring a hat, suncream, a torch, snacks, and lots and lots of water.
subcategory_ranking: #6 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Estrada Padre Antonio Dinis Henriques 1 Quinta Grande, Madeira 9300-261 Portugal
description: An out-of-the world organic farm comprising 9 rental cottages, a beach and a restaurant, located by the sea in Madeira island southern coast. Access to the property is done exclusively by a cable car that takes you down a huge cliff with more than 300 m to Faja dos Padres, or by boat.
name: Faja dos Padres
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Incredible tour to a 'Faja' with a story
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Tour | Full Day 4x4 Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Tour Halfday South Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Half-Day Small-Group Madeira Village Safari from Funchal
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Private Boat Tour with Snorkeling and Paddleboarding from Funchal
ranking: #22 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #22 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: A peacefull quiet place with lots of green vegetabels and fruits. Best guide ( Fatima R. ) with a lot to tell.
reviews/0/title: Relaxing place in a busy world 😇🇩🇰😇🇵🇹
reviews/1/text:
Great experience just descending the cliff in an almost perpendicular cable car!
We walked past the kitchen garden and through the banana plantation to reach the restaurant ( about 15 mins but that included stopping to look at the vegetation! )
Sat in the covered bit of the restaurant while the surf crashed on the beach nearby.
Octopus and Dorado were cooked to perfection and came with sweet potato, baked potato and salad, mostly from the restaurants own garden.
The journey back up was even more interesting as the wind had got up a bit and the gondola swung about a bit.
If the wind reaches 25 knots they stop running!
Very glad we finally managed to get there!
reviews/1/title: Worth the effort to get there!
reviews/2/text: The best dinner I had while in Portugal, and due to the tiny cable car we seemed to avoid the horrible cruise ships and tourist buses. A must do in my opinion
reviews/2/title: The best dinner I had in portugal
reviews/3/text: Nico and Fabrianna certainly no how to serve sumptuous food that matches the setting a thoroughly wonderful experience. Nico created a Chefs special for us - we had 4 courses and a little tipple. Even the cable car was a thrill.
reviews/4/text:
We had the tour with fruit tasting with Fatima and it was amazing, I would call it the highlight of our Madeira holiday. Fatima told us a lot about the history of the island and of the farm, we learned much more from her than from all our tourist brochures. The tour was both very informative and also relaxed, you could feel yourself immersed in the sheer beauty of everything around. It is a magic place and I cannot recommend it highly enough for all that it offers. The fruit tasting at the end was also great, we tasted fruit that we did not know it even exist, everything fresh and delicious.
After the fruit tasting we had lunch and we chose some dishes prepared with vegetables and fruit from their garden, the food was very tasty and the service very friendly and fast. Of course, we also enjoyed the beach in front of the restaurant, the water was crystal clear, calm and warmer than on other beaches we visited on the island.
reviews/5/text:
Worst part of our whole holiday. They need far more staff at the restaurant. Waited around for over an hour, had to hassle staff to get any service as they were so busy being only 2 front of house for hundreds of guests. Then the food wasn’t cooked so we didn’t eat anything. Everyone looked annoyed and I can’t see how anyone had a good time. Also no running water in the toilets which did not bode well for the kitchen. 

Location was nice, but small. Not worth the cable car trip down. The cable car in Funchal FAR better and longer. Also the beach area was small and everyone just sat on concrete. Much nicer areas around. Can also see the plants and bananas trees on most levada walks. 

The owners need to employ far more staff and put more attention into the area for tourists.
reviews/6/text: Just the worst customer service ever they took over an hour to take the order,  the food arrived cold and they continued to serve others before us
reviews/7/text: This place is really special. The tour around the farm including not public areas is such a good start of the visit and fresh fruits picked the same morning is an experience which no visitor should skip. Knowledge of the place, Madeiran history and the development of the wine was included as well as information about farming and the ethics behind the organic certification and their sustainable approach were explained. Booking directly on the website was super easy as well. Definitely worth the money.
reviews/7/title: Take the tour and taste the fruits!
reviews/8/text:
We did the tour of the Fajã with Fatima, our knowledgable guide. This was an amazing location made even better through the well paced and well-organised tour of the property. Fatima spoke great English, was friendly and engaging, especially with our 4-year-old boy, whom she involved in the tour and kept interested for the entire 2 hours. At the end of the tour, there fas fruit tasting at the on-site restaurant. 

The teleférico ride down was breathtaking. The lushness and diversity of the farm was amazing. The rental properties immaculately preserved. The fare at the restaurant top class (all ingredients used grown at the property, where possible, and all organic). 

Top tip: try the Surinamese cherry ice-cream. The perfect finish to this great tour.

Thank you Fatima! You are an asset to the Fajã!
reviews/8/title: Great day out in Madeira with Fatima
reviews/9/text:
Fajã dos Padres is the isolated village from madeira.

If you planing to go there only to see it it is not worth it.. you are paying to use the cable car and you will find only an restaurant.

Please be aware that the Last cable car ride is at 18:00.. so if you want to spend some time there go earlier.
reviews/10/text:
Really great place and amazing sea views with friendly staff, but the lizards 😳 they were everywhere and crawling on my feet when sitting to eat :yuck: I’m not a fan of slithering things but appreciate they have a safe space amongst the visitors and rocks there. 

Only a small pebble beach here and if you’re not eating at the restaurant there’s not much else to do besides swim and sun bathe-which is not a complaint ✨

Make a reservation for the restaurant as it gets crowded quickly.
reviews/11/text: €10 pp for the cable car down to the cobbled beach & back. Beautiful scenery & well kept gardens / farm land. Fresh tasty food at the restaurant. Friendly staff. Amazing views to unwind. Last car up is at 6pm but do make sure you have a taxi arranged to collect you as no bus route near by. We caught the 137 bus from Funchal (€2.20 pp) to Camera do Lobos & then a taxi (€15) to Faja dos padres. Because we did not pre arrange a taxi back, we walked quite a distance along some busy roads / bad bends asking locals the way. Finally came to a local bar & they pointed up 100’s of steps to a bus stop ! €2.75 pp back to Funchal. An experience yes, but I’d stick to the taxi lol
reviews/12/text: Faja dos Padres is one of the first places I visit when in Madeira and it never disappoints. It's a unique setting, accessed via cable car and with a pleasant walk through the farm. The Restaurant is unpretentious but good for meal and drink with memorable views. The whole environment is tranquil and this is just a great place to relax and enjoy one of the best madeiran experiences.
reviews/12/title: A great place to enjoy an afternoon
