reviews/13/text: We intended on visiting this beach with our children but for €50 to use the cable car we didn’t feel it was worth it. €10 per person. It looks stunning but all of the beaches in Madeira look equally as beautiful and cosy nothing
reviews/14/text:
Great place for a swim a relax day and a good food
Amazing view relaxing place to stay to dove and relax
Good food in the restaurant but need to book in advance
reviews/15/text: I booked a table at this restaurant as I had heard good reviews about it.  I was terribly disappointed with both the food and the service which was diabolical.  After waiting for 30 minutes and being totally ignored, whilst people around me were getting service, I went up and asked if I could get some service!  Without any apology I was given the menu.  When my food arrived, I had to request olive oil, salt etc which should have automatically been put on the table and yet it took a further five minutes to arrive and when I asked for a second glass of wine half way through my meal, it didn't arrive until I had finished the food, ten minutes later. The food was not any better than other places on the island, but more expensive and the fish portion size was too small for the price charged, although the Mango sauce was good.  When you add in the ten euro cost of getting there, it ended up being a big expensive let down.   They need to either improve their waiting staff, or get a big sign telling people to order food and drinks at the bar.   I will not be going back there!
reviews/16/text: My husband and I did the organic farm tour and fruit tasting with our guide, Fatima.  This is an excellent tour and we would highly recommend it!!   Fatima knew all kinds of interesting information about the farm and eagerly answered all of our questions.  She was very fluent in English so we could easily understand everything she said.  Fatima was very good at narrowing in on the topics that she could tell we were interested in.  The fruit tasting was much better than we expected.   There were all kinds of fruits to try and she also gave us information about each one as we tried it.   Afterwards we ate at the restaurant at Faja dos Padres and it was probably one of the best meals we had the whole time we were on the island.  This tour is very worth it!!!!!!
reviews/16/title: Faja dos Padres farm tour and fruit tasting
reviews/17/text: We absolutely loved our day at this incredibly special place! You take a cable car down to a gorgeous farm. There is a hotel which seems quite exclusive although we did not see it. We lazed on the jetty before lunch and swam. Lunch was wonderful. The staff were so accommodating- moving our table to the edge. We ate wonderful food overlooking the ocean. The food was not the best we had in Madeira but the location was one of the best. Do not miss out- a real experience
reviews/17/title: Great location - definitely must do on a Madeira trip
reviews/18/text: Well worth a visit for the novelty factor. We visited on a recommendation from friends who stayed here early 2020. Okay you have to pay €10 each to do down in the gondola but at the bottom you really are away from the crowds. We went down for lunch. The portions are large and it was lovely to sit next to the pebble beach and eat whilst listening the waves. Like all places on the island the adherence to CV19 regulations was excellent.  It has an interesting history. Go on a nice day for superb views as you go down/up the gondola.
reviews/19/text: We have visited here before, and thoroughly enjoyed the cable car trip to the location, and admiring  the bountiful gardens. So far so good for our trip here in October.  We had planned to enjoy some peaceful time on the beach before eating lunch in the beach front restaurant. There were several people at the resort, enjoying the good weather. We paid to hire loungers which were located on the jetty.  Unfortunately we were located next to a group of brash, loud Canadians who continually played music at full volume, and loudly shared stories punctuated with bad language to embarrassed visitors.  A sign clearly stated music was not allowed, so it is disappointing that staff did not enforce this. Several other visitors appeared uncomfortable.  We cut short our visit, disappointed that we did not experience the tranquil visit that we had expected. We will not return.
subcategory_ranking: #22 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Caminho Babosas 8, Funchal, Madeira 9050-541 Portugal
name: Telefericos da Madeira
ranking: #1 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #1 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: If you have time, you definitely need to take a ride. Actually, this is included in the standard program of tourists who arrived on a cruise ferry for one day in Funchal.
reviews/1/text: Not too long a wait to board. Enjoyable trip. Take time to visit the gardens when up top. The queue for toboggans was massive, so we gave this a miss. We took a single ride.......the walk down is tough on the knees due to the steep incline.....you need to be reasonably fit to get yourself down by walking.
reviews/2/text: Excellent trip, thoroughly enjoyed the views. There was a long queue at the bottom but it moved quickly. We went to Jardim Monte Palace at the top. Went to botanical gardens another day by bus and that was a much more difficult journey.
reviews/3/text:
The only way is up !

This trip up to the Monte Palace Gardens and back was awesome 

Well organised and waiting in line was 15 mins max
reviews/4/text: Lovely views from the cable car and ideal to get to the botanical gardens however beware we asked for a round trip to the botanical gardens and was sold this and entry to gardens but also ended up paying for round trip on cable car to funchal which we didnt realise when buying and didnt want. It may have been a special price but the girl didnt listen to what we wanted and didnt explain what she was selling clearly. When we realised and asked for partial refund she tried to say she explained it and made it very difficult to get a refund which we didnt get. If we had known and walked past that cable car station to the botanical garden one we would probably have saved 15 euros. We didnt want full cable car trip as had got sightseeing bus ticket and wanted to Tobagon down which we did go back up and do.
reviews/4/title: Beware 2 pay stations on monte for cable cars
reviews/5/text: my wife hates cable cars but I persuaded her to accompany me on this one.The views going up and down are terrific as is the view from Monte,especially with a cold beer from the cafe next to the cable car station.Would recommend this trip to anyone
reviews/6/text:
No queue’s and very smooth trip to the top. Clean and professional. 
It’s not clear when you book that you can then toboggan down a bit. So we paid €36 for cable car (2 people) then we paid €30 for the toboggan that stops in the middle of know where, so we then paid €10 for a cab back to the top to then return on the cable car to the bottom. The experience cost us €76 but we couldn’t find another way to do it. It’s too far to walk down into Funchal and too steep to walk back up!! 
We still had a great time though !!
reviews/7/text: Enormous queues to get on so, to avoid the wait, try to prebook your entry if you can. Really it will save you a significant wait. The cable car journey takes around 15 minutes and is a terrific experience. The views alone are worth the cost. 12.50 Euros one way if your going to be adventurous enough to chance the toboggan down. Just be prepared for a long wait at the top if you are. Either way, don't try walking down from the top. Its just too far and too steep a journey.
reviews/8/text:
We rode up the hill when it was grey, miserable and raining, but returned late afternoon in glorious sunshine! The views are pretty good, but ride is a must to visit Monte Palace Tropical Gardens, which are fabulous.

We paid €68 for cable car return plus Botanical Gardens tickets for 2 adults. The journey takes upto 20 minutes. Open from 9am to 5.45pm. Try to get seats with your back to the ascent. The base station is located in the garden of Almirante Reis, in the main area of Funchal, just a couple of minutes walk from where all the busses drop you off.

We arrived when the station opened at 9am and were lucky we didn't have to queue for any of the cable cars we took that day, although we did car share with another couple on some journeys. The staff were all friendly and it was quick and easy to buy our tickets and walk through - there is a board clearly indicating the prices for the different ticket types.

The Botanical Gardens were nice to see but not comparable to Monte Palace. However the cable car ride to the Botanical Gardens was much for scenic. It is just a couple of minutes journey on this cable car. Be aware that it is quite a long walk away - and all up a steep hill on the way back! I was heavily pregnant and just took it slowly. It would be hard work pushing a pram. 

As you leave the cable car station, Monte Palace Tropical Garden is immediately to the left (highly recommend this) and the walk to the cable car for Botanical Gardens is to the right, both well sign posted.
reviews/8/title: A fun touristy thing to do to get to the beautiful gardens at the top of the hill
reviews/9/text: Very long queues ( we arrived mid morning on 2nd March so not exactly peak season. 25 euro for both of us to go up, as we were choosing to get a toboggan down. Best to read up on your options before you go as you can get combined tickets with gardens (of which there are two up there) and there is also another cable car which we were unaware of. If you turn to the left when you get out it takes you to Monte palace and toboggans. If you go right it takes you to the other set of cable cars which go to the other gardens. An enjoyable wee ride, no particulary spectacular views but it was nice
reviews/10/text: We were in Funchal for the day on a cruise and took a trip on the Cable Cars, a bit of a queue but goes down fairly quickly. Make sure you get your tickets before you join queue and only get one way ticket if you want to do the toboggans at the top,
reviews/11/text:
Not accessible friendly.
 Staff at the entrance lower level did not know how to handle partially sighted travelers. Didn't open accessibility gate and made them go through turnstiles. Rude photographer who tried to shout at the blind guests to get their attention and wave their hands Infront of their face.
Upper level and return journey was so much better, priory boarding and all accessibility gates were opened for us.
reviews/12/text: A sense of calm, extremely beautiful and well worth a visit. Part of a full day discovering the very best of Madeira, close proximity to Funchal.
reviews/13/text: An amazing experience, well worth the 18 euro return fare. Felt very safe and very comfortable with incredible views. We left just after 9 am and had the cab to ourselves.
reviews/14/text:
Beautiful views from the cable car.
It feels very safe and doesn’t wobble like I had expected…! 
We went to the palace gardens once at the top which was also great.
Don’t be put off if there’s a long queue - it goes down fairly quickly as the staff are so efficient and keep things moving smoothly.
reviews/15/text: Take the cable car up and walk to Monte where you can visit the tropical garden around Monte palace and visit the church.
reviews/15/title: Great view from the best spot overlooking Funchal
reviews/16/text:
We took the cable car to Monte Palace & when finished a short walk to another cable car to the Botanical Gardens. The cable car to Monte has excellent city views & the cable car to the gardens have canyon & forest views.
Both experiences are frequently used and very safe.
reviews/17/text: Enjoy the views from the top through down and the sea views or city are amazing,  Staff are friendly and the trip is secure.
reviews/18/text: Great trip with wonderful views. Operators are helpful and aware that some people have mobility issues.
reviews/19/text: The exterior does not portray the inside which is fantastic and a sight worth visiting. Well worth it and seeing the history
subcategory_ranking: #1 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Madeira Portugal
name: Pico Ruivo
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Pico Arieiro To Pico Ruivo / Highest Peak Challenge
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Pico do Arieiro - Pico Ruivo - Achadas do Teixeira
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Sunrise Guided Hike PR1 Pico do Areeiro Pico Ruivo small group
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Sunrise Transfer To Pico Do Arieiro, Hike To Pico Ruivo & Return From Teixeira
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Morning Transfer To Pico Do Arieiro, Hike To Pico Ruivo & Return From Teixeira
ranking: #5 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #5 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Great hike from the parking area. we also found a great dog companion that followed us to the top and back. Bring him some treats if you go there❤️.
reviews/1/text: I started my hike from Pico do Arieiro and ended at Achada do Teixera. I personally found the hike quite challenging, and partly because it was my first mountain hike since the pandemic started and I’m definitely not in good shape. I was much slower and took longer to get to the summit but it was totally worth it!!! Would definitely recommend this route although it would be an easier hike to the summit from Achada do Teixera and come down the same way. Thankfully, the weather was great that day and what a great workout I had in a long time!
reviews/2/text:
How to explain 
I started at Achadas do Teixeira
It s November , fresh air , stunning blue sky 
First stop at Pico Ruivo refuge 
Then I discovered stunning view point and suddenly the rain arrives 
And the trail start to be dangerous because slippery !
I was more focus on my feet than on landscape 
But I realized that I was inside the clouds 
Nice feeling 
I took my time and qu’arrivés safe at Encumeada
It was a superb nice experience
reviews/3/text:
The view leaves you breathless.
It is really worth the crossing from Pico Arieiro to Pico Ruivo, despite the effort!
reviews/4/text: Walked from Pico do Arieiro to Pico Ruivo it took over 4 hours but the views along the way are stunning no matter were you look then the last climb to the summit of Pico Ruivo and its magnificent views are something else, no amount of photographs does it justice you just have to experience it yourself.
reviews/5/text: After finding parking (which wasn’t easy…), started the walk up the trail, as I wasn’t planning to do the entire trail, I said I’ll walk up till I get tired and then return. The climb isn’t easy but the views are so stunning that I found myself going just a little bit more, and again and again admiring the views in all directions and off course shooting numerous pictures from every corner. When I went down some clouds came from the sea partially covering the mountains which made the views even more awesome
reviews/6/text:
We did the shorter P1.2 hike. Its 2.8k to the top. Took us about an hour and 10 mins each way at a slow pace with stops. We arrived at 8.30am, perfect time to avoid heat and crowds. The hike is mostly made up of paths and steps, so probably suitable for most walkers.
I'd advise to bring water, wear suncream and wear a hat... you're above the clouds so the sun is beating down on you.

The views are fantastic and so worth the walk. Highly recommend 👌
reviews/7/text: This place when have finally arrived offers a view unlike other places and is nice and cool due to the height and humidity and the walk around is fresh and good.
reviews/8/text: There is a great rest stop and restaurant that is easily accessible from the parking lot. The hike to the lookout is more strenuous than it seems and definitely felt a lot longer than the 1 1/2 miles it is noted as. The path is all stone and there are some shade huts to stop in though.
reviews/8/title: Beautiful views - be prepared with water!
reviews/9/text: Beautiful mountains, not to see anywhere else in Europe. The path isn't easy but not extremely difficult either. You gotta go up and down and up again couple times. There are couple of tunnels too!
reviews/10/text: This is quite a hike to get to the peak but you are rewarded with stunning views. There is a restaurant with toilets about 3/4s of the way up for a break. The paths are a little tricky in places so wear stable shoes.
reviews/11/text:
Best hike in my opinion
Amazing views, steep descents/ascents but not a difficult tour. 
Wear comfy shoes, with grip soles. May be windy depending on season
reviews/12/text:
We did the Achada do Teixeira --> Pico Ruivo (and return) walk, starting at around 10am. At the time that we walked (Apr 22) the walk to Pico Areeiro was closed. There was plenty of parking at the car park and we parked in the second line, which had just begun to form. The walk took us about an hour and a bit each way and was of moderate intensity. There are steep bits at the end but not too difficult to manage unless you find climbing extended stairs difficult. Just before the peak there is a house/cafe that serves drinks (although not refrigerated these were still nice and cold). 

The views from the top are spectacular and we got lucky with our day featuring a low layer of cloud that we were above for the entire walk. It must be even more spectacular when it's a completely clear day. There were a few tour groups but it wasn't too busy. They were generally very good at letting faster walkers past as well.
reviews/12/title: 2-3 hour walk (there+back from the car park) of moderate intensity with spectacular views on a clear day
reviews/13/text: We did the hike from Pico Arieiro to Pico Ruivo and we really liked it! It was a very long hike (around 7 hours return) and different weather conditions (mostly low clouds) but with beautiful views. Unfortunately, we didn't have any views at the top because of the weather but we greatly enjoyed the route there!
reviews/14/text: You have two choices how to hike here, we chose the path from the parking „Achada do Teixera“ it is basically „paved“ all the way and can get crowded at times. Nevertheless still a good hike and once up there you feel like you are on top of the world !
reviews/15/text:
Great views!
One thing to note is that there are quite some steps up but it is really worth it. You can see second highest peak in Pico do Aeerio from there and if you're luck you will be above clouds!
reviews/16/text: I recommend booking a guided tour/or just a pick up so you dont have to come back the same way.  With  pick up/guided tour you go from pico ariero through pico ruivo to Achamada de Teixera - here the driver pick you up. All together it is around 9,3km and it is challenging hike (for people with moderate/good fitness level). If you go on your own the options are 2: 1) park at pico Ariero - when you reach pico ruivo you have to return and go the same way back ( you dont want that). Other option is to park at Achamada de Teixera and walk just 2,3km to Pico ruivo - thats the most beautiful part of the hike anyway and its enough if you dont want to sweat on hike.
reviews/17/text:
Given recent reviews talk of trouble with the road, thought I'd provide an update! We drove up today, has been repaired beautifully 👍 There was one confusing bit with a sign saying the road was closed but I think it was just left behind 😂 Few hundred yards of gravel they're still finishing off, then lovely smooth new tarmac.
Having thoroughly reviewed the road... The mountain itself was great! About a 45min walk from the big free car park to the peak. Easy because it's all paved, but super hot! Beautiful views from above the clouds 🤘
reviews/17/title: Road repaired! Lovely walk at the top
reviews/18/text: Failed attempt on 30/5: we tried driving to Achada do Teixeira but the service road is undergoing works. When you reach Pico das pedras you will see a red light. Don't bother waiting because it never turns green. If you try driving forward at some point you will encounter roadworks. We stopped at about halfway through. The workers didn't try to stop us or turn us away, instead moved from their position to "give us way". But there was a digger digging the road up so not sure what he was expecting us to do ??!! They didn't speak any English; we turned back. The govt website says the road is "open" but my guess is that you can only walk or cycle up, not take a car. The sign at the light also says the roadworks are from 10am - 5pm so maybe try the car outside these hours. Otherwise you can park at pedras and it's a 5km walk uphill which will take 1.5 hrs. If you succeed leaves a review for others.
reviews/19/text:
Impossible to hike from Arieiro to Ruivo because of landslide! Also, impossible to reach Ruivo directly because of roadrepair. Only way to reach Pico Ruivo is from Encumeada village but its more that 20km hike. It was worth to visit Arieiro only for
the sunrise (you should come before 7am)
subcategory_ranking: #5 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Avenida Arriaga 28, Funchal, Madeira 9000-064 Portugal
description: Located in a historical building in the very center of Funchal, Blandy's Wine Lodge has been the heart of the family's wine business for 7 generations, ageing the finest Madeira wines in a traditional canteiro method. Each room in the Lodge has unique wine ageing potential due to the different temperatures and humidity conditions, resulting in the diverse profiles of wines aged inside the building. We invite you to join us on our tours, wine tastings and events! Learn more about Madeira wine, history of the Blandy Family, witness canteiro wine ageing and enjoy one of the many wine tasting options we offer.
name: Blandy's Wine Lodge
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Madeira Wine Tour and Tasting with Funchal City tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Madeira wine tasting and sightseeing private tour from Funchal
ranking: #44 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #44 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: The tour was really interesting and very well delivered. The information booklet is excellent quality and contains a full history of the Blandy family and the wine lodge. The free tasting was also excellent. Would highly recommend to anyone visiting madeira. It was excellent value.
reviews/1/text: We had a premium tour and our guide - Patricia is the best! Fluent english, interesting stories about wine. Thank you a lot!
reviews/2/text: What a wonderful surprise.  Not sure Madeira wine was our thing but yes, several (4) different tasting opportunities to find pleasure in 3 out of 4 wines offered. Plus cheese, chocolate, and special molasses treat to pair with the wine.  The building itself is historical.
reviews/3/text:
Tried tasting the 10 year olds in Dry,  Medium dry, medium sweet & sweet. Was told that bottles could be delivered to Ireland at a rate of about €48.50 delivery for 3 bottles. 
Tried tasting the different ages of sweet wines through 5&10&15 years old and a 2007 bottle 
And the dry wines through 3 & 5&10&15 years old. Was very disappointed and insulted to learn that the company refuse to deliver to Ireland as they think it’s part of the U.K. and Brexit affects this. I tried to explain that the Republic of Ireland is using euro and is part of the EU but had to leave without purchasing anything as we got offensively lumped in with the Brits. Spent about €40 quite happily putting in the work to choose a product that I was told I could have delivered but extremely disappointed to come away empty handed due to an oversight in this company’s view of Ireland.
reviews/4/text: A very well organised tour in character filled surroundings where you can see all the barrels Blandy's is stored in before it gets bottled.  Deffo worth a visit.
reviews/4/title: Fascinating to see where it all began
reviews/5/text:
We really enjoyed our tour at Blandy’s and our guide was very informative and enthusiastic about the wine and the brand itself. 
Tour takes around 45 minutes and there are 2 tastings at the end. You can sample more wines for a small fee, a few euros however the older the wine the more expensive the tipple. 
If you buy a wine up to 15 yrs of age you get 10% with you’re ticket (don’t bin it until after you have left!). 
They also offer a service where you can collect your wine from the airport duty free which is helpful
reviews/5/title: Interesting tour and worth a visit
reviews/6/text:
Blandy’s Wine Lodge boasts the oldest wine cellars in Madeira, dating from 17-18th centuries. There’s an interesting collection of vintage wines, machinery and other objects relating to winemaking. Tours available daily except Sundays and allow you to visit the various areas of the Lodge, followed by a wine tasting. 

I was planning on booking on one of the following tours, having seen these advertised on the website: Premier Tour is 45 Minutes at €11.00 or Vintage Tour is 60 Minutes at €22.90. But when we requested the next English speaking tour, we were charged only €15.75 for 2 tickets, so guess there's more tour options? 

Our tour lasted about 45 minutes which was just the right amount of time really, as you take in a lot of information. The tour was fun/interesting yet informative, and then there was a great tasting at the end where we each got to sample 2 different Madeiras.

I read online that tours run Monday - Friday: 10:30, 14:30, 15:30, 16:30 (on request), Saturdays 10:30. But please double check this yourself on their website as our visit was several months ago now. We just turned up and requested the next English tour, which was running in 20 minutes, so we went outside and sat in the pretty little garden just outside and had a walk around in the sun for a few minutes.

There is a small central courtyard area near to where you have the tasting, and the toilets are here next to the Blandy's gift shop.

Very central located, in the heart of Funchal. Unfortunately you can't seem to book online or via telephone? so you have to pop in and hope for the best, or if walking past step inside and book your tour for another day. This is the only area of improvement I could suggest as online booking would have been our preference.
reviews/6/title: Taste the Madeira Wine at Blandy’s Wine Lodge - a must do while in Madeira
reviews/7/text: A very instructive tour by Sophia telling us all we needed to know about the complexity of producing vintage Madeira. We visited all the levels of the wine lodge to see the various stages of maturation and ended with  an enlightening and delicious tasting of four different wines.
reviews/7/title: A fascinating tour of Vintage Madeira wine
reviews/8/text:
Located in the centre of Funchal is Blandy's Wine lodge. Blandy's are the biggest producer of Madeira (a fortified wine) on the island of Madeira which is the only place in the world that it is produced.
Blandy's was created in 1811 by John Blandy, it remains a family business with I believe the 7th generation Blandy running the business.
There is a variety of tours you can take, I strongly recommend that you book ahead of time online because the tours are normally fully booked. The tours take you through the history and production of "Madeira" wine" and is followed by a tasting. There is a shop where you can buy Madeira, the older the vintage the more expensive the bottle.
The tour guides & support staff we encountered were very friendly & only to happy to answer questions.
reviews/9/text: Interesting tour that lasts about 45 mins with a tasting at the end. A good history and museum about the family Blandy
reviews/10/text:
I was flabbergasted and appalled by the attitude of the Blandy’s staff today.

I had read comments about their rudeness in other reviews on Tripadvisor, but thought people were just being a bit OTT. But, oh no, it’s absolutely true. Probably the worst experience I’ve had in a very long while.

We were given a brief tasting in our hotel yesterday and I spoke to the lovely lady afterwards about booking availability for today. She said it would be okay and said the hotel could book for me. Unfortunately they could not get through on the phone so we said that we would book in person.

When we arrived at Blandy’s, the lady (I use that word loosely) on reception told me that they were fully booked. I tried to explain the scenario briefly outlined above and she just dismissed me saying that it didn’t matter what I said, they were fully booked. I tried to explain twice but she just cut me off both times. She was so incredibly rude: what she is doing in a customer facing role is beyond me.

I had been eagerly looking forward to the visit, but I no longer have any desire to give them a second thought. And I certainly won’t be touching another drop of their Madeira wine. 

John Blandy must be turning in his grave!
reviews/11/text: Did the premium tour. Learned more than we thought we would, but not more than we wanted to! I.e. Guide pitched it just right. Tasting was a nice way to finish.
reviews/12/text:
Our tour guide, Patricia, did a wonderful job BUT unfortunately she could not compete with the tour behind us, following MUCH too closely with an obnoxious child who screamed & stomped around so loudly we could hardly hear poor Patricia.  

She rushed us thru our tour just to get away from that badly behaved child. Not good PR for Blandy’s & certainly not the tour we expected.  :(

I wrote to Blandy's about this, suggesting that if they choose to allow children to accompany their parents, they should have a disclaimer stating that children are expected to behave well for the sake of everyone in the tours & if not, parents will be asked to remove the ill behaved child.
Their reply:
"Thank you for your for letting us know what happened. 
We truly hope that on your next visit you will have a better experience. 
It's always been part of our policy that all of our visitors are welcome at Blandy's Wine Lodge."
There will be no next visit!  If the experience for all guests is not respected, we will not return.
reviews/13/text:
Very nice, well kept and interesting building which you can access to taste different Madeira wines and to buy souvenirs in the shop (even without guided tour!).

So far, so good! But wouldn't recommend the visit for 12.50 (incl. 2 small sips of 2 different Madeira wines).

Mass processing as at one moment 3 different groups (English, French & German) were in the same spot!? 
By the way, you see mainly tons of barrels... so best idea is to invest 12.50 Euro pp in "tasting" in stead of "visiting".

Female staff at ticket booth was unfriendly, our guide was knowledgable but the whole visit wasn't worth the money spent!
reviews/14/text: The wine lodge has areas accessible to the public even if you're not doing the tour. Was able to sample some of the delicious madeira wine in the tasting room. They also have a nice shop which has a great range of souvenirs and a restaurant which had a decent looking menu. Would like to do the tour next time I'm in Madeira as ran out of time this trip.
reviews/14/title: Visit the tasting rooms and shop even if you're not doing the tour
reviews/15/text: We have been visiting Madeira for years and until last week had never done the Blandys wine tour. I have to say it was great. We did 2 back to back(sorry cannot remember what they were called) but I would recommend this as the second was fascinating. The tasting at the end was really nice. I would definitely recommend this as a must do.
reviews/16/text:
Would have liked to have done the tour but the website times did not match the reality and we were there too early. Rather than wait for the tour which included a tasting of two drinks we opted for one of the tastings with chocolates. - 4 Madeiras and 4 matching chocolates. Hadn’t realised there were so many types of Madeira and dry too. There is an extensive menu of tastings - a bit overwhelming if you don’t know much about it. Very good value too. 
The wine lodge is lovely inside too with various rooms and a gift shop. Well worth the trip and just a short walk from centre of Funchal.
reviews/17/text:
The tour was very informative. It told of the history of the island and the brand, and enriched our understanding of how the wine is made. The guide Tatiana was very knowledgeable and funny, making it a pleasure to follow.

The tasting, in the end, was a nice and fitting finish, getting to try the delicious wines. 

If I could change one thing, it would be the pacing, as we did not have enough time to read every panel thoroughly.
reviews/18/text: Very reasonable and informative tour around the old winery. A tasting session at the end was very welcoming to us. Thoroughly recommend.
reviews/18/title: A must 'DO' while on the island
reviews/19/text: We first visited here on a Saturday late lunchtime, but sadly they had just closed and wouldn't let us in - we reckon they have really missed a trick here - I know most things close early on a Saturday afternoon, but there are just so many tourists around, I am sure they would get business on a Saturday afternoon.   We weren't that impressed with the jobsworth-ess of a young lady on reception, she was very po-faced when we arrived.   So my husband booked himself in for 10.30 am on the following Monday morning (just before we left for the airport) and managed to have a tour and a tasting, which he really enjoyed, and found very interesting.  Different style to Barbeito though.  He did buy a bottle to take home as a souvenir and to enjoy with friends over Christmas.
subcategory_ranking: #44 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Estr. de Sao Lourenco ER109, Canical, Madeira 9200-034 Portugal
animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
name: Ponta de Sao Lourenco
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Around the island - Two days tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Madeira East Tour from Funchal
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Guided Walk Ponta São Lourenço
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Remarkable East Tour of Madeira Island
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Discover The East - Madeira Island
ranking: #7 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #7 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: We visited with three tired kids so only made it part of the way through.But what we did see was impressive and worth the hike.It was a windy day on the island and especially windy on this stretch of land. Parking is limited so most people had to complete some creative parking jobs along the road.
reviews/1/text:
This area is famous for its rock formations, created by volcanic erosions over many years and this very east part of the island looks like another world. There are no trees and the area looks totally different to the rest of Madeira and was very very different to our other hikes. The scenery is starkly beautiful and we took so many photos. I have such great memories of this walk, I cannot recommend highly enough.

A clearly defined, and very popular, walking trail starts from the car park and leads you across the cliffs. This coastal 8km track leads to the furthest eastern point of the island with spectacular ocean and cliff views, then back again. We arrived very early in the morning and the carpark was empty, but when we left mid-afternoon the carpark was jam packed!

We had read that the hike is quite strenuous in parts with steeper sections up and down, and that hiking poles are useful, but this did not prepare me for how tiring I would find it. Recommended to allow 3-4 hours to enjoy the walk, but we spent over 5 hours as I was heavily pregnant and we took it very slowly.

Be warned, this hike is definitely not one to do on a windy day. It wasn't windy at all when we started our hike, but parts of the route are so exposed that the wind just gusts past you. There are sections where we were so exposed (luckily for only short periods of time or else I would have had to turn back) where my husband was literally gripping my hand as I felt like I might blow away - even at 8 months pregnant! I was a little unsteady on my feet anyway and the baby belly must have been catching the wind even more than usual! lol

Conveniently there is a cafe, Casa do Sardinho, at the further end of the trail. It's in a great location with tables outside and a marvellous view down to the bay and back along the promontory. The food is quite pricey however and there is a cost of €1 to use the toilets. There is also a picnic area and picnic tables by the rocks on the sea shore at the landing jetty a couple of hundred metres below the cafe.

Beyond the cafe there is one final walking opportunity up to the summit of the last accessible hill on the promontory. I had read that this is "up a steepish but well-made path with steps and should take about 25 minutes up and down again". While this may have been true at one point when we visited in April 2022 this was definitely NOT the case!I didn't make it up the final push to the top of the cliff for the views across the sea as the path was so very severely eroded. I have uploaded photos as you wouldn't believe the condition of the path, it was worse than scrambling. Being heavily pregnant and the path being so steep and eroded, I opted to sit on the side of the steep path while my husband finished the climb to the top - to take photos for me of the views out to the furthest end of the island

Overall an absolutely magnificent walk and of course a great contrast to levada walking. Ponta de São Lourenço is recommended as a great place for sunrise and sunset. A very popular tourist destination it is therefore recommended to arrive early, hike and leave before the crowds, apparently cars are usually queuing to get into the free carpark by 11am.

I had read that this was is easily accessible by Bus 113 from Funchal for €3.50, so we took a Bolt direct from our hotel outside of Funchal for €24 and then opted for the bus back to central Funchal. I very much regret taking the bus back! as it seemed to take hours, stopping constantly to pick up passengers as it is very much a local bus and not an express bus. Plus you have to get off and swap busses in another town on the way, such a carry on. Grab is so cheap and convenient, we would definitely recommend this instead.

A total contrast to our other hikes on the island (Levada do Furado (PR10) and Vereda dos Balcões de Ribeiro Frio (PR11)) but we loved this walk too, for completely different reasons.
reviews/1/title: I have such great memories of this walk, I cannot recommend highly enough - absolutely amazing scenery
reviews/2/text:
The most eastern coast of Madeira offers outstanding views of the nature.

Great place to enjoy a walk, go hiking...

Very busy wellknown tourist spot.

Extremly windy.

Must do 👍
reviews/3/text:
nice walk !
better to do it early morning before the crowd arrive
you can join the departure point BAIA d ABRA, via the bus 311, SAM company, from funchal .
you need 2/3 hours to reach the highest point
there is a cafe on the way.
the views from the trail are stunning 
trail is safe and medium level
reviews/4/text: Very dry terrain quite different from the rest of the island . Lovely viewpoints seen when we were on an East tour
reviews/5/text:
The view is breathtaking.
Unfortunately, we arrived too late and could not do the whole walk; however, we stopped halfway through to appreciate the beauty of the place.
reviews/6/text: Had to park a long way down the hill, almost at Quinta.  Toilets 1 Euro, rather than the usual 50 cents.  Very busy on the path, stopping to let others pass.  Nice cafe at the end of the main walk which was not too expensive, apart from the toilets.
reviews/7/text: Great intermediate hike! Amazing views. I would not describe it dangerous but I'd recommend not to bring small kids there. Last part of the trail (to the last hill) was closed but most people still did it, I thought it was ok with proper shoes. I was happy wearing hiking boots and a lot of sunscreen.
reviews/8/text:
must visit!
it's very hot, bring enough water, sunskin creme, there is no shadow at all, don't go here when it's too hot (over 30 degrees). it's a long walk to the restaurant at the end. Stunning views!!
reviews/9/text:
The highlight of our trip to Madeira! Breathtaking 360 degree views once you reach the tip top and even if you don’t go all the way you’ll see some awesome views of the cliffs and ocean.  That all said - be prepared! Have good walking footwear and sunscreen and be prepared for high winds. I’m a 50+ woman in pretty good shape but it was challenging - especially coming down. My legs got wobbly. We started up around 9:30 am (the earlier the better due to crowds) and got back to parking lot around 12:30 with a stop for cold drink on way down. There is a WC at the cafe which has a decent offering of food and drink. And when you get back two food trucks are there with cold refreshments and food. I would not recommend bringing young children on hike as paths are narrow and some
cables railings are broken. Many people had walking sticks and poles which would help!
reviews/9/title: Best thing we did in Madeira - stunning views!
reviews/10/text: We visited here in March 2022, and arrived at the carpark before 7am hoping to catch the sunrise. Unfortunately, it was too cloudy on that day. We started to do the PR8 Verada da Ponta de São Lourenço hike to the lookout at Miradouro Ponta do Furado. It was a leisure 2.5 hours walk from the carpark (including many stop for photos an flying drone) to reach the lookout point. Would definitely recommend people to do this hike while in Madeira. But try to come early as the place gets crowded on our way back to the carpark at around 130pm.
reviews/10/title: Great hiking trail in eastern Madeira
reviews/11/text: The best place for trekking and photos. In the morning there can be clouds but don't let it down you. It is worth to see in any weather!
reviews/12/text: An amazing walk along a beautiful landscape. One of my favourite places to visit. I'd saw the walk is moderate difficulty due to the steepness but definitely worth it.
reviews/13/text:
Great views and quite easy to reach the end with good footwear.
Be sure to have swimwear as there is a nice cove with clear inviting water to cool down and a cafe for drinks and snacks.
reviews/14/text:
Took the bus from Machico, 20 mins To the car park at the end of the bus line. Then 3 km to the coffee shop at the foot of the final ascent.
Walking is hard going in places, sometimes with only the guard wire rope rail to protect you from a potentially fatal tumble. Not for the faint hearted. 
However the views are stunning in places. 
We started at 1030 taking it easy and was 2 hours to the coffee shop.
Very very busy…..walkers in the hundreds  if not thousands . Very busy in places.
Decided to take the boat back, 10 eu per head, incl a bit of a guided tour looking for seals back to Quinta dos Lordes marina.
Take rain macs , can go from sunning to driving rain very quickly.
Overall definitely worth the trip
reviews/15/text:
No where to hide in the rain, hot sun and strong wind.  We were putting on and off our fleece/ rain jacket because of the crazy weather. Make sure you have proper hiking boots/shoes because you need it. Plenty of up and down paths and steps.

It’s not a easy hike especially after the shop/cafe part. If you decide to give up now, you can catch a boat ride near the cafe and they will take you near the car park.
Now, after the cafe they hike get harder in my opinion as it’s steep and lots of steps but once you get to the top you are rewarded with a beautiful view.
On the way down, stick to the path on your right as it’s flatter and easier than the steps on your left. 

We are not keen/ professional hikers and it took us just under 3 hours round trip.
reviews/15/title: Very windy - Bring windproof / light jacket.
reviews/16/text:
We started this walk today, took the bus and arrived at 10:30. winds of 26mph from the north , huge number of people, narrow paths, some long drops. We are accustomed walkers but this path is an accident waiting to happen. The wind was blowing people off track and some of the children walking had to stop themselves from being blown over. The previous reviews identify many of the problems and risk associated with this path, and on a good day with few people I'm sure the views are magnificent. But as expected, it is a victim of its own success. Anyone who says this is an easy walk must have done it when there is no wind and no other tourist blocking the path for the infamous selfie or instagram shot , oblivious to needs of others. Read Christian M's review , it is honest and clear about the reality of this path. If you have have  children or babies , think twice about what risks you and they will be taking if the weather is not perfect. We saw a number of sensible parents turn around after the second incline steps . realising the problems of trying to go on. 
If you do undertake this pilgrimage because it has a 5* trip advisor rating, take your own food and drinks as you will be seriously overcharged by the snack bar in the car park for everything.
reviews/16/title: Do your research and be absolutely sure about the weather, conditions and your own ability
reviews/17/text: Fabulous hike, but it is quite strenuous in parts, I used walking poles, glad I had them for the steeper parts up and down. We are slow walkers so took approx 3.5 hours, that included a stop at Oasis bar half way round which I would not recommend, if we come again we’d bring our own picnic, the food snacks were over priced, the worst quiche I have had, raw soggy pastry - the toilets were 1 euro which we felt very steep especially if buying snacks. So many people using the toilets they weren’t particularly clean, anyway it did not deter from an amazing hike - felt challenged by it and proud I’d done it. Thoroughly recommend to confident walkers with a head for vertical drops !
reviews/18/text: We hiked on a sunny but very windy day. In some places it was a bit scary, felt like the wind blows you off the path and it is a long way down if something goes wrong. We walked to the cafe mid-way and doubled back. The cafe was surprisingly nice.
reviews/18/title: Nice view, the hike is not a piece of cake
reviews/19/text:
Let’s get the facts straight from the start:

This wonderful and scenic walk is 6,7 km all in all. It takes 2-2,5 hours if you are fairly fit (we are almost 60 years old, and it took us 2,20 hours including time to take pictures and a 10 minute break halfway where we had some fruit and water that we brought ourselves).

The walk is among the most popular things-to-do in Madeira (no. 15 on Tripadvisor) - and though it’s quite strenuous you’ll meet lots of people, also children and elderly.

START EARLY! Park your car well before 9 AM (you’ll be among the first) - when you return to the parking lot a couple of hours later there will be hundreds of cars and buses …. You will meet all these people - and have to step aside for each and everyone - on the narrow path on your way back!

BRING walking shoes, maybe walking sticks (we didn’t), water, cap/hat and dress according to weather conditions. Don’t go if it has just been raining - or promise us to be extremely careful. Too much wind can be annoying, too. Also remember to go to the toilet before you start.

THE TRACK starts very easy, but soon gets more rough. Up and down it goes (it’s not af walk in the park), and most of the way you will have to concentrate where you place your feet. The drops down the cliffs are pretty serious - but on the worst parts of the track there are ropes for your protection.

HALFWAY is a bar - but it was closed when we got there at 10 AM in the morning. At this point of the walk is a small loop that goes through the bar area - take it counter-clockwise. There is a hill you can climb if you fancy more action and views (we didn’t).

This walk is a must-do in Madeira, much much more interesting than any levada … HOWEVER: Personally, I’m a little frightened by heights and the risc of falling down cliffs - to me the walk was quite a challenge, but I did it and I was proud afterwards.
reviews/19/title: Magnificent walk (and a little frightening, to be honest)
subcategory_ranking: #7 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Er103 Parque Natural de Ribeiro Frio, Madeira 6160-206 Portugal
name: Balcoes de Ribeiro Frio
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Madeira: Private 1.5-Kilometer Levada dos Balcões Hike PR11
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Sunrise Tour @ Pico Do Areiro | Half Day 4x4 Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Full Day East of Madeira Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Private Tour | Full Day 4x4 Tour
