ranking: #16 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #16 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
Vereda dos Balcões de Ribeiro Frio (PR11) is highly recommended as a very easy 3km hike on a very good flat path; 1.5kms to the viewpoint and then back.

From Funchal take Nos 56, 103 or 138 buses to Santana and disembark at Ribeiro Frio. I read that the cost is €2.75 each but for the convenience and hour saved we took a Bolt direct from our hotel just outside of Funchal for €21. From the bus stop, walk a little way downhill to find the track on the left, which is signposted for Balcões, just past the start of the Ribeiro Frio to Portela walk on your right. 

A wide, level path takes you along the levada (irrigation channel), through a forest and past a very rustic café before leading you onto a viewing platform with incredible views over the Ribeira da Metade valley. In addition, you’ll see the Laurisilva forest, classified as a World Heritage by UNESCO. The island’s highest peaks, Pico do Areeiro, Pico do Gato, and Pico das Torres, are also visible. 

This is a lovely little walk through the forest and then you are rewarded with absolutely amazing views! Suitable for pretty much everyone, there is no reason not to go on this walk - you could even manage it with a sturdy pram! We set off very early to avoid the crowds and there was only a couple more people at the view point, on the way back however we passed several couples/families.

Tip: Take bread from breakfast to feed the very friendly birds here. 

Located in Ribeiro Frio natural park. The mountains are covered in thick forest, and you’ve got a view all the way out to the sea on a clear day. Note: this area is very prone to mist and cloud cover, so plan in advance and check visibility on NetMadeira before making the drive.

I read that the Ribeiro Frio Restaurant near the entrance to the walk to the Vereda dos Balcões is highly recommended and also very reasonably priced. The prego (Madeiran steak sandwich) is very popular and made here with Bolo do Caco bread which is delicious. However, half way towards the Vereda dos Balcões (viewpoint) there is a rustic cafe which looked lovely, we would have visited but it was still early morning and we had a long day of hiking ahead of us (and full packed lunches in our backpacks).

We combined this short walk with the longer Levada do Furado (PR10), which finishes in Portela. This was hard work as I was heavily pregnant but I loved this hike so much. Walking past many little waterfalls and even underneath a couple! There were narrow walkways to traverse with precipices on one side! and even short dark caves to walk through! This walk really had it all and we definitely suggest combing these two levada walks as we did.
reviews/0/title: We loved this walk, can't rate highly enough for beauty with convenience, but we highly recommend full day with Furado
reviews/1/text: This is a levada walk that takes about half an hour each way and is not too difficult. You get some excellent views from the end of the walk. There is a good cafe about half way along the walk which offers a selection of hot and cold drinks and snacks. Parking at the start of the walk is on the side of the road and is quite limited.
reviews/2/text: Very picturesque drive to Ribeiro FRIO and the levada walk to Balcoes . Short , flat and very easy. But …..suggest you do not eat in the village cafes or restaurants as about half way on route to Balcoes you will find this lovely tiny cafe balancing on the side of the hill. Run by the most amazing and friendliest staff with some great local home cooked food. It is a must to visit …..enjoy.
reviews/3/text: This levada is a relatively flat walk & about 2km in length (more than the signposted 1km). It enables visitors to get a sense of the levadas without being super fit or spending all day hiking. The end viewing point can be quite crowded but the views are worth the walk.
reviews/4/text: We really wanted to walk a lavada whilst in Madeira but I'd had an operation on my knee so had to be careful.  We, therefore, picked this easy walk of about 3km that end at a viewing platform with magnificent views of the mountains on the opposite side of the valley along with sea views of the north coast.  You can also feed the local birds; some will feed from your hand.  We'd hired a taxi for the day.  He dropped us off in Ribeiro Frio and I've never seen so many cars/coaches in such a small town but there is another more difficult walk going from this town also.  About halfway along the track there is a small cafe.  On the way back we played Pooh Sticks where the lavada seemed straight enough to follow their progress.  It is a fair drive from Funchal for such a short walk but thoroughly enjoyable.
reviews/5/text: Very easy walk (around 3km both ways) with beautiful views of the valley in the end. Suitable for every age group.
reviews/6/text:
Hiking madeira by bus

Take bus 36 to santana ensuring it is the one that goes via ribeiro frio. Goes from depot next to cable car. Worth the 2.75E even if you just go to Santana and back.  If walking get off at Ribeiro Frio not much of a place but a great location to get on a hiking trail. Shortest option 2k to Balcoes lookout  4k out and back trip to Cabego Passeguero lookout. 7km round loop. PR10 10km one way to Santo da Serra for bus 77 ride home.
reviews/7/text:
Easy, flat 1 mile walk from the centre. Beautiful 270 degree views from a platform around the mountains and down to the coast. Very popular so don't expect to be alone! Choose a clear as day as possible as this is a cloudy area and you won't see much if that's the case. Early am is usually best, although we were there at 4pm in early October and it was super clear.

You can get a bus up from Funchal or drive (35mins) and park roadside.

Combine with at least part of the levada hike to Portela.
reviews/7/title: Easy short walk to one of the best viewpoints on the island
reviews/8/text:
Easy way without any difference in altitude to a great balcony over the rocks with fanatastic view into the valley.
Around the balcony you'll find a lot of endemic birds - signs and explanation board available there.
reviews/9/text:
It is only a short walk from the parking lot and there is an amazing viewpoint at the end of the journey. 

Great views to the green valley and mountains.
reviews/10/text: Short walk between the trout farm and a local restaurant. The walk is quite short, under the shade of trees, hence, very good for a sunny day. Nice little terrace overlooking the valley at the end.
reviews/10/title: Short walk to the beautiful valley
reviews/11/text:
The walk is easy and the view spectacular! Not many tourists in May and we definitely could keep the distance! 

Note: Birds have no fear! 😊So you can admire them as much as you want!
reviews/12/text: This walk was lovely and easy to do, but the most amazing part was the end, with the incredible views!!! HIGHLY recommend this, especially on a hot day since there is great shade along the walk.
reviews/12/title: Wait until you reach the end of this walk!! WOW
reviews/13/text: This is a short and easy walk. We went there on a rainy day and it was quite muddy, so wear good shoes and be careful. At the end there is a wonderful view - and some nice birds that seemed to be used to tourists.
reviews/14/text: When you have good visibilty you can from there Pico do Areiero, Pico das Torres and Pico Ruivo. These three peaks are the highest on the island.
reviews/15/text: Ok, this is the busiest levada walk you will do, but the view at the end is spectacular. It is a very easy walk, the starting point is just down from the trout farm, also worth a visit. Drink to start at the bar, we break at the bar halfway a long. Drink back at the bar when you return. Overall 2 hours is fine and fits in fine with the bus timetable. The bus trip is interesting too!
reviews/16/text: We did the walk after visiting the trout farm and having a coffee.  The walk is quite pleasant for those of us who are not regular walkers, a little uneven in places. The views at the end are stunning.
reviews/17/text:
We did this 20-30 minute walk as part of the East Tour.
Easy going flat walkway.
What made it special was the lookout. Not for the vista as much as the Madeira Chaffinches who have learnt over the years that tourists mean food.
They are so tame they will feed from your hand and you have to be careful not to tread on them.
reviews/18/text:
The trail is rather short, easy and goes through a forest. It was a bit difficult to find the start of the trail - if you arrive from the mountain top you need to pass through the trout farm and all restaurants and the trail will start on the left. Might be difficult with finding a parking place. 
The place is nice, good for a hot day and an easier walk.
reviews/19/text:
Ribeira Frio is nothing more than a very small village separated into two areas with restaurants and cafes. Most visitors and coaches park at the upper area and the walk to the balcony starts here (however, there is a shorter but initially steeper access path lower down which will save just under 1km of walking and joins path at the 500m to go point - see my pic for detail).  Path is easy going but you do need to watch your step over the 1.5km trek as it’s uneven. There’s a shack selling drinks and snacks at just under the 1km point. The viewpoint has extensive views down and across the valley and almost tame Madeiran Chaffinches fly around waiting to be fed scraps.

For some reason I just expected more and in my opinion it was rather a wasted effort getting there - Eira do Serrado viewpoint in the heights above Curral da Freiras is far better given the choice.
subcategory_ranking: #16 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Caminho Quinta do Palheiro 32, Funchal, Madeira 9060-255 Portugal
description: The gardens at "Quinta do Palheiro" are famous not only for the variety of plants that grow there but for the beauty of their setting in the hills to the east of Funchal, the capital of Madeira. Madeira has long been called the "Garden Isle" and it seems that almost anything will grow in its fertile soil.The Palheiro gardens are situated at about 500 meters above sea level and were started in 1801 by the original owner the Conde de Carvalhal. He introduced Camellias to the Island, hence our vast collection. The gardens, some 14 hectares (with about 650 species of plants),include the Camellia avenue, Main Garden, Sunken Garden, Rose Garden, Long Border and the Ladies' Garden where you find the tea house. There is also the Ribeiro do Inferno, a deep valley with treeferns and indigenous plants.
name: Palheiro Gardens
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Private Halfday Flower Palheiro Gardens Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Gardens, Embroidery and Market
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Funchal Old Town & Palheiro Gardens Private Tuk Tuk Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Full Day Madeira Island Private Discovery by Tuk Tuk
ranking: #37 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #37 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Very disappointing indeed. The €10 entrance fee seems somewhat excessive to visit gardens which really are not well looked after. I appreciate maybe March is early for a wide variety of colourful flowers however the grounds need a lot of work to make them looked cared for. The Rose Garden was embarrassing, the roses had never been primed or tidied, straggly looking specimens of plants with the ground full of weed. All in all an expensive morning to see very little sadly.
reviews/1/text:
This is a large garden full of lush vegetation and indigenous plants. There are many small areas to explore including Camellia Avenue, Sunken Garden, Rose Garden, Long Border and the Ladies' Garden - which is where you find the tea house, which seems to be highly recommended in other reviews. There is also the Ribeiro do Inferno, a deep valley with tree ferns and indigenous plants. We particularly enjoyed exploring this area, although the paths would not be suitable for anyone with limited mobility or a pushchair.

The paths in the main garden areas are mostly good and although the gardens are spread out, there's not too much walking required to get around and see it all, although there is initially quite a long walk of 10 minutes or more to actually arrive at the gardens from the main gate.

We happily spent a couple of hours walking around, but in late April there wasn't nearly as many flowers to see as I had been expecting, so I imagine a visit in May/June to be much better. I did particularly enjoy seeing the yellow poppies however. There are a couple of lovely view points too. The gardens were very quiet when we visited with not many other visitors.

There is a bus stop right outside the main entrance, and a bus timetable with full information on how to get to Funchal - take Nos 36 or 37 buses. We were going to get a bus but found Bolt (the local equivalent of Uber or Grab) so quick and easy to use and so reasonably priced that we opted for a quicker car ride to the next attraction on our fun packed touristy day.

Open daily from 9am to 5pm. Tickets are €10 each. We recommend to spend upto 2 hours exploring the gardens.
reviews/1/title: Not our favourite garden in Funchal, but we enjoyed a couple of hours wandering around in the sunshine
reviews/2/text:
Lovely open space, beautiful views from there. Possibly in some seasons there will be more to be seen than in others. 
However, to visit the place you need to pay more than to visit other better places such as the botanical gardens and Monte Palace). There is not very regular busses going up there essentially during the weekend so there is pretty good chance you might get ripped off from the taxi service around.
The quality of the food and the drinks in the Tea rooms is pretty average, in fact we had the worst BTL sandwich ever. 
I am not surprised now there were only a few visitors around.
reviews/3/text:
We arrived at the gardens after a walk from the No 36 bus stop. We then realised that the No 37 takes you right to the gates. There were no guides in English available.
Much less crowded than Monte Gardens, there is much to enjoy here in the varied planting that includes South African as well as native species.
For a person with mobility issues it’s not ideal; there are the usual small cobbles, steps and steep slopes, with no buggy available. (The so-called disabled loo at the entrance is up a cobbled slope.)
The tea room seems to cope with the number of visitors, and there are large and unusual cakes on offer to go with your mug of Tetley’s.
We were hoping there might be packets of seeds on sale, but that wasn’t the case.
Anyway, a pleasant visit to a peaceful garden.
reviews/4/text: What a delight to go round this garden with representative flora from many parts of the world, especially South Africa. Fans of Camellia will not be disappointed. I would love to be able to visit monthly to see the seasonal changes. Some of the trees are breathtaking!
reviews/5/text: An interesting bus ride from Funchal. Situated high above the city with a marvellous growing climate.  The garden had a lovely atmosphere and felt like a real family garden.  We walked in down a narrow track with trifolium in full flower so the meadows and roadside were a haze of soft yellow.  The range of plants is amazing from tropical to narcissus side by side.  Definitely the best and most interesting of the gardens we visited.  A nice small cafe is on site for refreshments.  Also have to mention that the camellias were gorgeous.
reviews/5/title: The most interesting garden near Funchal
reviews/6/text:
Monte is more popular, but Palheiro is much more floral and to our mind more attractive.  The walk from the entrance is also much less steep than Monte and takes you through an avenue of camellias.
It has an excellent snack bar at the bottom of the garden with delicious pastries.
The one challenge is the bus timetable - in particular there is a 2 hour gap for getting back in the afternoon. You can get a taxi to take you up and bring you back at an agreed time, but beware, they will ask an excessive price, so be prepared to negotiate.
reviews/7/text: The best of the several gardens we visited in Madeira. Well kept and attractive. If arriving by car make sure to drive through the front entrance and, having oaid, drive down to the parking area near the garden itself.
reviews/8/text: A lovely visit to Palheiro today, exceedingly tranquil! Lots to see, especially plants from tropical climes, many labelled. As signed by the entrance, you can walk down - or drive through the gates, pay, then continue down to a parking area. A pleasant light lunch at the Tea House at the far end on the gardens - Delightful!
reviews/9/text: The house & Gardens are owned by the Blandy family. It is an attractive garden, which is an easy walk around. If you come by car, go through the gate, stop to buy ticket, then continue down the drive as the is a car park near the garden entrance.
reviews/10/text:
Unfortunately our visit concided with a rare wet day, but undaunted we explored the gardens in our rainwear.  It was the first time we had toured the gardens in the winter, but we were pleasantly surprised by how much was in bloom, in particular the enormous camellia trees and the king proteas.  A very pleasant cafe for coffee and snacks.

Well served by the local buses and close to the Levada dos Tornos for walking.
reviews/11/text: Perhaps not the right time of year to visit the gardens. Well laid out and lots of information available about what you are looking at. Im sure it would be spectacular in the spring or summer. Some of the paths are in good order, others decidedly slippy when wet and uneven. Would be difficult to get a wheelchair user or disabled person round all of the gardens. It is (like everywhere else) on a very steep sided cliff/valley and is a bit of a hike. There is a nice cafe with views over the golf course. Well served by several buses and can be walked to along the Levada.
reviews/12/text: What a wonderful botanical garden - a real delight!  Even in mid-November!  We came here as part of our escorted tour to Madeira.  I was a bit nervous of the paths, because they were quite steep up and down, and quite slippy in parts.  But you just need to be careful and watch your step.  Absolutely wonderful gardens, with all sorts of surprises just around the next corner.  Who would believe that you can see red poinsettias growing "wild" at this time of year!  And there's a tea room for a break before you head back up  the paths to the exit area.  Not a great tea room, but you can get a decent cuppa and a cake to re-energise you for the return climb!  Definitely worth a 2 hour visit!
reviews/13/text:
These are lovely gardens with beautiful views across Funchal.  Being at an elevation means they are cooler than down by the sea so take an extra layer.  You can visit by bus from Funchal (double check bus times- we had a leaflet for the gardens given to us by Tourist Information that was out of date).  When you arrive they have helpfully included the return bus times at the entrance. Entrance was Euros 10.
The gardens are extensive and laid out with paths that criss-cross the beautiful spaces.  Even in November there was colour but the gardens must be even more glorious in spring and summer. There is a tea room where food and drink can be purchased. 
On arrival you will walk downhill for about 10 minutes to reach the gardens so be aware of allowing sufficient time to return to the entrance which is done via a different path, steeper but shorter!
reviews/14/text:
This garden is a little miracle! While everyone talks about the wonders of Funchal's botanical garden, the real wonder is Palheiro. This is real dream of Garden of Eden. This is old, maintained well but not over... If you are interested, the trees are labeled with the species of trees. There are a few different theme gardens - all nice and picturesque. There can be found nice white chapel and also very cute small tea house. The tea house menu is a bit expensive but our quiches and cakes were just excellent!

I recommend park your car near the main gate and take a walk to gardens from gate - this 15 minutes under old platane trees is worth walking. Amazing garden!
reviews/15/text: Such a relaxing atmosphere. And beautiful flowers! This is well worth a visit in case you like flowers and plants
reviews/16/text: Still plenty of botanical interest in September!  Parked at entrance and followed sign for ‘tea house’  - quite a long walk down uninteresting drive and would have been better to drive in, or take path to ‘garden‘ instead.  Some parking at bottom of drive by house.
reviews/17/text: My wife and I spent a few hours walking around these gardens and found it a really peaceful experience, lots of different plants, flowers and trees to catch your eye, all of it nice to wander around because it’s generally quite level, there’s even a good cafe where we stopped to have some coffees and snacks. We’d recommend this to anyone ..nice way to escape for a few hours.
reviews/18/text:
This is a very English type garden which is also called Blandys Garden, with a lot of native flowers.
Catch a 36 or 37 bus from near the cable car for 3 euros each way. Entry to the garden is 10 euros each.
A little bit hilly in places but well worth it with a fabulous viewpoint of Funchal in the distance.
There is a small cafe and toilets and is a good half a day out.
reviews/19/text:
We took the bus from Funchal - arriving as it opened - make sure you are back at bus stop for return journey at the time stated on the board just inside the entrance gate.
Very enjoyable wandering around in the variety of gardens and trees - some of which we had never encountered before (look out for the labels on the trees). Don't miss the pond and the tiny frogs jumping back in.  Lunched on a good sandwich at the Tea Room (pricey but worth it).
subcategory_ranking: #37 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Estrada Nova do Cristo Rei, Madeira 6160-206 Portugal
name: Miradouro do Cristo Rei do Garajau
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Garajau Tuk-Tuk Tour (Christ King Statue)
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Madeira Grand Experience (price per tukxi - up to 3 people)
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Tour | Full Day 4x4 Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Madeira Highlights: Guided 4-Hour Tour from Funchal
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Garajau (price per tukxi - up to 3 people)
photo/caption: Miradouro do Cristo Rei do Garajau, Madeira.
ranking: #43 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #43 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: This is another tourist attraction, which is located between Funchal and the airport. Christ the Redeemer as illustrated by the Portuguese. You can also use a cable car to go down to the beach.
reviews/1/text: This is a nice little spot but I personally found it quite difficult to get an actual good view of the front of the statue. There are nice views in general, but we only spent about 15 minutes there. For me, if you’re passing it’s worth a stop off but I wouldn’t go out of your way, especially when there’s so much else to offer in Madeira!!
reviews/1/title: Worth a quick stop if you’re passing!
reviews/2/text: Impressive statue built 4 years before it’s counterpart in Rio, Brazil..for the best views climb down the steps to a viewing platform as Cristo Faces out to sea.To get here you either need a car or a combination of bus to Canico and then taxi.Also fantastic views over to Funchal.Whilst here try out the adjacent cable car down to the beach which is only a short 3 euro return trip.There are cafes at both top and bottom.
reviews/3/text:
We combined the spiritual Jesus moment with a more physical experience … 2,5 km walk from Canico de Baixo to the statue and back again.

It’s a very scenic walk all the way - most of the track is on nice pavement, so ordinary trainers are fine. The hard part is the fact that most of the way is either up, up, up or down, down, down.

Start the walk on the corner outside Pizzaria la Carbonara - ask the GPS in your smartphone to guide you to ‘Miradouro do Cristo Rei do Garajau’ on foot.

If you go by car there is free parking just before the statue.

In front of the parking lot you’ll find a cable car that can take you to the pebbled beach at Garajau.

Walking, tanning, swimming and an impressive ‘Jesus disguised as king’ statue - what’s not to like?
reviews/4/text: Nice stopping point when out exploring. Good views. Very cool beach next to the statue with a cable cart down. Ample parking available.
reviews/5/text: Nice cost views, besides the statue itself. There is also a teleferico down to the beach. Coffe shop, quite a big parking
reviews/6/text:
Wednesday 16th June and we visited the Statue of Christo Rei, situated on the headland at Ponta do Garajau. 

From there we walked down the steps to the rocky viewpoint at end of the headland. 

There there were some wonderful views across to Funchal in one direction and Caniço de Baxia. 

Along the way there was a whale monitoring station. 

It was hard work climbing back up all of the steps but it was worth it for the views.
reviews/6/title: Lots of steps but worth it for the views
reviews/7/text: This Christo Rei is a definitely worth a visit if in the Garajau area. Its located a bit out of town but if you have your own transport there is plenty of parking. Its a short up hill walk from there to the foot of the statue which looks out to sea. You can look up from the base but to get a view looking back at Jesus you can wander towards the sea as far as you feel like. Its a popular spot with tourists and locals so don't be surprised to see Madeirans paying their respects.
reviews/8/text:
We did have a little bit of difficulty finding out how to get here. We had visited Blandy's in the morning and there is a tourist office right next door which directed us to the correct bus stop. If you head to the cable car area and right to the top of where the buses are, near to the Madeira Story Centre, the last stand will be for bus no.155 to Garajau. It cost about 2.40 euros pp each way. We sat on the two person seat on the bus which was very tight and we are small and so make sure you grab the three-seater! I used the GPS on my phone to work out where we had to get off but it wasn't exactly easy and we did have to check with our driver. Get off opposite restaurant Neptuno. Then head straight over the roundabout down a steep hill and it's a steep winding road down (signposted too). We had checked the timetable and were not too sure of the return trip and so made sure we were back for the next obvious bus which gave us about a 45 minute time slot to get down, look around and get back. We are 36 and 40 and are quite fit and so managed it with time to enjoy the statue and time to spare. But be warned the return trip back is steep and it was a sweaty journey back up!! The return bus is near to Tourigalo restaurant.

We were told by another British tourist that this was the prototype for the Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio and it's pretty similar. No entry charge you just walk up to it. Plenty of parking nearby if you're driving. There is also a restaurant there which would have been lovely to stop at and have a nice drink overlooking the beautiful views....if only we had time. There are steps down from the statue which are worth going down to take the picture looking back up. There was also beach we spotted right below and you can actually take a cable car down there or drive down. A real mad dash go see this but worth it but not everyone may think so and our way of getting here isn't for everyone. We didn't hire a car this time but if you do, this isn't too difficult to get to and worth a stop off.
reviews/9/text: Good views and awesome Jesus statue .just difficult to reach this place by bus but not impossible ,🙂
reviews/10/text: The Cristo Rei monument is definitely worth seeing. And the walk down, to look up at it is worth it. I took the cable car down to the beach because I read the drive down was treacherous. The drive is nothing, and it’s on a paved road. Definitely drive down instead of taking cable car. It is 3 euro round trip but there is nothing more to see than you can see from the top anyways. Plus the operator never had change for a 5 so I had to pay 5, go down, and buy something so that I could give him the exact amount when I went back up. Then when you are trying to get back up, you rely on him seeing you on his camera in able to bring you up, as there is nobody down there. I stood there for several minutes, jumping up and down and waving my arms. It’s not used much so he obviously didn’t pay attention
reviews/10/title: Monument very good, cable car not
reviews/11/text:
The walk way and steps have very well presented ( clearly the latter has been renovated recently) Amazing views - even on a grey day 
- Cafe disappointing ( a price list at the counter would be very helpful) - the facility could have been tidier, the Coofee was nice but more expensive than any other we had had around the island, disappointing to find smoking was allowed in seating area.
The online information for the cable car said it was open till 8 pm . We arrived late afternoon ( as it had been raining earlier)  and were told it closed at 6 pm all year round...
reviews/11/title: Room for improvement- Up to date information would be helpful!
reviews/12/text: This area you can visit again and again - lovely view - and if you are looking 25 minutes - yeah, then you can close you are eyes and get another look the next 45 minutes - lovely spot.
reviews/13/text: Visited here as part of an included trip with my Holiday company. On arrival most of us walked up to the high point where there was information on the area but unfortunately not in English, and the large statue of Christ like the one in Rio. The views from here are breathtaking and it was a lovely day. There is a cable car which takes you down to the beach, but we didn't have time for that. A cafe and loo's but non had locks on the doors. I also found whilst on the island the only lock l saw on a disabled toilet was in the airport!
reviews/14/text:
This one is easy to miss. It doesn't seem to be on the typical list of places to visit. It's a statue of Christ at the end of a parking lot, with a steep paved trail that goes down to a promontory.The views are really nice.There is also a road and cable car that go down to the beach, a long way below. The parking (at the top) is free, not sure how much the cable car is, we didn't take it. 

To put it in perspective, it was our last day and we wanted to do something easy and close by (to the hotel) and this fit the bill perfectly. It was a very warm day, and we just sat on a bench for quite some time. I walked down and back up the trail to the end of the headland. It's not too far, but relatively steep, so you have to be reasonably healthy and capable to do it.

We were staying at the Ocean Gardens hotel in Sao Goncalo. From there, go through Garajau to the roundabout and you'll see a sign "Cristo Rei". You go down the hill through a residential area until you reach the parking lot. 

Nothing special, but a nice place to sit outside and enjoy the views.
reviews/14/title: Underrated place to visit in Madeira
reviews/15/text: Myself and my partner visited on the first day of our trip and it was absolutely beautiful. An easy walk and a cable car down to the beach.
reviews/16/text: Beautiful monument of Christus. It´s not as big as RioDejaneiro one, but still nice walk, beautiful view from this place. We had nice time there. Just visit this place when you on Madeira, there is also restaurant and this is one of the "must see" place.
reviews/17/text:
Stopped here on a tour. Impressive statue looking out to sea but you can only take a photo of the back of the statue as it is too close to the edge to get a photo of the front unless you are able to walk down several steep steps to get  a better view of it.
Seats at the top for those with mobility problems and a small cafe near the car parking area.
reviews/17/title: Statue of Christ looking out to sea.
reviews/18/text: Had wanted to get here for a while, but found it not so simple to plan. Eventually got here as part of a tour and was glad to finally see it. There are great views and plenty of areas to look out from and take photos. The statue can be seen from far away so it was great to see it up close. If we had longer, we would have probably looked to walk down the hill to the beach or try out the cable car (If they were working). I think there was some toilets at this site too.
reviews/18/title: Wonderful Views and a Large Statue
reviews/19/text:
We walked to this place from Canico which is a challenging 3 miles mainly uphill .
The site of the monument  made the effort worthwhile as it has great views of Funchal & the coast.  There is a pleasant cafe beside the car park and a cliff lift that goes down to the beach almost vertically.
subcategory_ranking: #43 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Canico, Madeira Portugal
name: Praia de Garajau
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Kayak and Snorkeling Tour in Underwater Nature Reserve Garajau
photo/caption: laissez vous aller à travers les nombreux chemins et routes qui longent la superbe côte de garaj
ranking: #40 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #40 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Great place to visit and use the cable car. Nice walk in the area with places to drink and eat. Highly recommended!
reviews/0/user/user_location/name: El Puerto de Santa Maria, Spain
reviews/1/text: A lovely place to spend a sunny day. Good for swimming (if not too windy) or diving. Restaurant/café, changing rooms, toilettes, shower, sunbeds (€2,50). Cabel car down to the beach (€3 return). Not anymore possible to take the car all the way down, the road has unfortunaly been closed for cars half way.
reviews/2/text: What a fabulous find! This is a beautiful, secluded rocky beach that's perfect for snorkelling. Snorkelling/dive equipment can be hired at the Mero Diving Centre at the beach. Go down in the cable car and enjoy the beautiful beach, lovely cafe and fabulous snorkelling! Lots of colourful fish to see.
reviews/3/text: A beach with the most exciting view in the whole island. It is not sheltered so not the safest but definitely a fun!
reviews/3/title: Lot of fun and beautifil view
reviews/4/text: We came here just to see the unusual beach in a lovely secluded setting.  In April the water was surprisingly warm.  However, no matter how much we enjoyed the scenery, it was really difficult to get comfortable on larger than pebble size beach.  Really uncomfortable to walk around and ultimately confined to the concrete area of the restaurant.  If only it had proper sand.
reviews/5/text: This is such a beautiful place. It’s special from start to finish. You get there in a cable car or you can walk the steep path. It’s a rocky beach- bonus- no Sandy bits!! But it’s the water- it’s pristine and teaming with fish. Bring a snorkel and look around- it is amazing.
reviews/6/text:
Beautiful place 

We went here thrice on our 6 Day stay in Madeira.

 it’s a small bay very beautiful with natural outcrop of rocks and a natural underwater reserve. There is the huge statue of Christ like the one in Rio de Janerio on the top . 

The best bits are the cable car, the restaurant at the bottom and the most impressive one is the Dive centre/ school there. The dive school is run by Carlos a very experienced diver where myself and my family went diving along with them. They provide a guided underwater diving which is at a very reasonable price compared to EU states  and saw groupers /  turtles / stingray  as a highlight .I never dived in a underwater area with volcanic rocks before and this is absolutely fascinating.
The quality of gear their had  was very good as well.
Garajau- we will visit again !
We also did a fair bit of snorkelling here. The beaches pebbles and rocks as there is no sound at all however garage now reserve LOL has been a memories of a beautiful place
reviews/7/text: When going around and being impressed by nature then this is a nice location to see nature in layers as the mountain side looks incrediable with all the layers of History.
reviews/8/text: We did the cable car down to the beach which was fun! We did wait quite a while on the cable car to bring us back up. A nice beach - very clean
reviews/9/text: The cable car is excellent so you can walk one way on the windy road if you feel up to it.  The steak and chips is to die for at the cafe there!   There was plenty of seating and comfy sun loungers. We found trying to get across the large stones to dip in The sea a trial. Miss the sand but there are some beaches with imported sand at Calheta and Machita.
reviews/10/text: Very nice place, not noisy at all (the bar music is not loud). Recommend using beach shoes since it is not sand and off course bring your snorkeling equipment.
reviews/11/text:
To go to the beach you should take the cable car. 
You can go there also by car and that is what I did, but the road is very steep and narrow. There is no space for 2 cars (except 2 small cars like fiat 500) and if another car comes from a different direction you could have some issues. 
Thre is also a nice bar and restaurant on the beach.
reviews/12/text:
We visited here as part of a Tuk Tuk tour. (seperate review) Fourth time to Madeira but first ime to here, had alweays wanted to see it up close and use the cable car.
3 euro return trip. Very good value. Beeach is large black pebbles, waters are clear, plenty of space and faciliites at the beach plus a bar.
I feel the best option is to park at the top and cable car down. But there is a twisty road down if required.
reviews/13/text: We got a local tip to go snorkeling in Garajau and were not the least disappointed. The water is beautiful and clear, as all around Madeira. It is very easy to access the water from the pebble beach and around the eastern cliffs we saw plenty of schools of fish: parrot fish, wrasses, and other colourful species. The beach bar also serves great limpets and toasts.
reviews/14/text: Lovely pebble beach with good facilities. It has free communal showers and changing rooms, toilets and a bar, The beach is clean with a beautiful view. There is plenty of room when we went there and flat concrete sun terraces to spread towels out on. The swimming area is well marked out with a lifeguard in attendance. Although there is a road access it is single lane most of the way. Looked better to leave the car at the top and take the cable car down. Gorgeous views from the cable car and friendly staff.
reviews/14/title: Beautiful pebble beach best accessed by cable car
reviews/15/text: We got there by cable car which is really great and uncommon thing. The beach is clean, water crystal clear. It wasn't crowded and we spent really nice time there.
reviews/16/text: Nice to good in a nice walk. The bar down there is simpatico and the sea is really relaxing. Loved it
reviews/17/text:
You can reach this beach by car, on foot or by cable car (expensive but fun).
The beach is fabulous, quiet and clean. It's a pebble beach not sand.
They have toilet facilities, and a nice restaurant.
This place is definitely worth a visit.
reviews/18/text: You can drive down, but we took the cable car and parked the car on the parking lot next to it. The wall is stunning at the beach and we used the stones as hot stone massage items :) We saw 3 types of colourfull fish in the sea and more not so colourfull :). Maybe when you rent a sup board for 10 euro’s you can see more, but we didn’t do that, next time ;). The cable car shuts down at 8 o’clock in the summer and 6 in the winter. Might be important for people like us that arrive at 5 o’clock. It felt very safe and local somehow.
reviews/18/title: Hot stones, bright fish, stunning wall
reviews/19/text:
You can walk or drive most of the way.
Depending on the wind there is a cable car as well.

I would say it’s like most beaches in the area.

There is a cafe and plenty of space to relax, but not sure if the effort needed to get here is worth it
subcategory_ranking: #40 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Avenida Infante, Funchal, Madeira 9000-015 Portugal
name: Parque de Santa Catarina
ranking: #19 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #19 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
We were strolling along the waterfront promenade and just past the marina we came across a gate and some VERY steep steps leading upto a park. We climbed slowly up the steps, hoping for a great view when we got to the top.

The park rises from the city centre with lovely views of the nearby harbour and sea. There are pretty flower displays throughout and at the top end is the picturesque lake with small water feature. There is also a cafe near to the lake with public toilets. 

It was a hot and sunny day when we visited and there were lots of people lieing around on the grass and sunbathing. We also passed a guide leading a tour around the park, so it can be quite busy in some areas. Lots of seating throughout to relax and quieter spots to find to enjoy the tranquillity, we sat on a bench overlooking the lake. Open from 7am to 9pm. Free entry.
reviews/0/title: a pleasant park to wander around and enjoy the sunshine and some pretty flowers
reviews/1/text: We walked through Funchal and found this lovely park, It was a warm Sunday afternoon and there were fine views across the Harbour as well as appreciating the plants and ponds within  the park.
reviews/2/text: I visited Santa Catarina park early morning on a cruise ship stop in Funchal. It's a pretty park located quite close to Funchal centre and offers plenty of peaceful places to relax and some fantastic views over the harbour area and surrounding mountain scenery. Well worth a visit.
reviews/3/text: This park was a wonderful surprise for us as we were just wandering around city centre and let our 7 yo daughter google-map some place to go - she found this beautiful place and we went there and spent some hours, enjoying the spectacular views and the peace. There was also a nice cafe and the highlight of the visit for a family with young children - a cute playground between palm-trees. Great evening!
reviews/4/text: This is a very beautiful park, it is located in a great location between the top of the main road into Funchal and the bottom where the tourist areas are, it's nice to walk through here instead of the main road. We enjoyed walking here and sitting and enjoying the beautiful views and sounds of the fountain. A very warming and comfortable place.
reviews/5/text: Very nice park with a perfect picnic opportunity. Beautiful pound with swans and ducks. Very clean and calm
reviews/6/text: So perfectly presented and so quiet. A beautiful lake for birds and interesting fountains. Superb views over the ocean and marina as well.
reviews/7/text: Wonderful park to walk around with stunning views all around and plenty of seating dotted around plus a fabulous cafe over looking the marina. This was our through walk when going to the Lido, lots of lizards sunbathing on the walls in the mornings.
reviews/8/text: Beautiful park with views over the Marina. Lovely little cafe too. Lots of beautiful plants and other wildlife such as lizards and Monarch butterflies. One of our go to places during our stay
reviews/9/text: Such a beautiful park to wander through - lots of spots to sit and enjoy the views. We loved spotting the many lizards pottering about on the walls!
reviews/10/text: It's cooler in the gardens - lots of places to sit and picnic or have a coffee or an ice cream just enjoy the views.
reviews/11/text:
Good Viewpoint. Lake and waterfall.Childrens play area.Outdoor gym equipment.
Seats to sit and chill out and watch time pass by.
reviews/11/title: Chill out spot to wander through.
reviews/12/text: We visited this park more than once during our vacation on Madeira. It is a beautifull and free to visit park. It also has a kids playground and there is enough grass to play on with a todler.
reviews/12/title: Favorite park in Funchal has a playground
reviews/13/text: Very nice for a stroll. Go to the top of the park for a reasonably priced cafe and some nice views to the hills and outlying parts of Funchal.
reviews/14/text: Very nicely laid out with lots of trees and flowers. Lovely to stroll around or to sit and watch other people stroll. Definitely worth a visit if you're nearby
reviews/15/text: Parquet Sta Catarina is a beautiful well laid out public park. The flower beds are lovely and well looked after. The lake with the fountains is picturesque. There are two cafes in the park where you can sit and watch the cruise boats coming and going. Well worth a stroll through.
reviews/16/text: Fancy park, given that next to it is a home of an important political figure. Well maintained, witj some questionable art pieces, a small gym and a nice lake with swans. We walked here many times, always a pleasure.
reviews/16/title: Great park with a nice view
reviews/17/text:
Lovely little park overlooking the harbour.
Well, kept with lots of exotic flowers and trees.
Expansive lawns.
reviews/18/text: This is a lovely park in Funchal. There was an art exhibition there when we visited that was set up around one area of the park. This is always a nice place to sit and relax in the sun or to go for a quiet walk.
reviews/19/text: Wonderful park which is well-maintained. If you walk up the stairs next to Cafe Gruta there is an extremely friendly cat who is not very pretty (missing ears, speckled eyes, tortoiseshell fur) but very good natured. She was heavily pregnant when I visited and didn’t look very old. If you see her please pat her, give her some food and remind her to keep her legs closed (or tail down or whatever cats are supposed to do not not get Up The Fluff again)
reviews/19/title: Please keep an eye out for this cat! 😺
subcategory_ranking: #19 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rua Saraiva de Carvalho, Sao Vicente, Madeira Portugal
name: Igreja Paroquial de Santa Isabel
photo/caption: Igreja Paroquial de Santa Isabel in São Vicente
ranking: #106 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #106 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Great place to spend an hour or so. Great statue of Christ carry the cross and the cemetery is also nice to visit
reviews/1/text: Nice small church in Sao Vincente village. Really niece, good to see it when you area there. But for me is too commercial.
reviews/2/text: It was good to see my soul, beautiful colors inside and nice music inside. Perfect to take relaxing here!
reviews/3/text:
In the centre of the village, this is a typical small Madeiran church dating from the late C17th with  black and white exterior and square tower. It is is well worth visiting with a charming interior with its blue and white azulejo tiles around the bottom of the walls and in the chancel. The painted ceiling depicts St Vincent blessing the village. The massive gilded baroque high alter fills the east wall and there are smaller altars on either side of the chancel arch. 

Opposite is a small graveyard.
reviews/4/text: Small but beautiful interior presentation. Located on beautiful Madeira Coast. Accessible for people with disabilities.
reviews/5/text: So we just popped in, it's a smallish church but beautifully decorated inside, worthwhile a quick visit!
reviews/6/text:
As we were staying in Sao Vicente we had to see this church before leaving for Funchal. Most of the churches in Madeira look the same from the outside but vary a lot inside, some more ornate than others, this one was beautiful.
Don't forget to put a couple of euro in the collection for taking pictures, the cemetery next door is equally as peaceful.
We loved Sao Vicente, stunning scenery, lovely people and such a stark contrast to the south of the island.
reviews/7/text: We found this lovely church to be a peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of our tour of the west. Beautifully and sensitively decorated inside.
reviews/8/text: The charming parochial church in the main center of Sao Vicente is certainly worth a visit. The church might appear quite ordinary from the outside, but very impressive inside with beautiful ornaments, panels and decorations. An ideal place for a quiet break when visiting Sao Vicente.
reviews/9/text: We visited the beautiful church - Igreja Paroquial de Santa Isabel - when on a tour of the west and northern parts of Madeira island.  On that afternoon several local women were polishing the woodwork and arranging flowers.  Unlike many churches, this one smelt of beeswax and cleanliness which was in keeping with the beauty of the locally inspired panels about fishermen and the serenity of the holy artifacts.  If you are in the small town of São Vicente, a visit to the church is really worthwhile.
reviews/9/title: So beautiful and so well cared for.
reviews/10/text: Het bezoeken waard wanneer je door het (hele kleine) centrum loopt van Sao Vincente . Recht tegenover de ingang een simpel, maar goed barretje met terras.
reviews/11/text: La chiesa di Sao Vicente è imponente e maestosa e in un paesino così piccolo rappresenta una vera e propria sorpresa. Esternamente è bianca con una torre campanaria. Ha un interessante fonte battesimale e un peculiare crocifisso. Ci sono anche azulejos nella parte inferiore dell'interno della chiesa.
reviews/12/text: Usytuowany na centralnym placu i otoczony wokół wysokimi górami wygląda zjawiskowo . Po remoncie z 2008 roku wygląda trochę cukierkowo ale może się podobać ?. Wybudowany w  17 wieku po tym remoncie wygląda jak nowy . Duże wrażenie robi bardzo bogato rzeżbiony ołtarz. Pięknie prezentują się malowidła na ścianach i suficie . Warto również zwrócić uwagę na kamienną chrzcielnicę i manierystyczny portal na fasadzie kościoła . Przy okazji można także zajrzeć na nieduży ale bardzo urokliwy cmentarz obok kościoła .
reviews/13/text: L'Igreja Matriz è l'unica attrazione di questo paesino. Da notare il fonte battesimale, il soffitto colorato e l'altare.
reviews/13/title: Unica cosa da vedere a São Vicente
reviews/14/text: L'ensemble est effectivement très lourd, mais il faut pouvoir séparer chaque élément pour l'apprécier par lui-même. C'est ainsi qu'apparaissent quelques joyaux artistiques et historiques, et qui valent vraiment une visite si vous êtes dans cette petite localité du nord-ouest. Les gens du coin ont une manière un peu rebelle de penser, semble-t-il, et cet état d'esprit se note ici aussi.
reviews/15/text: Igreja Paroquial bem no centro de S. Vicente, estava enfeitada para as festas que acontecem no final de Agosto. Este ano uma festa comedida devido à pandemia. A Igreja é bonita e segue a arquitectura e estilo de outras da região.
reviews/16/text: Vieux village autour de l'église, avec une très belle décoration intérieure. très chargées, des tableaux intéressants et un christ très expressif portant une grosse croix de bois, peu de monde.
reviews/17/text: Kyrkan ligger i Sao Vicente på öns nordkust, lite undangömd i skydd av bergen. Enl vår guide byggdes den i skydd av bergen för att inte synas från havet eftersom det ofta fanns pirate där, på jakt efyer bland annat kyrkornas guld och silverföromål. Kyrkan är byggd på 1600-talet och har helt underbara målningar från den tiden!
reviews/17/title: En pärla bland alla kyrkor på Madeira!
reviews/18/text: Midt i São Vincente, en af Madeiras nordkyst byer, finder du en hvid landsbykirke. Kirken er omkranset af bjergskråninger, og ser derfor lidt Klein ud. Lige efter kirkens gærde, er der i trædestenene markeret en minde”tavle” for 304 mennesker, der døde i 1943. Du kan ikke se hvordan. Men de huskes stadig i byen. Vi kom i januar, og der er byen rimelig mennesketom og “lukket” i sit udtryk, i de hvide gader. De fleste butikker er vinterlukket, skodderne er for vinduerne i mange huse og vi var heldige, at vi kunne få en kop kaffe på cafeen/bodegaen overfor kirken. Selve kirken er indvendig markant nybarok isit udtryk. Masser af guld og religiøse billeder. Ganske flot af en landsbykirke!
reviews/19/text: Schöne kleine Kirche im Zentrum des Örtchens Sao Vicente im Norden von Madeira. Meist besucht wegen der Höhlen - wenn man dort ist lohnt sich der Abstecher zur Kirche um den eindrucksvollen Innenraum mit der Deckenmalerei zu bestaunen (oder wenn man gläubig ist zu beten).
subcategory_ranking: #106 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Caminho Voltas 15, Funchal, Madeira 9060-329 Portugal
name: Botanical Garden Cable Car
ranking: #25 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #25 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Great experience. Visited over Easter bank holiday weekend and was quiet getting a car to ourselves. Great views over the city. Monte church/cathedral at the top with the basket skiing men as well.
reviews/1/text:
We bought tickets at the cable car station in Funchal to include a visit to The Botanical Gardens. We paid €68 for all cable car rides, plus garden entry.

Boarding at Funchal you ride up the mountain to the first station. Here Monte Palace Tropical Garden is immediately to your left as you leave the station, and the walk to the cable car for Botanical Gardens is to the right, both are well sign posted.

Be aware that it is quite a long walk away - and all up a steep hill on the way back! I was heavily pregnant and just took it slowly. The hill is very steep but there are steps too. I think it took us about 15 minutes to walk from one cable car station to the other.

It was worth the walk for us, as the cable car ride to the Botanical Gardens was much more scenic, travelling across lush forests and countryside. It is just a couple of minutes journey on this cable car. 

We enjoyed our visit to the Botanical Gardens, but Monte Palace Tropical Gardens are a whole other level! and we highly recommend a visit.
reviews/1/title: A longer walk to the cable car station then expected, but worth it for the lovely views
reviews/2/text: After taking a cable car from Funchal to Monte Palace we took a second cable car to the Botanical gardens.First and second cable cars are very similar except for the views. The cable car to Monte travelled over Funchal so it was mainly urban views. The second cable car was over a lush valley, not spoilt by mankind and full of trees. Both were a lot of fun.
reviews/3/text: Used the bus and cable car ticket for 20 euros, great value. Well worth seeing, avoid the days when 2 cruise ships are in port as it gets busy.
reviews/4/text:
The botanic Gardens can be reached either by using the 2 cable cars - one to Monte and the second to the gardens or on bus or a combination. It is much cooler than in Funchal so take a jumper!
Avoid days when the cruise ships are in as the queues were horrific!  We left and came back the next day.  
The gardens were lovely even in January.  Excellent cafes on 2 levels.
Lots and lots of steps but there are slopes as well.
Combied with Monte you can make this a full day out.
reviews/5/text: Even though January still had to queue , if you buy ticket from one of the kiosks you can jump some of the queue ,but you pay a few euros more , the actual trip is about 20 minutes but views are worthwhile
reviews/6/text: Short trip that takes you to all the sights. It is great to use it one way and get the bus the other way.
reviews/7/text:
Service can be improved by communicating to  customers that you are closed for maintenance. 

Bought family ticket at cable car station in Funchal to get to Monte and then catch the 2nd cable car to the botanical gardens - arrived at Monte the 2nd cable car was closed for maintenance.  It’s a 58 minute steep walk to the botanical gardens (not possible carrying child).  Staff at cable car station wouldn’t refund and neglected to tell us that the botanical gardens are actually accessible by car/taxi.  Therefore we wasted a full day and 54 euro on a cable car ride to Monte (which we had visited the day before). 

The only communication regarding the closure was a blank piece of paper. 

So be warned … check and triple check before you purchase a ticket and travel on the cable car hoping to catch the second cable car to the botanical gardens.  

We met many more disappointed people couldn’t do the walk and who didn’t make it to the botanical gardens that day. 

No mention of the closure on the website - and no communication. 

Botanical gardens (when we got there via taxi with road access (16 euro) on our last morning) before travelling home in the afternoon were wonderful (but we only saw half).
reviews/7/title: Bought cable car tickets to Monte to catch 2nd cable car to Botanical gardens -  after paying 54 euro found it closed
reviews/8/text: Smashing views and beautiful gardens and plenty of time to look around the botanical of lovely flowers and unusual trees as well as butterflies and lizards on side of low walls fascinate the grandchildren. Overall, a lovely day spent, playing football and boomerang and the weather was just right for walks and activity games in between.
reviews/8/title: Beautiful view of the Botanical garden and magnificent view from the cable car.
reviews/9/text: Excellent attraction, very efficiently run. There were 'hawkers' outside the entrance trying to engage you and give you advice on the cable car. Not sure why or what their game was as the ticket office was most efficient and the price good value
reviews/9/title: Must do attraction and good value
reviews/10/text:
We were in funchal recently and went down one day deciding to go up the cable car again as we did it 10 yrs ago but that day there were 3 liners in and the queue was colossal! So gave
it a miss and went back another day and got straight on with a car to ourselves  so if you want to miss the hour long queue go when there are fewer liners docked
reviews/11/text: Well organised cable car. Worth the time taken to experience the views from the top. Do take a waterproof jacket as the weather can change.
reviews/12/text: Absolutely a must see when you are in Funchal. Credit to the gardeners. Very well maintained and presented.
reviews/12/title: Just Fabulous well worth a trip
reviews/13/text: We discovered this cable car & gardens after having a small walk away from the main cable car. It cost us 18 euro for the cable car & gardens. The cable is very pleasant with 6 people maximum. The journey takes about 10-15mins and covers a large area with great views down the valley and also down the Funchal. Toilets at both stations if needed. Tickets are purchased at a little booth at the top and small walk down to the station
reviews/14/text: Wish we had visited earlier in May, there were still many beautiful displays, lovely trails taking you from one garden to another. There is a cafe there if you wish to stop for refreshments.
reviews/15/text:
Once you have taken the cable car from the seafront in Funchal this second cable car will take you to the botanic gardens. It is a steep walk with 200 steps or you can take the slope. We stopped for refreshments and a lovely cafe on the way.
The cable car journey is not long and takes you directly to the entrance of the garden.
reviews/16/text:
This was good but if you want to reach the top you need to get off half way and walk to the next station t continue upward.
It was so stifling in the car we decided not to continue.
reviews/17/text:
We caught the mountain cable car from the harbour to Monte. There are stunning views of Bay of Funchal, the ride was very smooth and all very modern, would recommend. 

Avoid when the cruise ship had just docked as there will be very lengthy queues.
reviews/18/text: This is a great way to get down from Monte to the botanical gardens. The views through the valley it travels through are incredible and stunning. It is a great journey.
reviews/18/title: Great way to access the Botanic garden
reviews/19/text: This takes you from Monte across the valley and the views are terrific.  The cable cars are as good as the one from Funchal.
subcategory_ranking: #25 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Er 209, Madeira 6160-206 Portugal
animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
description: This type of wild and scenic forest landscape is fast becoming a rare sight along the Mediterranean, and Madeira is one of the few places where they still exist.
name: Laurissilva Forest
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Rabaçal Hiking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Folhadal Hidden Treasures Running Tour (Moderate)
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Buggy Off-Road Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Walk with a local
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Private Tailored tour to the East in a 4WD. No shared groups!
ranking: #41 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #41 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Worth the trip-booked via Viator with Madeira Tours. Small tour on a minibus. Visited the highest peak, the Laurissilva forest and several wonderful viewpoints. Great scenery and affordable lunch stop.
reviews/1/text: We drove by parts of the forest, and it was like something from another planet. Unbelievably beautiful! We didn't do any hiking -- when you're on a whirlwind tour of an island (even if it's small), it doesn't leave one much time to go hiking. There's so much to see in Madeira - we should have planned a week or two instead of a few days!
reviews/2/text:
they say it's best time to visit when it's foggy. we did not have that chance, and seen it with warm sunny weather.
great place to start a hike, something different, nice views!
reviews/2/title: Nice Hiking - on sunny weather day
reviews/3/text: The laurissilva is a beautiful and mystical part of Madeira. From Ribeiro Frio you can do a really easy (flat) and relaxing levada walk to Balcoes (balcony) that will end at a 'balcony' overlooking the surrounding area. I definitely recommend doing that walk when you are in the neighborhood.
reviews/4/text:
I had the luck to see it on a sunny day and on a foggy as well during my one week stay on the island. 

With the gps you can find it as: Posto Florestal Fanal. 

Very atmospheric place, enjoyed it greatly.
reviews/5/text: We stopped in to explore on our way across the spine of the island, and had a picnic within the clouds. The place could very easily lend itself to some form of dramatic movie scene, but has a very old, clean, and safe feeling to it. The silence is enormous here, and the shifting density of the clouds makes you feel the prehistoric nature of this place.
reviews/6/text: What a lovely, peaceful place...just happy wandering around the trees as didn’t have time for a longer walk...perfect!
reviews/7/text:
Old trees all aroud you, forest untouched by human being. (ecept track you are going on). 
Walking beside levadas, you can enjoy quiet and fairy tale-like surrounding. 
Lot of humidity, water dropping from somewhere above your heads on you. If you go afternoon (make sure you will have enough time to come back before sunset!) you will miss most of tourists doing the same track. All the walks in forest were amazing, especially Levada do Caldeirao Verde  (PR9). :-)
reviews/7/title: Amazing experience. Totally surrounded by old giant trees in a deep and relaxing quietness
reviews/8/text: On the slope facing North is the primitive Laurissilva Forest. We stopped by to admire and hug the tree, thanking it for offering shelter, fresh air and greenery to us. It is especially precious as we don’t have this in our tiny small country in Asia. Praise the governor and people of Madeira for protecting them so well.
reviews/9/text: Imposing and lush vegetation, many species of plants. This is a real forest, not just big shrubs like on the Canary Islands.
reviews/10/text: We came across the forest while driving on route E 209 from Ribiera Da Janela, southwards, on a foggy day which added to the atmosphere. The scenes of the forest were unique. Just watchout not to skid ...
reviews/11/text: No idea why so few reviews and I know not many people go there prefering widely advertised levada walks. This is a fantastic place, one feels like in an ancient forest from Talkien books. When we were there, there was a thick fog but it didn't prevent us from enjoying this magical place.
reviews/12/text:
Full day coach tour from Funchal to the North West of the island. one of the highlights was to go through the Laurel Forest on our way to the Northern resort of Porto Moniz.
We were very disappointed when approaching the forest area we were told by the tour guide that the road was closed due to a religious festival in the forest. I know it was Sunday, but I would have thought that the tour operator would have checked for any hold up delays on the island beforehand.  So I would suggest anyone going on these tours on Sundays to check with the operator if the forest is likely to be closed.
reviews/12/title: Laurisilva Road Closed for Religious Festival
reviews/13/text:
This ancient woodland is one of many Unesco World Heritage sites which no visitor to Madeira should leave without seeing. I chose to see it as part of a guided levada walk from Ribeiro Frio to Portella, the last few kms of which are spent traversing this ancient woodland. 

It really is beautiful the way the light filters through the trees, leaving patterns on the snaking waterways that gently guide you further along the path and deeper into its green and majestic depths. Of course I only really scratched the surface of this island and indeed the woodland, which covers many, many miles but I am nevertheless grateful for the time I did get to spend here.
reviews/13/title: A beautiful protected area that everyone should see
reviews/14/text: There are several trails in Laurisilva, we did the Levada do Furado, which is 11 km between Ribeiro Frio to Porto da Cruz. We took bus 56 at 8 in the morning and bus 53 from Porto da Cruz back. It was just us and one person more who started at this point at this time, and once he left us behind, we didn't see a human soul for 1.5 hours. This is in contrast to what others have written, and I suspect that it could be explained by low season, starting early and a bit of luck. The weather was great and we got to see stunning views. It didn't feel like walking in a European forest, as it was so green and humid (similar to Borneo and Rwanda were I've hiked before). No flashlight or walking stick needed on this one, and the trail was in good shape. The last part was muddy (it had probably rained before we arrived), and then it was great with gore-tex shoes. The only thing that didn't meet our expectations was the lack of flowers and birds, and it was probably explained by season.
reviews/15/text:
We picked a short circular walk starting at the forestry building at Fanal from a book. Starting up and across moorland with cows grazing and then dropped down a narrow track with wooden steps. Turned onto PR13 and were soon walking through ancient laurel trees that looked as if they were Tolkien ents - gnarled trunks and branches covered with beards.
When we left Funchal, the weather was foul, here it was warm - you need to chase the sun in Madeira sometimes.
reviews/16/text:
One of the last places on Earth one can find the Laurisilva. As UNESCO put it "an outstanding relict of a previously widespread laurel forest type. It is the largest surviving area of laurel forest and is believed to be 90% primary forest. It contains a unique suite of plants and animals, including many endemic species such as the Madeiran long-toed pigeon".
The wildness and uniqueness made the Laurisilva forest Word Heritage. If you like nature go for it.
reviews/17/text: Lovely area, well worth taking the time to plan a walk here.  Unique habitat, green verdant and totally tranquil when we visited
reviews/17/title: Get off the track here and walk
reviews/18/text:
We choose to do the Leveda Dos Cedros (PR 14) walk. 

Had some difficulty finding Fanal - were expecting a more built up area than just a sign off the road!

Parked up alongside the road and started our decent down hundreds of steps. It was worth it at the bottom as we reached a very peaceful place with a waterfall. Very tranquil and didn't see any others there!
reviews/19/text:
We did this Levada walk after spending the morning visiting Pico de Aireiro and combining the two made it a superb day. The trip to Ribeiro is exciting as the road is well maintained but you are climbing and awful long way just to come back down some. I think it's about 1200-1300 above sea level but the road has many tight bends and switchbacks and it is real fun to drive.
Anyway parking in Ribeiro is quite difficult as cars take one side of the road and force traffic down the other or you can park at the top of the hill and walk in. If you do, you pass a trout farm with free access and an interesting area to spend 15 minutes. A couple of souvenir shops and places to eat and just around the next corner is the Levada walk. Through dappled sunlight the walk is easy and on fairly solid ground. The walk to Balcoes is 1.5km and they suggest 1hr 45 on the board. personally we took it a lot slower than that and spent a long time at the viewpoint wishing the clouds to move away from the mountain peaks to get that dramatic photo. Unfortunately after a hour of waiting it was obvious that the wind was not going to play ball and so we made our way back.
The way is probably good enough for a motorised wheelchair although their are some steps as you make your final approach and there are some sections that go through the middle of sheer rocks and so it would depend on width.
The views from the Balcoes down to the sea are lovely and the mountains all around you do give a feeling of vastness. Also there are a lot of birds that come for food once the place clears of large numbers and we took many pictures.
My advice is to take your time rather than rushing. We spent a wonderful three hours doing this trip and felt refreshed for it.
There is also a cafe half way along selling drinks, snacks and some souvenirs.
reviews/19/title: Ribeiro Frio Levada Walk to Balcoes

name: Santana
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: East Tour of the Island
