ranking: #109 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #109 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
This was a long drive for us today as I wanted to see the thatched houses

Whilst they were interesting they were also sadly underwhelming 

Most had been turned into tourist shops and there was little to explain the history 

The town cashes in on them with overpriced cafes 

The walk down to the park is work it
reviews/1/text: Absolute tourist trap, really not what we were expecting at all. Definitely wouldn’t recommend, way too busy and not worth the trip.
reviews/1/title: Way too busy, not worth it
reviews/2/text:
Cute little traditional houses, some of them had souvenir shops inside, but that’s about it- not much more to see in that village.
About a 15min stop, so if there’s a short stop there in your tour it’s fine!
reviews/3/text: The houses are quaint and that’s about it.   As other reviews say it’s only worth a stop off.   Maximum 1 hour as nothing else to do apart from have coffee.  I’d consider making the trek here as it’s an hour from Funchal
reviews/4/text: Some pretty traditional thatched cottages built as a tourist attraction. There is little else to see here. In total it’s a 20 min stop… and that includes a coffee and a cake. It should not be an extended visit so check your tour details before coming. We had 2 hours here (yawn)
reviews/4/title: Worth a very quick visit … nothing more
reviews/5/text:
Big disappointment.

This small village with rebuilt "traditional" houses was part of our "Madeira East" group tour.

It reminds me of a kind of artificial mini-amusement attraction for children. Not interesting at all for adults, not historic, just "kitsch" to attract tourists. (At least free entry). In the triangular houses plenty of awful and overpriced souvenirs are sold.

Not worth to visit.

And the village of Santana is not nice/interesting at all!! 
Small, dirty .... with some shabby joints, "feeding places" where tourist groups end up with their guide to have a terrible lunch 🤮
reviews/6/text: The main feature of Santana is the colourful stone houses with triangular thatched rooves which offer a variety of souvenir and food products for tourists. There is plenty of parking in the town. It is worth a visit if you are in the area but I wouldn't go there specially to see the houses as they are somewhat of a manufactured attraction for tourists.
reviews/7/text: Depite being winter the weather was good - occasional rain. Lovely views,interesting place to visit. Would recommend the Botanical Garden and a whale watching trip, even in winter. The market in Funchal is a must visit - go on a Saturday. Only caution - some things have shut down because of COVID, for example the village where they used to do the weaving, so check to make sure you are not disappointed.
reviews/8/text: Super nice park to visit with kids (3-12) and learn more about the island. The park is made with love and a lot of attention was paid to tell the visitors about Madeira. History, crafts, plants, tourist attractions - everything is covered in the exposition. Good to visit during rain )) thank you, we really enjoyed 🍀
reviews/8/title: Great place to visit with kids and learn about the island
reviews/9/text: Not what you would expect.Very pretty but has been cleverly photographed.Very touristy.One of the islands treasures.
reviews/10/text: A pretty little town, with historic A Frame houses, each now equipped as tourist shops. Little else to keep you here.
reviews/11/text:
I must admit I looked forward to visit those houses while on Madeira and I was super disappointed as there were just a few and they turned out to be some kind of souvenir shops 😬

So if you’ll be around you can stop by and make an obligatory photo but honestly there is not much else to do.
reviews/12/text: Not much to this. 5 or 6 traditional houses. No information that I could see providing any history. No-one there to talk too. Some of the houses are now shops. So we bought an ice pop and left. Don't travel to see this. If you're in the area, might be worth a 5 min stop off.
reviews/12/title: Only go if you're in the area
reviews/13/text: Stopped for lunch whilst on a fairly soggy east of the island tour. The A Frame houses look nice, and are different to houses found elsewhere. However after two minutes you have seen them. I wouldn't make a special trip to do so. There are about 5 of them together, next to what looks like a town hall.
reviews/14/text: Currently sat on a bench in the town square, we saw the little thatched houses and have another hour before the bus moves on. There’s a pretty white cat walking about which is the main attraction, but it looks quite old so if you’re reading this review after 2024 it’s likely passed on.
reviews/15/text: Absolutely chucked it down whilst it was dry in Funchal. Be aware the weather on the north coast is so different to the south. The houses themselves look great and we drove round the village and found few more examples.  Had a great lunch at Peters on the way
reviews/16/text: From my first visit to Madeira, I always wanted to see these signature houses. And I was glad we finally managed this year, even though the weather was far from clement. Probably it would be not worth for most people to drive specifically to see them, but they are lovely. Of course, do not expect them to be real living houses nowadays, though noticeably, there are similar buildings inside of the local properties, though hardly used for living in.
reviews/17/text: Cute houses that you can wander round and see inside. My only comment would be that it is quite a long drive for not much to see.
reviews/18/text: Traditional houses used by the town folk are on display. A type of thatched cottage. Access can be gained as one is a shop, another used for weaving. It is easy to park nearby. Worth a quick visit.
reviews/19/text: Expected so much more. But hey, we've been there 😂 just 5 small houses. Thought it would have been a whole town or so. But no.
reviews/19/title: Didn't expect it to be so small.
subcategory_ranking: #109 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Caminho do Meio Bom Sucesso, Funchal, Madeira 9064-512 Portugal
description: A visit to the Botanical gardens provides visitors with the names and origins of the splendid variety of exotic flowers, vegetables, herbs and other useful plants found on Madeira.
name: Madeira Botanical Garden
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Monte & Botanical Gardens
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Halfday Madeira Garden Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Botanical Gardens Tuk-Tuk Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Mount And Botanical Garden
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Madeira Grand Experience (price per tukxi - up to 3 people)
ranking: #52 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #52 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
The garden is a unique experience, amazing display of plants and flowers, currently 7E to get in.  The views out over the town are amazing and a sit in the small cafe will allow you to soak it up.
Just be aware the paths are at times rocky and uneven, not wheelchair accessible.
reviews/1/text: Beautiful lovely views and lovely variety of flowers, plants, trees and cacti. Very well maintained lovely pool area too with turtles. Lovely formal garden too.
reviews/2/text:
We visited these gardens on an action packed day; starting with the cable ride up the hill, a wonderful visit to the Monte Palace Tropical Gardens and then the second cable car ride to these Botanical Gardens. Afterwards we enjoyed the fun touristy toboggan ride, before getting the cable car back down to Funchal and having a walk along the promenade by the sea. A very busy and fun day! The highlight was definitely the Monte Palace Tropical Gardens for us, so in comparison these gardens disappointed.

The Botanical Gardens are more open and formal than those at Monte Palace. One of their most famous features is the patterns in their borders made from plants, spelling out their name and the year. We enjoyed walking around in the sunshine, the paths are mostly good but uneven and narrow in some areas. In April there wasn't that many flowers to see. 

These gardens reminded me more of a really nice park from back home in the UK. Spread out across a large area and on a steepish hill, you will need to be relatively fit to get around all of the garden/park, I was heavily pregnant but just took it slowly.

We bought tickets at the cable car station in Funchal to include a visit to The Botanical Gardens. We paid €68 for all cable car rides, plus garden entry. 

Boarding at Funchal you ride up the mountain to the first station. Here Monte Palace Tropical Garden is immediately to your left as you leave the station, and the walk to the cable car for Botanical Gardens is to the right, both are well sign posted.

Be aware that it is quite a long walk away - and all up a steep hill on the way back! I was heavily pregnant and just took it slowly. The hill is very steep but there are steps too. I think it took us about 15 minutes to walk from one cable car station to the other.

It was worth the walk for us, as the cable car ride to the Botanical Gardens was much moew scenic, travelling across lush forests and countryside. It is just a couple of minutes journey on this cable car. 

We enjoyed our visit to the Botanical Gardens, but Monte Palace Tropical Gardens are a whole other level! Whilst the gardens aren't amazing, I would recommend seeing as you are already so close when visiting Monte Palace (a must see!) and it does all combine together to make a wonderful action-packed touristy day.
reviews/2/title: Reminded me more of a really nice park than a garden, but so close to other great activities you may as well visit
reviews/3/text:
Do not bother.
Save your money and your time - visit the fabulous Monte Gardens instead.  

The Botanical Gardens are scruffy, full of weeds, in need of attention throughout, clearly unloved and completely unattended by any staff.

The checkerboard beds - the iconic photo so many of us see - are half dead and festooned with weeds.
The topiary section - also an iconic photo opp - were in need of a really good trim.
The cactus area was awful - lots of brown/dead plants and so much graffiti scratched into the cactus fruits - if staff had been on site, maybe this behavior by visitors could have been averted. 

We should have realised our mistake when we met the only surly person in Funchal 
 - on the botanical Garden ticket booth.
reviews/4/text: This is less well publicised than the Monte Palace Gardens but we much preferred it. Came by bus which is an experience in itself. Lovely open gardens with a wide variety of colours and plants and with extensive views over Funchal. A simple cafe offering coffee to hamburgers and again with views. A very pleasant 2 or 3 hour visit.
reviews/4/title: An attractive alternative to Monte Gardens
reviews/5/text: Not sure if I was going to like this garden as much as the Monte gardens but we really enjoyed it - despite the rain . Took the local bus ,which was easy , and had no trouble navigating the garden as the signage was great . It is smaller than Monte but has more flowers  ( yes ,in February ) and had a nice layout . Not as steep and hilly as Monte which is set inside a canyon ( and you descend into it , and take the golf cart ride back - it is worth the 2 euro cost ! ) whereas these gardens are set on a hillside with a fantastic view over the city. Both are lovely and I would encourage to visit both . They are different in layout and plant life .
reviews/5/title: Lovely  garden and the slight rainfall made the flowers lovely to photograph
reviews/6/text:
The Botanical gardens are on a steep gradient, so you spend most of your time walking the very steep slopes.
We visited in February so maybe all the flowers were not in bloom? The cactus garden was impresive.
The cafe was not surprisingly, very busy as everybody was taking a breather after traversing the slopes.
reviews/7/text: Took the No. 31 bus from the centre. 7.5 euros entry fee per adult. Beautifully maintained gardens rambling down the hillside. There is a cafe. Some of the paths are difficult to negotiate as they are very steep but there are hand rails. There is an exit at the bottom with a bus stop, which saves walking back up the hill!
reviews/8/text:
The Botanical Gardens were a bit disappointing on our visit. 
After our sojourn we spoke with some other visitors who had similar views but put their disappointment down to visiting during a low season and a couple of months too early for some of the botanical collection to be showing its best.
That may be so, but having visited Monte Palace Gardens at the same time last year, their displays provided a much richer and vibrant experience.
The museum near the entrance is tired and uninteresting, and in some ways a bit creepy with its displays of older taxidermy specimens.
Another disappointment during this visit was that the bird collection was off-limits, with no official explanation why.
The only saving grace was that it did not cost a lot to enter, at €7.50 per adult.
reviews/8/title: Not quite showing its best in February...
reviews/9/text:
Not the garden we thought we were visiting and don’t loose your ticket!!

We brought a ticket for the cable car (return) and entry to botanical gardens for 35 euro’s each. We asked if this was the gardens with flamingo and told yes it was……. No it isn’t! That would be the tropical gardens which would cost us another 12 euros each! 

So to try and make the best of the situation we headed down to the next cable car and to the gardens. When we arrived frankly it was nothing interesting. If you like plants and seeing how they have imported various species to the canneries fine. Toilets have not seats and honestly the gate attendant are unhelpful and not friendly at all! 

They removed our tickets which had been stapled together and then Didn’t return them all resulting in us having to pay for yet another ticket to get back to monte. 9 euros. The shops are nothing but tourist tat and if you are not good at hill walking just don’t bother! Steep, poorly layer out and very little to see or peek interest. 

It is having some work to improve the lay out but at this moment I wouldn’t bother. Shame as it could be lovely and interesting but the staff and the lack of customer engagement / service just doesn’t seem worth it.
reviews/9/title: Poor layout, steep paths, unfriendly and unhelpful staff. Don’t bother!
reviews/10/text:
If you were to visit these in isolation, you would probably find them very pleasant, but in all likelihood you are probably tagging them in with a visit to Monte palace and gardens. If so, you may find the botanical gardens a little underwhelming by comparison to Monte. If you only choose one of the gardens to visit, choose Monte. If you do wish to do them both, you can comfortably do them in a single day. 

We took the cable car from Monte down to the botanic gardens and back which was convenient, if a little expensive. Entrance to the gardens is cheap enough, so maybe get the bus rather than the cable car. There may also be a combination ticket available for the cable car from Funchal to Monte then from Monte to the botanic garden (they are two separate cable car routes from different sites) which could reduce costs, but we didn’t explore that option.
reviews/10/title: Visiting the same day as Monte made these feel underwhelming
reviews/11/text: You can take bus 31 from the center to the Botanical Gardens @ 1.95 euro pp. Entrance in the garden is 7.50 euro pp, cash only. There are 2 toilets - one (in the cafe) is "brocken" and we did not find the second one. Staff from the entrance and the cafe are not polite, and the pavement is broken in many places. But the garden is magnificent! You can rarely see such a beautifully arranged garden, where lots of plants, trees and exotic flowers are so well mixed creating a magical atmosphere! Very nice view over Funchal and its port.
reviews/12/text: I climbed up steep hills from Funchal to visit the gardens and was rewarded with brilliant views and stunning gardens. Paid 6 Euro entrance fee which was good value and spent an afternoon there. Could have easily stayed longer and would definitely revisit again. Fantastic collection of exotic plants, indigenous plants and trees (palms and cycads). Nice collections of succulents, paradise plants and orchids. Garden nestled in the hills with some steep walks and climbs in places. Checked out a museum exhibition with a cool rock collection and enjoyed seeing a traditional Maderian dwelling. It’s a little slice of paradise and highly recommend.
reviews/13/text: Thought this would be more interesting based on what was shown in holiday guide but we were disappointed. May have been the time of year or the fact that refurbishment was taking place at various locations.
reviews/14/text: You drive up a VERY steep road to reach the entrance.  The garden is on many levels so you will be ascending and descending quite a bit.  There are some very nice views of Funchal.
reviews/15/text: Great garden, but the cafe /.bar in the garden is very poor. The best thing on offer was a glass of acceptable wine. You have been warned!
reviews/16/text: I was absolutely surprised the size of plants. Very wild and keeping free lifestyles living all plants and trees. Very interesting and very recommended.
reviews/17/text:
Entry was 6Euro per person and it was well worth the cost

There was an amazing collection of trees, shrubs, plants of all shapes and sizes, cacti, succulents etc etc  - I believe over 3000 in all

Even in January the colours were amazing

It is well laid out and as it is based high on the hills there are superb views over the city and along the coastline
reviews/18/text: You don’t have to be particularly interested in flowers or gardening to enjoy it here. We came on a quiet sunny Sunday morning in January. I guess it can get pretty busy as the tourist season gets going though. The gardens are very well set out and we spent a couple of hours just wandering around and enjoying the colours and forms of all the different types of flora. It’s very relaxing and relaxed. There’s a nice little cafe/bar just outside the gardens on the corner by the bus stop which does very nice espresso while you wait for the bus back to Funchal too.
reviews/19/text: A visit to the botanical gardens when you're here in Funchal is a must. The garden provides visitors with a splendid variety of exotic flowers and plants. I found the garden to be quite therapeutic with the variety of plants and flowers, it's a sight to behold honestly, you also see a spectacular view of Funchal. Overall the garden is well maintained and very well presented in the mesmeric Funchal setting. An added bonus was getting to see what I can only assume is the garden's cat. I would fully recommend visiting the botanical gardens you will not be disappointed!
subcategory_ranking: #52 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rampa da Sacristia 1, Funchal, Madeira 9050-208 Portugal
description: This 18th-century church, a pilgrimage site, is located in the picturesque village of Monte.
name: Igreja de Nossa Senhora do Monte

offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Monte & Botanical Gardens
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Monte Tuk-Tuk Tour TOBOGGANS
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Eira do Serrado - Monte
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: TukTuk Private Monte Tour (price per tukxi - up to 3 people)
ranking: #39 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #39 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: The church is reached by a short walk from where you get of the cable car at the very top or up a very steep road from the famous toboggan run. You then have to climb a steep flight of steps. The church is the most important pilgrimage site in Madeira and during the Feast of the Assumption of the Virgin in August, pilgrims climb the steps to the church on their knees to pay homage to the statue of the Virgin. Emperor Charles I of Austria, who died in exile on Madeira, is laid to rest in the church.
reviews/1/text:
Our tour guide, with our cruise ship excursion, took us up a hillside path, with wide stone steps, as an alternative to reaching the church entrance with the 52 stairs at the front of the church. We came to see the coffin of Emperor Karl I who had died in Funchal of Spanish Flu in 1922 after choosing to be exiled in this town after WWI when his Austrian-Hungarian Empire was dissolved in 1918. This year is the 100th anniversary of the king’s death and the church was celebrating it in different ways with events noted on an oversized poster at the church entrance, beside the bronze statue of the Emperor. 

Inside the church, the coffin is on the left hand side of the church and is placed in a side room.  On one wall, the king’s youthful portrait was hung, in the middle was his coffin, and to the right of the coffin were objects to show his once kingly status. The gilt crown on top of his dark coffin, without the jewels, of course, is a copy of the coronation crown called, Crown of St. Wenzelos, as explained by a bronze plaque placed beside the coffin. In front of the coffin there was a special wreath with the number 100 filled out in yellow flowers. At the main altar, 10 large white floral tributes were placed at the church’s main altar and a similar number beside the coffin.  What a wonderful display of flowers! 

The small church itself was unremarkable, but I was, indeed, surprised with the amount of gilt used to frame the paintings and the surrounding architectural features behind the main altar. Above the main altar on the ceiling was an inspirational, cheerful painting done in a style popular in the 19th century, while the rest of the ceiling was wooden.  

This church is close to the toboggan rides and the cable car ride – perhaps one way to reach Monte hill to see these attractions, but effortless with a cruise ship excursion. I was glad we had signed up for this tour rather than doing it OYO.
reviews/1/title: Church is associated with the burial site of Emperor Karl I
reviews/2/text: Just around the corner from the chair lift is this beautiful building. Well worth a visit. Inside it is full of historical painting and history boards.
reviews/3/text: Worth a visit and particularly up the steps to the 1st floor for the history of the Austrian Archduke
reviews/4/text: Picture post card church, small interior with an organ upstairs but very beautiful with amazing views.
reviews/5/text: On our walk about we stopped to light candles here.  Very interesting interior, lots of old wood, and a magnificent organ.
reviews/6/text: After taking the cable car we had a short walk to the church.  There are a lot of steps.  At the top the view is amazing.  The church is very nice inside as well.
reviews/7/text: AN amazing church with irresistable decoration inside. There are many shrines including the last King of Hungary. The site is incredible and well worth a visit if you take the trip up to Monte.
reviews/8/text: Lovely place to visit. Was the day after the bank holiday festival so the church was full of flowers and outside was decorated beautifully too. Views over Funchal and the sea amazing but very steep for climbing if mobility is not so good.
reviews/9/text:
Stunning little church, with beautiful details. You can get there by taxi, public transport (2euros) or cable car (13euros).
You will have beautiful views of Funchal from up there, there is beautiful garden on the right side of the church.
reviews/10/text:
Nice visit when waiting for the toboggan ride, we’ll maintained building in a nice area.
Worth a visit if in the area for an hour or so.
reviews/11/text:
We visited here in February. There are quite a few steps leading up to it, so not suitable for those with mobility issues. 
The Church itself was  quiet when we visited and was quite peaceful. 
We loved the ornate decor and amazing paintings that adorned the place. 
Well worth visiting if you are visiting Monte.
reviews/12/text: We visited this lovely church, it is stunning. You get to it by going up the cable cars which is a nice experience to do i think its about £15.
reviews/13/text: There are 60+ steps but if you are fit it is well worth and there is a really pleasant snack bar close by with good toasted sandwiches and local wine!
reviews/13/title: A wonderful interior in this special church overlooking Funchal.
reviews/14/text:
I am basing my score solely on the setting and views from the top of the steps leading to the church as we did not go inside.
Great views of the city of Funchal and the location is not far from the top cable car station as well as some of the gardens and the start of the toboggan ride.
As we visited in November we managed to avoid the crowds that go during the height of the season and at festival time.
reviews/15/text:
Pretty little church in Monte. Definitely worth a visit for the views outside & the internal decorations of the church - it has some serious chandelier action going on.
You approach the church up quite a few pebbled steps & pathways so maybe difficult for anyone with mobility issues. I have Rheumatoid arthritis so took it slow & used my husband’s hand where needed. It is worth trying as the church is very pretty & it was interesting to find our about the history of Charles 1st the last Austrian emperor who is buried there & who lived in exile in Madeira. Nice little cafe Sweet Monte where you can stop after your visit at the bottom of the church grounds with views over Funchal
reviews/15/title: Serious chandelier action in the church
reviews/16/text:
My wife and myself are currently paying a return visit to Madeira and - unlike last time -  we travelled to and from Monte this morning by cable car.

This proved most enjoyable (Review to follow) - particularly as our outward journey to Monte was around 0930 which not only meant missing the long ticket queues but meant there were relatively people in Monte itself. This was particularly so at the nearby Church of our Lady which - unlike our previous visit in May 2019 when there was a Graduation Ceremony taking place - we almost had to ourselves.

The only disappointment was the Church being closed so we weren’t able to see inside. No matter, we still much enjoyed our visit and would encourage all visitors to Monte to spend at least 15-30 minutes at the Church (including walking up the impressive front steps!).
reviews/16/title: Much Quieter than our last visit!
reviews/17/text: Typical medeirense church with wooden ceiling. The the wooden doors are also a curiosity. From downstairs small orguel or harmonium. When this is first seen for Portuguese Catholic Church this is a nice one.
reviews/18/text: I wouldn't say the church itself is particularly amazing, but if visiting the Monte Palace Gardens do add it in, just to tick the done box!
reviews/18/title: Great Climb, just to say you've Done It!!
reviews/19/text:
Friday 11th June and we visited the Civil Parish of Monte, we took the Teleferico cable car. 

One of the main attractions in Monte is this 18th century Church which was completed in 1748. 

The name of the Church translates as Our Lady of Monte, who is the Patron Saint of Madeira. In 1818 it was inaugurated in her honour. 

The Feast day of Our Lady of Monte is celebrated each year on the 15th August. 

We climbed the 68 steps up to the Church. On a courtyard/landing area, between the 2 flight of steps, stands the Statue of Emperor Charles I of Austria. 

One of the features inside the Church is the coffin of Charles I of Austria in one if the altars along the side walls of the Church 

As we entered the Church we were certainly not expecting what we saw. Normally can always find something to say, in this instance lost for words, it has to be seen to be believed. 

The main altar is ornate, elaborate with its pillars, golden sculpted surround and painted religious images. 

Everything about here is spectacular, took our breath away. 

The walls are adorned with large paintings of religious imagery. 

There are a number of highly ornate altars that line the walls of the Church. 

Even the wooden ceiling with it's paintings is worth a mention.
subcategory_ranking: #39 of 446 things to do in Madeira

offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Cristiano Ronaldo Tour

offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Cristiano Ronaldo Premium Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Funchal Guided Tour with visit to the CR7 Museum
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Mountain Biking Tour - Beginner Easy(deposit only)
ranking: #56 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #56 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Unhelpful and rude staff. Came as a family of four, paid our money to go in. Looked round the room of trophies then up to the shop upstairs. Asked if i could go back down to take the children (age 4 and 6) to the toilet before we left and they refused and said we would have to go find somewhere else. The staff member then moved on to shout rudely at a tourist that was looking a shirt for sale for 180 euros. Don't bother going if you have children, overall an unpleasant experience.
reviews/1/text: Beautifully presented, huge array of trophies and mementos from Ronaldo’s career so far. Audio-visual displays showing many amazing goals. At 5€ a head it was well worth it.
reviews/2/text:
Less of a museum, more of a shrine. Just a big collection of his trophies and medals without any real info or context. And a chocolate statue, of course. Personal highlight was Ronaldo’s Go Karting trophy from a Man Utd preseason tour. Truly his most impressive accolade. 

Note - cash only unless you’re buying 3 tickets or more.
reviews/3/text: Second time to see this incredible selection of Ronaldo’s memorabilia. First time was many years ago, in a different building. The second time in the CR7 Hotel. Both times I got the real experience of one of the greatest football player of all time. 5€  entry/ person, entry fee has not increased since my last visit, many years ago. Outside of football, this man has devoted his life to help Madeira in many ways. Sea front location will help many people to see this new museum in its glory. Visiting  Madeira it’s a must to see , football fan or not.  Don’t miss it.
reviews/4/text:
Great attraction, absolutely loved every minute spent at the museum. The trip was for my son who is a crazy CR 7 fan, entire family had a great time. 

We were totally blown away but the collection of trophies and achievements of Ronaldo. 

A must visit place for any fan of on the greatest footballers ever. 

Cafeteria was also nice, we had some good vegetarian options.
reviews/5/text:
The museum is located on the seafront by the main port and is part of the same building as the CR7 hotel. It looks minute from the outside this is because the museum itself is located underground.
The museum is full of replica silver trophies, football shirts, medals etc. It is not very interactive.
If you are a Christiano Ronaldo fan it is a must see.
reviews/6/text: Nice museum with lots about CR achievements but would be nice to have something about his life in a museum about him! 5 euro entry and free for kids was reasonable value for money.
reviews/6/title: If you love CR you’ll love this museum
reviews/7/text:
Located where cruise ships arrive.

Entry ticket 10 Euro for 2 (cash only?!).

Very boring old style exhibition! You see plenty of trophies.... but no attractive explanations about CR7's life, like family etc

And the only interactive stop is only a cash machine!! You are not allowed to take a picture (only in this place forbidden, elsewhere ok). The "museum" wants to sell you a picture made by them for 5 Euro!

What was really shocking was the awful "souvenir shop" where they sold alcohol!? Madeirawine with CR7 name and publicity! Well well... can't understand this as CR7 is against alcohol ....

In front of the museum entrance you can take a picture for free with CR7 statue (in fact, sadly, it looks more like a King Kong statue 🙈)

Don't recommend this boring tourist stop/trap, time and money lost.
reviews/8/text:
I'd say the CR& museum was worth a visit but would point out its more of a trophy room than an actual museum. CR has won countless trophies and honours and there are dozens and dozens of replica cups

It is well laid out and easy to move around and the cost was 5 Euro

It would have been a lot better if it had told his life story from being born into a far from well off family in Funchal. Coming away I felt I'd learned very little about CR the man

It did seem very popular with visitors
reviews/8/title: Very Good, If You're A Big Football Fan
reviews/9/text: For any football fan out there this is a must visit, especially if you're a Ronaldo fan. The museum contains a lot of memorabilia such as; signed football shirts, golden boots, match balls, club trophies, individual honors & trophies (Ballon d’Or), a nice fan's correspondence section and some statues etc. I think it's worth a visit for €5. While there isn't much bg information on Ronaldo fans should ideally know his history prior to coming here, the teams he's played for, his most important goals he has scored and some of his major honours, he has had a trophy laden career, this museum only represents a visual collection of that. So, enjoy it if you go!
reviews/10/text: My husband and I have visited that museum and we had a great experience there. Nice and cosy place with a lot of stories of Ronaldo's football history since the very beginning
reviews/11/text: Not a CR7 fan at all BUT do respect and admire his achievements. The museum is a bit strong at 5 euro although you can see replica trophies galore and a few signed shirts boots etc. Tacky gift shop selling cr7 sunnies t shirts aftershave etc. Bit of a james bond theme running throughout.
reviews/11/title: Like walking through his trophy cabinet, WOW
reviews/12/text: A must visit for all football fans especially those who follow Ronaldo. Lots of memorabilia and trophies from his career. Worth a visit for €5
reviews/13/text:
My wife and I are Ronaldo fans. If you go to Madeira and you are a football fan, even if you're not a fan of Ronaldo, this museum is still a must see. As the home of Ronaldo this museum takes on a different meaning with all the good things Ronaldo has done for the Portuguese people. All proceeds from the museum go toward charities (except the salaries of the staff and operating costs). The displays are interesting and the championship trophies and awards given to Ronaldo and his teams can only be seen here.

A special feature is an interactive 3D photo device where you can have a very life-like Ronaldo put his arm around you in the picture or dribble a football with you, for a fee, of course. It's worth the admission fee. Very reasonable.
reviews/14/text: A good place to spend a hour looking round the  museum,it doesn't open till 10 am so has to wait outside.It has lots of trophies and pictures  to look at.
reviews/15/text: We stopped in as this was close to our cruise ship.  There are some great photos of him at different stages of his career.  There is a giant statue of him in front of the building.
reviews/16/text: Surprised there are negative reviews here. Yes it's not huge but for €5 and a chance to see loads of football trophies and awards is great value for me
reviews/17/text: It only showed his cups, medals, balls and memorabilia rather than explaining his career at each club and for Portugal. There was only one video screen a couple of more showing his goals for club and country and maybe interviews with him his managers and players would have added a lot more to understanding Ronaldo’s amazing career.
reviews/18/text:
Utilised the free tickets as part of the packaged holiday. As a football fan I found the museum an interesting place. On the day of visit there were mostly young & male visitors.
There are collections of medals and other memorabilia including golden boot and other awards, photographs and correspondence from fans from around the world. It’s very well put together & a great place where all his memorabilia can be safely stored & be shared with the public.
reviews/19/text:
Whilst it helps if you are a football fan and even more a Man U fan this is still worth a visit.
The sheer scale of his awards, trophies etc is amazing.
At 5€ it’s good value and even the merchandise for sale isn’t a rip off.

photo/caption: Santa Maria jeszcze czeka na gości...
ranking: #34 of 446 things to do in Madeira

reviews/0/text: A beautiful little street with loads of restaurants and shops. I'm glad that I saw it on here because I don't think we would have found it just wandering around, as It's over the main road. There is a cute little area at the far end where we ate the following day.
reviews/1/text: A visit to a living art project. Great paintings amongst the narrow cobbled streets of old Funchal nestling between the street restaurants.
reviews/2/text:
The street is full of romance, which gives you the opportunity to think about how people lived here when the island could not be reached by airplanes.
The doors decorated by artists are truly original. Some are very simple, but some are true works of aesthetic art.
There are many good restaurants in the street.
reviews/3/text: Me and the kids love art trails so we all really enjoyed walking along this street and seeing the different painted doors whilst stopping for a gelato on the way. Free activity to do as a family.
reviews/3/title: If you like art trails, walk along this street
reviews/4/text: A great little street to wander around and se the paintings on the doors and the little restaurants without being hassled
reviews/5/text: Easy walk with frescoes along the way. Some are amazing and others are more .. amateur. I generally loved the old streets and doors in this area. Worth a visit and a stroll.
reviews/6/text: We had dinner at Santa Maria restaurant and the waitress were lovely. Nice old street and we foun also a Duck store from here!
reviews/6/title: lovely doors and old town feeling
reviews/7/text: Went here with a walking tour and learnt so much more about the history of the area and the door painting
reviews/7/title: Fun to see all the doors
reviews/8/text: This was amazing, in the true sense of the word! So many doors painted so artfully, with beautiful colors and designs. It's like any high-quality mural you would find in the U.S.., only on doors instead of walls.
reviews/8/title: It's like a public art gallery.
reviews/9/text: Lovely walking around the old town except for every restaurant cafe bar owner begging you to come in. Lovely architecture and all very interesting.
reviews/10/text:
On Santa Maria Street nearly every other door is painted with a different design. They’re all unique and very colourful, I've included photos of a few of my favourites. They are a hundred or more different ones to find, some down side alleys and just off the main street. You can easily explore for half an hour or more, before stopping to enjoy a meal at one of the many restaurants you'll find along the way.

There are many many restaurants here in old town (reviewed separately). We enjoyed all our meals especially at Basmati Indian restaurant. Most of the street is pedestrianised and some restaurants are set up outside right in the middle of the street, so it can get a little crowded in these places where the street becomes much more narrow.

We visited on 2 separate occasions; earlier on the morning is much quieter, before the restaurants open up, but later on there is more atmosphere if it does get a little too crowded.

A short couple of minutes walk from the seafront and the Avenida do Mar. The main bus stops and the cable car terminal is also just a couple of minutes walk away, so a very central location. There are public toilets near to the main bus stops.
reviews/10/title: Walk along Rua Santa María to see the many colourful painted doors
reviews/11/text: Walk along the street in the day time and enjoy the artwork on the doors, at night it becomes alive with outside seating for the numerous restaurant's, it does get very crowded.
reviews/12/text: Loved Funchal...the old streets were very inviting. Full of restaurants...indoor and outdoor. Shops were interesting. People were very friendly.  Would certainly visit again.
reviews/13/text: Quirky and unique sum this up.  We walked randomly and suddenly we were here.  Great street, full of character and energy with a calm and relaxing vibe.  We didn't have enough time to spend here but on our next trip, I'll be here for longer doing what the locals do, sitting,  taking coffee or brandy, taking my time to sample the culinary delights.
reviews/14/text:
Walk in the morning before the restaurants are all open along the street and wander also up the side streets.Origionally the paintings on the doors depicted the craft or employement of the owner,or if only a home,some defining attribute that would identify thta particluar home.
Some buildings are in use,others semi derelict still but return ,in the evening,and see the area buzzing.
Be prepared for small groups of potential diners shoving you out of the way as the passages become slaloms around the street tables.!
Some reasonable restaurants  hiding in plain site if you look carefully.
reviews/14/title: Walk morning for looking at architecture,evening for atmosphere
reviews/15/text: A pedestrianised street with wonderful art on the doorways loads of little restaurants along the street a great way to spend an hour
reviews/16/text:
A brilliant pedestrianised street where all of the doors are covered with the most amazing artwork.
Most of the outlets on the street are restaurants; we ate at several of them during our stay, the quality varying from very good to excellent.
It is always busy and very atmospheric. Love it!
reviews/17/text:
Really like this street. Started at the end with the oxen statue and meandered all the way to the fort.
 
The doorways are very informative, and, some of the paintings are very good, others less so.

Regardless this is a must see must do when in Funchal.

Just be wary of all the restaurants trying to drag innocent passers-by into their establishments, although it is safe before 11.30.
reviews/18/text:
If you come to Funchal, I think this is a must see before you go back home.
Best to come early before the restaurants on this narrow street open up for trade. Maybe 10:00am.  We arrived around 11:15 am and some restaurants/ cafes were opening up so you so it was difficult to see some of the paintings on the doors.
reviews/18/title: Arty street, worth spending some time here.
reviews/19/text:
The street is easy to find - behind the cable car terminal point. A stroll early morning allows you to see the various painted doors - restaurants open later 
Some artistic, some saucy

reviews/0/text: Delightful church especially at Christmas. Interesting history. Superb decorations at Christmas we arrived on the night of the Christmas lighting parade. We also saw a local wedding with so many guests in their finery.
reviews/1/text: Painted ceilings. A spiral staircase to the gallery and a raised platform for the choir? Rather unusual design. Also a stained glass window which reflected pretty colours on the crib. Worth a visit!
reviews/2/text: From the bus and cable car station turn right you can see the church it’s about 15 minutes walk up a hill but it is worth the effort the views are great and it’s nice to see part of th hold town and painted doors
reviews/3/text:
Beautiful church with a beautiful architecture and amazing painted ceiling.
Nice place to visit in Santa Cruz, Madeira.
reviews/4/text: Lovely church but can get busy outside so try and visit early. Link this visit with the short walk to the market to while away a couple of hours.
reviews/5/text: well worth a look; architecture lovely. Situated in peaceful square. Quaint and beautiful place to visit.
reviews/6/text: We visited the local church near the end of our visit to the hotel Vila Gale.  It is absolutely gorgeous with the most amazing painted ceiling.
reviews/7/text: another nice church, santa cruz very quiet which makes a change from funchal, but too quiet, nothing here, a relaxing stroll would not make an effort to come again
reviews/7/title: not much else to see in santa cruz
reviews/8/text: We stopped by the church one afternoon, and it was amazingly busy.  A celebration with live music and dancing was well underway, with a crowd, just in front of the church.  There were folk coming in and out of the church, so we were able to witness the role it has in Santa Cruz.  The structure itself houses ornate items, but nothing outstanding.
reviews/9/text: Despite a warm day the church was cold and musty.  The altars are richly decorated but the whole place felt unwelcoming.
reviews/10/text: Lovely church with some very unusual statues. I liked the group one of Jesus washing the disciples ‘ feet. Quiet, cool and tranquil.
reviews/11/text: This is a lovely church to visit and was filled with flowers on the day we vsiited. It is in a square with cafes and trees.
reviews/12/text: A beautiful  church as are all the churches that we visited in madeira.....so peaceful inside and calming .
reviews/13/text: This is a beautiful, contemplative church that is just perfect for a few minutes' meditation or silence on a busy holiday.
reviews/14/text:
While strolling round santa cruz came across this delightful white church.
Would have loved to attened a service here but couldnt find times for services.
reviews/15/text:
The Gothic Church of Santa Cruz ,Named by some As Sao Salvador is the biggest Church outside of Funchal.
The Building was started in about 1479  and finished in  around 1520 ( not exact figures but near to ).The Church is one of the oldest on the Island of Madeira and has a similar design to the Cathedral of Funchal. It is reputed to have been designed And built Built by Architect Pedro Enes and Master Mason Gil Anes. who Built The Cathedral in Funchal.
Inside the church you will find the Tomb of Micer Joao supported by crouching lions which is next to the Chapel of the Morais family 1522'
The Altar has a a 16th century painting of the life of Christ by Grigoria Lopes.
The Sacristy is entered through a Manueline Portal. You will see a 16th. Century Carved and painted Last Supper Tableau.
This is a beautifully Ornate Church ,very peaceful and well worth a visit.
The people of Madeira are very Religious and when Mass is celebrated the Church is Full, standing room only'
About 4 years ago we attended a service where our Madeiran friends celebrated their Golden Wedding and renewed their vows with their large Family in attendance It was a Moving Ceremony and one we will always remember..
On the 12th to the 15th of January the Festival of Santa Amaro is Celebrated but this is worth a review separately which I will write later.
reviews/16/text: A lovely church at any time of year but to get best suggest visit during the end of Christmas celebrations for Santo Amaro. The efforts made to decorate the church and the adjacent squares are impressive.
reviews/16/title: Visit for Santo Amaro on 13-15th January
reviews/17/text: We visited on 16 January. The huge Nativity model was still in place in the area of the altar and there were many beautiful flower arrangements and decorations everywhere. The side altars are very ornate. It was a lovely peaceful atmosphere.
reviews/18/text: This is a charming old church in the centre of the lovely small town of Santa Cruz. There is a full set of the last supper in a transept.
reviews/19/text: The ceiling is beautiful and altar quite stunning.  It is clear that the church is well cared for by the local community.

address: Estrada Ribeira Garcia Parque Empresarial Camara de Lobos, lote 8, Camara De Lobos, Madeira 9300-324 Portugal
address_obj/street2: Parque Empresarial Camara de Lobos, lote 8
description: Vinhos Barbeito entered the wine business in 1946, during a particularly dark time for Madeira. During World War II, production and sales had ground to a virtual halt. As a result, far more companies were leaving the business than were joining. But Mario Barbeito had faith in the future. He also believed that the value of great Madeira could only go up as it became older and production of young vintages declined. But while Barbeito saw those vintage wines as a nest egg for the future, he was content to let the wines age. He wisely built the business in the early years around more modest Madeiras. It was left to his daughter Manuela - when she gradually took over the business from him in the 1970s to continue his work. In the mid 1990s, Manuela Barbeito began to turn over the reins of the company to her son Ricardo Freitas. He not only brought a deep respect for Madeira's classical roots, but also brought new energy and new ideas to the company. One of these ideas was to restore the role that Madeira once had as a companion of food. Ricardo is continuing his grandfather's and mother's legacy of making wines and preserving them for future generations. But he is also creating his own legacy: a series of Madeiras he calls his "Signature" wines. These handcrafted wines combine the best elements of Madeira's classical tradition with Ricardo's own quest for purity and vineyard and varietal expression. Made in tiny lots, their astonishingly graceful style has prompted British wine critic Jancis Robinson to call Barbeito the "Lafite of Madeira".
location_string: Camara De Lobos, Madeira, Madeira Islands
name: Barbeito Madeira
photo/caption: We are waiting for you, in our winery, for a tour and wine tasting.
ranking: #4 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #4 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: We were given a wonderful "Platinum" tasting by Leandro - it was just my husband, myself and a couple from Vienna .... We tasted 8 Madeiras and Leandro kindly threw in a 9th - a very special Madeira indeed, and we felt very honoured!   Before the tasting, we were given a tour of the winery, which was fascinating!  Thanks to Leandro for a wonderful afternoon up in the hills.  It's not quite in Camara de Lobos, we ended up getting a taxi up there from our hotel, and paid the driver a little bit more to wait for us.  my husband purchased a couple of their wines to take back home with us  The process of making Madeira is very special - and the wines we were given to taste were all wonderful - from very dry to quite sweet ....
reviews/1/text: Very nice opportunity to get to know the typical “Madeira Wine”! The winery has a wide and unique history and our guide was just perfect: he had a lot of expertise, flexibility and entertainment 👌🏼
reviews/2/text: amazing tastings of their growths from this year and each stage up to their very own 50-year-old bottling, amazing experience and can see how the methods and ageing process really changes the taste, colour and aromas of the wine would highly recommend and definitely should buy some there, as it is much cheaper than online and quite hard to get back in the UK.
reviews/2/title: A walk through the ages! (of Madeira wine)
reviews/3/text: Great tasting (platinum), the wines where amazing, very uncommon to have so many good/expensive wines provided in a winery tasting. friendly staff.
reviews/4/text:
Legendary tour guide. He’s very friendly, well informed and funny. 
The tasting was great, he presented us a fine selection of different wines and provided us with the necessary info. There is no purchase obligation, but after the tasting you just want to take home some of the wines you tried. Totally worth a visit!
reviews/4/title: Best wine selection and tasting, totally worth a visit!
reviews/5/text: Leandro gave us a wonderful tour and tasting - very highly recommended. Wines tasted from 15 to 350 euros a bottle, all included in the very reasonable 20 euro price. Well worth the trip out from Funchal.
reviews/6/text:
Visited as part of a Jet2 excursion. I’ve visited a number of Madeira producers before in Madeira such as Blandy’s but never Barbeito.
Really interesting tour - you see the factory elements which you don’t often get on other tours. The highlight is the tasting as the 5 yr old medium dry Barbeito rainwater is something else. Totally unlike other Madeira’s I’ve tried from Blandy’s & D’OLIVEIRAS thanks to their unique production methods. It’s a taste sensation & we snapped up a couple of bottles at the airport. Leandro wasn’t available when we visited so thank you to the young woman who stepped in it was really interesting.
reviews/6/title: A different take on Madeira wine
reviews/7/text: Huge highlight of our trip to Madeira. The wine production site is nestled atop a hill, up above Funchal, not far from the Santo Antonio restaurant (where you can go to for lunch before visiting here). This is a producer that doesn't sell many bottles in Europe and is mostly known within Madeira and Japan. The quality is incredible, the prices are fantastic and it is the most intimate tour you can get at any wine producer in Madeira. Highly recommend (and bring some bottles home with you!)
reviews/8/text: We have been welcomed by Leandro who provided us a wonderful tour of the Barbeito production. A fantastic journey to discover Madeira whine, history and techniques. The awesome tour ended with a very nice wine tasting with a well detailed explanation of the different wines. I really recommend the tour for anyone who wants to discover more about Madeira culture and history.
reviews/9/text: Very interesting tour and amazing wines. Nothing too much trouble for the guide. I would highly recommend this experience
reviews/9/title: Amazing wines in a relaxed atmosphere
reviews/10/text: Barbeito Madeira offer a very welcoming and informative tour of their modern wine making facility with the history beautifully preserved. If you are looking for something more unusual than the big commercial providers this establishment is definitely worth visiting. We climbed the hill on a hot afternoon to be greeted kindly by our considerate and very knowledgeable host Leander. Even though there was just the two of us Leander showed us all the areas of the process of making Madeira wine with the history and technicalities of the grapes and the complicated ageing process. At the end of the tour we were offered a choice of a free tasting of two wines, 5 wines including a 50 year old for 10 euros or 8 wines for 20 euros. Leandro took us through 5 very different wines with full explanations. Then we were left to make our choice of purchase from a very reasonable range of prices. It was very good of him to put the same energy in to a tour for just us as a big group. Many thanks for a memorable afternoon.
reviews/11/text: We absolutely loved our tour at Barbeito! Leandro led a very funny, knowledgeable tour and let us try about 7 or 8 different madeiras. It was a lot of fun!
reviews/12/text: Having researched the other wineries to visit we decided to walk to the one closet to us using one of the Levada walks. We were not disappointed. Leandro provided us with a very informative tour around the premises and educated our palates with a good range of sweetnesses and ages of Madeira. We can certainly recommend a visit to Barbeito.
reviews/12/title: Madeira Wine at its very best.
reviews/13/text:
Highly recommend a trip up the hill from Cabo Girao to this excellent artisan wine making plant.
We arrived a little early for a tour of the winery (which comprised of only four of us) and were made to feel so welcome during our wait for the other couple to arrive.
The tour was really informative and personal as was the tasting during which we were treated to an amazing array of superb wines.
It all felt very personal and not at all like just another tourist trip.
Highly recommended.
reviews/14/text: Amazing tour. Our guide was awesome. Very knowledgeable and friendly. The tour was free which was incredible considering how much wine we got to taste. They were far more generous than the blondies tour which was about 6e each. The bottles were also priced way more faire than the blondies as well. Definitely recommend and will be coming back.
reviews/15/text:
This place is fantastic. The tour was intimate and informative. The views are stunning. You will truly learn all about Madeira wine. I can still smell the lovely scent of the room storing all the barrels of Madeira. The gentleman who took us around and did the tasting with us was an excellent host. Very friendly and knowledgeable. And of course, the wines are SUBLIME! 

A must do trip if you are a wine lover. Far superior to the bland Blandy’s tour in town. This is a real experience.
reviews/16/text:
We enjoy visiting vineyards and doing wine tasting when on holiday so when we came to Madeira it was only natural to pick one or two too. We went by location and tripadvisor rating and therefore Barbeito was a no brainer. We booked a tour via email and with a little trouble found the place the next day. Weather was beautiful and the location is fantastic with great views over the fishing village of Camare de Lobos. The host was great, knowledgeable, spoke great English and had the perfect attitude wanting us to get to now all different types of Madeira wine. The place itself is very modern. Even though they have some old barrels, you won't see any old timber roofed buildings here. The great smell is there though ;) 
After the tour you get to the tasting part. You get to try 10 madeira wines, young ones and older ones so it gives you a good cross section, along with a good desctiption and some history.
As an added thing if you buy madeira wine for more than 25€ you do not have to pay for the tour, which we did and took a nice bottle back home for Christmas.
We can only recommend it. You need a car to get there though.
reviews/17/text:
A brilliant tour and wine tasting. The host spoke very good English and made you feel welcome! 
The tasting was generous and the madeirawines were delicious! 
Beautiful views! 
We highly recommend a visit!
reviews/18/text: Loved the tour that took us through the entire wine making process.  Our host was so knowledgeable and friendly.  I loved learning about the older, reserve wines they have and the tasting was presented in the most excellent way and tailored to each of our tastes.  I can't wait to go back!
reviews/19/text: Most amazing experience! Don’t usually drink wine but the wine they produce there is really nice. We started off looking at the machinery they use to make the wine there. Lovely people who run it!
subcategory_ranking: #4 of 446 things to do in Madeira

name: Sao Vicente Caves

offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Cabo Girão Skywalk+Vineyards+Wine Tasting in 4x4 Tour + Dolphin Watching
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: West Full Day: Skywalk, Porto Moniz Lava Pools, Fanal, Paul da Serra & more....
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Northwest + Southwest & Caves
ranking: #75 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #75 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Beautiful garden around the Grotas. Unfortunately the caves are closed till the end of the year because of maintance. You can see the 3D movie and a little video about the Island, but we chose not to. If you are close by it is worth it to take a little walk around the garden
reviews/1/text:
First of all: the caves are currently closed "for maintenance". This review is for the Center of Volcanism only.
Second: this is my impression from a visit with my wife and no kids. If you're planning a family visit, the experience might be different.
We visited the Center on a Friday. One of its staff ladies informed us that the caves were closed (which we already knew) and suggested that we can visit only the Center itself if we want for 5€ per person. IncIdentally, there was a guided tour coming up, so we quickly bought the tickets and went down the path to the center.
Let me tell you this: the "guided tour" was a letdown. All the guide did was press some buttons for some "effects" (such as an eruption demo, or a movie) to start and showed us the way from one attraction to the other. To us, a tour like that just seemed awkward. And the attractions like designed and made in the nineties.
1. The volcano eruption demo: ok, but no explanation of what is happening followed. There are informational posters on the first room, which probably explain all that, but I didn't have enough time to read them all, and my wife was unwilling to come back after the tour so I could finish reading them.
2. About Madeira movie: okay, but it felt pretty much like a VHS being played on an old TV. Also, reading the English subtitles and watching the film felt rather difficult sometimes.
3. The "earth core" room was okay, but again, not much explanation of why we're supposed to stare at it for a few minutes. Well, at least the mirrored mirrors was somewhat fun.
4. The 3D movie was... I don't know... Crap? One of the reasons: my glasses were apparently working the wrong way and I had to put them upside down for the 3D view to normalize. The film itself looked like an intermission in a nineties TV show for kids. It was supposed to explain earth's layers, but with the glasses working bad, and the film itself being so badly rendered, that purpose was lost, at least to me.

I don't mind having donated my 10€ to the Center, but that's all I consider my payment for the tour being: a donation.
reviews/1/title: Not worth it while the caves at closed
reviews/2/text:
Wanted to go and have a look, specially looking forward to cooler caves on a warm day, but found this place was closed due to Covid-19. 
The small park around is nice and took a walk through there on the way back to the car.
reviews/3/text:
Thé caves are closed, so don't go there. It's a nice village.
On thé website it is not mentioned. It van je Nice In think. Thé lady at thé restaurant thought they would open in 2022
reviews/4/text:
Wednesday 23rd June we were heading towards Sao Vicente on the north west coast of the Island. Along the way we saw a sign for the caves "Grutas" and we thought let's give it a go. 

We followed the signs to the Grutas and parked up in the car park and walked towards the caves. We took the pathway under the road which led us to the entrance gate to the gardens where the caves are located. 

We followed the signs for the ticket office and climbed up the numerous steps only to find at the top that it was all cordoned off and ticket office closed due to COVID. There were no signs at the bottom to say the caves were closed. 

We should have realised that something was a foot as all the small souvenir and photo kiosks, in the gardens were shut. Having said that there were gardeners tending to the gardens. 

It was possible to walk around the well maintained gardens.
reviews/5/text: Was there in August 2019. Although well advertised, to me they were a disappointment. Volcanic air vents. Cement floor and they go in to the mountain a fair bit. Bit of a damp squid. Staff gave the appearance of bored students. Outside surroundings were picturesque. The restaurant was closed for staff lunch, at lunch-time. Sums it up really. If the whole tour was free I would not complain but at rip-off prices at about 18 Euros (if I remember correctly).
reviews/6/text: One of the most beautiful places I had ever been to. You will fall in love with the volcanic caves. Take a coin to throw in the tiny lake for a wish!!
reviews/7/text: It's like I'm in a dream because it's so beautiful and I like caves but this one is one of the best with a little lake inside, Tom.
reviews/8/text:
Currently the caves are closed however this company believes that rushing through a laughable journey to the centre the world tourist experience, with a guide that really couldn't care less,  is enough to justify being considered open. This means if you are booked on a tour you have no option but to go along because technically the centre is open.
OK I except Funchal did suffer a 5.1 earthquake on Saturday. Minimal damage to was seen in the form of rock slides on a few high roads on the south side of the island on Sunday, but safety is important. However please warn people especially tour operators that you are closed.

So as you guess this is about the 3D movie and journey to the centre of the world experience rather than the caves. So for you get the idea think of a B rate 1970s SciFi production and you may be close (except here you can see the mirrors). Add several groups being herded into several small spaces, starting the show before all the guests are inplace, no time given to read the information and the worse 3D production I have ever seen and you will be closer.

Thanks for the enjoyable visit.
reviews/8/title: Caves are closed, its the centre only for at least a week dispite what the website says.
reviews/9/text:
Trip is divided into two parts.
In 1st part you will see the actual caves how lava has made them. This is about 30min.
At 2nd there is theory part which show you how Madeira has created and how volcanic things work.
Caves was pretty nice, even some of them was under maintenance and not for public.
2nd part otherwise was awful. Videos from 80's with VHS quality.
8e for about an hour is not much so recommend, but still, stuff should provide better equipment for there.
reviews/10/text: It is nice to see how the island of madeira is made. i think it will be special interesting for kids
reviews/11/text:
I can not believe this many people found this interesting.  This was just awful ! We wasted 1:30mins here ... and paid for it.  You walk though a cave , as a group. Then exit and head into the worst interpretation/ exhibition centre , as a group - no time to read through because the rest of the group wants you to keep moving.  The guide then starts the hokey volcano - just weird. Then she guides you to this glowing ball - to a fake (so bad) elevator.  Then there’s the really really really bad 3D movie.  
This was built 20 years ago.  The exhibit / movie has to be updated
The whole structure, gardens, buildings ... are so well done.  But a total fail on delivering one of the greatest stories this island has to tell
reviews/12/text:
We visited the Sao Vicente caves in February after finding out about them on our last visit to Madeira. We had also seen an interesting film about the caves before we left for our trip. They are situated at the bottom of Sao Vicente town and there is a specified parking area which can be tricky to get a space in. The entrance cost is £8 euros each. Unfortunately the cave tour was underwhelming and probably lasts only around 30 minutes and then you are taken into a theatre type room to ‘experience’ what it would have been like in a volcanic eruption. A lot of the time we were waiting for our guide to explain in other languages, which in itself is ok, but this waiting around just added to the tediousness of the experience. On our visit part of the cave was also closed off for repairs meaning we had to return to the entrance we started at rather than going through the entire cave. They didn’t tell us that bit until we were half way through the cave! 
One really concerning thing was that they did not pre warn at the start that there would be intense flashing lights in the theatre feature. For those suffering from epilepsy, this is definitely a real problem!
We were also herded into a makeshift lift (about 30 of us) in which the whole thing started to shake for about 60 seconds. Any one with clostraphobic tendencies could easily panic at this point! 
Overall the experience was not fantastic and we were quite disappointed after having looked forward to our visit. We certainly wouldn’t go back again and wouldn’t recommend anyone to make a special trip there unless you just happen to be in Sao Vicente already. Not really value for money.
reviews/13/text: This tour has two parts, the trip into the lava tubes (caves), and the information/3D experience afterwards. The trip into the caves is interesting, and not your normal caves due to them being a series of long lava tubes in a volcanic mountain, so worth the visit for something different. The exhibition afterwards is good with plentiful information, but there was not enough time to read much of it before being moved on to the 3D movies, which could do with being updated. They didn't take away from the fact that the caves are worth a visit in themselves though.
reviews/14/text: These caves are different from any in United Kingdom as they are lava caves. Interesting as to how they were formed for comparison but certainly not as “pretty” as caves in Somerset. England.
reviews/15/text: The lava tubes were really great and I enjoyed that part of the visit. I’d skip the volcanic center/museum. The 3D video was hard to watch and quite dated.
reviews/15/title: Interesting lava tubes, skip the 3D movie
reviews/16/text: Great place to understand how Madeira was created. Lots of informative displays and a kilometre of lava tube to walk through.
reviews/17/text: as caves were carved out from lava. More like tunnels with signs of lava movement on the ground. Also lovely spring which was most atmospheric. Then a 3D show, also a simulation of being in the centre of the earth plus the origins of how Madeira came to be. Great introduction to volcanoes.
reviews/18/text: It was a very interesting journey through the history of the Madeira Island. The guide spoke very good english and was really friendly. This Journey is good idea for people in all age.
reviews/19/text: We enjoyed this trip, they run tours every half hour and they are worth the 8 euro.  The first part is going in the lava cave and then they take you to the exhibition on volcanoes which is interesting.  There is free parking and a reasonably priced gift shop.

name: Capelinha N. S. Fatima
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Great Tour of the Sanctuary of Fatima and Óbidos medieval castle
ranking: #142 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #142 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: We have climbed up to the chapel before but decided to go again as it’s such great views. A gorgeous little chapel, absolutely amazing views, w fair few steps but you can go at your own pace and they are safe steps and not uneven.
reviews/0/title: Fantastic views from this pretty little chapel
reviews/1/text:
You need to climb about 200 stairs to the top but once there, the views are amazing. The valley and the towering mountains and cliffs around are breathtaking.
The church is in the tower, it is locked, but one can view the inside, not something special
reviews/2/text: We set off from our hotel in Sao Vicente, it iwas 4,3km of uphill road including 186 steps to get there. Nice stroll, magnificent view from the top, and hidden path back (at the side of the entrance to the chapel). You walk down and you're dangerously close to Sao Vicente Poncha which I'm going to describe in the separate post. Generally, recommend.
reviews/3/text: For years we have driven along the road in Sao Vicente and wondered how to get to the little church as it’s high on the hill. With a little help from Google maps we drove up, parked and climbed the steps to the top. The church is closed but even so it’s so worth it for the views and you can see through the glass doors to inside the church. The path around the church is being re-laid so just walk carefully but definitely not unsafe. It’s a few steps up but take your time, it’s not hundreds and it’s most definitely worth it.
reviews/3/title: So glad we finally got to it
reviews/4/text: Quite a climb to this small chapel but the views are spectacular. Looked lovely inside through the glass doors. The paving around the chapel is still being laid so it is important to be careful where you put your feet.
reviews/5/text: The chapel is at at the top of a hill that one has to walk up to. It is a fair walk up. Once at the top the views of the valley below are wonderful - the chapel is not open and the area around it was in the middle of some major repair.
reviews/6/text: The place is awesome and amazing. When standing there feel great and blessed with all the mostly beautiful views
reviews/7/text:
Tijdens onze 4 dagen in Sao Vincente deze kerktoren/prachtige uitzichtpunt bezocht. Wij hadden de auto geparkeerd  casa da pidade en vanuit daar het "pelgrimspad " naar boven gewandeld. Goed pad om te bewandelen en redelijk pittige klim. Zeker met een 2 jarig zoontje die getild wilde worden...  met een wandelwagen is dit niet te doen. De route met fantastische uitzichten maken de klim naar boven zeer zeker de moeite waard. (Zo'n 40 minuutjes wandelen en klimmen. Met een kleine man) 

De mogelijkheid om je auto dichterbij te parkeren is er overigens ook. Dan ben je met een paar traptreden op de top bij de toren.
reviews/7/title: Neem de moeite om het Pelgrimspad te lopen
reviews/8/text: Boa vista para todo o vale de São Vicente e até para o mar, temo que dentro de uns anos irá encher de turistas
reviews/9/text: Kiedy w punkcie informacji turystycznej dowiedziałem się ,że tutejsze jaskinie są zamknięte postanowiłem zrobić wycieczkę do kaplicy Św. Fatimy na Pico da Cova. Po drodze zajrzałem do zamkniętych jaskiń a póżniej stopniowo wspinałem się na wzgórze z kaplicą . Z dołu wydawała się bardzo odległa i położona bardzo wysoko. W rzeczywistości idąc krętymi ścieżkami na wzgórze nie czułem ,że idę jakoś bardzo wysoko . Po wejściu na wzgórze widać ,że góruje ono nad całą okolicą .Stojąc pod kaplicą mamy piękny widok na całą dolinę i Sao Vicente aż po Atlantyk . Nawet tylko dla tych widoków warto się wspinać pod samą kaplicę . Kaplica jest trochę zaniedbana a przez oszklone ale zamknięte drzwi widać wnętrze kaplicy z niedużym ołtarzem . Można schodzić tą samą trasą . Ja wracałem bardziej urozmaiconą i trochę dziką  Levadą  dos Cardais . Po drodze był punkt widokowy Miraduro dos Cardais z pięknym widokiem na Atlantyk i zabudowania Sao Vicente. Po drodze miałem jeszcze kolejny punkt widokowy przy Praceta dos Cardais z widokiem na Atlantyk na wyciągnięcie ręki . Wszędzie dookoła było dużo bujnej zieleni ale także bardzo dużo winnic . Urokliwe i spokojne miejsca a po drodze nie spotkałem ani jednej osoby . Tylko kontakt z przyrodą w towarzystwie śpiewających ptaków i czasem szumu wody w lawadzie . Po niecałych 3 godzinach łażenia zdążyłem umknąć przed ulewą [ choć trochę zmokłem ] i wylądowałem w pubie O 'Corvo .
reviews/10/text: A capelinha tem uma forma característica e devido à local onde se encontra pode ser vista ao longe. Essa mesma localização preveligiada permite também quando estamos junto da capelinha ter uma visão da bela paisagem em redor. Habitualmente a capela está fechada, mas é possivel ver o interior através do vidro da porta. Vale a pena visitar.
reviews/11/text: Kell egy keveset gyalogolni a templomhoz, de megéri a kilátás miatt.A környező hegyek felhőkben vannak, szépen lehet látni a szőlőültetvényeket.
reviews/12/text:
Hoffentlich gut zu Fuß und mit Kondition, sonst ist der Aufstieg mühsam.
Der Blick ist es wert, bei uns war es leider sehr diesig.
reviews/13/text:
Questa piccola chiesetta ruba l'occhio già quando si percorre la strada verso Porto Moniz; la strada corre subito sotto al colle su cui si staglia la chiesa e percorre la vallata che si trova chiusa fra strette montagne dove c'è appena lo spazio per lo scorrimento di un fiume e della strada oltre a ritagliare un piccolo spazio in cui è ospitato il colle su cui sorge questo gioiellino.
La salita è molto ripida e può essere percorsa sia in auto che a piedi; il luogo è infatti considerato di culto e numerosi pellegrini si avviano a piedi verso questa meta.
Il panorama dall'alto del colle su cui sorge la chiesa è uno spettacolo puro di 360 gradi.
reviews/14/text: Trafiliśmy tam całkiem przypadkiem, widząc z miasteczka São Vicentę wieżę tej kapliczki. W ramach zabicia nudy postanowiliśmy sobie zrobić spacer. Na miejsce można również podjechać samochodem, prawie pod samą kapliczkę, pozostanie do pokonania tylko kilkadziesiąt schodków, wzdłuż których znajdują się stacje drugi krzyżowej. Po wejściu na górę roztacza się panorama m.in. São Vicente. Rewelacyjny widok.
subcategory_ranking: #142 of 446 things to do in Madeira
