reviews/0/text:
Lovely mini-moon to Calheta beach, great hotel with amazing food and facilities.

The spa was brilliant with the relaxation rooms. The cocktails used proper spirits which is a bonus on all inclusive. 

The right size of place, not too busy and good entertainment. We did the Funchal and Calheta trips which were good fun.
reviews/1/text:
We stayed here for a week end Feb/early March.
Delighted with our stay. Very friendly and helpful staff.
Buffet-style high-quality food with an immense choice.
Our room was well equipped and spacious with a terrace and sea view. (Well worth paying a little extra for)
Thank you to the Director and all the staff. 
A bientot!
reviews/2/text: Beautiful views, people, accommodation, weather and fun holiday for the first week in February 2023.. weather was between 20-23 c all week excluding last day rain… already rebooked for next year…thank you to all the staff at Savoy Calheta Beach Hotel 4star.
reviews/2/title: Stunning breath taking and just right x
reviews/3/text:
Another excellent holiday at Calheta beach. All staff were welcoming and friendly, hard to say who was the best. Good food and drinks (except the brandy), some were branded. Comfortable room, everywhere very clean. Animation team were very sociable. Gym and spar with indoor pool, table tennis, darts and pool table. Supermarket nearby but no big shops. Several restaurants on the harbour. Can be too quiet for some people but suite us perfectly

We will be back!
reviews/4/text:
Calheta is the warmest place in Madeira.
Even in January it was really warm.🏖

The beach was artificially made (importing sand from Morocco).

Nice beachwalk with clean beach cafés/restaurants.

Also a marina with some nice boats to have a look at ⛵🛥
reviews/5/text: Had a  great holiday. Very relaxing. The hotel is very clean, rooms are good size. Food was superb. I am a vegetarian nd the head chef cooked some deliciosu meals for me. The desserts are mouth watering. Would defintely visit again. Thank to the entuier team for mamign our holiady memorable.
reviews/5/title: Relaxing holiday in beautlful environment. Madeira is a very beautiful island with so much to see.
reviews/6/text: Clean, and decent showers and toilets close by. A few good and inexpensive restaurants close by, a pleasant way to spend an afternoon
reviews/6/title: Nice place to spend an afternoon
reviews/7/text:
Very good if you want the all-inclusive experience and don't plan to leave the hotel as there isn't much else there!
It will develop in time but there are only 2 hotels and 4/5 marina restaurants. Car hire is a must if you want to get about.
reviews/7/title: Great for all inclusive fans with small çhildren.
reviews/8/text: By now we were seeing one beach or one mirodouro after another.  This one had a decent commercial area next to the beach.  I left the beach area and found a busy Pingo Doce supermarket.  I bought tins of sardines, tuna, and octopus at fair prices.  Pingo's own brand of tins were really a great buy.  I also bought piri piri, poncha drink, and Madeira wine.
reviews/8/title: Pingo Doce for last minute shopping
reviews/9/text: A sheltered, sandy and save beach. The Machico beach is cleaner and have free parking spots but this one is bigger and has a beautiful views.
reviews/9/title: Beautiful views and a yellow sand
reviews/10/text: Small but cozy!  Great place to rewind and if you feel like having a bit to eat then fear not there is a bar  waiting for your order.
reviews/11/text:
Calheta Beach is a good opportunity to get at dip in the sea around Madeira. Most of the beaches on the island are rocky or with pebble stones - and the ocean is wild and often somewhat dangerous … but Calheta Beach is sandy and protected from the waves.

The beach is not the prettiest place on Earth, but who cares as long as the purpose is to get a dip and maybe an icecream or a snack at the nearby restaurant…?

There are (paid) parking spaces on the road above the beach - and (free) toilets beside the beach.
reviews/11/title: One of the few sandy beaches on Madeira
reviews/12/text:
Lovely beach! We stayed in Calheta and spent a few hours here soaking in the warm weather. 

Sun loungers are 3.50 euro for one and 5.50 euro for 2 and an umbrella and well worth the money although you can just plonk a towel down if you like. 

There are two sides to the beach and the sea area is protected with a wall so its very calm if you want a swim. 

There's also a little restaurant very close and toilets so you have everything you need for the day! 

Lots of parking along the roadside also for a few euros.
reviews/13/text:
Not really an authentic island experience due to the imported sand, but we spent a nice couple of hours relaxing here on very reasonably priced sun loungers (€5.50 for two, with parasol, unlimited time).

Street parking was reasonably priced and there’s a good Pingo Doce supermarket (and multi-story car park) just down the road for stocking up on supplies too. 

I didn’t swim but you’re protected from the sea by barriers here so it’s probably a good place for it.
reviews/14/text: You would never expect to have a sandy beach on a volcanic island, which is what makes this beach a nice change. The sand is imported, and the beach is protected by a large wave breaker, so the beach is quite calm and good for a swim.
reviews/14/title: Good change from the rocky beaches of Madeira
reviews/15/text:
Lovely sandy beach to spend a day on.
Very friendly bar stuff, great music and superb atmosphere. Water was lovely. Suitable for toddlers and teenage kids too.
reviews/16/text: Good place for a quick swim, as it was quiet full of people and there is stones and sand so walking or finding place to lay with distance is not that easy.
reviews/17/text: This beach is not natural and is like a man made pool out of ocean water. It’s super crowded (At least in July) . The stretch of man made beach is very small and there’s nothing to write home about. I drive an hour to get to this beach and wasted a beautiful day . I left without even taking a dip in the ocean . Super disappointed ☹️
reviews/17/title: Don’t bother going to this beach
reviews/18/text: The sand has been brought from Morocco, otherwise sandy beaches are extremely rare on this island. Good facilities. Splendid cafe very near. On a week day in June the beach was more or less empty, groups of visitors sitting very far from each orher
reviews/18/title: Probably the nicest beach in Madeira
reviews/19/text: Probably the only (small)  sandbeach (imported sand). It is very liw key, in the afternoon the locals tend to come over. We visited to get some sun, since in Funchal it was very clouded. We rented 2 sunbeds and an umbrella for the day  eu 5.50 and parked our car next to the beach for eu 0,70/hr.
subcategory_ranking: #59 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Estrada Santo Antonio da Serra 387 Santo Antonio da Serra, Santa Cruz, Madeira 9100-268 Portugal
animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
description: At Madeira Equestrian Club you will find a diversity of activities associated with equestrian practice. The Club has excellent facilities, with large riding stables, well-kept stables and conditions that guarantee the well-being of all horses. Our horses are mainly Lusitanos. It is our goal to promote a harmonious relationship between horse and rider through the different equestrian practices.
name: CEM - Clube Equestre da Madeira
ranking: #144 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #144 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
I can recommend CEM with a pleasure for everyone interested in riding! I have had a long break from riding and got a suggestion to try it at CEM again after many years.
I took 3 private lessons from Iisa and that was definitely the highlight of my 2 week holiday in Madeira.
Iisa is a very professional instructor. She is very patient, supportive and clearly enjoys her job.
What made me very happy was that the horses were very well taken care of, the stable and the surroundings were clean.
The stable is only about 20minutes from Funchal, so very easy to go to!
reviews/0/title: Warm suggestion to anyone interested in riding!
reviews/1/text: Lovely place, beautiful nature all around you and what a glorious horses - they are well behaved and trained dressage horses :). I can definitely recommend this stable to all riders who want a high-quality experience with a lusitano horses.
reviews/1/title: Rode several times in between 2016 till 2018.
reviews/2/text: Lovely stables, surroundings and facilities. Easy going, friendly people. Adorable, well kept and trained dressage horses. Easily accessible premises. I truly and warmly recommend all riders this place! Pony riding also available for children. Great indoor riding school for rainy days.
reviews/2/title: Rode twice here during my stay in January 2019.
reviews/3/text:
Unfortunately I discovered the club way too late in our three months stay at Madeira!! (But maybe that was a good thing for my husband and son, otherwise I would have spend all my days at this lovely place and then missed a lot of other sights here at Madeira). 
The people who running Madeira Equestrian Club is friendly, welcoming, professional and they all shared a passion for horses (mainly Lusitanos 😊). They offer a personal riding experience to everyone, even if you are a beginner or an advanced rider (you find all detailed information at the website). The horses are in very good condition, well trained and the instructors are the best practising classic Portuguese dressage. I just wish that I could have stayed longer and just spent my days at the stable, riding, have a good chat in the coffee room and just hang out with this absolutely amazing horses (and people of course!) 

I will come back!!! 💕💕

/Lina
reviews/4/text: As regular visitors to the island we thought we would try a new activity suitable for the whole family. As complete novices when it comes to horse riding we booked an introduction session with Isa. Each of my children (ages 4,7,14), had a one to one introduction helping to build confidence with the horse as well has how to sit properly etc. Isa took it slowly and encouraged my children to feel confident to hold on with one hand (4 year old), trot (7 year old) and canter (14 year old). I then had a go myself (I am not sporty!). Isa was encouraging, kind and firm which made us feel confident about trying new things.  We all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, my children are really keen to go back and get back on a horse when we are back, they loved Isa too. Thank you!
reviews/5/text: Recomendo vivamente, superou as expectativas!!! Muito Bom para iniciantes e para avançados!! Gostamos imenso do Cosmos um cavalo super querido e amigo. Queremos agradecer particularmente a professora Beatriz por tornar este dia tão  especial e pela atenção!!!
reviews/6/text: O  Club fantástico para subir escada de equitação e passar o tempo na atmosfera da comunicação com os animais .
reviews/7/text: Foi uma experiência fantástica! Os profissionais foram muito amáveis e atenciosos. Ideal para realizar com crianças ou com a família. Recomendo vivamente!
reviews/8/text: Excelente local para uma primeira abordagem à equitação. Recomendo vivamente esta experiência. Um bem hajam.
reviews/9/text:
Magnífico espaço, muito bem organizado, com todas as condições necessárias à prática, quer para iniciantes, quer para praticantes experientes.
Aconselho vivamente a quem gosta de estar em comunhão com a Natureza.
Um agradecimento especial à Isa Kautto , que é uma professora experiente, é muito simpática, permitindo que iniciantes como eu consigam praticar de forma descontraída, tirando prazer da modalidade .
reviews/10/text:
Recomendo local onde pode visitar os estábulos e o pessoal sempre acompanhar e a dar explicação sobre os cavalos.
Muito obrigado
reviews/11/text:
Isa piti ratsastustunnin 11v tyttärellemme. 
Voin lämpimästi suositella paikkaa niin lapsille kuin aikuisille.
Tila ja hevoset on hyvin hoidettu ja opetus on laadukasta. 
Jää varmasti muistoihimme ikimuistoisesti, kokihan lapsi ensilaukkansa Actorilla. 
Isot kiitokset vielä Isalle!
subcategory_ranking: #144 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rabacal, Calheta, Madeira Portugal
name: Lagoa do Vento
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The Fantastic Waterfalls -Private Service
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Guided Walk Lagoa do Vento
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Wind Lagoon And Waterfalls hike and tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Madeira Lakes - Levada do Alecrim
ranking: #124 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #124 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
What a perfect walk! Starting at the parking lot of rabacal. But instead of following the herd of people, we took the road to Alecrim. After some time the trail splits in half. Either you follow the levada do Alecrim, or you go way down to lagao do Vento. We´ve chosen the way down, and it was worth it! It´s a lot of stairs to go all the way down. But what you see is one of the most amazing places in Madeira. It is like a fantasy spot... 

The way back you can choose to go back up or take the path to the rabacal house.
reviews/1/text: We originally were supposed to do only the Alecrim Levada as we had our 3 year old with us but risked it and went along to Vereda da Lagoa do Vento. It's quite a hike but the reward is well worth it. I wouldn't recommend doing it with children, specially small ones, unless you have a backpack to carry them and have a good stamina . The Vereda da Lagoa do Vento is a 1km hike downhill with loadssss of steps, mud, water and stone. It's quite something the waterfall, there's no words. Go early so you get plenty of day light through the vegetation.
reviews/2/text:
mais um experiência única na Madeira, 
faz parte de diferentes levadas/caminhadas do rabaçal com opções mais "leves" para famílias e ou outras com maior grau de dificuldade, mas todas especiais
reviews/3/text: Die Lagoa do Vento Wanderung ist die am wenigsten begangene von Rabacal aus. Warum können wir nicht verstehen, da das Ziel einer der schönsten Plätze in Madeira ist. Man kann die Tour wunderbar zu einer Rundwanderung mit den 25 Fontes und dem Risco Wasserfall gehen - am betsen aber früh am Morgen und bei schönem Wetter.
reviews/3/title: Lohnt sich in Kombi mit den 25 Quellen und dem Risco Wasserfall - wenig begangen
reviews/4/text: Abitando a Madeira ho avuto la possibilitá di fare quasi tutte le levada/vereda piú famose dell'isola e devo dire che Lagoa do Vento é davvero spettacolare, soprattutto la cascata finale é incredibile. La partenza é da Rabaçal e ci volgiano all'incirca 3/4 ore per completare il giro e tornare alla macchina (unico modo per arrivarci, in autubus/corriera é molto difficile). Vi consiglio una volta a Rabaçal di fare anche le altre levada presenti nella zone (sono tutte vicine) come Levada do Alecrim da fare assolutamente insieme a Lagoa do Vento oltre a Levada do Risco e 25 fontes, se avete tempo e voglia vi consiglio di farle tutte.
reviews/5/text: Al Lagoa do Vento se llega por el recorrido de la Levada de Alecrim. Es una caída de agua de 40 o 50 metros impresionante. No tiene nada que envidiar a las 25 Fuentes o al Caldeirao Verde. Recomiendo iniciar el paseo en RabaÇal, y tras visitar el Lagoa do Vento y el nacimiento de Alecrim, regresar por la propia levada
reviews/6/text:
Jest to z pewnością jego z najpiękniejszych miejsc na tej wyspie.
Urok i siła natury jest tu do zobaczenia i poczucia. Polecam dla szukających wyjątkowych wyrażeń wizualnych i słuchowych
reviews/7/text: Rando un peu technique ça grimpe et ça descend. La fin vaut le détour !!! Exceptionnel chute d'eau. Lac qui fait du bien aux jambes. Panorama magnifique. Attention difficile à trouver l'accès. Faut aller derrière la Casa de rabacal. Vers le resto
reviews/8/text: Uma levada relativamente acessível, com uma paisagem muito bonita. E para os mais corajosos, com direito a um mergulho gelado no fim!
reviews/8/title: Uma das levadas mais bonitas da ilhal!
reviews/9/text: Warto poświęcić dodatkowy czas na dojście do wodospadu. Wspaniała trasa przez lasa, niezbyt wymagające zejście. Polecam każdemu szukającemu ciszy i chwili relaksu.
reviews/9/title: Pobliski szlak na trasie do 25 Fontes
reviews/10/text:
Ce lieu est atteignable depuis le site de Rabaçal (25 sources - cascade de Risco - etc).
L'avantage c'est qu'il n'est pas trop fréquenté et vraiment l'effort en vaut la peine - magnifique chute dans ce petit lac à mi-hauteur de la cascade de Risco - Nombreuses possibilités de combinaisons 
On a adoré
reviews/11/text:
A caminhada não está bem assinalada (pelo menos em Dezembro de 2017), mas vale bem a pena. O percurso começa no Rabaçal, mas na parte de cima, não é preciso descer até à casa, basta encontrar a Levada do Alecrim (que também não está assinalada) facilmente identificável à direita do portão da carrinha que faz o transporte até à casa do Rabaçal. A partir daí o percurso é plano e encontra-se em bom estado até que a cerca dos 2km existe uma entrada à esquerda do percurso (não assinalada, mas visível por ser larga e ter degraus) em que começa a descida com cerca de 1km e 200m de diferença de altitude, o que torna o percurso difícil, principalmente na subida, não porque o acesso esteja em mau estado, mas devido à inclinação acentuada, que para uma pessoa com capacidade física normal é acessível, pode é demorar mais ou menos tempo a ser feito. A cascata tem uma altura vertiginosa e é visível durante a descida, assim como a lagoa também é bastante bonita, com diversos tons de verde, azul e vermelho, parecendo ser um local ideal para um mergulho no verão (em dezembro não arriscamos o frio). Após a subida recomendo continuar a levada do Alecrim até à próxima cascata que fica a cerca de 1km, mas num percurso muito mais fácil e plano e com uma cascata diferente, menor em altura, mais larga e com outros efeitos, também propícia a um banho (no verão).
Assim, para fazer a lagoa do vento e a levada do alecrim (ida e volta) são cerca de 8km, enquanto para a lagoa do vento são 6km, num percurso que prima pela grande cascata e pela menor popularidade em relação a outros percursos no rabaçal, como a própria levada do alecrim, a levada das 25 fontes ou a boca do risco.
reviews/11/title: Uma caminhada escondida com direito a cascata
reviews/12/text:
Um dos melhores lugares da ilha da Madeira!  É simplesmente fantástico!  Um lugar escondido dos turistas,   relação às 25 fontes que tem excesso de pessoas!  
Podemos passar uma tarde nas calmas..um retiro da cidade!
reviews/13/text: Paysages magnifiques loin du surplus de touristes qui reste sur la levada 25 fontes. Nous avons bien essayé de nous baigner mais l'eau était trop froide. À faire ++
reviews/14/text: Esta é uma caminhada fácil e muito agradável pelas montanhas verdejantes com um banho frio no fim para os mais corajosos
reviews/14/title: um dos meus passeios favoritos na Madeira
reviews/15/text:
Wir sind von der Levada do Alecrim abgestiegen, haben den Abstecher zur Lagoa gemacht und sind dann am Hang zur Zufahrtsstraße des Pesto Florestal Rabaçal zurück (so wie im Rother beschrieben). Ich dachte des öfteren, wir hätten uns verlaufen, da der Weg teilweise glitschig war und wir über Steine und Wurzeln klettern mussten. 
Am Ende hat sich die Mühe auf jeden Fall gelohnt, wir hatten den Wasserfall für uns.
Stöcke und Wanderschuhe würde ich schon empfehlen, weil die Stufen teilweise recht hoch sind und Trittsicherheit im steilen Gelände bei der Überquerung kleinerer Wasserrinnsale gefordert ist.
reviews/16/text:
Pittige hike over onverharde paden. Ik heb de route die wij gebruikt hebben bijgevoegd als afbeelding. Ik beveel aan hem tegen de klok in te lopen, dan begin je met het pittigste en eindig je met het gemakkelijke stuk langs de levada (extra voordeel is dat je dan later bij de levada bent en het dus niet zo druk is). Het eerste stuk, vanaf het startpunt (midden onderin) tegen de klok in naar het Rabacal house (tweede groene POI marker) zou ik niet aanraden, dat is enorm overgroeid. Wij zijn in plaats daarvan de asfaltweg afgelopen tot je bijna bij Rabacal house bent, en dan kruis je op gegeven moment weer de route van deze hike (GPS aanbevolen!! Wij gebruikten de "WalkMe" app die 5 euro kost). Verder hebben wij wel de hele route gevolgd. (dit weet ik omdat we de eerste dag niet goed gekeken hadden en daarom per ongeluk de asfaltweg afgelopen waren, de tweede dag hebben we het overgeslagen stuk alsnog gelopen maar dat viel dus tegen).

Zo'n beetje de hele route behalve het laatste stuk (vanaf na de laatste POI marker op de kaart) zijn wij niemand tegengekomen wat heerlijk was. De hele route is pittig, nergens verhard en relatief veel klimmen en dalen, maar wel goed te doen. Ik zou onszelf als gemiddeld sportief omschrijven en dat was genoeg. De lagoa do vento is een prachtige plek voor een picnic en een duik. Als je om het meertje heen klautert naar de overkant van waar je aankomt zit daar een stuk waar veel minder algen groeien.

Na de derde POI komt de route uit op een levada, als je dat leuk vindt kan je die nog weer omhoog volgen naar een bronnetje/watervalletje. Bij de levada kom je ook weer mensen tegen.
reviews/17/text: Достаточно впечатляющий маршрут с красивыми видами и достаточно крутыми участками. Сложность между средним и легким, но обязательно нужно одеть хорошую трекинговую обувь!
reviews/18/text: Esta caminhada é realmente muito bonita! É acessível por todos, porem é sempre preciso ter alguma precaução! Convém levar equipamento adequado para esta caminhada, tênis confortáveis, roupa confortável, agua, e um casaco. Aconselho!
reviews/19/text: É uma caminhada exigente, com um percurso de dificuldade média. Aquilo que observamos na chegada é qualquer coisa de deslumbrante, um paraíso escondido. Adorei e aconselho um mergulho na água fria da lagoa!
subcategory_ranking: #124 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Er 209, Madeira 6160-206 Portugal
name: Pico Ruivo do Paul da Serra
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Private Transfer to Levada do Alecrim - Rosemary Levada (easy)
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Northwest Terraces and Volcanic Pools 4x4 Full Day Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: 4x4 Jeep Safari Porto Moniz - the "Farowest" tour - Full Day Small Groups
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Discover Madeira In 2 Days (from 09h To 17h - Each Day)
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: All Madeira In 2 Days Tour
photo/caption: Paul da Serra Ilha da Madeira
ranking: #65 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #65 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: There's a short, easy and very dramatic route up to Pico Ruivo's summit from the big car park at Teixeira, 3km east, where there's also an excellent new restaurant and cafe Abrigo da Heidi which serves great coffee and delicious Austrian-style cakes. Teixeira is an easy drive up mainly good roads from near Santana. The route up to the summit is almost entirely stone-paved and it's an easy and wide path with gentle gradients but some very dramatic views to both sides, particularly if the clouds are coming and going as they often do up in the mountains., and the views from the  summit itself, in every direction, are truly stunning. There's even a government rest house just a few hundred metres from the summit for further refreshments if you need them, with a large sheltered terrace outside as well as seats inside. And from the summit or just below it there are also some much more challenging and rougher routes both west (to Encumeada) and south (to Pico Ariero) though both take 4-5 hours one-way and are not for the faint-hearted or those who suffer from vertigo..! A great walk and a huge pay-off for remarkably little effort
reviews/0/title: Easy and dramatic ridge walk to the summit, and stunning views
reviews/1/text:
This is usually a stop on the tour of the west of the island and, cloud permitting, affords great views of the coast. I also understand that it is on a levada walk as well.
If the cows are still in the vicinity be aware that they can be a bit grumpy
reviews/1/title: Worth a trip if only for the views
reviews/2/text: Don't miss out on climbing the Pico Ruivo (make sure you either have transport arranged or do a there-and-back-again walk), it's a fantastic viewpoint all over the island. You're above the clouds, it's sunny and the views are breathtaking. Hiking gear and UV protection is essential.
reviews/3/text: We walked a short stretch of this as part of a tour of the west. Pleasant enough, with some good views, but there are more exciting levada walks!
reviews/3/title: just a taste of levada walks
reviews/4/text: We stopped at the top of the mountain on our way to Rabacal. The highway up the mountain is very steep and windy. We didn’t do the hike but saw the windmills and solar panels. There are no trees only scrub bush and it was ten degrees cooler up here. Going down to Porto Muniz is a better road.
reviews/5/text: The trip is suitable for all people, there are 2 ways. You can go longer or shorter way. The longer way is not for older people, children and so on. It is quite challenging. The views are amazing. Be carefull for weather. It can be very cold there.
reviews/6/text: Not so crowdy as Risco, 360 degrees view after a rewarding climb to the top. You van park Your car nearby in the shade in a little forrest.
reviews/7/text: It's all about the getting to and going from. The scenery changes initially to what resembles the new forest. Odd I know. Gorse heathland with cows and cattle grids but with valleys with clouds in them. You gradually rise and the scenery changes to deep green valleys with blue seas beyond up to peaks of stone and even better views. It doesn't matter where you look, where you take a picture or video. Nothing quite captures the beauty or splendour. Lots of viewpoints but not needed. Just pull up, you won't be in the way. It changes again with hills full of wind turbines. I love them and though incongruous they work. Nothing here to do but be awed. Brilliant.
reviews/8/text: Be there close to the sunset, a couple of hours so you can explore several sites around you. Between 17:30 GMT to 18:00 GMT be there. If you are lucky you will feed yourself like inside the cockpit on a smooth flight. Just a few feet bellow the clouds welcome you without the movement of the aircraft, the "cockpit" is still. The sun ahead will come down slowly inside the clouds the colours will change to red, orange and almost pink, the sun will disappear and if you wait a while you will se ir reappearing briefly on the bottom of the cloud. Keep un mind you are above 4.500 feet.
reviews/9/text: The views here are truly amazing. Absolutely worth a visit to the top. If it's clear you can see for miles and it's most definitely worth it. We were lucky to go up when it was clear.
reviews/10/text: There are absolutely brilliant views from up here, you can virtually see for miles on a clear day. There is a wee concrete tower which my husband climbed up, as I was too short to do so and he got some good photos. The scenery of the surrounding area is stunning.
reviews/11/text: Visited here in the spring this year.  Unfortunately the weather in Funchal was beautiful, but not so up here.  I can imagine it would be magnificent on a brilliantly cloudless day.
reviews/12/text: As part of the off road jeep safari we reached the highest point on the island along dust tracks. What a way to see the island. Much better than the buses orvhireing a car. The guide is so knowledgeable. This is a must if you are staying here.
reviews/13/text: This is the highest pic in the island acessible by car. The other pic areiro is more high but only acessible by foot trail. The view is very nice, but it could be a little cloudy some times. The nature is fabulous! You must see it.
reviews/14/text:
We did not walk here, but we drove all over the place. It was most beautiful and very quiet, we did not see many other cars there.

The road from Encumeda was closed, but we found the way in another way and it was well worth the drive.

It is very beautiful and very different from other parts of Madeira.
reviews/15/text:
Excelente miradouro com vista para São Vicente (se não estiver nublado).
Infelizmente, neste momento, os 3 acessos recomendados têm algumas zonas com muita vegetação (carqueja e feiteira) o que dificulta a caminhada. 
Para os corajosos é de experimentar, mas convém usar calças compridas.
reviews/15/title: Caminhada curta mas com muita vegetação infestante no percurso.
reviews/16/text: Pico Ruiovo do Paul je nejvyšší bod náhorní plošiny Paul da Serra v západní části ostrova. Auto je lepší nechat na novém parkovišti po pravé straně cca 500 metrů po odbočení z ER 110 než v průvodcích doporučovaného levém hned u odbočky, kde začíná výchozí bod uváděný v průvodcích. Bohužel cesta navazující na levostranné parkoviště  je zarostlá krušinkou, která nyní nádherně žlutě kvete, ale její trny vám z cesty skrz ní udělají peklo. Druhý jen hůře průchozí úsek na  úbočí hory se dá projít pokud máte dlouhé kalhoty a rukávy. Výstup samotný je sice strmější, ale krátký a výhled pokud vyjde počasí ( lepší absolvovat dopoledne) je super.  Srdce každého meteorologa zde musí plesat blahem, neb je zde nádherně vidět jak se mraky zaražené o severní stranu ostrova postupně teplem vyzdvihnou a po polední zaplaví  vavřínový les mlžným oparem.
reviews/16/title: Zrádná  trnitá krušinka může výlet pokazit při nevhodném oblečení
reviews/17/text: Bajeczne miejsce! To uczucie i widok gdy chodzisz w chmurach! Coś niesamowitego!  Obowiązkowe miejsce.
reviews/18/text: Não é muito longa, mas suas vistas são fabulosas, tanto sobre o Paul da Serra, como para São Vicente. O dia estava fantastico, ceu limpo, onde a visão tinha um longa alcance, pois vislumbrar todo o Paul da Serra, mas nem uma hora depois tudo muda e vem as nuvens e nevoeiro, fazendo ondas como um mar, é uma beleza unica.
reviews/19/text: Przepiękne miejsce,6km urokliwej trasy,w chmurach,zieleni,przepaści.Warto przelecieć na Maderę polecam
subcategory_ranking: #65 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Sitio dos Lameiros, Sao Vicente, Madeira 9240-211 Portugal
description: The museum centre is directly associated with the regional natural and cultural heritage and is partially integrated in the Natural Park of Madeira. Located in São Vicente, it covers an area close to 12,000 square meters and it´s the perfect place to enjoy the local scenic beauty. The visitor can find two limestone quarries, a lime kiln and a lime house, and other constructions to support agriculture and livestock, such as a hayloft, an irrigation well and a transport cable. The path that passes through the museum centre maintains its old configuration and allows one to appreciate all the beauties that this place has to offer. This area is unique on Madeira, because it´s the only place where marine limestones can be found, as well as several types of marine fossils (some as old as 7 million years). In the lime house there´s a permanent exhibition and a video which explains the transformation of limestone into lime. Guided tours in English, German and French are offered.
name: Museum Centre - The Lime Route
ranking: #122 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #122 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
One of the best place where come at one of first trip days. You will get so much useful information about Madeira! And tips and tricks for traveling around island.
Thank you!
reviews/0/title: Nice place where start your trip
reviews/1/text:
We were guided around by Sé who gave us an interesting tour where we learned about the laborious lime  excavation. We also learned a lot about the Island its inhabitants and its history.
We had a very nice tour, great conversations and lots of laughs. 
Paula and Richard, NL
reviews/2/text:
Few minutes drive from Sao Vicente or even with nice long walk, you will find this hidden place where you can get a sense of the history of limestone extraction  decades ago. 
Really toucing to see how hard they worked in this process at the time, and the tools of the time, the oven, have also been preserved.
reviews/3/text: We really enjoyed the video and all the information was in English also. Tour about the limestone quarrying
reviews/4/text: Nous avons pu rencontrer Zé Moniz qui est un guide très sympathique et qui nous a fait la visite de ce lieu. Il nous a appris l'histoire et l'utilisation de la chaux sur l'ile de Madère. Nous a donné de précieuses recommandations de visites sur la partie Nord de l'île où il vit depuis toujours. Le tout en français. Nous avons passé un agréable moment en sa compagnie. Zé Moniz est un super ambassadeur de l'ile de Madère. Nous sommes ravis d'avoir fait sa connaissance et nous avons  bien profité de ses recommandations pour la fin de notre séjour.
reviews/4/title: Notre visite à la route de la chaux
reviews/5/text:
Cruzámo-nos com a Rota da Cal por acaso… ou talvez não. Algo me chamou a atenção e era impossível passar sem lá ir. Foi incrível.
Um espaço encantador, bem conservado e cuidado. Um espaço em que se nota amor e dedicação.
Aqui não se perde tempo, mesmo quando o tempo para visitar a ilha é curto, porque o que se ganha, é muito mais.
reviews/6/text:
Wir sind nur durch Zufall dort gelandet und waren vollkommen begeistert. Es wirkt sehr unscheinbar und sogar ein bisschen versteckt, aber der Besuch ist mehr als lohnenswert. Ein superfreundlicher Guide hatte uns dort eine Tour gegeben, die sogar kostenfrei ist. Das waren 30 Minuten Privatführung und wir waren sehr dankbar dafür. Die Entstehungsgeschichte und auch die Informationen wie der Betrieb gelaufen sein muss, war hochinteressant. Auch landschaftlich ist es sehr schön. Inmitten der Berge muss man weniger hundert Meter gehen um dann über eine Treppe zum Kalkofen und dem Museum zu gelangen.

Vom Guide hatten wir dann noch tolle Tipps für Madeira bekommen. Ein unglaublich freundlicher Mensch!!! Vielen Dank nochmals für die tolle Erfahrung.
reviews/7/text:
Caminhada simplesmente fantástica, recomendo a 100%.
Passeio agradável e com coisas muito interessantes de se aprender
reviews/8/text: Adoramos visitar em família este local, onde a história e a geologia andam de mãos dadas...Os visitantes podem ainda lanchar e apreciar uma paisagem deslumbrante sobre o vale de São Vicente. Recomendo.
reviews/9/text: Wider Erwarten bot das kleine Museum interessante Erläuterungen zur Kalkgewinnung und dem beschwerlichen Weg dorthin. Unbedingt sollte man sich den kurzen Film im Museum vorführen lassen.
reviews/10/text:
Nous avons été très bien accueilli dans ce lieu qui mélange centre explicatif de l'extraction et confection de la chaux avec un magnifique jardin potager odorant !!!
Je croyais pour ma part que l'entrée était payante, mais finalement les visiteurs entrent tout à fait gratuitement et peuvent contribuer au bon fonctionnement du lieux.
Salle didactique intéressante et guide très obligeant.
Sur le chemin de retour, arrêtez-vous à la chapelle de Fatima...
reviews/11/text: Important lieu de mémoire où est raconté l’histoire des personnes qui se sont sacrifiées pour l’extraction de la chaux.
reviews/12/text:
Um pequeno tesourinho de S. Vicente. 
Oferece uma excelente vista sobre S. Vicente e a sua geomorfológia. Oferece também pequeno trilho, espetacular de se fazer.
Muito recomendado, seja em familia, sozinho ou com o parceiro e em qualquer altura do ano!
reviews/13/text: Um Museu absolutamente a não perder nos arredores de São Vicente. O espaço museológico é muito interessante, com uma explicação muito completa do processo de produção da cal, além de explicar os outros usos da pedra calcária. Depois da parte musealizada, é também muito interessante passear até às pedreiras de onde era retirada a pedra calcária. A visita a este Museu também permite ver fósseis com 5 milhões de anos. E todo este privilégio, de forma gratuita, pois o acesso ao Museu é gratuito!
reviews/14/text: hier kann man am besten am frühen Abend Ruhe geniessen. Dann sind alle Führungen durch und Ruhe kehrt ein!!
reviews/15/text:
Percurso bonito feito quase todo na companhia de galinhas.
Interessante conseguir conhecer um pouco mais de história em comunhão com a natureza.
reviews/16/text:
Il n'y a pas grand chose à voir et de plus quand j'y suis allé fin mai 2016 le four à chaux était fermé.
Je pense que cela ne vaut pas le détour
reviews/17/text: Petit musée sur l'extraction de la chaux qui mérite le détour et qui se mérite(petite route avant d'arriver)
reviews/18/text: Bon petit musée avec des explications sur l'extraction du calcaire puis la transformation en chaux. Petit parcours jusque la carrière où l'on peut voir une hutte de paille traditionnelle.
reviews/19/text: Um ecomuseu que reflete a exploração da cal durante vários séculos, um documentário realista e uma coleção de fósseis com 7 milhões de anos. A visita guiada compensa, mas tem de ser marcada com antecedência.
subcategory_ranking: #122 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Off ER109 Saída da ER109, Canical, Madeira Portugal
name: Miradouro da Ponta do Rosto
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: East of Madeira | Full Day 4x4 Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: East Tour - 4x4 - Small Group
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Wheelchair Handicap Full Day East Tour Santana Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Wheelchair Full Day Tour Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Madeira Jeep 4x4: Old Forest Full-Day Tour incl Pico Arieiro
ranking: #8 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #8 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Takes a bit of a walk to get there, and it can get windy, but the views are amazing. One can feel the enormous forces at play that shaped the coast line and the whole island. The path is very well prepared and safe, simple normal shoes will do.
reviews/1/text:
This is the easternmost point one can drive to on the island; beyond that only on foot and at one's own risk.
Once past Caniçal, the area looks a lot like the Canary Islands, rather barren but still very beautiful.
The blueness of the waters combines wonderfully with the dark rocks and the beige sand/vegetation, amazing photos!
Oh, and no tourist masses over there, another plus!
reviews/1/title: As far as one can get eastwards
reviews/2/text: Having parked the car on what seemed to be a very non noteworthy car park, we walked along a gravel path into a grassy area. After about 25 minutes of walking the landscape begins to reveal its hidden beauty. Breathtaking rock formations, crashing waves, every shade of green and plants galore. An absolute must to visit.
reviews/3/text: Great view with easy access and they have refreshments and snacks so after a walk is possible to recharge your energy before continuing.
reviews/4/text:
Thursday 17th June we were driving around the São Lourenço Peninsula through the wild and rugged landscape 

We stopped at this Mirador which is located in the northern part of the Peninsula. 

We parked up in the small car park area and went walking about. There is a viewing area,  with hand rails, to stand and admire the views. For those more intrepid visitors there were pathways, with no rails, further along the headland. The reward for their bravery was even more fantastic views. 

We could see the outline of Porto Santo in the distance 

This was definitely not for the faint hearted especially on a wild, wet and windy day like today. Would definitely recommend bringing a jacket with you, just in case. Having said that there were people walking around in vests and shorts.
reviews/4/title: Wet, wild and windy with great views
reviews/5/text: Nice coastal view of the east part of the island.  Parking, coffee shop. Not crowded. Can be windy. Some tables for pick nicks.
reviews/6/text:
It is such a relaxing scenary 
Walking lovers will enjoy the tour and relaxing silence of the site ...
reviews/7/text: Unique scenery in a landscape more like Scotland than the rest of this ‚tropical’ island. Walk to the end of the peninsula is easy to do, great views down the steep cliffs. Can be windy! Restaurant at end of the walk closed due to the pandemic. Remember to bring a swimsuit, there is a fine spot (small quay) down from the restaurant.
reviews/8/text: One of the most underrated parts of the island - the views from the coast are spectacular! The cliffs are completely bare showing the island's volcanic past and they fall straight into the raging sea, it's like scenery from a fantasy world. However, there's no facilities anywhere in the area so nobody wants to do tours round there. To get there you have to get past a recycling plant and a commercial port which is really offputting. It is such a shame that it is only a stopover for a photo call.
reviews/8/title: Amazing views but no facilities at all!
reviews/9/text: The place is easily accesible and shows you all the highlights of the area. Can be an alternative to doing the trail.
reviews/10/text: Viewpoint is a short drive further along from the Prainha roadsign - access road to the small car parking area is narrow but there are passing places.  When we visited there was a flower seed seller - wish I could grow some of these back in UK!  It’s only a short walk up to the edge of the cliffs where you get sweeping views along the peninsula (vista is cloud dependent!).  Even though it’s not a difficult walk I would still recommend wearing footwear other than sandals as I did notice a couple of women slip on the stony/uneven ground.  A big disappointment for me was looking down onto the small inlets and noticing all the litter washed up from goodness knows where in the world :-(
reviews/11/text:
We visited on a classic Madeira day of changeable weather, which turned out to be ideal for this Miradouro.

At the far Eastern corner of the island, it offers fantastic views along the North and South coastlines. The Southern side of the island was overcast and the sea appeared slate grey. We turned 180 degrees and the Northern side was basked in sunlight and the sea was a beautiful azure.

Whatever the weather though, the views are stunning.
reviews/11/title: Stunning views of North and South of island
reviews/12/text: It was not planned, but we visited it at sunset and got amazing view! A must-see of Madeira, the nature here is different than the rest of the island
reviews/13/text:
At the far eastern tip of Madeira, this has a very different feel to the rest of the island. It isn’t as high and isn’t wooded. There are dramatic views of the cliffs falling sheer into the sea, although depending what time of day you visit, the angle of the sun can make taking pictures difficult. 

Unlike the other viewpoints, there are no tourist facilities here - just raw nature.

It is worth spending a bit of time here to walk and enjoy the views.
reviews/13/title: Good viewpoint at the eastern tip of the island
reviews/14/text: Fantastic hike with amazing views. If walking briskly can do out and back in under 2.5 hours.  A must do!
reviews/15/text: All our hikes were by levadas except this one and I will return here again! The views were spectacular, the hike is quite easy, especially if it is not on a sunny day
reviews/16/text:
Parking next to the miradouro. Easy access.You see the Sao Lorenco peninsula and if you walk up a hill you have a nice view to the north. A very dramatic shoreline.
There is a stand selling flowers and bulbs by the miradouro. A very nice woman sells them, good prices and beautiful flowers.
reviews/16/title: Nice view over the Sao Lorenco peninsula
reviews/17/text: We were lucky to be on a clear day - persistent splashing waves against the violent volcanic landscape was a breath-taking
reviews/18/text: I have to say that every "miradouro" here in Madeira has so beautiful view and is absolutely worth to see if you want some coll photos.
reviews/19/text:
We were supposed to just pass by Caniçal and see the view, but noticed it was possible to go further in this peninsule and arriving the farthest possible with our car saw that people were leaving for a trekking.
So there we went and was quite a surprise.
Grandiose awesome scenery. Highly recommended

ranking_subcategory: #33 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Set off walking and having done a steep, hot climb found that it was closed for refurbishment until 2023. Disappointing to say the least. Would be useful to have this sort of information on Trip Advisor.
reviews/1/text:
One star for the exercise getting there. Sadly still closed so we could not enter. 
The plus was we wandered into the museum gardens just a stones throw away up the hill and enjoyed a very pleasant lunch in café situated within the grounds there.
reviews/2/text:
Still closed. January 2020.
Please UPDATE your information.
Its a fair climb up cobbled streets to get there, only to find out that its closed.
reviews/3/text: No respect for visitors. The convent is closed for restauration. But they don’t respect you and your time and update the webb accordingly. You will find info on the entrance door. Unbelievable.
reviews/3/title: Ni respect for people and their time
reviews/4/text: Having ensured we would be there for its 10am opening, we  were very disappointed to find the Convent closed for refurbishment until the end of 2021.  I’m sure it will warrant 5 stars when visitors can visit again!
reviews/5/text: I am only giving this attraction a low review to warn visitors that it is closed until the end of 2020. I had to go all the way to the convent to find this out! It wasn’t written anywhere on the internet when I did research about the convent.
reviews/6/text: If you want to step in the footsteps of the first explorers then come here and see the amazing Convent which is still in use today. It is so worth the climb up the hill!
reviews/6/title: Wonderful guided tour of such a historical olace
reviews/7/text: Enjoyed the visit here and the guide was very knowledgable. The interior is beautiful and so is the exterior areas. Well worth a visit
reviews/7/title: Beautiful building with lots of history
reviews/8/text: Beautiful place with lots of interesting history. Friendly guide answered all questions. Remember to bring cash for the tour (2€).
reviews/9/text: This is a beautiful building that is finally receiving the attention it deserves.  The tower and roof is being restored.  It is now operating as a daycare centre.  You are free to wander into the outer courtyard and there are WCs onsite if needed.
reviews/10/text: This old monastery is located about 15 minutes walking up the hill but it’s worth the effort. It’s not possible to visit it by yourself; you must be guided, but the girl who does the guiding does a great job – she really puts her soul in the explanations. The monastery is quite interesting but the best without any doubt it’s the church covered with magnificent glaze tiles panels in rug patterns – pity that the main altar was destroyed during one of the city assaults and the rebuilt one is quite poor considering the church in general. Enjoy!
reviews/11/text: This is well worth the walk up the hill and the 2 euro entry. The small group were shown around by a very knowledgeable guide. There were several wow moments. A beautiful building with a very interesting history.
reviews/12/text:
We visited the convent after reading TripAdvisor recommendations. Initially, we were the only ones on the tour but two others joined towards the end - the guide just keeps going around from 10-12 and 3-5 and visitors can join up at various points.

The guide was great fun and very knowledgeable about the history of the convent and Madeira. The tour lasted 35 mins and was great value for 2 euros.  Well worth the effort of walking up the hill from Funchal city centre.

We combined going to the convent with visits to the nearby ornate San Pedro church and the gardens of the Museu da Quinta das Cruzes (free entry to gardens)
reviews/13/text: At 2 Euros per person this was great value. So interesting to hear about the lives of the nuns who fled to the Valley of the Nuns.
reviews/13/title: Fascinating tour for such a good price
reviews/14/text: Wasn't expecting it to much, it's only 2 Euros, and you have to ring the bell to enter at the northeast entrance to get in.  It was early October, I was the only one there.  Tour guide Susan enthusiastically showed me all over the convent and knew tons of history and interesting stories ... the tombstone of the first mother superior, the Clairesse nuns meeting room, the place where noblemen hid their money, the Novice nuns room, the beautiful Santa Clara church, St. Anthony of Padua, who is actually Portuguese, and they know him as St. Anthony of Lisbon ... the tour was close to two hours, and well worth the time.  Best time to arrive, just after opening at 10 a.m. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Madeira.
reviews/15/text: Full of history and priceless treasures. Our tour guide was fantastic and we got a feel of how it felt like to live in the convent as a nun in the old days. I could not believe how much there was to still see after a lot had already been damaged. The church is an absolute gem. Check out the wooden statue of Our Lady in the church. An exceptional piece. It was nice to have our tour accompanied by the laughter of children. Brings some happiness to a place that I am sure could be hard at times.
reviews/16/text: We arrived at 10 am and the guide came to meet us in the courtyard.  We think the tour was meant to last about 15 minutes but it was so interesing with history and the parts we saw that we were there about 90 minutes.  I think this one not to m be missed.  The guide was brilliant.
reviews/17/text: At only 1€ to enter, don’t forget to ring the bell for entry ! This is well worth a visit. Susan is an excellent enthusiastic guide and the place itself which is still home to a open order of nun’s and a day school from 5 months to 5 years is fabulous. So much history preserved to enjoy. Such a calm place inside busy Funchal.
reviews/18/text: Guide was somewhat abrupt and I think the escorted tour was over in around 15 minutes and she had to speak in 2 languages.
reviews/18/title: Not worth the long walk uphill.
reviews/19/text:
Set on the hillside above the town centre, and tucked away behind a wooden doorway in the wall, you have to want to find this place. It is well worth the effort!

Pull the old fashioned bell pull to gain admittance. Although you can enter the church without paying, it is definitely worth the €2 to join a conducted tour of the monastery. Tours are in English. This takes you along corridors around the cloisters and into small chapels used by the nuns as well as the nun’s choir, where the nuns could watch mass taking place in the main church. There are two wonderful oratories behind wooden doors - look out for the delightful picture of the cockerel on the big one. 

Tours are run continuously and it is possible to join one without having to wait. 

Remember it is shut from 12-3, so plan a visit round these times. Allow 30-60 minutes to visit.
subcategory_ranking: #33 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Porto Moniz, Madeira Portugal
name: Levada Ribeira de Janela
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Ribeira da Janela Tunnels and Waterfalls Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Guided Walk Levada Ribeira da Janela
ranking: #30 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #30 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: One of my favourite days of our holiday. The scenery is glorious, the walks unforgettable, the landscape deserted.
reviews/1/text: The trail is nice, but comparatively dificult, with the tonnels. We were able to pas only a bit more than half-way. Picturesque views, waterflls, tonnels, shady levadas
reviews/2/text: It is a nice and easy walk that basically stays even the whole time. If you plan a longer hike, be Ware that the Levada is closed after the first tunnel. Still worth it nevertheless
reviews/3/text: Easy walk, at the begining you can find info that instead od 25km there is a closure after 4,5 km, which is right after the first tunnel. Restaurant near  parking lot closed, probably due to covid.
reviews/4/text:
This is an easy walk with no climbing in it. You walk trough the forest and at the beginning you have some lovely flowers. Further we thought it was a bit boring... There was no waterfall (August) and the second tunnel was closed because of construction. 
You walk the same way twice.
reviews/5/text: This one is really easy, but still very nice, good for older people or families with kids but also for easy hikers. Nothing especialy dungerous here, there are some cliffs, waterfalls and the views are very nice.
reviews/6/text: Mostly flat trail following a levada, this trail has beautiful views and a unique twist of a few old dark tunnels to hike through. A headlamp or the light of a cell phone required to get through the tunnels. A waterfall or two along the way and lots of flowers.
reviews/7/text: Tranquil yet adventurous, lovely way to spend the day. Nice environment with lots of forest. Not for the elderly but ok for kids!
reviews/8/text: We enjoyed the trip very much. The views, the nature, the water, the birds...Take only a good jacket and shoes. It is place, where the weather can change very quickly
reviews/9/text: A very safe and, evidently popular levada path. Suitable for all adults including the elderly. The vews were exceptional.
reviews/10/text: Not that easy to find as you should not go to the town named Ribiera de Janela to get there, but instead, the oppoiste way to Laceimeros up the hill from Porto Montiz, cross the village until you reach the final car park after the church. a 3-4 hours walk, easy, flat along the levada until you reach the tunnel (take a lamp).
reviews/11/text: A good start to Levada walking. We walked as far as the long tunnel before retracing our steps back to Lamecheros. The walk was easy to find and walked through eucalyptus and native laurel. We managed to see Madeiran firecrest, trocaz pigeon and a very tame Madeiran chaffinch. It took us a couple of hours each way but we walked very slowly enjoying the views and wildlife. The tunnels require torches and we saw one group who had donned hard hats!! We managed fine with some ducking but we did get wet.
reviews/12/text: amazing walking! Take some food and water with you and all that you need to crossing tunnels and water. The landscape is amazing. In many areas you don't have network coverage so I advise you to don't do this walk alone... just in case... apart that enjoy!
reviews/13/text:
However, here is how you shouldn't approach it   ; -)

Me and my girlfriend started at Lamaceiros at noon. Weather was nice and in the first three hours we passed some tremendous lookouts, waterfalls and laurel trees. The tunnels by then had been narrow and streaked with puddles – more or less. Anyways, none of them required much effort or more than five minutes of walking. At some point, we reached a tunnel we could barely look through. As I learned later this was the one with a remarkable length of sheer 1,5 km. It would seem the thing to turn back here, or – for the ones who love the tunnels – to pass it and go back through right after. On our way through the tunnel we helped ourselves with phone flashlights
and got little wet passing the waterfalls in the middle.
We went on, lead by the false assumption there would come a junction for the road soon. Also, we weren't eager to go back for it had been quite a walk till there and getting darker. Few short tunnels followed, with the very last of them being extraordinarily muddy. The way became worse evermore, eventually – after five hours of walking –leaving us surprised at its southern deadlock.
After a brief discussion we figured it would be unreasonable to proceed walking up the brook there. Going back the same way daylight was about to fade. We increased our paces, running wherever possible. Passing the tunnels this time we didn't give a monkeys about dirty shoes. Our phones batteries had run low and we wanted to save it for the remaining tunnels. We were grateful for each wire fence to cling to so that we could walk on quicker (the Levada runs along the scarp). Luckily the full moon had risen soon to lighten the way and we were looking forward to each obstacle to come.

Certainly, our thrill to hike was just as big as our naivety.
In any case, you'd be better off with torches and waterproof clothes.
reviews/13/title: Unique walking past tunnels and biodiversity
reviews/14/text: With our friend we enjoyed such a lot in this wonderful area with sights and sounds - managed to gain another experience of Madeira well worth a vist
reviews/15/text: We walked the first 6 km. Started at around  9:30 am. We were the only couple on the trail for almost two hours. Nice views. The first part is easy to walk. The last part of the 6 km is more difficult. Just before the waterfall there is a tunnel for which you will need a light. In the tunnel your feet may get wet. In August the waterfall did not show much water
reviews/16/text:
We stumbled across this Levada by accident and as a consequence were not prepared. Waterproof boots, and a torch are a must.
 Having said that we still really enjoyed the walk and with the tree cover the temperature and terrian were comfortable.

The wildlife seem unpiturbed by walkers the finches imparticular are both friendly and beautiful.
reviews/17/text:
Sometimes trying to find the start of a Levada walk is trick but not this one! There is a trout farm, a restaurant and a couple of quite touristy shops to mark the start.
The problem with these walks its that they are linear so you either do the walk and get a taxi back tho the start (expensive and time consuming) or you walk there and back (long) or you walk for as long as you want and then turn around (you miss out on stuff).
We did about 1 1/2 hours and then turned around so felt we had managed a good walk but a shame not to have completed it - next time we will start from the other end so we can say we have done it twice!
It is an easy walk with a few high narrow bits and some lovely views although you are walking in the cover of trees most of the time.
The trout farm is interesting but it is a shame there is no one there to tell you about it and no information as to what happens to all these fish. Trout does not appear to be common on many menus so no idea where they end up.
There were a lot of people (cars and coaches) around the restaurant and shop but once on the walk not many so I think a lot just come up for a look see but not to walk.
Gift shops sell a lot of woolen clothes as well as tourist tat.
reviews/17/title: Trout farm at the start of a levada walk
reviews/18/text:
If you're looking for lush forests, impressive waterfalls and dingy tunnels then this walk is for you!

Recommendations:

1. Wear walking shoes, the more waterproof the better
2. Bring a torch, ideally one torch per person and even more ideally a head torch to leave your hands free to help you balance...
3. Be prepared to do a bit of balancing on the levada wall in the tunnels to avoid getting wet feet (either in the levada or the puddles alongside)
4. Our sat nav (google maps) tried to take us up a dodgy road (the caminho da ladeira) in Porto Moniz to the start of the walk. Our hire car ceouldn't do it, even in first gear! I would strongly recommend staying on the ER101 as long as possible before taking the road across to Lamaceiros
5. There are toilets, parking and picnic benches at the start of the walk in Lamaceiros
6. There's a hut halfway along which is a good place to stop for sandwiches. We continued past this through a couple of further tunnels before getting to a part of the levada which was overflowing where we turned back.
7. There's no public transport to the start of the walk so a hire car or tour is the best bet (otherwise you have to walk up from Porto Moniz which would be quite a trek)
reviews/19/text: Another of Madeira's fabulous levada walks. An interesting assortment of plants along the way. Some native ones besides all the invasives.
subcategory_ranking: #30 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Avenida do Mar, Funchal, Madeira 9000-900 Portugal
description: This busy and vibrant boulevard is home to many seafood restaurants and outdoor cafes with waterfront views.
name: Avenida do Mar

offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Christmas Lights Tukxi Tour (price per tukxi - up to 5 people)

reviews/0/text: Lovely promenade in Funchal,  some building work going on building a new marina. What we were not expecting was to see groups of men openly dealing and injecting drugs, in the middle of the day in full sight. Not very pleasant hence my score.
reviews/1/text:
This is the main promenade along the coast of Funchal. There are many statues, sculptures and fountains along the way. Also several cafés, restaurants and bars, but also more peaceful spots with benches amid flowers or small grassy areas to just sit and take in the views. 

One day we strolled all the way from  Fort Sao Tiago at one end, past the marina and walked upto Santa Catarina park, before looping back.

Only a short couple of minutes walk from the Rua Santa María. The main bus stops and the cable car terminal are also just a couple of minutes walk away, so a very central location. There are public toilets near to the main bus stops.
reviews/1/title: We enjoyed several lovely walks along Avenida do Mar
reviews/2/text: Long avenue to enjoy a leisurely walk with the sea on one side and plenty of shops/restaurants on the other.
reviews/3/text: We were on a cruise and wanted to walk the area and see the local shops and eat local food.  We also love to people watch.  This met all our standards
reviews/4/text: There's lots to see along the walk. Ar one end, people go for swims from the rocks. There are lots of statues and busts along the way. You walk on past the cable car station, the location where the catamarans sail from along to the CR7 museum. There are a number of cafes and bars along the way. The wine festival was on when we visited and we spent a very enjoyable night there with music and lots of wine.
reviews/5/text: I'm not sure of the precise length of the Avenida do Mar but it is a great place to stroll along as there is so much to see particularly looking seaward. Our visit was during December so there were additional Chrismas decorations on display. These were particularly good to see at night when they were all lit up.
reviews/5/title: Great place for a leisurely stroll
reviews/6/text: Best place for a sip of poncha, morning or evening coffee and piece of cheese or honey cake. Gentle breeze helps not to care of hot sun… Lazy time to relax.
reviews/7/text:
É muito agradável passear ao longo desta avenida, junto ao mar, com várias zonas verdes. É uma avenida com muita vida (tivemos a sorte de assistir a fogo de artifício à noite, na Pontinha) e por onde passam vários autocarros, que levam a diferentes zonas da cidade. Vale a pena perder algum tempo a passear por aqui.

It is very pleasant to walk along this avenue, next to the sea, with several green areas. It is an avenue with a lot of life (we were lucky enough to see fireworks at night, in Pontinha) and where several buses pass, which take you to different areas of the city. It's worth spending some time walking around here.
reviews/7/title: Um passeio agradável / A pleasant walk
reviews/8/text:
A long avenue running right along the sea front.

There is so much to see and do here, that more than 1 visit is necessary.

On 1 side you have the Marina, on the other side the historic centre. 

All along the way there are various statues to to admire, and a few to ponder; what is it?

The cable car station to take you up to Monte is here as well.
reviews/9/text: Really nice for a stroll along the ocean. Walk along the harbour, buy icecream, so exhibitions and visit the shops along the boulevard.
reviews/9/title: Really nice for a stroll along the ocean
reviews/10/text: Avenida do Mar, as its name suggests, is a long street along the seafront in the Old Town of Funchal. Great views of the sea, historic buildings set back, plenty of restaurants and cafes, multitudes of fine statues and when we were there at the end of the Flower Festival, huge amounts of floral displays, exhibitions and dancing groups performing.
reviews/11/text: Went to see folk dancing and flowers in the road, not impressed.  Road noisy and not beautiful how I had imagined.  Very disappointed. Just for tourist.  Snack bars and ice cream shops, not history about the street.  No street signs or tourist offices
reviews/11/title: Large noisy road and not much planting.  too touristy for me.
reviews/12/text: Pleasant walk, gets very windy, places to drink, have a snack or a rest, not to be missed, but nothing spectacular either.
reviews/13/text: The main promenade along the coast in Funchal, passing the museum dedicated to Madeira football legend, and also passing the marina, although not as grand as some marinas in the world. Plenty of café’s restaurants and bars to choose from, but also just benches to sit and take in the views.
reviews/14/text: I lived in Madeira for 4 months. This is a great place to walk and go jogging but not important to visit on its own.
reviews/15/text: Hotel CR7 was on that avenue that takes you to everything you need to see. How easy is it to manage and where to start? come to Avenida da Mare and you can't go wrong. Restaurants, cafes, street vendors, catamaran boats, central market, everything is there. Just the way it should be
reviews/15/title: A name that says nothing and that is amazing
reviews/16/text:
This major roadway,  Avenida do Mar e das Comunidades Madeirenses, stretches for 1,300 metres along the waterfront in Funchal. 

It runs from Admiral Reis Garden to the east of the City to Rotunda Sá Carneiro, on the west side. It has the statue of Christiano Ronaldo at one end and a giant statue of a footballer at the other. 

It is an amazing Street with so much to see and do, it really does have it all. 

The historic walls of Palicio Sao Lourenco run along the Avenida. 

A number of small parks line the route, Praco do Provo, Praca do Autonomia, Jardins de Teleferico and Jardim do Almirante Reis. 

When we walked along here parts of the Avenida was a sea of blue and white  agapanthus flowers, which just happened to be my favourites. 

Also from here visitors catch the Teleferico Cable Car up to Monte and the Botanical Gardens. 

There are a plethora of statues, sculptures and memorials. Some are more recognisable than other, some are fun others have a more serious message. 

There are a number of fountains along the way as well, but as result of the COVID restrictions they were not working. 

Funchal Marina is also along the Avenida 

This is such an important National Street, that when we visited here on 9th June a stage was being erected as the focal point of the celebrations for Portugal Day, the next day on the 10th June.

There were plenty of seating for visitors to use, maybe give their weary feet a rest or simply just to sit and watch the world pass by.
reviews/17/text: We saw this area a few years ago, just as it was being completed and reopened. The planting has matured and the beds are well tended. Buzzing at Christmas with the lights and stalls.
reviews/17/title: A place to sit and watch the world go by.
reviews/18/text: Lovely to walk its length by the side of the sea. Flat for folks with mobility difficulties with several stops for coffee or a drink.
reviews/19/text: The Avenida is a nice relatively flat promenade along the sea front. There are a variety of vendors selling cakes and ice creams etc.As it was december when we visited,there were lots of horse chestnut stalls which were great.

description: This open market is a hive of activity, noise, color and high-energy, where you can buy any of Madeira's specialties from fresh fish and vegetables to exotic flowers and local crafts. Purchase tropical fruits, vegetables and spices on the upper floor; fish and meat are for sale on the lower floor.
name: Mercado dos Lavradores

reviews/0/text: AVOID the dried fruits stall upstairs. The owner (female, dark hair) was SO NASTY and rude that we didn't even want to buy anything in the end and she left such a sour taste in our mouths. Forceful selling, rude customer service, don't bother even approaching her stall and do not accept any tastings!
reviews/0/title: AVOID the dried fruit stall updtairs
reviews/1/text: Worst fruit market ever. Def do not reccommend. It's way better to buy it from a supermarket. They push you so hard in buying fruit you do not want. I just wanted maracuja and a mango. And i got some more fruit and ending up paying 40euros!!!! Sickening. This should be reported. The fruits you eventually get is so bad as well. I would pay 5 euros for this kind of fruit back home, and I live in the Netherlands
reviews/2/text: Avoid buying fruit here-it is a tourist trap! The prices on the fruit have no resemblance to the price you will pay if they realise you are a trusting visitor. The fruit you are encouraged to try will leave a very unpleasant taste if you then agree to purchase. I thought I was quite a savvy traveller until I met these first class Funchal scammers! Please learn from my mistake-a sad reflection on this resort.
reviews/3/text: Attention !  very expensive, do not buy fruit there, very expensive.  !  around the corner or down the road.  can be purchased 200% cheaper.  and better quality-    ( cheating! !!!
reviews/4/text:
All the stall owners are thieves! Such dishonesty and such a rip off! You choose your fruit only to have then swapped out by the vendors at the back!!
Apalled by all the different disgusting smells all over the place! Definitelt not worth a trip to the "farmers market"
reviews/5/text: Watch out! You can be very easily ripped off, especially on the upper floor where the produce is much more expensive (approx. 3 times) than on the ground floor. It is nice to visit, have a look at the local produce and take some pictures. The vendors try to attract your attention while offering you some fruit to taste, however, the prices are extreme. We came with the intention to buy some fruit to take back home, which we eventually did, but paid 15 euros for 3 small maracujas and one medium size annona (custard apple). When buying, make sure you see the price tag
reviews/5/title: Watch out, you can be easily ripped off. We paid 10 euros for 3 marakujas (passion fruits)
reviews/6/text: People absolutely rip you off in this fruit market. The woman serving us gave a very good talk about the passion fruit etc. She filled a bag with fruit then charged us 29 euros. I could not stop laughing at the fact she thought we were so stupid. I think the police should do something about this. It is abuse and scamming tourists. Everyone has been struggling since lockdown. We all have to work to pay for our holidays. We are not all rolling in money. So please do not take us for mugs. This is a crime. I hope the Portugal police pick up on this and deal with it. You can not say anything bad about people begging in the street as this crime is just as bad.
reviews/6/title: Absolute rip off in fruit market in Funchal
reviews/7/text: don't buy anything from the fruit and spice folks. they are swindlers who pray on tourists. they try to get you hook line and sinker with bubbly personalities only to try and screw you over on the price of goods. nothing is Market with the prices and they seem to charge you whatever they want. don't go here its a complete tourist scam
reviews/8/text: It is a shame as some vendors put extortion prices! give a terrible impression of Madeira, portuguese people and that affects the rest of the farmers, it's terrible! Please be aware of the thieves market stalls!!!
reviews/9/text:
I was astonished to read a number of poor reviews as regards the Mercado dos Labradors.
So many brightly coloured fruit on display, we knew what some were & some we did not. They let us taste the fruit before purchasing  and it was absolutely fine. As long as you monitor what the stall holder is doing you will be fine.
As we arrived at around 11am the fish market was wrapping up for the day, for fish you need to be there at 6am latest.
reviews/10/text: Very clean and pleasent place to discover local food and explore tourist shop. The fresh fish market is very interesting
reviews/11/text:
There’s some lovely exotic fruit on display and they let you taste it, but be careful, this stall switched our fruit between selecting and it getting packed by another guy further back in the shop.
When we got our three purchased pieces back to the ship, one piece had been swapped out for an out of date rotten piece.
The fruit isn’t cheap so we felt it was a bit unnecessary.
reviews/12/text: Tasted pineapple bananas and custard apples , delicious and unusual, many other fruits Iam unfamiliar with . Be warned prices to buy are at least twice what you would pay elsewhere . Taste all the fruits buy something at a reasonable price and go elsewhere if you really want to buy a particular fruit.
reviews/13/text:
Building is interesting, nice azulejos at the entrance.

A lot of exotic fruit and flowers to be admired and which are great for picture taking!

But, beware! Sellers cheat on you as they offer free tasting of artificially sweetened fruit and give you bad quality stuff and you pay a very high price for bad quality (10 times the normal price!).

Walk around, take some pictures, have a look at the fishmarket, go upstairs to see the rooftop café (also overpriced).

Plenty of places in beautiful Funchal where you better follow the locals and buy fruit, flowers.... for a correct price/quality ratio. (Supermarkets like continente are ok).

Visit mercado dos lavradores, enjoy the colourful ambience, take some pictures and bye bye 😉
reviews/14/text:
Just to be sure, this not a real farmer's market. It's colorful and all but seems primarily designed as a one stop Funchal/Madeira experience for the cruise ship crowd. 
Just down the street, two blocks away at the Continente supermarket, you can buy the same stuff at the prices locals pay and on the way you'll see other shops of interest.
Getting back to the tourist trap angle, this place is mostly filled with aggressive, pushy vendors and overpriced merchandise. 
Sure, go there but be aware of what it is.
reviews/14/title: Not a Farmer's Market. Designed For The Cruise Ship Tourists.
reviews/15/text:
This is just a warning to everyone who visits this market, and if you can avoid it, AVOID IT.
The fruit sellers are a bunch of petty criminals, who entice you to taste the exotic fruit, and in a very clever way sell you old, and very, very, expensive fruit.
I know I am an idiot and fell into the trap, but I don't want other inocent people to fall as well.
I paid 40 euros for just a few bits of fruit. One mangoe, one dragon fruit, four little bananas, some berries, and another one that I can't remember the name.
reviews/15/title: Fruit sellers are all thieves 8n this market
reviews/16/text: Wonderful array of fruit and vegetables. Beware you will be offered a tasting of various types of exotic fruits and before you know it, you’ll agree to buy some but just wait until you get the bill which will be eye watering. You will realise that you have been well and truly fleeced but by now you are embarrassingly conscious that you must pay up and put it up to experience.
reviews/17/text: Go in have a look but do not, I repeat do not purchase fruit here unless you want to pay EUR7.00 for 2 passion fruits. Such a shame it's a tourist trap with money grabbing stall holders. Some great photo opportunities and the fish market is interesting.
reviews/17/title: Look but don't buy rip off merchants
reviews/18/text: Bountiful and colorful place to shop, but prices seemed higher than they should be. Vendors seemed more persistent than they should be, at least to Americans. The exotic flowers were so beautiful!
reviews/19/text: birthday trip to Funchal, november, lovely and warm, very warm, we had a hire car and went all over the island, which is amazing, really, good places to eat, nice friendly people plenty of hills to walk up, depending on where you are staying, cable car and tropical gardens are a must see, oh yes the market, good for coffee and trinkets some of the fruit is great but the sales people are persistant so be resolute only get what you absoloutely want and check the price first, by the way the dates were lovely, and the fish restaurants are really good, there is one down in the old town, opposite a couple of indian places which was brill, lovely wine good service and reasonably priced, havew fun and enjoy it
reviews/19/title: should be on your bucket list
