reviews/0/text:
We stopped at this scenic lookout as part of a cruise ship excursion around some of the sights of Madeira. Whilst not as spectacular as some of the mountain views in central Madeira, this one offers some excellent panoramic views across the Funchal valley and the surrounding area. 

There are a few different vantage points and as we only had a short stop I headed to the large viewing area beside the cross and the interesting trees. Well worth a stop if visiting that part of the island.
reviews/0/title: Panoramic views over Funchal valley - worth a stop
reviews/1/text: just stunning views as you would expect and it was fairly quiet but no toilets open. Avoid the cafe there as they charge like a wounded bull
reviews/1/title: Well worth the effort to get up here
reviews/2/text: This is a great viewpoint.  You can see in all directions.  The island is beautiful and this gives you a good overview.
reviews/3/text: We visited here as part of MBTours half day excursion and you certainly get great 360degree views over Funchal, the port and hills inland.  There’s also a bar/cafe just down from the viewing area (also with great views).  Parking seemed sufficient but it probably gets busy with cruise passenger excursions when ships are in port, although there’s plenty of space at the viewing terraces.  Our next stop was the Nun’s Valley viewpoint.
reviews/4/text: We stopped off here on the red bus tour. There are a few viewing points. There is a wonderful panoramic view from up the steps beside the cross. There is a cafe. Unfortunately the toilets were closed when we were there.
reviews/5/text: Pleasant little park with great views over the city of Funchal and out to sea.  It's worth a short stop.
reviews/6/text: We came here on our way to Nun's Valley. The viewpoint provides panoramic views of Funchal, the ocean, and the Desertas Isles. It also has a small cafe.
reviews/7/text:
We walked here from the Lido / Monumental area - its around 45/50 minutes of walking however the key point is that a large portion is uphill with some very impressive inclines. The point itself is over 1000ft above sea level so you get an idea of how high you have to get. 

If you're fit and used to hill walking then don't use the bus or car and walk up - its a great trek. Otherwise, you'll need an ambulance at the midway point.

The view is spectacular across the island but obviously plan your trip with the weather in mind.

Lovely little cafe on top to get a coffee and bite to eat.

A must visit.
reviews/8/text: Excellent way to view Funchal from the sea to the mountains. Islas Desertas can be seen on a clear day. Cafe excellent, plenty seating. Pastel da Nata very good.
reviews/9/text:
One of the most beautiful viewpoints on Madeira island 📸
You can get there with a car or bus ...
Great view on Funchal, you can see all the way to Monte ...
Oh, also very nice "panorama" bar 🔝
reviews/9/title: Beautiful view on Funchal, Monte and Atlantic ocean
reviews/10/text:
We bought tickets on the Yellow hop-on-hop-off bus and this is one of the stops along the route.
The bus stops for a few minutes for you to take photos, but if you don't get off the bus and have a walk around, you are missing the best of the views.
Simply walk up the hill, through the car park and gardens and you come across a viewpoint across the whole of Funchal. It's superb and not to be missed!
There is a cafe at the top - you can sit back and take in these views. Highly recommended!
reviews/11/text: We found this place by accident while travelling back from Valley of the Nuns.  You could easily spend an hour or more here because aside from a fantastic view, there's places to eat, buy souvenirs and walk about the landscaped gardens.  We were surprised how few people were here and it felt more like a park than a lookout.
reviews/12/text: Visited this viewpoint on the Yellow Bus and also when we had a private car excursion.  Did not get off bus so saw only half of view.  Then visited with car and saw the opposite side and also were able to use the free toilets.
reviews/13/text: Well worth a visit on a clear day. Easy to get to if you use the red bus tours, toilets and cafe at the site.
reviews/14/text:
360⁰ panormaa overlooking Funchal and surrounding hills.
Some of the tours stop here (The Nuns Valley).
reviews/15/text: A lovely viewpoint overlooking the city. Obviously valued by locals too. Then to seal our enjoyment the cafe served delicious coffee and warmed custard tarts.
reviews/16/text: of Funchal and of St Antonio, municipality where Ronaldo, the famous football player came from. Great views of the Atlantic Ocean. We were lucky to see a beautiful rainbow across the mountains.
reviews/17/text: Had a quick stop here for some time to take photos of the view  before going  to Nun's Valley. Very good viewpoint for a panoramic view of Fhnchal.
reviews/18/text: Not far from the city, this sightseeing point, in clear days (as it was when I’ve been there), offers you and magnificent view over the city and the Atlantic Ocean. It’s a must while visiting Funchal. Enjoy!
reviews/19/text: If you like walking you should walk up to the viewpoint it is  a great walk it takes  one and a half hour from the city center but it is worth it since you have great view over  the city almost  the whole time and when you are to the top the view is even better

photo/caption: Vereda do Pico Ruivo | Madeira, Portugal
ranking: #87 of 446 things to do in Madeira

reviews/0/text: This is a lovely route. Unfortunately, it was really cloudy the day we visited so the views were not as good as they could be. What a good excuse to come back here!
reviews/1/text:
Before you set off, best to check live webcam for Pico Ruivo, although the weather is constantly changing you don’t want to visit your time coming to the mountain in the fog, like we did.  However, we did not give up and made sure we checked weather forecast and live webcam and yes we made it to the peak.
The walk was not hard for my teenagers and they got to peak in 1 hour and 15 mins. For us, we took about 1 hour and 35 mins.
After the shop/ cafe, the hike becomes more difficult but you can always stop and rest a bit and enjoy the views.
There is a toilet and you need to pay 50c and don’t forget your sun cream ! 
We didn’t drive nor join a tour, we hired a taxi driver and asked him to wait for us and on the way back we asked him to stop at other tourists places.
If you are a group of 4 to 7 people then I believe this is a better option as you have a better control of the time and your plans.
reviews/1/title: PR1.2 Vereda do Pico Ruivo Hiking Trail
reviews/2/text: It is a good walk  up until the "Casa de Abrigo". You should take your time and go easy but steady. The views are great, you are on the top of Madeira, on a clear day. Take lots of water and a hat (if hot and sun), and a coat for the cold days, it can get cold if it is cloudy (fog). The last 100 meters are very hard ... you need to have tracking shoes and be very careful with children. Our two kids (10 and 11 years old) really liked it.
reviews/2/title: The last meters are very hard, but the views are amazing!
reviews/3/text:
As you are able to go by car far, the hike to the highest peak of Madeira from the northern side is only a 1 hour walk on good paths. Starting early in the morning makes sense as often the clouds are coming after noon.
Beautiful view into the surrounded mountains.
reviews/4/text:
The so-called easy way up  proved to be challenging and steep walk up to the mountain's top. It is advisable to dress accordingly (it is windy and gets really freezing cold at the top), and not to be afraid of heights, as the way gets leather "airy". 

Is it worth it to go all the way up? Actually no, as the views after the first 500 meters up from the  parking Lot are the best. There is not not much of a change or an improvement if you climb further, it is rather a psychological thing = there are those who would go up anyway.

I went in December on a rainy day. The weather changed at 1000m altitude.  With clouds below, it was a nice view on a sea if white clouds.
reviews/5/text:
We did this walk again on our last visit in October and were lucky to be free of cloud in decent sunshine  - and its really a great relatively easy walk in good weather. This is my second review as I wanted to update my previous review in 2017 as there have been some changes. Unless you go on an organised trip you will need a car and although the route from Funchal is not obvious - we managed to use google maps to find it without too much difficulty. The drive from Funchal itself should take around an hour (depending on where you are staying) and you need to get on the main highway that takes you past the airport, then Machico and you need to get off after Porto da Cruz at a roundabout junction where there is a Continente supermarket (hopefully you will be able to spot it in advance providing you keep your eyes peeled). When you get off at the junction turn left and you should drive past the supermarket (which will be on your left) and keep going up hill - you are aiming for a car park at the Archado do Teixera -which should take you around 15-20 minutes.
The dirt car park is basically at the end of the road and is level and free. There are no toilets at the car park but they have now built a hotel with restaurant nearby where they charge 1€  to use their toilet (whether you use the restaurant or not!). The car park its surrounded by bushes and shrubbery and most hikers previously used this for cover if they need to relieve themselves - because after this there aren't so many opportunities. However, there are signs prohibiting this now - so they clearly expect you to now pay for the toilet! Its not a difficult walk being paved for most of the way making walking easy, but it is a climb (330m vertical ascent) so be prepared if you are not used to it. The trail splits towards the end where you need to go right which soon takes you past a white house where there are toilets (and you have to pay again I think) and you can also get refreshments here - plus there are now tables and chairs as they have refurbished the place from old. If you go left instead of right on the trail you are on a hard walk over to Pico do Ariero that currently involves steep climbs and descents and is a much more challenging prospect. From this point (the white house) its a short but quite hard climb to the top where there are three lookout points giving you great views on a clear day (make sure you keep left at the first junction you meet otherwise you will end up on another trail.

It took us around 3-4 hours with some stopping.

Would only recommend it if you have good visibility and if you go on the off chance be prepared for bad weather. When I was on an organised trip many years ago walking from Pico do Ariero over to Pico do Ruivo I was caught in lashing wind and rain on the way back to the start of this walk and despite all the right gear was literally frozen - and this was in October when everyone in Funchal was in shorts and sandals - so beware. [as a foot note to this warning - we returned a couple of days after our successful trip in October 2019 to be met with lashing rain as we entered the car park - so we turned around and drove to Canical to get some sunshine and dry weather!]
reviews/5/title: Best route to the top of Madeira
reviews/6/text: Stuning scenery and very steep heights. Took some nerve as someone who is a little vertigo. It was worth it nevertheless, one of the best things to do in Madeira. I wouldn't go for it if weather conditions weren't great though.
reviews/7/text:
Also known as Highest Peaks. In this journey you can visit the three highest peaks of Madeira: Pico do Areeiro, Pico das Torres and Pico Ruivo. 

This is a mountain trail so it requires some physical preparation and endurance for hikers, who are faced with many ups and downs. However, the effort required is offset by extraordinary views that the walk provides. In sunny days, you may have a 360 degree view of the island with its main points highlighted: Curral das Freiras, Porto Santo, Desertas, Ponta de São Lourenço and others.

Length - 15 km; Time - 6 hours; Difficulty - Hard
reviews/7/title: PR1 Vereda do Areeiro - Pico Ruivo
reviews/8/text:
We did this walk a couple of times on our last visit in November and were lucky to be above the clouds in beautiful sunshine each time - so when its like that its a great walk. However, unless you go on an organised trip you will need a car and although the route from Funchal is not obvious - we managed to find it without too much difficulty. The drive from Funchal itself should take around an hour (depending on where you are staying) and you need to get on the main highway that takes you past the airport, then Machico and you need to get off after Porto da Cruz at a junction where there is a supermarket (hopefully you will be able to spot it above the motorway providing you keep your eyes peeled). When you get off at the junction you need to drive past the supermarket (that should be on your left) and keep going up hill - you are aiming for a car park at the Archado do Teixera -which should take you around 15-20 minutes.
The dirt car park is basically at the end of the road and is level and free. There are no toilets at the car park but its surrounded by bushes and shrubbery and most hikers use this for cover if they need to relieve themselves - because after this there aren't so many opportunities. Its not a difficult walk being paved for most of the way making walking easy, but it is a climb (330m vertical ascent) so be prepared if you are not used to it. The trail splits towards the end where you need to go right which soon takes you past a white house where there are toilets (but you now have to pay - I think) and there are no longer any refreshments here (so take what you need with you) - (if you go left on the trail you are on a hard walk over to Pico do Ariero that currently involves steep climbs and descents and is a much more challenging prospect). From this point (the white house) its a short but quite hard climb to the top where there are three lookout points giving you great views on a clear day.

It took us around 3-4 hours with some stopping.

Would only recommend it if you have good visibility and if you go on the off chance be prepared for bad weather. When I was on an organised trip many years ago walking from Pico do Ariero over to Pico do Ruivo I was caught in lashing wind and rain on the way back to the start of this walk and despite all the right gear was literally frozen - and this was in October when everyone in Funchal was in shorts and sandals - so beware.
reviews/8/title: Easiest Route to the Top of Maderia
reviews/9/text: One of the best things I have saw in Madeira, the nature is so beautiful, lot of flowers "above the clouds". Have a  flashlight as you need to go tunnels and sometimes it's totally dark inside.
reviews/10/text:
Ignore the title, this is the walk, route PR 1.2 to the summit of PICO Ruivo, the highest point on Madeira. 

First, you need to get there, by car (as we did, a one hour drive from Funchal) or there are various organised walks, with bus to the site included, by taxi and I think there may be a public bus. It is an interesting last 7km up the mountain, but the road is quite wide enough for two cars. The hydrangea hedges and other flora are spectacular on the way up (and down).

There is a good car park at the site which is level and free.

The walk starts easily enough and is paved for most of the way making walking easy, but it is a reasonable climb (330m vertical ascent) so a fair workout, but we saw all abilities make it to the top where the views are brilliant. There are three lookout points at the top which give you views to all four points.

There is a toilet about 2/3 the way up close to where the trail splits, but no refreshments so take everything you need with you.

We recommend an early (ish) start, we got there at 10:20 and by the time we were coming down 13:00) it was getting pretty busy. 

Because of the mix of abilities/fitness, there can be a couple of bottlenecks on the upper parts where it gets a bit narrow and steep, but everyone is good natured.

Routes 1 and 1.1 are also accessible from here and look exciting but we didn't have time that day.

Like all mountain trails, weather is key. There are shelters on the mountain but keep an eye and prepare accordingly (I know, grandmother and sucking eggs!!). It also is fully exposed so sun can be fierce.
reviews/11/text: Lugar incrivel. Depois de se parar o carro, anda-se um pouco ate se atingir um sitio onde rapidamente percebe que ja estamos acima das nuvens. La no alto, a experiencia é irrepetivel.
reviews/12/text: Après une marche magnifique, vers le restaurant, ayez encore le courage de monter pour voir cette vue! En plus, il y avait un peu de brume donc c'est magique.
reviews/13/text:
Wir hatten hier einen tolle Wanderung vom Parkplatz zur Spitze und zurück. 
Die Wanderung ist auch für Ungeübte zu machen. Es sind nicht einmal 6km und 430 Höhenmeter zu überwinden. 
Der Weg ist durchgängig präpariert und einfach zu gehen. 
Man sollte aber vorher nach der Wettervorhersage schauen. 
Wir waren um 11 Uhr am Parkplatz und es war schon ziemlich voll. 
Wir hatten tolles Wetter und konnten bis nach Porto Santo schauen.
reviews/14/text: Íbamos hacia la Achada do Teixera y no podíamos ver el bosque de Laurisilva por las nubes. Una vez que deje el coche en la Achada e inicié el sendero hacia el Pico las nubes iban y venían. Sendero bien marcado y de fácil acceso hasta 500 m antes de la cima( donde está el bar con la terraza). A partir de ahí escaleras y subida en picado. Ya estaba por encima de las nubes. Una vez en la cumbre 1861m aparecían los Picos Areiro y Encumeada sobre las nubes. Los últimos 500m cuesta, pero merece la pena, ¿Que vista tiene que verse en un día claro?
reviews/14/user/user_location/name: Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain
reviews/15/text:
Mooi aangelegd pad, soms flinke treden te nemen maar goed te bewandelen.
Ga goed voorbereid op pad, kan kan flink fris zijn,  zeker op bewolkte dagen kan het koud aanvoelen en nat zijn.
Ondanks dat wij een erg bewolkte dag zijn gaan wandelen kunnen we het aanraden toch te gaan bij veel bewolking.  Het  landschap heeft dan een heel eigen sfeer die wij erg mooi vonden.  Helaas dan dus geen verre uitzichten op een dergelijke dag maar nog steeds de moeite waard.
reviews/15/title: Mooie wandeling,  let op het weer!
reviews/16/text: Не стоит тратить время и ехать по плохой дороге. Вид не очень. Ещё и надо идти 3 км. Очень холодно. Есть Pico Do Arieiro он лучше в сотню раз.
reviews/17/text: Vyšli jsme z parkoviště (zdarma) pod Pico do Ariero po desáté dopoledne a vrátili jsme se  před patou. Trasa podle ukazatele je 5,6 km jedním směrem, mě sporttracker i krokoměr udávaly spíš kolem 7 km. Většina trasy je buď klesání nebo stoupání, většinou tak prudké, že jsou tu schody. Pouze prostřední (asi 1,5km) část je celkem rovná, s několika tunely. Často se jde ve velkých výškách, je tu ale zabradlí. Pod vrcholem Pico Ruivo je chata, kde si můžete koupit např třetinku piva (4€) nebo vody (2€). Vodu ale můžete doplnit i z kohoutku před chatou. Šli jsme v srpnu, bylo vedro, takže možnost doplnit vodu před cestou zpět jsme ocenili. Výhledy (i přesto, že pod námi byly po celou dobu mraky) jsou nádherné.  Celý trek je nezapomenutelný zážitek! Doporučení: nezapomeňte hodně vody, svačinu, opalovací krém, dobré boty, baterku a bundu ( l když my šli celou dobu v tilku).
reviews/18/text:
No se como será en otras condiciones más pintorescas desde luego, con condiciones perfectas y calor, me ha resultado una decepción, ni las vistas son espectaculares, ni el camino en sí (escaleras 80% del tiempo) me ha parecido increíble e imprescindible, de hecho si te encanta (pero mucho) el trekking bien, sino coge el coche y vete a ambos picos y disfruta, porque esta ruta no es disfrutona.
Decir que estoy en buena forma física y se me ha hecho dura, aviso a navegantes.
reviews/19/text: De wandeling gaat over een mooi aangelegd pad naar de top van de Pico Ruivo. Onderweg liepen we door de wolken, maar op de top hadden we prachtig uitzicht over Madeira! Het pad is goed aangelegd, bij eventuele splitisingen staan paaltjes. Op 2/3e naar de top een huis waar je drankjes kunt kopen en waar een toilet is. Het is wel een populaire (drukke) wandeling.
reviews/19/title: Mooie wandeling naar de top van de Pico Ruivo (PR 1.2)

ranking: #45 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #45 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Very centrally located and an easy walk from the cruise port, the Funchal Cathedral is the main religious building on the island. Apparently it is also one of the few buildings that has survived colonisation. The altars are magnificent and the wooden carved ceiling is amazing.
reviews/1/text: Sé Catedral was built in the 15th century and is located in the heart of Funchal Old Town on Rua do Aljube. The cathedral of Funchal has an ornate ceiling carved from local cedar wood. We took a couple of photos when walking past but didn't think it worthwhile to spend very long here.
reviews/1/title: Very centrally located, but nothing special in our eyes
reviews/2/text: The cathedral is situated in the heart of Funchal. It is well worth a visit and will not take long to look at the various chapels & stained glass windows.
reviews/3/text:
I popped in to Funchal Cathedral during a walk around the town just before Christmas 2022. The town was adorned with millions of lights and loads of decorations and the cathedral had its own small festive displays. 

The cathedral is free to enter and (like most cathedrals) even if you are not overly religious, you have to admire the sheer beauty of the decoration and construction. 

This cathedral dates back around 500 years but is virtually unchanged inside. Well worth a look.
reviews/3/title: Small but pretty cathedral in central Funchal - worth having a look
reviews/4/text: We were walking back to the cruise terminal when we came across this beautiful small cathedral. We wandered in and there was a service being performed so we quietly walked around the side of the pews to take in the statues and motifs. The fact that the service was going on in the background as we strolled around made it quite captivating.
reviews/5/text: Small cathedral with very beautiful ceiling.  Subtly decorated for Christmas.  Just a short stop on a Tuksi ride, would go back to fully appreciate if return to the city
reviews/6/text: This late 15th-century Gothic cathedral was built using thousands of blocks of volcanic rocks carried from the cliffs at Cabo Girão. The interior is quite beautiful, having three naves, arches, several chapels, Moorish motifs, and beautiful gold statuary as well as an altar decked in gold.
reviews/7/text: When looking around outside it does not convey how beautiful the Cathedral interior is, it is so beautiful.
reviews/8/text:
A lovely place to visit whilst wandering g around Funchal.
Beautiful interior. The organ was being played when we visited which was lovely
reviews/9/text: The cathedral is a lovely looking building and the inside is just superb. There are a lot of interesting and pretty chapels and shrines. A lovely place to visit.
reviews/10/text: The main altar is beautiful and very ornate. There are also a lot of side altars which are also very decorative. Interesting that the Cathedral is used for Catholic and Anglican services. Nice place to visit.
reviews/11/text:
Small cathedral that I looked at whilst walking past.
Fairly Central  twixt old and new Funchal.
A good way to pass 15 minutes or so
reviews/12/text:
Funchal Cathedral is relatively small as cathedrals go, but well worth a visit. A little bit away from the main tourist area, it is mainly locals that you will encounter inside.
Not as riotously decorated as many churches in Spain or Italy, but beautiful, with many fascinating side altars. A great place to sit and meditate in lovely surroundings away from the crowds
reviews/13/text: Went today (sunday) when it opened to the public between 430 and 730pm. We were a few minutes early and there appeared to be a service on. The interior was very nice. However, i then noticed my guide book suggested going to a service when this otherwise dark church is lit. There were lights on each of the side altars which added to the beautiful appearance. Don't forget to look up at the carvdd wooden ceilings. The very plain exterior gives no clue as to what lies within.
reviews/14/text: When we went mid May the ceiling was totally covered which I understand is the cathedrals main selling point! Whilst it would have been nice to see the rest of the cathedral is still nice to walk through.
reviews/14/title: A nice cathedral to look in
reviews/15/text:
Funchal Cathedral is a walk of only a few minutes, all downhill, from Good Memories Lodge.  The gothic style cathedral is mainly  whitewashed on the outside; on the inside the decorations are many but not cluttered as is the case with other gothic churches and cathedrals that we have visited around the world. There is an immediate calm when entering the nave that is large but not vast. Quaint but not awe-inspiring. 

We visited on Easter Saturday with no suggestion  of a fee for entering. There cathedral is also a superb backdrop for those all important holiday snaps.
reviews/16/text: Make sure you go inside this beautiful Cathedral. For the outside it looks quite plain but the interior is stunning.
reviews/17/text: The outside of the cathedral looks ordinary but this belies the splendour inside. The Church has been carefully restored over the last few years and is definitely worth a visit. The ceiling is fascinating and displays a North African influence. We were there for Sunday Mass and they have a superb choir.
reviews/17/title: A stunning Church which has been recently restored
reviews/18/text: Following a walk around the town decided to visit the cathedral. Mass was taking place and so we sat through the service and then walked around. Impressive and stunning
reviews/19/text: Beautiful cathedral ,In the process of renovations but this is necessary and does not impinge upon the glory of the building .Please remember that this is a place of worship and not just a tourist hot spot .When i was at mass with my husband and went to light candles i was appalled by the inappropriate behaviour of some of the tourists  during mass .They were speaking over the priest and as the congregation were praying they seemed oblivious to their lack of manners in a religious environment .I was embarrassed as a foreign national .The locals seem to be resigned to it but we found it pretty awful. Please be respectful and quiet it may not be everyones "thing" .However if someone is in there having a look around during mass some respect does not go amiss.I visit every year and this is not just a one off incident it is very much ongoing .

address: Funchal, Madeira Portugal
name: Zona Velha
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Old Funchal Walking Tour

ranking: #29 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #29 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
Many of the streets in Funchal are pedestrian, which means strolling around the typical Madeiran pavements made with pebbles very easy and safe. We spent hours walking around Old Town (Zona Velha) taking lots of photos and discovering hidden little places.

On Santa Maria Street nearly every other door is painted with a different design. They’re all unique and very colourful. They are a hundred or more different ones to find, some down side alleys and some on the main street. You can easily explore for half an hour or more, before stopping to enjoy a meal at one of the many restaurants you'll find along the way.

Many many restaurants here in old town (reviewed separately). We enjoyed all our meals especially at Basmati Indian restaurant. Most of the street is pedestrianised and some restaurants are set up outside right in the middle of the street, so it can get a little crowded in these places where the street becomes much more narrow. The cobble alleys at the back of the restaurants seemed very crowded to us, with people constantly squeezing past the packed tables, so we opted for restaurants that opened out onto the front, so we had more space and privacy.

We visited on 2 separate occasions, earlier on the morning is much quieter, before the restaurants open up, but later on there is more atmosphere if it does get a little too crowded.

Remember to try Bola de Caco everywhere you eat in Madeira! This is the local flatbread often served with meals. It is often covered in garlic butter - basically a flat garlic bread but sooooo good!

Zona Velha) is just  short couple of minutes walk from the seafront and the Avenida do Mar. The main bus stops and the cable car terminal is also just a couple of minutes walk away, so a very central location. There are public toilets near to the main bus stops.
reviews/0/title: lots of walking to explore the old town and the nearby seafront
reviews/1/text: Zona Velha is also known as the old town. It consists of a few criss crossed streets that  are full of bars, restaurants and numerous pretty individually painted doors. It is also a great place to people watch. If you visit Funchal you really should go for a drink or a nice meal.
reviews/2/text: Just spend your time in the day wandering the narrow lanes, lots of restaurants and  bars, does get very busy later in the day and when the cruise liners dock.
reviews/3/text:
This is the place to be in Funchal. Lots of truly nice (not just touristy) restaurants, also some shops and bars. I basically came here everyday during my stay on Madeira.

And those painted doors are marvellous! Come early in the morning, while everything is closed, otherwise you won’t be able to see this beauty.
reviews/3/title: Come early in the morning to see the painted doors
reviews/4/text: The old town is a great place with a few interesting things. It is a great place for a meal with loads of restaurants of all types all vying for your business. There are also a large number of painted doors which are very interesting and well worth the trip. If you need food, drink or even a souvenir shop this is the place.
reviews/5/text: We both really liked the place because it was quirky and artistic with its’ gaily painted doors, lots of nooks and crannies , plenty of cafes  and generally pleasant atmosphere. Best part of Funchal
reviews/6/text: The artistry of the various painted doors sprinkled thoughout the old town adds a nice touch of whimsical charm to a delightful pedestrian-friendly neighbourhood.  Narrow cobblestoned streets come alive at lunch and dinner time with streetside tables for dining al fresco.
reviews/7/text: We were lucky that we had chosen a hotel in the Zona Velha rather than the over-touristy Lido area. It meant that we were right by all of the interesting parts of Funchal - the Farmers' Market (Mercado dos Lavradores), the marina, the old cobbled pedestrianised streets with their wonderful street art, old buildings, statues, floral displays, churches, the cathedral, outdoor exhibitions, the Fort and countless great restaurants, cafes and bars.
reviews/8/text: The old town is definitely the most picturesque part of the town, well worth a visit and a meal there too as the choice of restaurants is just amazing.  Don't forget a stroll to the Fort for amazing pictures of the bay.
reviews/9/text: During Christmas, the cozy old town of Funchal is redesigned as the very City of X-mas. Tons of Christmas decor in every little street, thousands of lights in the night, it’s like a movie … I wonder how it looks the rest of the year…?
reviews/10/text:
No visit to Funchal is complete without a stroll around the Old Town. So on Wednesday 9th June we spent a couple of hours walking along the cobbled streets exploring and sightseeing 

The Old Town or Zona Velha stretches from the Mercardo de Lavradores (Farmers Market) as far as Fort of São Tiago ( Fort of Saint James). 

It was so enjoyable walking through the narrow streets lined with cafes, bars, restaurants, artisan and gift shops. Keep an eye out for the Duck Shop, a bit of fun. 

We thoroughly enjoyed visiting Capela do Corpo Santo and Igreja de Santiago Menor, two beautiful Churches. 

We did stop for a short rest and a beer or two at Tapas do Anibal, more local trade than tourists. 

One of the many highlights of Old Town is a walk down Rua Santa María to be amazed by the incredible street art. 

Nearby Praca do Autonomia are Forte Novo (Ruins). 

The Funchal to Monte Cable Car Station is also located in the Old Town. There are a number of statues and monuments dotted about the place.
reviews/10/title: So much to see and do - a definite must do
reviews/11/text:
Nice place with many pretty murals. You may be bothered by restaurant's staff but just say "no, thank you." 
In my opinion, Funchal is a nice town. I was enjoying that place a lot. 
Quite a few homeless people and beggars but they are not annoying and often hide. 
I recommend Madeira to everyone :-).
reviews/11/title: I actually loved Funchal and Madeira :-)
reviews/12/text: In general in Madeira there is not much to see. That said, The old town of Funchal is not bad. There is not much to see but a must if you visist Madeira.
reviews/13/text: A great place to look around with lots of nice restaurants and locals going about their business undisturbed by tourists.
reviews/14/text:
I love to go to a traditional Portuguese restaurant as it is the only in Madeira Island - "Sabor a Fado" restaurant - you can eat a very good meal while you listen to Portuguese Fados live!!!

Also, I found a new restaurant, in Portugal we call it a "tasca" - with very good local food and cheap. Please go to the "A tasca da Maria".
reviews/15/text: You can't say you have seen Funchal unless you have wandered through the Zona Velha. It's a small but vibrant part of the city with plenty of cafes, restaurants and bars. The painted doors are lovely and worth the walk alone. Do go as far as the bright yellow fort (Fortaleza de Sao Tiago) which in itself offers some great views.
reviews/16/text: So nice to see this characterful quarter being gentrified in a sustainable way. Lovely to wander around and lots of shops, bars and restaurants to keep you entertained.
reviews/17/text: It is worth taking time out and having a walk from the old fort down the street down towards the indoor market. There are lots of cafes and restaurants.
reviews/18/text: Admittedly touristy with a great number of very similar restaurants with very similar menus, many with people outside trying to pull you in, but entertaining nevertheless. A lot of the house doors have been brightly painted with some fairly artistic murals.
reviews/19/text: We really liked the painted doors in the area and the colourful vibe with all the bars and students around, however, just like anywhere else that's in all the guidebooks there's lots of tourist traps. You're constantly pestered by the staff trying to entice you into their restaurant so best to pick one to relax (prices are touristy of course).
reviews/19/title: vibrant and colourful but a bit of a tourist trap too

address: Caminho da Padaria, Curral das Freiras, Camara De Lobos, Madeira 9030-311 Portugal
description: The "Nuns Valley" is a small village situated in the crater of an extinct volcano, which has kept its 16th-century Santa Clara Convent where the nuns used to hide from pirates who were attacking Funchal.
location_string: Curral das Freiras, Camara De Lobos, Madeira, Madeira Islands
name: Valley of the Nuns
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Madeira Valley of the Nuns Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Nun's Valley Open 4X4 Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Nuns Valley Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Madeira Nuns Valley Sightseeing Tour from Funchal

ranking: #18 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #18 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: If you go early in the morning you will miss the coach crowds from the cruise ship in Funchal. Stunning views from the top, an excellent viewing platform to cater for the crowds. Worth stopping off at Pico Dos Bacelos on the way to enjoy the view of Funchal. Do get a coffee in the shop and sit outside to enjoy the views
reviews/1/text: If you do one excursion whilst in Madeira you have to do this one. The views on the way up are astonishing and the town itself,Curral de Freiras,has a number of restaurants to help you soak in the views. We were lucky as the sun was shining when we went but I wouldn't want to do this trip on a cloudy day if visibility is poor.
reviews/1/title: Fantastic views of the Nuns corral
reviews/2/text: Great view point at eira du serrado, then walk down the path to Currel do freiras. Relax with a beer, then a 50 min ride down on the hairy bus tour
reviews/3/text: With knee problems making going down stairs more troublesome than going up, we took the decision to get the bus down from the hotel and walk back up. We are so glad we did it that way. There were plenty of corners and switchbacks to stop and rest if needed, even a picnic table half way. We purposely went slowly and it still only took us an hour and a half (plus an additional 15 minutes worth of stops). Of course there were people going much faster, in both directions. Good luck to them. We took the opportunity to look around us and enjoy the view, not just look at our footing the whole time. In fact, there were sections where the people coming down were slipping and struggling, whereas going up felt stable. People thought we were doing something hardcore, whereas especially in hindsight, we are certain that going up is easier.
reviews/3/title: Recommend Walking Up if only going one way
reviews/4/text: This was a lovely morning. Half a day to see spectacular views and visit a small village steeped in history. The driver/ guide was very informative and was appreciated by all of  the customers.
reviews/4/title: Pleasant way to spend Sunday morning
reviews/5/text:
Nice spot to visit on a clear day.   The village in the valley has some good places for eating and some souvenir shops. They offer some nice dishes with chestnuts, and you may visit an old style home of the nuns, fully maintained and authentic, with all the home interiors.
The is a very good viewpoint overlooking the valley from the Estalagem Eira do Serrado Hotel, just turn left before entering the tunnel, on EV6 .

There are several hiking routes you can take if you have the time, all will give a great view of the valley and surrounding peaks
reviews/5/title: Nice village in a beautiful mountain area - central Madeira
reviews/6/text: It is well worth a visit and worth climbing the steps and going up to see the views. Leave the car behind and take your time if you are able as the views are fantastic
reviews/7/text:
Stunning scenery in this mountainous part of Madeira...we didn't visit the village itself but admired it from high above using the excellent viewing platform and restaurant facilities at Miradouro Eira do Serrado which overlooks this tiny village located in the bottom of a volcanic crater. 

Visibility was a bit hit and miss due to the low clouds passing over the mountains and it could change dramatically within minutes, indeed when we got there the view was clear and five minutes later the passing cloud had obscured most of the view...it cleared again shortly afterwards.

Well worth a visit if you want stunning scenery and have a clear sunny day.
reviews/7/title: Amazing views of this village in a volcano from above
reviews/8/text: We visited in January, which is probably not the best time of year for the flora, but the Christmas nativity displays in the church are absolutely stunning and may even be better than the one in Funchal. The small cemetery was also of interest. The views are really spectacular, although there are no level walking trails. A very interesting bus ride from Funchal, and a peaceful and relaxing place with a few interesting shops, cafes and nun's house display.
reviews/9/text: This was so cool to see. A village in the crater of an extinct volcano! When looking down at the village, it's way-y-y down there. We saw it around the middle of the day when there was a lot of sunlight and it wasn't overshadowed by the crater walls.
reviews/10/text:
Lovely village with excellent views, nice shops and cafe.
And visit the hotel at top of mountain for first class views of surrounding area.
reviews/10/title: Lovely village and excellent views from hotel at top
reviews/11/text: We were brought here as part of our escorted tour to the Island - what stunning views - essentially in the middle of nowhwere in the middle of nowhere.  Stunning!
reviews/12/text: Amazing that people actually live in such a remote area. We saw this valley on a jeep tour and saw it from the west side of the valley in the am, causing  half of the valley to be in shade . To see the valley in full light a mid day visit would be needed
reviews/13/text:
Absolutely stunning! 
If you want to see clouds going through the pass and pouring into valley you are in exact spot. The valley is surrounded by mountains from 4 sides and looks amazing. Plenty of chestnut trees and eucalyptus on the way.
To get here you can take direct bus from Funchal center - it is coursing all day.
Also in the town you can find unique liquors from Madeira that are hard to get anywhere else.
For easy walk I reccomend the way from Eira do Serrado to the bottom of valley. 
If you are achiever you can try hike to Pico Ruivio via PR 2 Vereda do Urzal which starts in this valley.
reviews/14/text: Get bus 81 from funchal (opposite Savoy at 9:00). At Curral das freiras switch to small bus up to Faja Escura. Take road up hill soon becomes a track at sign for Pico Grande.  Long haul up hill with great views. When it flattens out go past Pico Grande sign - unless you fancy a scramble up and back. Go to the junction and turn left then straight to Boca Corrida. Down from carpark to Mario’s bar to await the 96 bus back. Note time on timetable is when bud will go past then wait and return 15 minutes later   You may have to swap busses half way home but next bus will be waiting and use the same ticket. Can get off at Savoy.
reviews/14/title: Walk from corral das freiras to Boccaccio corrida
reviews/15/text: We'd hired a car so happy to drive out and look at the views - not much in village itself but we had a coffee and it was a really enjoyable trip - stunning views.
reviews/15/title: Stunning views - not much in village but worth a trip
reviews/16/text:
The drive up to this village is beautiful, at least those parts which are not in tunnels
The village itself is in a valley surrounded by towering mountains. There are small picturesque streets and some souvenir shops selling local artifacts and liquors
reviews/17/text: Travelled out to the valley in our hired car . Difficult to find , sat nav useless as are the road signs.  But a marvellous place and well worth a vist .
reviews/18/text: Beautiful location with lovely mountain scenery, small museum and church, also pretty little shops to look around in the village.
reviews/18/title: Well worth an excursion to enjoy the views.
reviews/19/text:
Despite the fact this small village is located in an amazing gorge, there is nothing to see or do there.
To drive all the way up to Eira do Serrado and overlook the village, though, is an experience not to be missed in Madeira.
reviews/19/title: Not worth the drive at all
subcategory_ranking: #18 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rua Garcia Moniz 1, Canical, Madeira 9200-031 Portugal
description: The Whale Museum in Madeira is currently one of the most innovative museums of its kind in the world. Holder of a valuable museographic collection, this space rigorously documents the history of whaling in Madeira. Through stereoscopic 3D movies and among models of whales and dolphins in full size, visitors can learn about the life of these fantastic creatures and their marine environment in a fun and interactive way. The Whale Museum also promotes research on cetaceans and its preservation and study  of the history of whaling in Madeira.
name: Museu da Baleia da Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Wheelchair Handicap Full Day East Tour Santana Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Wheelchair Handicap Tour Full Day To Kids
ranking: #42 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #42 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
We came to visit since it was raining outside. The museum in itself is in good condition but we did not expect it to be mostly on whale hunting. It is good to explain the practices that were used years ago by whale hunters and how was used the whale itself after it was killed. However, glorifying the fact that it was a difficult job and that “hopefully, no man died while hunting” was a bit indelicate. This museum should focus more on raising awareness about sea life and why we should protect it at all cost rather than anything else. 
Overall disappointment.
Also, 10€ for the entrance it too pricy
reviews/1/text:
Whaling happened, times have changed and now it is important to educate why it is inappropriate.  This museum does the opposite and glorifies this sad part of Madeiran history.  Celebrating the names of the whalers should not be done. 

The section on the science of the whale is more interesting, but the films would be better just in normal imaging rather than a poor attempt at 3D.  No hands on sections so quite dull for young children.  Wouldn't recommend or go back.
reviews/1/title: Glorification of the whaling industry = unimpressed
reviews/2/text:
Really interesting to learn about the whale hunting industry in Madeira and how it developed.  Liked the old black and white films of how they caught and processed the whales and learning about all the uses the meat and oil was put to.
Bit sad to hear how many whales were killed but impressed by the bravery of the men who went out in small boats to capture these huge animals.
We got the service bus 113 from Funchal to Canical and it took about 1hr 15mins.  Some hairy twists and turns on the roads but passed through lots of small towns we wouldn't have seen from the motorwary.
reviews/2/title: Very interesting history of whaling on Madeira
reviews/3/text:
This is a top level museum in terms of audio visual and displays.  A museum about the cruel practice of whaling is always going to be grim, you expect that, but I did not appreciate the museum’s tone of national pride about Madeira’s history of whaling.  I totally appreciate that times and attitudes have changed and you can’t judge the past by today’s standards, but I feel that the museum should have done more to acknowledge the barbarity and destructiveness of whaling.  They could do this easily by re-recording the narration of the displays and videos.  
The second stage of the museum about marine mammals and evolution is much more accessible and enlightening, but it was a distressing experience overall and we left feeling sickened frankly.
reviews/3/title: High level exhibits let down by not acknowledging destructiveness of whaling.
reviews/4/text: The museum gives a very realistic picture of the history of Madeira. This is the way people lived, nothing was wasted, all of the animals is used. This even if it is not pk today..
reviews/4/title: A good way to learn about Madeiran history
reviews/5/text: Surprisingly good.  First part is about whaling, which I only had moderate interest in.  The second part is about whales and is presented as various videos, some 3D.  You can watch as much or as little as you want and there is a huge amount of interesting scientific information contained, should you choose to watch it all.  I found the evolution section and comparison of body structures between whales and humans fascinating.
reviews/5/title: Very informative and engaging presentation (for adults anyway)
reviews/6/text: Huge building with very little in it. Not really worth the money. A lot of films (pretty bad 3 D) but not a lot to look at otherwise. Films were interesting, but I don't need to go to a museum for watch a documentary. Children (12 and 14) were not impressed. It might have state-of-the -art technology, but I we thought it was a waste of money and all the media and audio guides that start automatically, are not necessary. On the plus side, staff were very friendly and there were only a handful of visitors, so lots of space. Would not go again and would not recommend.
reviews/6/title: Huge space with very little in it
reviews/7/text:
Yes yes, everybody knows that hunting whales is a bad thing. Still this museum does an outstanding job in bringing close whale hunting to the visitors. It describes and shows in detail in a non-judgemental why it was done, how it was done and by whom it was done (until it stopped a few decades ago). That part is important for us to understand, also as it makes us realize how much the world has changed since then. 
The permanent exhibition on whales with the different movies (you got your own headphones that pick up the relevant signal at every movie or exhibition item) and your 3D glasses, is done very well and insightful too. Our teenagers loved it too and the way of showing and delivering this content is compelling. We warmly recommend this museum.
reviews/8/text: This large modern museum is dedicated to the whaling industry of Madeira and for ongoing scientific research of whales..Entry is 10 Euro or 8.50 for seniors.Audio guide in your language included in the price and a cafe on site.Some of the information went over our heads, but a different experience and overall we enjoyed our stay of about 90 minutes.
reviews/9/text:
This was on our 'things to do list' and overall we are glad we went, that said tears could be evoked in young children visiting.  As the title says - mixed feelings.

The museum is bright and airy with plenty of space.  There is free parking in the adjacent car park.  The whole site is disabled friendly with full access available.  The museum enjoys wondrous views, across the ocean towards the deserted islands (Las Ilhas Desertas)  This is a paid activity - see website for current admission costs - and as it is mainly inside, it would be very suitable for a rainy day.  All of the exhibits and displays have details in Portuguese (naturally) and also English (very helpful to many tourists) besides which there is an audio 'wand' included in the price of admission which guides you around in several languages.  Back in the day (and not that long ago either) Madeira had a whaling industry.  Canical, where the museum is situated, became the centre of this industry.  You can, if you look hard, see bits of architecture that are from this period in the history of the island.  There was a fascinating account of the, substantial, pressure exerted by tourists, for this industry to cease.  Many, many letters and postcards flooded in from across the globe - eventually resulting in the cessation of commercial whaling in Madeira.  Some of these are on display - don't think that small actions can have no results, this display proves otherwise.  The museum does not shy away from this subject (commercial whaling) and makes no apology for this part of Madeira's history.  Lets not forget that other countries participated in whaling too - Whitby (England) has a couple of whale jawbones making an archway overlooking the North Sea.  There are full size boats on display - imagining people setting sail in these small craft is quite frightening.  One swipe of a whales tail......... Its not just whales that the museum looks at, there are full size models of other marine life - giving a real feel for just how large some of them are.  We particularly enjoyed the interactive experience of going inside a craft which can  dive down to the ocean floor, looking at the creatures at various depths.  We learned why those black scabbard fish (Espada) are black.  Today, one of the problems that Madeira (and indeed the whole world) faces is pollution from plastics.  Right outside the museum is an artform made from waste plastic items encased by wire mesh, in the shape of a whale.  See photo.  Plastic waste in our seas and oceans is killing marine life.  There is a display listing just how long some items take to degrade in the sea - this was an eye opener too.  Just like those pioneering tourists (every postcard made a difference) YOU can do something to help this current plastic problem.  Reduce, reuse, recycle.  Please dispose of your waste plastic in an environmentally friendly manner.  There are several  topics within the museum and you could stay longer than the 1-2 hours suggested, although interest levels, particularly in younger children, would start to wane.  There's a nice cafe within the museum selling a range of items.  We took ours outside, since it was a nice day, onto terracing overlooking the Atlantic Ocean and reflected on some of the exhibits. 
 Spotless toilets and a well stocked giftshop

Interesting exhibition on the history of whaling in Madeira.  Some exhibits are however quite brutal.  Spotless toilets.  Nice cafe.  Wondrous views.
reviews/10/text: Nice museum that gives interesting information and history on the whaling business in Madeira. Quite clean and informative, great for kids and adults alike.
reviews/11/text: Small and modern museum about the history of whale catching. It is no longer practiced in Madeira since 80s. Anyhow, part of the island’s history.
reviews/12/text: My wife and I decided to visit this museum expecting it to focus solely on Whales. Not so it is splitting 2 floors, one all about whales, not bad but mostly on screens and the other about the short-lived whaling industry on Madeira. This had more hands on exhibits and talked in detail about the industry. We spent twice as long here. They explained why it grew up, what it was like and what they did. The industry was wrong but the people involved did not know that. Their lives were hard and dangerous.
reviews/12/title: A whale museum with a different point of view.
reviews/13/text:
Having had a lifelong interest in whaling but never been a supporter I must stress, I was really looking forward to visiting this museum and it was top of my “must do” list whilst in Madeira.
I must be honest and state that it was disappointing in the extreme. To describe this as world class is a bit of a joke. There are much better such museums in Norway and Hull Town Docks museum has a far better section on whaling with better exhibits and atmosphere. 
Basically it’s a huge building which must have cost millions of euros with very little in it.
The staff however, all 5 or 6 of them with virtually nothing to do, were very helpful if only to give good directions to the bus out of the place.
Shame on the guidebooks for the exaggeration.
reviews/14/text:
The history of whaling is interesting. Good exhibits. Extremely annoying audio guide which has a automatic feature which means that it jumps to a different topic if you move. It would be better if it was only manually controlled. 
The museum was almost empty. I suspect this may be due to the fact the Whaling is no longer considered acceptable.
A second room with marine life exhibits and films. Technology in this room rather dated.
reviews/15/text: Our visit in Museu da Baleia da Madeira took 1 hour but one could spend there more than we did. The exposition shows the history of whales fishing in Madeira. Audioguides give the information automatically according to the place where you stop. It is very interesting and educational place! The entrance cost 10,-EUR.
reviews/16/text: The audio headphones give a full and interesting insite to what the museum is all about. With interesting artifacts and video content, this museum is well worth a visit for the 10 euro entrance fee..
reviews/17/text: The history of whaling was interesting and upsetting.  The 3D videos of whales swimming etc were great.  Worth a visit wasn't expensive.
reviews/17/title: Interesting look at whales and the history of whaling
reviews/18/text:
We visited the museum during a day trip to Caniçal - the entry fee was 10 Euro each and you were given a headset and audioguide to wear as you walked around. The soundtrack could be selected manually or it would change automatically as you changed areas.
The museum explained the history of whaling in Madeira and how Caniçal became the main centre for the whaling industry on the island eventually building a whaling factory to process the catch.
With scale models, boats, whales, tools used in the industry it gave a fascinating insight into the whaling industry. Some of the film / video footage was quite barbaric showing the chase once the whales had been spotted, the harpoons being launched, and the whales being cut up back at the factory.
As someone who has seen sperm whales close up I found myself both admiring the bravery of the men who set out in small boats to capture the whale, and horrified at the way in which these magnificent animals were butchered at the end of the chase.
Thankfully whaling in Madeira stopped when it became unprofitable and now the story is told via the museum - definitely worth a visit - it will take approx 2 hours to complete the tour of the museum.
reviews/18/title: Very good museum - worth a visit
reviews/19/text: Excellent for all the family. Great audio tour with adult and child versions. Friendly staff. Really good portrayal of whaling history. Very informative whale and marine conservation areas too. Definitely visit this museum.
reviews/19/title: Excellent balanced museum on the history of whaling and on going marine conservation
subcategory_ranking: #42 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Ponta Do Sol, Madeira Portugal
location_string: Ponta Do Sol, Madeira, Madeira Islands
name: Levada do Moinho
photo/caption: Tolle Wanderung entlang der Levada Moinho und der Levada Nova in Ponta do Sol.
ranking: #68 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #68 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: We started walk at 5 at evening and finished at 7.30 route was very easy to follow and doesn’t require any special skills or good physical level of fitness. In some parts railings were missing but I was was able to go by no problem even I’m scared of heights and suffer with vertigo. Lovely views all way up to waterfall. We didn’t do full circle but came back same way.
reviews/1/text:
Among the worst hikes I've done in my life! The Levada Nova had several parts with NO railings at all and steep precipices on one side. One stumble and you die, no kidding. 

Not a hike for the inexperienced, and not if you are afraid of heights (or dying).
reviews/2/text:
I did the hike in early September when conditions were fairly dry. I got dropped off at the starting point of the hike where there was a climb up to join the levada. Good to follow the signs carefully until you get on the right path. 

There are some up and down sections to start with but then it broadens out with wider paths and nice views. There were a few turns where it was helpful to have a map (or I found the WalkMe Madeira App helpful).

There was one tricky bit where there was either a practically non-existent crumbled path around a drop or a kind of narrow walkway across. I held my breath and went across the walkway! Apologies I didn't take a photo of that section. Apart from that it was a relatively gentle hike.

I got picked up from where the levada met the main road. I think you can go on further though.

A very enjoyable hike, and one which I felt comfortable doing alone (although after doing a couple of others with a guide and with good local advice for this one). Would love to do it again!
reviews/2/title: Tranquil walk, not too steep and narrow
reviews/3/text:
Despite the rather frightening description in older guide books, this is a beautiful and safe walk. The vegetation does not encroach on the path, which is mostly good to walk on (with sensible shoes, of course) and has a guard rail all the way. 
I would avoid walking down to Ponta do Sol, but arrange a taxi or get a lift as it os an extremely long and steep route. Rather spoils the point of a levada walk!  
The Levada Novo, which runs above is more modern concrete but is scary if you don't like heights and the guard rail - such as there is - is dodgy in parts.
reviews/4/text: Very nice levada walk fresh air and lots of trees i suggest you go for a walk get ready to take pics and enjoy nature...after sun goes down it can be really chilly
reviews/5/text:
This is an in and out trail unless you take the stairs near the end which is a must do to join Levada Nova.  This takes you to the falls which are spectacular!
What we did was park at the church, go to the back and up the steps to the start of the trail.  The trail hovered the side of a canyon with some drop-off sections but not dangerous as the wire rope fencing kept us safe.  The trail is mostly dirt and rock.  We could see Levada Nova above us at times.  Great views all along the trail with a nice picnic stop about ¾ of the way down.  We went up the steps to the falls and back to the church via Levada Nova.

If you suffer from vertigo, I suggest you do not do Levada Nova as it has steep drop-offs without any rope fencing in places.   What you can do is go to the falls then turn around and head back the same way you came along Levada Moinho.  
Both trails not busy when we went in January.  You need a flashlight for the tunnel along Levada Nova.
reviews/5/title: Canyon trail with a wow factor
reviews/6/text: This is a great walk that can be reached by bus. From the bus stop we walked up the road for about 20 min until we rea had the levada Nova. We then took this and walked up a beautiful valley with great views. The path was clear and not many bumps. While often there were rails, this was not always the case - so may be a challenge for those not liking heights. We walked along until near the top of the valley there was a tunnel flowed by a lovely water fall, very beautiful. A lite further on the top.of the valley is reached. At this point one desends to the levada Moinho and take the walk back to the village. Each levada is about 30m height difference, but the views and feel of each levada were very different. At the end of the levada we went back down the hill to the bus stop (designated by two yellow lines on the road). This is a relatively short walk but it packs in a lot- this is a great walk.
reviews/7/text: It can be reached by car to some extent, and then you have to walk a lot. The road passes through such a beautiful terrain that it will stun you, and the final destination is worth all the effort to climb up
reviews/8/text: We started this trail at the Church of the Lombata in Ponta Do Sol, and it is listed as an 8.5 Kilometer/5.3 Mile hike, but we ended up with 9/6, and every part of this hike was breathtaking. In all of the literature we went through before coming to the island, it details a long loop trail starting and ending at the church. The hike is mostly flat, with an altitude change of 100 meters/300 feet in the last leg of the hike. We decided to do the loop in reverse of the recommendations to do the altitude first, then mostly flat back to the church. And this was by far the best way to approach it, not because the altitude change is difficult in any way (it is on paved roads, and easily maneuvered in either direction), but the first sight of the falls at the far end of the loop when arriving is most certainly the best way to discover them. You know you are almost there when you reach a tunnel. The view as you exit the tunnel is straight out of a great novelist or artists mind. It was so amazing that we laughed when we first played back the GoPro video I shot while passing through exit of the tunnel and I said “Oh Wow” out loud unintentionally. It is truly magnificent, we got to the trail head at 8am, and were alone on the trail out, and were alone at the falls the whole time we were there. We sat and marveled at the site from the many places available there, and from behind the falls themselves as the Levada trail is carved out of the rock as a passageway going around and behind the falls. The little canyon the falls are in is very unique and beautiful, and the falls are a not to miss while living place. We also recommend doing the altitude first is that at this point you will also have done the most challenging part of the hike first, due to most of it is walking along a two foot wide concrete Levada wall that also passes along multiple spots of sheer cliffs. You are walking along with 200 to 500 meters of oftentimes near sheer drop of a cliff on your left, and with only intermittent guide wire rails. It is not for anyone with vertigo issues, but also not too much for an avid hiker. The views are consistently so amazing that you are nearly unable to worry about the trail. The trail back starts with some rock stairs down to the Levada that brings you back to the church (actually pops out in the church yard). This part of the hike is equally as wonderful as the first half with water stairs, and descents that are a real treat as you follow the water on this part.
reviews/9/text: This time I went solo and used it as walking meditation.  The ability to stop now and then and just take in the sound of nature was bliss.  The waterfall and tunnel is the climax of the walk.
reviews/10/text: Great Levada, you park by the church and old school, then walk up about 500 meters to the levada Nova this is the hardest part, once on the levada its all flat. after the tunnel and waterfall you come to some wooden steps where you walk down to the levada Moinho, where you will then finish back at the church by your car. Takes in total 3-4 hours with a picnic stop
reviews/10/title: Excellent walk and good for first timers
reviews/11/text: A great walk along the levada in the north west of the island. We went with Sara and Lido tours and had a fabulous day. Very informative. We would highly recommend this walk.
reviews/12/text:
We walked this Lavada on 5/8/18 and to be fair to the authorities they had closed it but the barrier had been removed.
The Lavada does have 2 footpath collapses after 1 & 2km approx. Both are passable with care but you will be exposed briefly.
We climbed up to the Lavada Nova to see the waterfall and found stretches of the barrier missing. We felt more exposed here.
All in all the walk was excellent. Early start recommended so you can do most of it in the shade.
reviews/13/text: Please beware that a part of the path is broken off. We started the path at the church this morning and found that after about 1km a 2.5-3m gap appears in the path. We did not deem it crossable and turned around. All that remains is the ledge of the levada and the levada itself. We encountered people working on the path a bit closer to the church and they were not aware of it.
reviews/13/title: Path broken off after 1km from church
reviews/14/text: Had a very lovely morning walking to levada do moinho. It was BEAUTIFUL -so many different landscapes and views! There were railings the majority of the way and only a few occassions where we had to walk a thin bit. One of us has a severe phobia of heights and although he was nervous to start with, he enjoyed the walk. We turned back once we reached levada do moinho instead of continuing to levada nova which was recommended to us due to the fear of heights.
reviews/14/title: Beautiful, easy, good if have a fear of heights
reviews/15/text:
At the beginning of this trail stand out the well cultivated farmland, providing a pleasant sight to walkers. Among them stand out the fantastic panoramic views of the valley and the beautiful village of Ponta do Sol, that this route offers us.

Enjoy the walk and all that it has to offer. Delight yourself with the sights, the endemic flora and fauna and waterfalls.

By the end of the route you can climb the path that leads to the Levada Nova. Once there, follow the opposite direction until you reach the impressive waterfall of this Levada. It is certainly a fascinating vision that deserves a few moments of contemplation before continuing.

Length - 9 km; Time - 4 hours; Difficulty - Moderate
reviews/16/text: The hike offers amazing views and a great variety. Unquestionnably the highlight is the waterfall which appears after one has crossed a 200m tunnel. Further on the path leads you below the waterfall
reviews/16/title: Wonderfule hike, but be free from giddiness
reviews/17/text: sometimes sunny, sometimes foggy, sometimes dense forrest, sometimes burned forrest, sometimes jungle, sometimes typical european forest, meadows, relics from ice age, few waterfalls and cascades.. many stairs along the way... a bit harder to get to the levada (into two houses near the village center)
reviews/18/text: We started this levarda walk on the levarda nova and joined this walk to make a circular walk. We parked at the church and walked up the hill to the start of the nova trail. The walk was beautiful with breath taking views and the waterfall was glorious I enjoyed this walk as I think it encapsulate' s the best in a levada walk. Would walk it again. Should wear long trousers in summer as could get ticks from the vegetation.
reviews/18/title: Beautiful levada walk with breath taking views.
reviews/19/text:
Eine der schönsten Levadas die wir gewandert sind
Die Ausblicke welche man hier hat sind einzigartig
Der Weg ist zwar sehr schmal aber meistens mit Geländer
Für den hin und Rückweg haben wir ca4 Std. benötigt.
Man kann den Rückweg aber auch über die Levada Nova bestreiten, ist aber anstrengender da ca 100 Höhenmeter
subcategory_ranking: #68 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rua da Praca, Santa Cruz, Madeira 9100-166 Portugal
name: Municipal Market of Santa Cruz
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: South East Tour Sunday from Funchal
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: traditional Farmers Market Open 4X4 Half Day Tour
ranking: #133 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #133 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: When walking along the adjacent Promenade we popped into the market to see what was available to purchase. We were staying in a hotel in Funchal for a week so buying some of the excellent looking fresh fish was certainly out of the question. However we did make a couple of purchases including a relatively inexpensive bottle of Madeira wine from one of the better known producers.
reviews/1/text: classic art deco market in old town, may not be the cheapest place to but stuff but it is fresh  and has loads of atmosphere
reviews/2/text: The market is between the old city and the downtown. If you walk by it you should enter even if you are not interested in doing shopping. It’s like a show-room of the local products where you can find fruit, fish, handicraft, among other things. Enjoy!
reviews/3/text: it really isnt worth the effort to get there a few fish,fruit and veg and empty stalls .out side on the sea front was quit nice but again not really anything to talk about .will not go again .
reviews/4/text: Just a small building with a few little shops/stalls. Things like fish, fruits, vegetables and souvenirs are on sale. Toilets and a place to buy hot food are also there. The Santa Cruz market isn't worth a trip, but the Funchal market & Santo da Serra market have much much more to offer.
reviews/4/title: Small and Not Much Going On
reviews/5/text:
We went to the market 4 times on are 2 weeks holiday the best day in Friday lt more going on large fish market down stairs fruit and veg middle an top floor as well leather goods toilet are all on top floor there is a great cafe on the top floor near the toilets 
Good food and very pleasant people we are on a cruise in 3weeks and will look forward to another visit
reviews/6/text:
I feel like it is still a place you should go just to see it, the fresh fish market is very interesting. It is however, very crowded and touristy. Most of the vendors are selling the same things, when you walk around they all try to get you to sample. 
The sad thing is that after exploring here we went across the street to a large grocery store and found a wider range of fruits and vegetables at better prices than this market.
reviews/7/text:
Like other reviews, the market is a massive con where the vendors let you taste the fruit which, from their samples are sweet and delicious. However, when you taste the fruit you buy it is bitter and inedible.

Furthermore, the pricing is simply fraudulent where they charge you for the for what appears to be the price per 100 grams.

We picked however the word forced would be more appropriate, 2 passion fruits, 2 dragon fruits and 4 bananas (which were a freebie) and were charged €26!!!

Avoid this place like the plague!

Madeira is a great place to visit and this is the only place I would recommend avoiding. Or if you do go, don’t buy anything.
reviews/8/text: We have travelled the world but never previously seen some of the fruit in this market. The flowers are also wonderful and lots of ugly fish to gape back at.
reviews/9/text: This was a very interesting visit, the fruit and vegetables were of extremely good quality and value.  The flowers were beautiful and exotic.  The fish catch of the day varied, some of which we had not seen before
reviews/9/title: Interesting to see all the local produce
reviews/10/text: Fruit tasting interesting but we didn't like most of it! You can refuse to buy if prices go up when you are about to buy, and then they often go down again. Lift to first floor, where there are free toilets. Wine shops on ground floor surprisingly reasonably priced.
reviews/11/text: As a disabled traveler it is often difficult to see everything able bodied people do. However the fruit market was a revelation and had a handy lift too ! Beautiful produce and traders keen to give a visitor a taste of their wares. Saw unknown fruit and got a taste of one that’s a mix of pineapple and banana ! Wonderful ! Dates bought though a bit pricey. Chilis ready to buy too.
reviews/12/text: An interesting place to wander round but quite expensive to buy anything, having said that it is worthwhile to visit.
reviews/13/text: A few fish that looked tired, a wine shop, a greengrocer and a tourist tat shop is about all that there is, hardly a tourist attraction! Not worth the walk, and we only stayed across the road.
reviews/14/text: The fresh fish market is extensive, and fun.  Vendors will describe their catch and you can watch them slice and prepare the cuts.  The flower and vegetable market is very large and busy too.  Again, there are an incredible variety of items, with friendly vendors.  It is a good place to buy fresh fruit for snacks during your vacation.  The vendors will give you a generous sample, and the items are inexpensive to purchase.  Enjoy!
reviews/14/title: Great Marketplace of the Best of Madeira's Banquet
reviews/15/text:
This is a fascinating market with gorgeous displays of flowers, fruit and vegetables, not to mention the very interesting fish market on the bottom floor.
However, beware of the ‘freebies!’ Lots of stall vendors will be very willing to give you a sample of fruit or vegetables to taste, but they do expect you to buy after you try!! 
A great place for people watching and photo shoots; just be a little wary!
reviews/15/title: Lots to look at, but beware!
reviews/16/text: Nice market with a very nice outdoor play area for kids up to 8 years. It has a nearby cafe for parents to relax while kids run around in a gated playground with new play equipment.
reviews/17/text: Unlike the much larger market in Funchal, no one bothered us and we were free to wander around and enjoy looking at everything. Lovely mural on walls inside and out.
reviews/18/text:
this is a excellent place to visit - either just to look at what is available or to buy if you are staying locally 
the fruit and veg are very fresh and not expensive. the fish is very good but if you want fish you need to shopin the morning.
reviews/19/text: best fish market i have ever been too , so clean - ALL fresh , reasonable priced and will too sell smaller quanties as we only wanted a few for a BBQ
reviews/19/title: AMAZING - every type of fish going
subcategory_ranking: #133 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: C. C. Monumental Lido 1 Floor, Shop 23, Funchal, Madeira 9004-541 Portugal
name: Madeira Explorers
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Rabaçal / Risco / 25 Fountains Full-day walk
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Full-day Walking Experience in Pico do Arieiro
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Half-Day Paradise Valley Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Referta / Castelejo 2-Hour Hike in the North Coast of Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Walking Experience in the Serra D'Água Valley
ranking: #14 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #14 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
On this years visit I did two walks with ME, the first to Wind Lagoon and the second Larano.  My wife does not like heights, so I joined the groups on my own.
The first was very pleasant, with a bit of a climb back from the Wind Lagoon up to a higher Lagoon where we stopped for lunch, which was nice and peaceful.  The Larano walk was also good, although it started with a steady climb and included more vertiginous parts.
It is a wonderful way to spend a day, in beautiful landscapes with many stunning views.
Margarita (hope I have the name right) was informative and friendly.
Two good days and I am looking forward to next year for my next Madeiran explorations.
reviews/0/title: Two good walks, Wind Lagoon and Larano
reviews/1/text:
Picked up from hotel by Maria, fabulous all day walk to see Lavada's and waterfalls
Excellent pace, all good walkers in our group so no waiting around for unfit people in the wrong shoes
reviews/2/text: We did two half-day walks - Mimosa Valley and Paradise Valley.  Our guide was Adriano - he was excellent and had a wealth of information on the plants and trees along the way, He was amusing, funny and made sure all the group enjoyed the walk.  Wouldn't hesitate to recommend this company.
reviews/3/text: Yesterday afeternoon I went by their office and booked Ribeiro Frio to Portela walk for our last day here. Afterwards I learned from another operator that this walk was closed. I asked the representative about this. After checking she came back to me and confirmed the hike was going to go as scheduled. This morning they came to pick us up, only to inform us the walk was closed. Instead they ofeered us another one we had not heard about. The fair and professional thing would have been to inform us at least last night. This is not down to weather or things like that. The government page on the levadas was updated early yesterday evening, and it stated that the walk was still closed. What Madeira Exploreres do is a very bad way of trying to fool people.
reviews/4/text:
I did 2 walks with Madeira Explorers, Fanal and the Peaks.  I went with Madeira Explorers as my wife does not like heights and so I would have been on my own otherwise.
The Fanal walk included quite a way walking through the woods as well as some higher paths with great views, although by lunchtime the cloud had spoiled some of these.
