address: Caminho do Pedregal Ribeira da Vaca, Ponta do Pargo, Calheta, Madeira 9385-269 Portugal
location_string: Ponta do Pargo, Calheta, Madeira, Madeira Islands
name: Vereda da Garganta Funda
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: South + Sunset tour - 4x4 - Small Group
ranking: #97 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #97 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
A short walk from the very small parking lot takes you to an amazing view point overlooking a waterfall flowing several hundred meters, and from the other side you can see the cliffs towering over the ocean.
Walk back is uphill and a bit challenging but certainly worth it
reviews/1/text: This is a little bit out of the way on the east of the island. We went out of our way to go to it and I personally wouldn't go again. If you're passing, its a nice spot, but there's only space for about a few cars, it's quite difficult to find and quite a barren walk to the viewpoint. The viewpoint is quite far away from the waterfall itself and the waterfall was quite narrow when we saw it. Of course it's pretty, I just think by comparison to everything else we did on this beautiful island, it wouldn't be my first choice by a long shot.
reviews/2/text: The view is breathtaking, really great viewspot. The waterfall was not really a fall but assume it is due to the season. There is a small parking lot, but not big. Recommend to park in the village and walk- about 1 Kilometer.
reviews/3/text: Waterfall viewpoint is off the beaten tourist track and just as well as there’s not much in the way of parking.  Park if you can just before the dirt track begins and it’s then around 200m further along.  The track is very uneven and a bit steep towards the end,  so you’ll need to check your footing unless wearing decent shoes.  Unfortunately we visited in October and the fall was more of a trickle but no doubt it is spectacular in season.  Even so,  I still felt the effort worthwhile.
reviews/4/text: When hiking in Ponta do Pargo make sure you stop for a quick visit to this waterfall- Amazing view and easy to reach
reviews/5/text: Better to see in winter season. The waterfall was almost dry. It is 10 minutes far from the road. The pavement is dirty, muddy and loose.
reviews/6/text: Short walk from limited parking brings you to a viewpoint overseeing the waterfall. Further short walk takes you to the edge of the cliffs. No access to walking further along the cliff edge.
reviews/7/text:
This is a waterfall on a cliff inside a gorge. You can see it from above so it looks like it is in a hole. The surroundings are very beautiful, you can see from here the lighthouse too. And it is very quiet. We spent about an hour there and there were only 2 other people that came.

You can drive until almost there. There is like a small(2-3 cars) parking lot before the trail starts. The trail is a dirt road, almost flat, that takes about 4-5mins of walking. You have signs for it too. At the end there is a viewing platform there.
reviews/8/text: The Garganta Funda ( Deep Throat) waterfall is located in the parish of Ponta do Pargo, in Calheta. The walk is short and view is stunning. Worth visiting.
reviews/9/text: The walk is short and the scenery is stunning, lush green with wild flowers and you walk beside may fields being tended by local people. The waterfall itself is beautiful and just below the viewing platform you can climb down to a nice warm place to rest on the grass with the blue sky and sea all around you.
reviews/10/text: Don't miss to see these cliffs and this coastline. This is one of several stunning viewpoints along the west coast of Madeira, and - in my humble opinion - the best. Not just because of the views north and south, but also because of the nearby lighthouse and the restaurant (separate review) that make this a simple visit, but one that nestles itself in your heart and memory!
reviews/11/text: You can drive down to the viewpoint or drive down to the lighthouse from the village. The scenery is stunning.There is a walk that links the viewpoint and the lighthouse which is about 1 km each way.
reviews/12/text:
The area round these cliffs and the lighthouse offer spectacular views of the Atlantic and the scenery is quite stunning. There are lovely walks along the cliffs and if you are lucky you will see the Bertholet's Pipit - a rare bird found only on these islands. 

The cliffs fall away sharply so anyone who is a bit spooked by heights should stay away form the edge!

Well worth the visit although you really need a car to get there from Funchal.
reviews/12/title: Great views - watch out for vertigo!
reviews/13/text: Cascata imponente, mesmo não tendo água em Agosto de 2022. Ainda assim, adorei a visita. A caminhada faz-se bem, cerca de 600 m por terra batida, de grau de dificuldade fácil. A vista é deslumbrante e ainda é um local relativamente pouco conhecido. O estacionamento pode não ser fácil, e pode ser necessário deixarem o carro junto à estrada principal, o que acrescentará cerca de 500 m ao percurso.
reviews/14/text:
Cascata de fácil acesso de carro através da Via Rápida. O caminho faz-se bastante bem. Para estacionar é mais complicado, mas onde houver um espacinho deixem o carro. Nós deixamos junto a uma árvore e fizemos o percurso a pé. São cerca de 600m para cada lado e vale a pena.
O trilho é em terra batida e pedras, mas faz-se bem. 
A vista compensa.
reviews/15/text: É com muita pena que vejo um Mirador, com vista para bela cascata da Garganta Funda, e um vista mar belíssima, num estado degradação. Tudo o percurso em terra batida é com cada vez mais vegetação de ervas e silvas por todas as partes.
reviews/16/text: É uma das vistas mais deslumbrantes, é uma paz interior, que nos precisámos para desanuviar fora da vida profissional 😘
reviews/17/text: O percurso lentamente vai revelando a "cereja no topo do bolo". É realmente muito bonito e interessante. Em caso de chuva desaconcelho a visita.
reviews/18/text: Dá até medo do precipício, principalmente que estava ventando muito quando visitei, mas valeu a pena. O local é lindo
reviews/19/text: O Miradouro da Garganta Funda fica em Ponta do Pargo, na Calheta. O trajecto faz-se a pé e demora cerca de 7 minutos entre a vegetação e oceano Atlântico. Deslumbrante a vista sobre o oceano e o verde da terra. Pena a queda de água não ter água. Quanto ao mais, é um sítio pouco visitado, logo mais "virgem", mas que devia ter mais segurança. Vale a pena!
subcategory_ranking: #97 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rua dos Ferreiros, Funchal, Madeira 9000-082 Portugal
description: Founded by royal charter of D. Sebastiao in 1569, the Jesuits' College of Funchal marked, throughout the centuries, the lives of the inhabitants of Madeira Island. For more than 400 years of history, it served a number of tenants, from British invaders to the University of Madeira, coming to serve as a military facility and a number of schools. Despite its military applications, it has always kept a close relationship with education. Portrayed as "one of the most remarkable buildings that exist in the island" by historian and professor at the University of Madeira Rui Carita, the Jesuits' College of Funchal is the stage of a cultural and scientific awareness project lead by the Students' Union meant for both local residents and visitors of the region. The inauguration of another Gaudeamus - AAUMa Academic Store at the entrance of the College was the starting point of its opening for the general public. Added to it was a circuit of autonomous tours of the College, as well as monthly gatherings for Coimbra Fado and a service of guided tours, whose circuit includes reserved areas of the University of Madeira Rectory, among others. The Students' Union has also published The Jesuits' College of Funchal - A History, by Rui Carita, a book that narrates the history of the College, its tenants and its transformations throughout the centuries. These are projects that, above all, show the spirit of this institution, which benefits from a precious asset both scarce and undervalued in this country; the volunteer work and the dedication of a solid team. Everyone's contribute will be vital, even if in the form of a simple visit to our store. Only then will we be able to continue financing all of the projects that we have to offer to both our associates and the population, whether free of charge or under a symbolic price.
name: Colegio dos Jesuitas do Funchal
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Old Funchal Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: The Mysteries of Funchal Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Best of Funchal private walking tour with local specialities tasting
ranking: #20 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #20 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: We visited the church. The main altar is magnificently ornate. There are a number of lovely side altars too. The sun shines in a stained glass window to leave a lovely colourful design on the pews. For €1, you can visit the tower which has more information, storage of the crib figures and outside to great views.
reviews/1/text: The Colegio das Jesuitas hosts the rectorate of the University of Madeira. It has a charming inner yard and the old building is perfectly adapted for meetings and also has a very attractive dinner room. The souvenir shop deserves a visit. But the main attraction, which should not be missed, is the church (it faces the very nice square), so beautifully decorated, in a typical Madeira style. It makes you feel being in heaven!
reviews/1/title: A must for a visit to Funcahl!
reviews/2/text: Passing by, we heard beautiful singing and went to look.  This is a most beautiful church and well worth a visit.  The tower is open to visitors for a (small) fee although we did not take advantage of this!
reviews/3/text:
Lovely chance to say a prayer for those who have left us
Remembering the lives of those who made Madeira great
Loved lighting a candle to remember  my loved ones
reviews/4/text:
My wife and myself are currently holidaying in Madeira and during our Old Town Walking Tour earlier today (see separate Review) we not only visited the Jesuits College but this was both the starting and end point of the Tour!

As such, it is dIfficult not to be impressed with the Building facade but the end of the tour included an inside tour of the Church which is truly magnificent. By all accounts it took centuries to complete with no cost spared.

Hopefully, this comes across in my photos but - in practice - it has to be seen at firsthand to truly witness what is, without doubt, one of the Island’s finest buildings!
reviews/4/title: Eye Catching Building but even more impressive inside!
reviews/5/text:
The facade is magnificent, so is the typical Jesuit interior of the church.
Drop in when you are in the neighborhood, it is worth the effort
reviews/5/title: Magnificent old church in the old center of Funchal
reviews/6/text: A majestic building which contains a beautiful interior church which is so much prettier than the 'normal' Baroque style of the period. Endless fine details of the artistic panels making up the interior. Very well worth a visit - doubly so as it is a free visit! An additional visiting area is at the rear which forms (I understand) part of the university.
reviews/7/text: Beautifully decorated and serene inside. Access to the roof was on the rear-left after entering. Well worth the visit.
reviews/7/title: Beautiful inside and roof worth visiting.
reviews/8/text: This is the finest church interior in Madeira, better than the Se (Cathedral), and all the other lesser ones.  The artistic and religious cycle is complete and undamaged, and in the finest condition.  The effect is sumptuous and breathtaking.  You need 30-40 minutes to appreciate its complexity. The liturgical scenes are easily understood, too.
reviews/9/text: Interesting building in its own right but also provide other historical tours of city hall, main church etc. City Hall very interesting with good knowledgable guide. Well worth the visit
reviews/10/text: The church is exquisite and you need to go to the roof to see the view of the city from the top.  Take you mobile and do a panorama
reviews/10/title: Visit to the roof is recommended
reviews/11/text: Beautiful, really enjoyed this visit interesting whether you are religious or not, worth a visit its part of the history.
reviews/11/title: Tuesday afternoon, walk about in Funchal
reviews/12/text: We visited this college and church and were impressed by the stunning ornate detail.  Entrance is free and there is the option of climbing the tower for a €1 and this gives you a good view of Funchal towards the harbour and the mountains.   The description of ‘tower’ is more a roof terrace but worth the climb.
reviews/13/text: A small but warm and very friendly educational institution. Students study in small groups by experts professors.
reviews/13/title: A warm and friendly educational institution
reviews/14/text:
The Jesuit College  is now the administrative centre for the University of Madeira . The church, although part of the building, no longer belongs to the university and is completely independent of it.  

The college was founded in 1569 and until the C19th was the largest building on the island and built round two courtyards. It was responsible for educating boys until the Jesuits were expelled from the island in 1760. 

It is a simple white building with dark basalt surrounds to the windows. An archway leads into the main courtyard with a well. Off is the shop and cafe.

Audio guides are provided in English, German, French and Portuguese. On Saturdays students run guided tours lasting 90 minutes. I joined one of these and was the only person on the tour. The guide was extremely knowledgeable and I learnt a lot not only about the Jesuits but also the history and economy of Madeira.

I was shown around he corridors surrounding the main courtyard which was used by the students. The Jesuits sat at window seats and watched the students and ensured good discipline. The smaller courtyard was used by the priests and is private.

I went into what is now the general council room but was once part of the library. This was designed with a domed ceiling which amplified any sound however quiet. - a good way of enforcing silence... 

This was a very worthwhile visit.
reviews/15/text: If you are in Madeira and even if you are not religious in any way a visit to this fantastic church is a must. Everybody who can should take time out to sit quietly in the pews to admire the hard work- commitment- skills- dedication- attention to detail needed to produce such amazing works of art .... do not miss the chance to visit if you are in Funchal
reviews/16/text: The college itself is now part of the university and there is little to see apart from the main courtyard.  The main attraction is the church which is next door (see separate listing).
reviews/16/title: The main attraction is the church!
reviews/17/text: We took 2 guided walking tours of Funchal (€10 each). The guides are volunteers and the money goes to help Erasmus students. We also took the self guided audio tour of the college and church.  We were very fortunate to attend the wonderful performances by 4 groups and an individual singer on 16th March, and also on 23rd with Fatum and Rosa in the square. Such a treat. Look out for advertisements for the fado group Fatum.  Information at the 2 Gaudeamus shops inside the college and La Vie shopping centre.
reviews/18/text: One of the many buildings worth visiting in Funchal. From the putside, the building has a very characteristic facade, and inside you find a lot of beautiful artwork. Don't miss it!
reviews/19/text: Just wow, there was a service on when we arrived and the church was packed.  We waited until it finished and wandered inside, it is stunning, so ornate, the gold, the paintings, statues, carvings, the craftsmanship was outstanding so beautiful.
subcategory_ranking: #20 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: ER207 Madeira/Cristiano Ronaldo International Airport, Santa Cruz, Madeira 9100-105 Portugal
name: Busto de Cristiano Ronaldo
ranking: #329 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #329 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Our taxi driver was explaining to us about all the things that had been named after Cristiano Ronaldo, so I suppose a photograph had to be taken.
reviews/1/text:
This statue is situated just outside the arrivals doors at the airport named after Cristiano Ronaldo.

Good to see the Madeiran authorities are trying to milk this mans fame to promote the island. 

It is soo bad it could be anyone - even me!!!
reviews/2/text:
The bust of this famous Maderian footballer is situated outside the arrivals hall of the airport, which is also named in honour of the footballer.

When we arrived it was not possible to get near the bust, hence the rubbish photo, it was by the COVID health check and testing area, so all a bit busy. It did not seem appropriate to push through just to get up close.

Suppose it is a sign of the times but someone had put a coloured face mask on the bust. Let's hope when visible again that it bears more resemblance to Ronaldo than the larger statue of him in the Port area of Funchal.
reviews/3/text:
Good idea how to make Ronaldo more famous...
Nothing much to say about this attraction, just take a picture a front of airpor with Ronaldo busta and your holidays can start. First attraction starting on the airport and make you happy on the begining of your holidas.
reviews/4/text: Quality, refined attitudes and WARM reception of the guests. You feel the RESPECT of Cristinao for all are happen in the place in a decisive place marked by its emblematic existence
reviews/4/title: I felt that CR7 was with me...
reviews/5/text: Busto muito horrível preferia a primeira versão o magnifico busto original feito pelo um presidente berreiro socialista com problemas de visão
reviews/6/text: O busto do CR7 está no exterior do aeroporto, junto à porta de saída dos passageiros nas chegadas. Devido ao controlo que é realizado a todos os passageiros que chegam à Madeira (covid-19), o busto está escondido na zona dos passageiros sem teste realizado e onde se forma fila para realizar o teste, no local. Como viajamos com o teste feito, tivemos de tirar a foto ao longe e com algum cuidado para não apanhar na foto os passageiros que aguardavam para realizar o teste à covid-19. A máscara no busto é uma novidade do momento!
reviews/7/text: Nada melhor do que o busto do Cristiabno Ronaldo à chegada à Madeira. Pode-se começar logo com a série fotográfica...
reviews/8/text: 나름 현지에선 사연 많은 동상.. 처음 만든 동상이 하나도 안닮아서 2번째로 다시 만들어서 바뀐 동상임. 그래도 현지인들에 말에 따르면 첫번째보다 훨씬 낫다고 함.
reviews/9/text: Quem se deslocar há maravilhosa Ilha da Madeira,podemos apreciar no Aeroporto,o Busto de Cristiano Ronaldo,o maior jogador Português de todos os tempos,e um dos maiores do mundo.Um verdadeiro Monstro Sagrado.
subcategory_ranking: #329 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Canical, Madeira Portugal
name: Prainha do Canical
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Whale & Dolphin Watching in Madeira
ranking: #66 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #66 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Nice beach! Great water and perfect beach for children! The water is very clean! We do have to walk until the beach but anyway its really good, it is on est side of the island has great view!
reviews/1/text: Really nice beach with natural sand (black). We were there on a Monday afternoon - quite busy, but still able to socially distance comfortably. We stopped here on the way from walking at Ponte da Sao Lourenco. Easily accessible, about 10 minutes drive from Machico. Parked on the main road, lots of spaces, and then a walk down the stairs to the beach. Sea warm, small waves. Friendly atmosphere, full services of toilets, showers and restaurant just above beach but we did not use. Not the best beach in the world, but for Madeira it is very nice indeed.
reviews/2/text: This beach is just wonderful. Beautiful clear flat water. Soft black sand. Gorgeous picturesque location. Has a toilet, change room and a restaurant.
reviews/3/text: Atlantic ocean, clean, shops and restaurants near by, can be loud. Parking space available!! Good for a day out if you don't live in the area but reachable
reviews/4/text: We were in octomber here so it was not crowded. It is one of our favourites beaches in Madeira. You were there by car. The car must be left in the parking lot and then you need to go down on some stairs untill you reach the beach. It is a natural beach with black sand, not so big. It is good also for snorkeling. We saw some fish but not many. There is also a litlle bar at this beach. They serve also food. The problem was that if you wanted to use the toilet or the shower you needed to buy something drom the bar and ask for the key. But in my opinion you need to see this location!
reviews/5/text: A bit busy and crowded, but that is understandable. Nice spot to get into the sea. Enjoyed a quieter time on the rocky beach a bit further along.
reviews/6/text: Loungers, umbrellas, even shower or changing cabin are paid. The sand was very hot, so you did not bend on the towel.
reviews/7/text:
Great natural beach with sand, fantastic colorless, clean and  warm sea water.
Protected from the wins by the valley, it worth’s the 300 or more steps you will have to climb back.
Don’t missed, assure you go there middle of the morning on weekday to avoid the weekend and afternoon crowd.
Ideally choose the low tide hours, to maximize your experience, it is a relative small beach. Reserve at least 2 to 3 hours to be there and relax. 
There is a small restaurant down there, but did not tried, I took some water and fresh fruit to cope with my stay.
reviews/7/title: The best beach in Madeira Island
reviews/8/text: After a week of rocks and very little possibility to get into the sea this was a surprise to find a sandy beach (sand brought in from Morocco we were told). It is not very big and I can imagine in full summer it would be swamped with people but if in this area worth a visit.
reviews/8/title: The ONLY sand beach on the island, small but worth a stop over on a hot day
reviews/9/text: Good sand. In January less people with volleyball field and enough space for an (illegal) football match.
reviews/10/text: Dark sand beach that is a small slice of paradise... especially the clean blue water. Is tricky to get there... but it's worth the sweat. Avoid eating in the bar... get a few drinks, you will need to climb back.
reviews/11/text: Rather an industrial area. Pebbly beach  leading to a dock. Good for a walk but I don't think I'd recommend it for children
reviews/12/text: Nice golden sandy beach where my children had chance to swim and play in the sea. Madeira is amazing, but not full with quality beaches. It was the best of all what we seen. Changing area, shower, restaurants, sunchairs, parasols around. Spent a good few hours here. Recommend the place.
reviews/13/text: The beach itself was a rugged rock beach. However the area you would call the prominade was full of local restaurants there were very few visitors o ly locals. The beach had views over a commercial harbour.
reviews/14/text:
Came here today for a bit of snorkeling and to chill out away from the busier parts of the island.

Nice clear water and easy access. Not in full season yet so not as much open and available, still had a quick bite to eat before we left at one of the many little cafe/restaurants.
reviews/15/text: We were tired of the over prices restaurants in Funchal and was told by a polish couple that Canical has some nice low price and good quality seafood restaurants. We visited there and had lunch at Restaurant Amarelo (unfortunately coud not find it on Tripadvisor). The food was really low price but really tasty. The restaurant had a lot of local family from Madeira, so it was a good sighn of getting a reasonably prices and good local food. The villege is small but a nice stop over place after visiting ponta das gaivotas.
reviews/15/title: great place to find fresh seafood
reviews/16/text: We travelled one hour by bus 113 SAM from Funchal to this quiet cove near Canical. The black sand beach and warm seas made it a perfect spot to spend a sunny day. Beach cafe run by friendly local family served grilled fish and cold beer and wine!!
reviews/17/text: It's necessary walk down from the cliff on relative safe sidewalk. Near beach is showers and small bistro, but due weather was closed. Reallocation is before Oceanodroma, there is quite big car parking on cliff. Its our favourite natural beach with volcanic sand.
reviews/18/text: I like the beaches of Madeira, and this one has white sand (something rather uncommon in the main island). You can have a really fun time over there, surrounded by short height cliffs.
reviews/19/text:
Encontrámos a praia um pouco por acaso mas o nosso filho decidiu logo que tínhamos que descer. Foi uma ótima decisão. Passámos ali um par de horas, praia muito  confortável, de areia escura, com mar calmo onde havia uma quantidade inesperada de gente na água em Novembro :) 
Foi um momento bem passado e um repouso muito bem vindo depois de madrugarmos para apanhar o voo para o Funchal.
subcategory_ranking: #66 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Vale dos Amores, Calheta, Madeira 9370-111 Portugal
name: Centro das Artes - Casa das Mudas
ranking: #126 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #126 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
We assumed the gallery would be in the whole array of buildings  - it wasn't. 

Even the bit that it did occupy had one exhibition floor closed. In and out in less than 30 mins.

No other facilities open.
reviews/1/text: very bad uhggg can not find words to describe! Only word that come to me is "disgusting" the exibition is not worth it the employees are very bad during our visit they where shouting at each other in the museu what???? And the building is falling to pieces even the coffee shop is closed...
reviews/2/text:
Worth a visit for the views alone! We walked up from Claheta Brach Hotel- hard work but worth it - the views from the museum are amazing abd you don't actually have to go in to see them.
We did visit the museum - it is closed between 1pm and 2pm though - the art us absolutely in the eye of the beholder!!! I got some of it but others were a total mystery to me as to how you could class them as art! Having said that I'm a very analytical person so maybe I just need to learn to look at things differently!!!
reviews/3/text:
The most fantastic building in a location to be envied. Just a pity it does not match the structure with an equivalent exhibition. Within two minutes of entering the exhibition the “Emperor’s New Clothes” came to mind. Sorry, I do not understand why you would waste such a brilliant space with things like 20 square canvases all painted black or bashed metal boxes and none of the other exhibits were any better - a total con
However I loved the building!
reviews/4/text:
We very much enjoyed our previous visit last year and having been told that the temporary exhibitions did change thought that we would visit again.  Unfortunately there were floors without exhibits (presumably as they are being changed) and although the entrance cost was reduced to just €1 each, we are not sure that we would have driven from Funchal to see the limited pieces on display.  I must admit I do not know if the reduced displays was highlighted on the website, but imagine that before visiting again this is something we would want to check.
We did go to the cafe this year as it was not open when we visited previously and did have some nice coffee and of course the views from the gallery are still as stunning as before.
reviews/5/text: If you want the views or the sunset even if the Museum is closed just jump in and enjoy the panorama, if you got time to spend have a bite or something more elaborated and local at the Mudas Restaurant from 10am t0 10pm everyday. 😉
reviews/6/text: I'm a fan of contemporary art, but what the MUDAS shows is rather boring and unimaginative work reminiscent of kindergarten drawings. The architecture of the museum is then only partially conciliatory.
reviews/6/title: The worst exhibition I ever saw!
reviews/7/text: Really wonderful architecture, on top of the mountain. Not all but some of the art was great. Must do!
reviews/8/text: Modern art is not for everyone. You start on the top floor then go down 3 levels (they do have a lift) the shop was shut and photos are not permitted.... however its only 4 euros, good cafe and fantastic view.
reviews/8/title: The building and view is better than the art.
reviews/9/text: White elephant?  I think not.  Fabulous building in itself and the art we saw exciting and well hung.  Examples below but do visit if you’re nearby - only 4 euros.
reviews/10/text:
This massive building in a dramatic location must have cost millions. Unfortunately:
1. It's miles from Funchal, overlooking a tiny nondescript town on the southwest coast. You really need to want to go there to make the effort. An extra challenge is the absence of clear signage to show you the way in once you get there.
2. Most late 20th century contemporary art seems to be conceptual: weak or strong ideas, well or poorly executed, successful or unsuccessful in communicating emotionally with the viewer. Sadly, almost everything in these cavernous white spaces falls into the weak ideas, averagely executed, and largely failing to communicate. The usual method to cover that is a pretentious artist's statement intended to make the viewer feel it's all their fault for not understanding - see the example below.
3. The centre wins one prize however, for having a cafe with the most disgusting and poorly maintained toilets on the island. 

Nice view though.
reviews/11/text: Whilst the architect has been awarded for this great design and build of the building itself, the exhibition is lacking. It is a contemporary exhibition of no real quality.
reviews/12/text: What an amazing building this is! It's made from basalt which fits the environment perfectly. Some of the artifacts are thought provoking and very interesting.
reviews/13/text:
The arts centre contains Portuguese artists work and is very contemporary.
It is worth a visit for the building itself and the fantastic views of Calheta.
reviews/14/text:
What looks like a very ugly building perched high above Calheta houses a fascinating exhibition of Contemporary Portuguese Art. The inside of the building belies its ugly exterior and it makes great use of modern wooden flooring. The exhibits are well spread out with plenty of room to view and enjoy each piece. It really is a museum to make you think.
4 stars for the exhibition and 5 for the building, so, four and a half overall.
Would visit again.
reviews/15/text:
Spotted the building perched high above Calheta, decided to visit. Wonderful piece of modern architecture which whilst may not be to everyone's taste offers unrivalled views from the terrace down on Calhetta.
The building houses an eclectic collection of modern art some disturbing, some thought provoking.  Well worth a visit for  a tranquil afternoon away from the heat of Calheta.
reviews/16/text:
We visit this amazing building, this morning. It's a pretty space and clever build on the cliff over viewing caletha. 
We where amazed by the architecture of the building and would love to call it our home. The art was contemporary and modern, local artists and more famous Portuguese artists. The quality was good and nice presented in the spaces. 
Def a recommendation if you like modern art, and pretty views. It also has a nice cafe, and store.
reviews/16/title: Amazing building on the cliff and nice modern art
reviews/17/text:
We stayed local to this centre and found it by chance. 
We saw great modern art here. 
Great thing is was quiet so you could explore without too many people around

Great experience
reviews/18/text: We are staying in Calheta and noticed the grey building on top of the cliffs. Discovering it was a gallery of modern art raised our interest but we didn't have high expectations. It would be a challenge to access without a car but if you do make it it's well worthwhile . A beautiful space with beautiful art  . I particularly loved the work of Lourdes Castro . She used a variety of mediums with simplicity and impact. We were the only people in the gallery , so how they keep it going I'm not sure . What a jewel !
reviews/19/text: Wonderful views, great cafe...and very stimulating art, both semi-traditional and modern.  If you are not into art, just go visit the cafe and admire the area.
subcategory_ranking: #126 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Estrada Monumental 390, Funchal, Madeira 9004-568 Portugal
description: Take a trip in first class. 75 stores with major brands, restaurants and 6 Cinema. Shopping with a class, innovation and modernity. Come visit us...
name: Forum Madeira
ranking: #49 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #49 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: The Forum Madeira is a wonderful place for shopping, has a vast range of shops, is well maintained, clean and has good facilities. A great range of restaurants on the top level, good coffee shops and a delicious Ice Cream shop. Basically all you need to spend a great time shopping.
reviews/1/text: Nice mall. Nice brands, quality of clothing is great and pricing is fair too. The mall is all dressed up for the holidays. Good restaurants and coffee shops in the mall.
reviews/2/text: 3 floors of shops cafes and outlets. Bottom floor is a C and A and a large supermarket. middle floor is a mix of retail clothes, jewellery, nail bars, and food outlets. top floor is a mix of eateries with lots of mixed seating available and some clothes shops plus a book shop. Clean and safe.
reviews/2/title: All good here and friendly staff
reviews/3/text: We always have a smashing time here and my wife spends lots of my money.  It’s easy to find and there are not too many shops but the ones they have are good.
reviews/4/text: Great experience again. Nice friendly staff in all shops.  Managed to find some lovely clothes and shoes. Always happy to shop in here and highly recommend
reviews/5/text:
Good range of shops  and cafes with  helpful staff.
However the two staff members in Bershka store were extremely rude in as much  as they sold me an item without even looking at me never mind a smile or a single word they were far too deep in their own chit chat.
reviews/5/title: Mostly a positive experience,but won't be going to Bershka EVER again.
reviews/6/text:
A nice shopping centre, a little tucked away so you could easily miss it if you weren’t looking for it. A good range of shops plus a cinema and supermarket. Lots of high street brands
Like Zara, Pull and Bear and Stradivarius etc.
reviews/7/text: Great shopping centre with lovely shops. Can easily spend 2+ hours. Pingo Doce supermarket. Lots of reasonably priced shops. Especially like Lefties and Parfois. It’s also nice to see C&A-always worth a visit!
reviews/8/text:
A nice clean shopping mall with a wide variety of shops, a great supermarket and
a good place for coffees and juices. Easy to reach by bus from the City Center
reviews/8/title: Clean mall with a wide variety of shops
reviews/9/text:
Lot's of very trendy clothes shops for adults and children in a clean and tidy environment. 
A couple of nice cafes outside and inside.
A cinema complex.
A McDonald's
Highly impressed with the supermarket. The quality of fresh and frozen food here. Fresh fish, meat and bread counters look amazing. The frozen fish, prawns section put the UK to shame with the amount of choice! Very busy at checkout Friday and Saturday.
All in all, a nice complex
reviews/10/text:
Excellent shopping ,large variety of shops,manyoffering discounted goods.Large supermarket,competitive prices,
great variety of very fresh fruit,vegetables and salads.
reviews/11/text:
Busy Mall. Lots of nice shops including C&A.
Also, a large supermarket (expensive compared with the UK).
McDonalds upstairs. Cinema at the back.
reviews/12/text: Madeira is an amazing island. I am impressed. I was there with a guide Sonia Otrębska, who perfected everything. She is a real specialist WHO cares about clients' need.
reviews/13/text: Madeira is a really picturesque place. I've already been to many exotic places, but Madeira is especially a plus. I took advantage of the Madeira Dreams offer, thanks to which I visited the most fascinating corners of the island. Madeira Dreams adapt to individual needs - not only for weddings, but also for the tours offered. Thanks to them, these important and unforgettable moments in my life were exactly what I dreamed
reviews/14/text: Lovely shopping centre, very clean and good covid protocols. Has a great range of shops, lots of English ones too which is great for tourists like ourselves. We got a pizza from crispys chicken and it was delicious!
reviews/15/text: Recently I was in Madeira with the best guide Sonia Otrębska. It was an unforgettable journey! I learned a lot of new and intriguing things about Madeira. This is definitely one of the most interesting islands.
reviews/16/text: Recently I was in Madeira. I took advantage of the Madeira Dreams offer. I am delighted. It was a great choice. The guide Sonia Otrębska knows the most attractive places in Madeira very well. She is very knowledgeable.
reviews/17/text: Visited with my husband on our trip to Madeira. There were a few shops to wander round. Wouldn’t say it was overly exciting.
reviews/18/text:
We visited as a couple not planned one evening. 
We liked it so much we went back the following day and spent more money. 
Variety of shops and eateries all very covid conscious. 
It’s small but adequate and worth a visit.
reviews/19/text: Small mall with very similar selection of shops to another mall in town centre so I would only bother if your accommodation is nearby.
subcategory_ranking: #49 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Camara de Lobos, Madeira Portugal
name: The Camara de Lobos promenade
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Exorbitant West Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Full Day - Madeira West
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Private Tour Halfday South Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Private & Customizable Safari 4x4 Half-Day Shore Excursion
ranking: #85 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #85 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: Tourist trap Cafe... avoid Sunny Bar where the service is anything but sunny, the food rubbish and the whole experience just blurghhh.  And super expensive too.
reviews/1/text: Camara de Lobos is a small fishing town 6 miles from Funchal town. It is quite enchanting in the surface, with small side streets and lots of cafes and restaurants to choose from. There is a small cove/ pebbled beach area which is mainly occupied by local fishing boats. It is nice on a sunny day, but can be windy and bleak on a bad day. There isn’t that much to do in the town once you’ve looked around, although there are a couple of nice bakeries. One thing to be wary of in this small town are a couple of cafe/ restaurants that will rip you off. One in particular is the Sunny Bar cafe which I would advise anyone to avoid at all costs, even if you’re desperate.
reviews/2/text: We started from our hotel near the Lido and walked the coast path, through the tunnel to end in Camara which overall took about 90 minutes. A wander round the village and then on to the hop on/off bus back to our hotel and another well-earned beer.
reviews/3/text: Nice village, nice views, fishermans playing cards (as they are not allowed to catch fishes now). Worth to stop for 1 hour and walk around.
reviews/4/text: The most magical place on the island. Absolutely beautiful little streets and craft ship. Lots to see and do. Generally a beautiful little town.
reviews/5/text:
Take a walk by the sea, where fishermans play cards and drink poncha ...
Picturesque atmosphere, true fisherman village ...
reviews/5/title: The most beautiful village on the island.
reviews/6/text: We started at the lido and walked the coastal path, small diversion as the tunnel was closed. Lovely views, I would class the walk as moderate, as there are some fairly hefty climbs. Camara itself is touristy but there are some good things to be found with a bit of exploring. Walk back was a bit harder after food and drink!
reviews/7/text: Great views and excellent fish lunch. We visited as part of a private Madeira tour and we are glad the guide/driver took us here.
reviews/8/text: We decided to take a local bus ride to the this lovely quaint fishing village which is just a 30 minute ride out of Funchal with interesting views on the way. It is worth the very reasonable fare to spend a few hours to familiarise yourself with the place that Churchill liked. Make sure to go to the bar where Churchill's statue is and walk the side streets with collages made out of recycled materials. We had a lovely lunch at Deserta Pequena where we were served with excellent starter of Chicken Samosas with almond and carrot sauce. Very unusual and delicious. We had the famous Black Scabbardfish for our main which was cooked to perfection. We were served a complimentary posha liqueur which finished our lunch. I would highly recommend this place to enjoy a tasty lunch.
reviews/9/text: We started our walk from the public parking lot in Camara de Lobos.  It's a short uphill stretch to reach the promenade.  This is a lovely walk along the sea with great views.  Before a storm ripped out the boardwalk closer to Funchal, it joined the Lido boardwalk and you could walk all the way to Funchal.  There are no washrooms on the promenade.
reviews/10/text: We walked from Funchal to Camara De Lobos along the promenade. The views were interesting and beautiful, with a few little areas where you can come off the path and explore the rocks on the sea. We were disappointed that the tunnel by Doca do Cavacas leading to the beach was closed therefore we had to head inland to get around which wasn't as nice. Apparently it has been closed for some time. When reaching Camara De Lobos there were a few restaurants to sit and watch the world go by in the harbour. The village had some beautiful art work and there was a little shop that sold delicious ice creams. Worth the walk.
reviews/11/text:
The harbour area of this village has a collection of colourful fishing boats above a black rock beach.  A few character cafes are nearby, but the main delight of what was once a small fishing village is the sea-sided walk to the east of the harbour. This takes you past (now smartened up) fishing cottages, an old lime kiln, sea swimming pool and underneath some spectacularly stratified cliffs.  Stop when you reach the end which overlooks the cement factory in the next bay (or if you are really energetic you can continue the walk all the way back to Funchal).
The village is easily reached by local bus from Funchal (15 different bus nos. – get a local bus map and buy a Giro pre-paid fare card) which can be combined with a visit to the nearby Cabo Girao Cliffs.
reviews/11/title: Fishing village favoured by Winston Churchill  – now much developed.
reviews/12/text: I decided to go for a walk from the ship after leaving the port I headed along the promenade passing cafes and restaurants
reviews/13/text: but the stretch near Camara de Lobos is best because it is a walk by the sea all the way and no traffic fumes! Great views and sun often shining. Lovely breezes and you can paddle on the Praia Formosa.
reviews/13/title: Fabulous walk all the way to Funchal
reviews/14/text: Visited the bakery coffee and cakes very nice excellent value. Good  milky coffee and beautiful cakes
reviews/15/text: Great way to spend a few hours relaxing. Loved the monk seal artwork. Little trip up to the skywalk was good too.
reviews/16/text: This is a really quaint fishing village.  There are plenty of small cafe's and restaurants around the harbour.  Also more of them up the cobbled narrow streets near to the church which is a must see.  On the main road near the harbour there is the road train that takes you up into the hills to see the famous glass bridge.  Red and Yellow hop off tours go through this village.
reviews/17/text: Did two walks from our hotel to the village. About 4K. Had a real nice feel about it. Didn’t eat here but restaurants looked good Wine and beer was well priced. The hop on bus comes through as well. Definitely worth a visit.
reviews/18/text:
We walked the promenade several times as it was a really nice walk to Camara Lobos, a touristy fishing village. There’s a small area of storm damage on the promenade but otherwise in really good condition and suitable for wheelchair users too. 
There were lots of joggers using the walkway as well as families.
reviews/18/title: A good walk to Camara de Lobos from Funchal
reviews/19/text: Camera the Lobos is different than many other places on the island. It is nice to walk near the water to see the fishing boats and to listen to the story about the origin of the name - The chamber of the sea lions
subcategory_ranking: #85 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Rua do Cais no 6, Porto da Cruz, Madeira 9225-050 Portugal
description: The Porto da Cruz 'Engenho' (mill) is a testimony to the importance sugarcane had and still has on an economic and cultural level in Madeira. A visit to our mill is like taking a journey through time, visitors can walk the original circuit that goes from the collection of sugar cane, through to the various stages of production and ending in a visit to the Rum House.
location_string: Porto da Cruz, Madeira, Madeira Islands
name: Engenhos do Norte
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The best of the East Tour in Madeira
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Northeast meet the locals 4x4 tour - Santana / Caniçal
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: East Tour - 4x4 - Small Group
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Wheelchair Handicap Full Day East Tour Santana Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: East private full day
ranking: #71 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #71 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text:
Engenhos do Norte is a nice rum distillery in Porto da Cruz. 
It is free of charge to enter and you can the process how rum is made!
reviews/1/text: Quaint little distillery really helpful staff. Suggest place for lunch.  Let me taste loads. Try their punch it’s on 2.5 euros.
reviews/1/title: Worth a look if over Machico way
reviews/2/text:
Cool machines, however only look-around tour without much info. You can only guess what the machines and kettles are used for. Really short video on how the sugar canes come in and are processed. Did not find anything on the process of rum making. 
However this was even overshadowed by an unfriendly lady behind the desk who acted like I was stupid and wasn’t very keen to give additional info. Only after repeatedly asking for it, since we had been driving for an hour to visit the place, she gave in.
Bought another €6 shot of (good) rum. However did not manage to set aside my frustration so I didn’t buy a bottle, only so that I wouldn’t be reminded of that woman every time I drank the rum at home.

Good to have a 5 min look inside if you happen to be in that town, but not worth the drive from Funchal.
reviews/2/title: Not worth a visit if you’re really interested in the process of rum making. Cool machines though. Unfriendly staff
reviews/3/text:
Although this was on our "things to do in Madeira" list, we happened upon it quite by chance.  We were touring the coast and stopped off in the nearby car park to look at the bay (surfing and other watersports available) before strolling to the historic building.  You could say we "arrived under our own steam" lol.  Its a real, working distillery, with free entry and free tastings available.  You can purchase direct from the manufacturer - we got a few bottles for gifts - keeping down our retail carbon footprint.  A self-guided tour is available with a video, in English, running to show the complete process.  All the exhibits are labelled, in Portuguese and English.  Rum is made from sugar cane, which is grown across Madeira.  This arrives in flat bed vehicles and is loaded by grab crane (see photo) before being crushed to extract the sugar syrup.  The remainder of the plant is used as fuel for the steam engine (see photo) as it is burnt on site.  The sugar syrup is then the ingredient used as fermentation to produce the alcohol which is then distilled to give the high strength final liquor for cask ageing and bottling.  Its a really clever set up.  They do not run at full production every day - they were not working during our visit - but the video shows the scene and the exhibits bring it to life.  Great insight into the whole process.  You can finish the tour in the gift shop where you can sample the rum produced and also, should you wish to, purchase drinks for consumption on and off the premises.  The 'poncha' is freshly made and you can have a creamy cocktail containing it too.  They had a special rum called 'Fire' which apparently, although strong, doesn't burn your throat like some rum does.  Tours of the island often visit here and two 4x4 vehicles, full of tourists, arrived whilst we were there.  Everyone seemed to enjoy the experience, particularly those sampling the final product!

Recommended
reviews/4/text: You have a possibility test a Rum and Vine. Also buy alla the kinds of drinks. Tasty rum cotail with cream. The musieum is free entrance
reviews/5/text: If you have a half hour or less and passing by. This is ok for a short visit and a walk through to see a little of the history of Rum making in Madeira.
reviews/6/text: Nice little rum distillery. Free entrance. It  is actually working, not just a museum. Little shop, you buy not only rum, but also some other sugar cane products like sugar cane honey or cookies.
reviews/7/text:
Second time visiting this restaurant. Lovely setting. Unfortunately food is terrible. No flavour. Wait Staff lovely and attentive and smiling. 
I wasn’t going to leave a review as the wait staff were nice. My issue is I didn’t eat my fish soup explained it wasn’t great and had no flavour. 
They took away asked if I wanted to order anything else. 
I said no I am fine as my partner had finished. 
Then they charged me on the bill. 
If think maybe they thought I was a tourist so they wouldn’t see me again. 
Unfortunately for them I am a local and won’t be visiting or bringing any family or friends here again.
reviews/8/text: We stopped over as part of a group tour and enjoyed ourselves - tried the rum, had some poncho (various flavours are available), they also have lovely dark chocolate with rum. There's plenty to choose from and you can see the distillery. We all felt rather jolly after the stopover.
reviews/9/text: One of the bedt poncha on the island right from the source.The surrounding is also nice - perfect place for a short walk around with a cup of poncha.
reviews/10/text: What a waste of time this was . Did not see any of the rum making process and was given a tiny tiny bit of rum to taste . The lady went around offering this small taste and I went and offered up my glass again thinking it was a refill and she screamed across the room at me in Portuguese the gist was “one per person” .This was in front of others in the room so I immediately left at being spoken to in such an awful way . I was going to buy lots of products in the shop so it was all there loss as I left because of this staff member
reviews/11/text: as you can walking along the coast for quite a way, not  to mention the shore just in front of the distillery. You have to pay for all drinks thee. No free samples. However on sale are freshly prepared poncha.
reviews/12/text: The rums produced at this unique distillery really are remarkable. I first tried their rum four years ago and now I would never buy anything else. On this visit I was given a sample of the Madeira cask finish rum at 60% vol. and I have never tasted better. The price for a bottle was 81 euros and worth every penny. We were driven there by a friend who lives on Madeira and he also did our own private tour of the distillery which was very interesting. We loved the shop and the very nice woman who was serving. I would love to go back again at a time when they are in production and see how the rums are made.
reviews/13/text: Except for the bored and non communicative staff at the gift shop, everything was beautiful and interesting. The location is beautiful.
reviews/14/text:
For many tourists the Rum Distillery in Porto da Cruz is located away from the usual tourist hotspots. However, the Engenhos do Norte Distillery is an interesting diversion accessible by using the SAM bus service from central Funchal at an appreciably cheaper cost than a private tour. Not only is it cheaper but it provides a leisurely way to visit the beautiful area on the way to and at the village of Porto da Cruz. The village offers good walks in a dramatic landscape, with a good selection of restaurants and cafes. 
The Distillery itself operates April and May when the steam operated machinery can be seen working, but can be visited at other times to sample the product at very reasonable cost.
reviews/14/title: An interesting visit in the north east of the island
reviews/15/text: This is good for a quick afternoon visit. Not very big but really interesting. Great drinks from the distillery afterwards at €2 a throw.
reviews/16/text:
At the end of May, the factory was working and it was a step back into history. The factory still using the original steam driven machinery to crush the sugar cane to release the syrup. You can watch sugar cane being unleaded from lorries into the factory and then move along huge conveyor belts through massive crushers and the remains passing into trucks waiting outside the factory. There is pronounced sweet smell There are no safety barriers and our H&S would have forty fits!!

The sugar cane syrup is filtered and then distilled to make rhum. This can be sampled in the shop which also sells rhum, very good cakes and biscuits made from the syrup
reviews/16/title: It was worth coming to Maderia just to see this!
reviews/17/text:
My wife and myself are currently holidaying in Madeira and earlier today we visited the 150-200 year old Rum Distillery at Porto da Cruz.

There is no fee for looking around the Distillery which looks as if the both the machinery and process have changed little over the years. It certainly makes good use of much of the homegrown Sugar Cane and - should it be your tipple - there is an opportunity to sample the end product at the end of one’s visit.

All in all, an interesting local attraction that is located in an attractive setting and - as such - well worth 30 minutes of anybody’s time.
reviews/17/title: Good Place to see the making of Madeiran Rum
reviews/18/text: We watched the lorries of sugar cane unloading & being processed into juice using the most primitive & basic machinery - & then got a free tasting of a few different rums at the end, and some delicious lemon poncha (€2). Well worth it if you’re in the area.
reviews/18/title: Interesting to see the process & taste the end product - very authentic
reviews/19/text: Nice journey to Porto da Cruz (Windsor Travel) and then a short informal tour of the rum making premises. The history was interesting and the tasting well worth it (for me anyway). Nice we shop with bottles at a good price. The sugar cane biscuits were also very tasty.
reviews/19/title: Worth a vist for the trip there alone

reviews/0/text: Probably one of the most scenic hikes in Madeira! You get it all, stunning ocean views interspersed with jungle-like dales and so many photo ops you'll need to add a couple of hours to do this stunner justice. Warning, the parking area is really horrible around the closed tramway. Go a little further on the unpaved road for marginally better parking.
reviews/1/text: We walked from Pico de facho via Boca do Risco to Porto da Cruz. This is a great walk when the weather is good. We walked initially along the lavada do Canical before turning off and  gently up the valley to Boca do Risco. Lovely quiet valley with great views. Once at Boca do Risco there were great views along the coastline. We walked along the coastal path through woods providing shade before coming out and skirting round a cliff face. From a distance the path cut into the cliffs looks imposing however the path was wide enough but one needs to take care when walking - some fencing in parts ..... Very tall cliffs afforded great views. We then continued along the path through larano and down to Porto da Cruz, a nice small village on the coast. This is a great walk with breathtaking views but suggest only in good weather and sure footed. We got to and from this walk by bus.
reviews/2/text:
Overall about 8km Larano through Boca do Risco.. We were dropped at a dead-end overlooking PontaD'Cruz., which is awesome to look back on during the first 1km of rugged but level wide path. From then on it's all single width as it weaves through some shaded forest. Then the path then wraps itself around the cliff at some altitude and is precarious in many places, where there are sheer cliff drops and NO guard rails. Your risk, but our guide was ensuring we had good foot-holdings, thank goodness. Our morning was cloudless so quite hot & humid in places. Look down the cliff to the sea...it was a rare calm sea day on the north side.
Really spectacular views made it all worth while, however the last 2Km downhill to Machico is very rocky & rugged. Not for the infirm, asthmatic or faint-hearted ! Take a jacket, water, sun protection, sturdy boots and a human guide if not familiar.
reviews/2/title: Not "Easy" category but Moderate plus (IMO). Views well worth it.
reviews/3/text: This walk is a MUST in madeira it is absolutely breathtaking. easy to walk, long descend to Porto da Cruz, but that also has very nice views.
reviews/3/title: on of the most impressive walks in Madeira
reviews/4/text:
Along the way, take some time to enjoy the sights and all the surrounding of this walk. Once you reach Porto da Cruz you can relax for a while and get to know this location of the island, full of unique cultures and traditions.

Length - 13 km; Time - 4-5 hours; Difficulty - hard
reviews/5/text:
La randonnée commence à Machico le long de la levada dos Maroços au milieu de terres agricoles cultivées en terrasse. C'est une mise en jambes paisible.
Au bout d'une heure on quitte la levada pour emprunter un chemin non signalé pour arriver après une heure de montée raide au Boca do Risco, superbe point de vue sur la mer, où on peut déjeuner tranquille.
Ensuite on suit un chemin escarpé qui serpente à flanc de falaise à 300m au-dessus de la mer. On découvre vers l'est des points de vue superbes sur la Pointe Saint-Laurent. On marche vers l'ouest pendant 2 heures avant d'arriver au-dessus de Porto da Cruz, petite station balnéaire encaissée au pied du rocher de l'Aigle. Les points de vue sur la côte sont superbes. La descente vers Porto da Cruz le long d'une levada prend 1/2 heure.
La randonnée dure donc 4h30 (hors pause déjeuner) et ne présente pas de difficulté particulière.
C'est l'une des plus belles randonnées de Madère parce que c'est une des rares à  combiner la marche en moyenne montagne et des points de vue superbes au-dessus de la mer.
reviews/5/title: Une randonnée escarpée à 300m au-dessus de la mer
reviews/6/text: Nous nous sommes garés à côté du tunnel. Les premiers kilomètres sont plutôt simple avec des vues sur machico très sympas! Pour monter aux pics, la pente est plus raide mais faisable! De la haut, belle vue sur les falaises!
reviews/7/text: Jedna z naszych ulubionych tras pieszych na Maderze. Najlepiej przejść się tą trasą gdy niebo jest bezchmurne- gwarantujemy że połączenie błękitu oceanu i zielonych stromych klifów, zrobią na Was wrażenie. Niestety podróżując autem powinniście się nastawić na spacer w 2 strony. Jeśli robicie trasę w 2 strony to warto pomyśleć o tym, żeby trasę zacząć od Porto da Cruz i dojść do punktu Boca do Risco. Wtedy pominiecie zbędne schodzenie do Machico i zobaczycie to co najpiekniejsze. Znacznie też zmniejszycie dystans do przejścia, który wyniesie około 11-12km w 2 strony.
reviews/8/text:
Nach dem steilen Aufstieg von Porto da Cruz aus verläuft der Weg zunächst spektakulär entlang der steil abfallenden Küste. Anschließend kann man zur Levada Nova hinabsteigen und dieser bis nach Machico und zum Aussichtspunkt Pico da Facho folgen. Die Gesamtstrecke beträgt dann rund 15 Kilometer. 

Die Wanderung ist nur bei trockenem Wetter zu empfehlen, und auch dann kann der Weg stellenweise sehr matschig und teilweise rutschig sein.

Zurück nach Porto da Cruz kann man mit dem Bus fahren, dafür muss man aber vom Pico da Facho den sehr steilen Abstieg nach Machico bewältigen. Ich habe mich stattdessen von einem Uber abholen lassen und wurde für rund 13 € zurück zum Parkplatz in Porto da Cruz gebracht.
reviews/9/text: Paisagens fantásticas! Vale a pena realizar esta vereda. Com grau de dificuldade reduzida. Fazer com tempo aberto e sem nevoeiro.
reviews/10/text: Výlet, který stojí za to. Přístupová cesta krkolomná - řidič musí mít opravdu pevné nervy. Silnice úzká a sklon nevídaný. Parkování velmi špatné, je nutno zaparkovat u posledních domů na silnici. Dál je nutno pokračovat cca 1 km k staré nákladní lanovce, kde je tabule s mapou. Nádherný výhled směrem na  západ.  Prvních cca 2 km je to nuda, protože je  všude houští. Pak se ale otevře výhled z útesů na oceán dole  a na východní stranu ostrova směrem k Porto da Cruz.
reviews/11/text: So posso agradecer a esta maravilhosa ilha ter paisagens de perder o olhar e cortar a respiração, trabalho muito árduo dos nossos antepassados fazer estas maravilhas 😍😍😍
reviews/12/text:
Uma viagem fascinante, um passeio rico em paisagens agrícolas começando na Cidade rural de Machico. Subindo uma elevação de aproximadamente 300 metros, alcança-se um platô grande com uma vista soberba sobre parte da Ponta de São Lourenço e sobre o Porto Santo (dependendo da neblina no local), bem como da zona nordeste da Ilha da Madeira.

Essa trilha era orginalmente usada pelos aldeões como ligação entre a costa norte e a costa sul da Ilha da Madeira, entre as vilas de Machico e Porto da Cruz.

O ponto de partida dessa caminhada acontece junto à chamada “casa dos levadeiros”, tendo nesse momento a companhia do curso hídrico da Levada dos Maroços, que conduz para o cenário dos campos agrícolas cultivados com frutos e legumes típicos daquela área, num misto de interação com os pequenos bosques exóticos.

Até à primeira etapa do percurso (Levada dos Maroços), o cenário é tranquilo e comandado pelos tradicionais poios agrícolas. Seguindo o trilho que se encontra bem visível, rapidamente chega à Boca do Risco e a partir daqui é fácil perceber porque é considerado um dos miradouros naturais mais bonitos da zona leste da Ilha.

A Vereda da Boca do Risco é por si só um trajeto muito interessante e envolvente, que termina de forma emblemática, tendo no miradouro natural da Boca do Risco, o ex-libris de toda a caminhada, pois a vista sobre o Oceano Atlântico é soberba, assim como também a Ponta de São Lourenço, a Penha d’Águia e se o tempo permitir a ilha do Porto Santo. A partir daqui a trilha poderá ter dois sentidos, ou seja, seguir o sentido da freguesia do Caniçal ou o lado oposto, o sentido da freguesia do Porto da Cruz.

Optamos pela segunda alternativa.

Todos os trilhos associados aos percursos costeiros, efetuados através da escarpa da montanha, outrora caminhos reais que serviam para as pessoas se deslocarem entre as vilas de Machico e Porto da Cruz são caminhos mais vulneráveis à erosão e como tal mais suscetíveis de desgaste.

A trilha é estreita e vertiginosa sendo escorregadia durante os meses mais úmidos.

No caminho até Porto da Cruz é possível observar uma das formações rochosas mais emblemáticas da Madeira: a Penha D’Águia.

O percurso até o Larano a partir da Boca do Risco é um trajeto deslumbrante do ponto de vista paisagístico, mas que oferece riscos inerentes que merecem cuidados extras aos caminhantes, principalmente experiência. Em algumas zonas de desgaste, foram colocados cabos de aço que auxiliam a mobilidade.

Ao chegar ao Larano, a vegetação endémica é substituída por espécies exóticas, mantendo, no entanto, a intensidade verdejante. A vereda termina praticamente no Caminho do Cabo do Larano, onde existe um pequeno teleférico para uso exclusivamente dos moradores locais e trabalhadores.

Daqui pode optar por descer até à Vila do Porto da Cruz.

DETALHE: Distância total entre Machico e Porto da Cruz: 12 Km. Dificuldade: Difícil. Duração: 3 a 4 horas do início ao fim. Altitude min/máx: 10 m / 350 m
reviews/12/title: vista vertiginosa nas montanhas da Ilha da Madeira
reviews/13/text:
Die Tour beginnt mit einer Wanderung im Land des Inneren entlang der Wassersysteme und am Hang mehrerer Gärten bis man nach circa 1 Stunde und 15 Minuten (5,3km) an einem Aussichtspunkt ankommt, von dem aus man zum ersten Mal das Meer sieht. Von da an läuft man stetig entlang der Küste auf ca. 350 Metern Höhe.
Die Wanderung lohnt sich alleine durch den tollen Ausblick.
Der Weg ist zum Teil schmal und es geht nebenan den Hang hinunter. Da er jedoch ausreichend gesichert ist, hatten wir nie ein ungutes Gefühl.
Der einzige Nachteil bei uns war am Ende der Wanderung, dass wir den Bus um 13:15 Uhr knapp verpasst hatten und nicht bis ca. 17 Uhr auf den nächsten warten wollten. Das Taxi hat zurück zum Startpunkt der Wanderung, an dem unser Mietwagen stand, 20€ gekostet.
Trotz des Taxi Preises würden wir die Tour bei einem nächsten Besuch wieder machen.
reviews/14/text:
Sendero de horizontal trazado y cómodo recorrido que, discurriendo entre Boca do Risco y las inmediaciones de la deliciosa localidad de Porto da Cruz, nos regala fantásticas panorámicas de la costa NE (incluyendo la Ponta de São Lourenço).
Antiguamente era utilizado por los borracheiros en su quehacer de transportar toneles de vino.
reviews/14/title: Cómodo sendero con fantásticas panorámicas de la costa NE (incluyendo la Ponta de São Lourenço).
reviews/15/text: Desde Boca do Risco a Porto da Cruz, impresionante paseo plano con vistas desde Porto da Cruz a la Punta de San Lorenzo, típica exhuberancia de Madeira acompañado del furioso rugir de las olas...en Porto da Cruz esperan buenos restaurantes
reviews/16/text: Soprattutto se avrete modo di andarci con una giornata tersa, come è successo a noi, il panorama che si gode da questa altura è sensazionale!
reviews/17/text:
Dieser Wanderweg führt überwiegend über schmale Pfade direkt an der Küstenlinie entlang. Dementsprechend ergeben sich immer wieder hinreißende Ausblicke auf die zerklüftete Landschaft und den beeindruckenden Terrassenbau der lokalen Landwirte. Da der Weg in luftiger Höhe angelegt ist, sollte man beim Begehen schwindelfrei sein. 
Der Ausgangspunkt dieser Tour ist nicht besonders gut ausgeschildert, es lohnt sich also der Blick in eine gute Wanderkarte. Parkmöglichkeiten sind am Einstieg allerdings vorhanden.
subcategory_ranking: #123 of 446 things to do in Madeira

address: Avenida Arraiga 18, Madeira 6160-206 Portugal
name: Funchal Tourist Office
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Camara de Lobos and Funchal Hop-On Hop-Off Bus Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Tour The Wedding Proposal
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Traditional Sunday Market - Half Day Tour - 4x4
ranking: #171 of 446 things to do in Madeira
ranking_subcategory: #171 of 446 things to do in Madeira
reviews/0/text: A must to visit on day one of your break unless you have already checked out what Madeira has to offer. Helpful knowledgeable staff
reviews/1/text: We have been into the tourist office 3 times this week and each time the women have been surly, dismissive and unhelpful. Not what you want when you’re in a new city and country
reviews/2/text:
Visited tourist information centre 9th September 2022 with a simple enquiry re a lavada walk … The lady was very unhelpful’ I have no information!’ Seems to much trouble to help people! A terrible impression to Madeira… thankfully everyone else I have met have been lovely and the island is beautiful 
Most other reviews on Google are the same!
reviews/3/text: Very helpful lady who spoke very good English, helped us choose a 4 WD tour and explained about the hop on/hop off bus trips. Lots of pamphlets and leaflets available to take away.
reviews/4/text:
We visited this Tourist Office on a recent sightseeing visit to Funchal. It is easy to find and is located on one of the main streets Avineda Arriaga. The big green sign with the information symbol was highly visible

The lady we spoke with was really helpful she gave us a free map of the Island and the City, along with useful information.

There were a number of brochures available in paper form or they could be downloaded.
reviews/5/text: Very friendly and helpful, gave us good addresses for hairdressers, diving and to visit the mountains. Really cool
reviews/6/text: The tourist office staff in the waterfront office were very friendly and clearly wanted to help though the opening hours seemed directly at variance with the hours with the greatest numbers of tourists on the waterfront.  But that may not matter since we found none of the information given was ever correct.
reviews/7/text:
We visited the tourist information centre to get the start time of the Corpus Christi service at the cathedral. This is a huge event in Madeira, it is public holiday and hundreds of people come to the centre of town to see the parade and attend the service. We wanted to know the start time so we could book a table for our evening meal. The staff at the information centre told us the service would start at 6.30 and we booked at table for 8 o’clock. They should have had the correct information to give out to the public. 
 By 7.55 there was no sign of the parade and I left to cancel our booking. The parade eventually arrived at the cathedral at 8.10. 
Please double check any times and information the staff give you. 
We had arrived at 5.50 to get a good view of the event but after standing for 2 hours I left disappointed.
reviews/8/text: Went to this office for asking about tourist buses outside Funchal. They provided good service, but were not so familiar with restrictions to tours, like which days they departed etc.
reviews/9/text:
This was an 'exploratory' visit to return, possibly, for a walking holiday. Unfortunately the weather was not kind.
I was surprised that the Tourist Office didn't accept credit card payment for the hop-on/Hop-off tour. Otherwise, very helpful despite pressure from pushy tourists complaining that there was only one person attending during lunch break.
Funchal is a great place, the old town that is as the developments to the West are absolutely ghastly and the invasions from cruise ships.
reviews/10/text: The office provided tickets to seating for the Carnaval parade, and some useful maps.  The information to take with you was a little sparse, but the attendants were very well informed, and fluent in English.
reviews/11/text: What a beautiful island.   Be sure to take the cable car up and than the fun sleds down. From where they let you off it’s easy walking downhill thru the winding streets.  The hop on/off bus will take you around and the yellow bus also takes you out to a good view point.
reviews/12/text: The 2 girls there were too busy chatting to really want to assist.  I wanted to purchase tickets for the concert at the English Church for next week, so popped into the tourist office.  Purchased 2 tickets and thankfully spotted they were for the day just gone.  Pointed this out and she issued new ones.  This is the first tourist office that I have ever used that does not take credit cards and not very helpful. Come on Funchal, you have a lot of tourists and really aren’t making the effort to help them.  This place seriously needs looking at being reorganised.
reviews/13/text: Surprised at how poor this was. Several staff on mobile phones (I had to make two visits). I asked about walking and was given a leaflet with little detail and told nothing else available. I tried looking for more information on the web and discovered that several trails were closed. No mention was made of this in the tourist office. I don’t know what they think they are there for but they were worse than useless!
reviews/14/text: I came in one afternoon during the flower festival week 2018 to ask some questions about going on levada hikes. I politely approached a female staff member sitting next to a young man (perhaps a trainee), to ask my questions but she seemed fed up with me in a couple of minutes despite the office not being very busy. She offered no advice or suggestions but reluctantly gave me a brochure of levada walks only when I specifically asked if she had any (because I had read online that they were available). She was obviously impatient and irritated with me - the situation was very uncomfortable and awkward. I quikly left but any useful information and lifesaving tips regarding hiking on Madeira I got from reading on the internet.
reviews/15/text:
Funchal

Funchal was a very interesting destination with some unique history. Being on a cruise ship, tours are offered for pretty much everything, but unable to do in the seven hours that was allowed for shore leave. 

Except!!!! If you do it by taxi. We were fortunate to find Luis Abreu a taxi driver. We took the Cruise-ship shuttle to central downtown. That is where we met Luis, a 20 year old college student/taxi driver full of energy and information about his home island.  He provided a four hour tour which included almost all the sites provided by the cruise-ship tours. It is with his permission I provide his contact information.  
luisabreu97@hotmail.com. 
It is well worth contacting him for your own personal tour. Cost $100US +tip
reviews/16/text:
Agree with other reviews. Staff are disinterested. It appears to be a problem that visitors come in and ask questions. No answers to questions. If wanting bus information you can get online or on the promenade where the buses stop. Bus companies very helpful. 

Clearly the recruitment and selection criteria needs attention. 

No. 1 criteria people friendly.
reviews/17/text:
The staff appeared pretty disinterested and very poorly informed about the many walks that Madeira offers (surely one of the island's great attractions). Maybe just my cynicism, but perhaps this is because there's no real scope for them to promote money making island tourism businesses?
This was most obvious when it came to our enquiring about the islands 3 bus companies (few of the walks on the island are circular so you need very precise information about bus routes and timings for the start and end of your walk). The tourist office did have one, rather battered folder containing most of the timetables, to be consulted in the office. It actually requires quite careful study if you're new to the island--and the presence of a queue of people all, quite reasonably, wanting to look at the same folder did not contribute to the experience. Eventually we tracked down the websites of the companies and for most routes you could download pdf timetables. Why oh Why did the tourist office staff not have the wit (or go to the small trouble) of producing a single sheet containing the website addresses.

Our view of the enterprise was confirmed by our second attempt to visit the tourist office. It was the opening day of the February carnival--a saturday--and it wouldn't be that surprising if visitors to the island wanted to find out about the programme. But they certainly couldn't find out anything from the tourist office. It was closed and shuttered--begging the question 'What's it for?.
reviews/17/title: Oh!! You want information? Sorry, not here!!
reviews/18/text: Some of the staff are very unhelpful, whilst others are absolutely charming and cannot do enough to help.
reviews/19/text:
Having read the latest reviews of the Tourist Office, I have to add our own disappointment to that of others with the main office in Avenida Arriaga.
We've been coming to Madeira regularly for over 30 years and don't recall ever getting any useful information, offered in a pleasant or friendly manner. Nowadays you can't even get comprehensive bus timetables there!

On our last visit, nearly a year ago, we went in to enquire about the opening times of Sugar Museum. We were told it couldn't be visited as it was shut. As its website said the contrary, but didn't give times, we went along to see, 350 metres away  - and found it had been open for 6 months! (See my separate review).

We also enquired whether the Office had any lists or other information of holiday apartments to rent for - as every tourist office anywhere has - and were told no!  But then the lady reached into her handbag and handed us a business card, saying her friend had an apartment. Fishy, or what?

We'll be returning to Funchal next week and will use the internet...
reviews/19/title: Why does the City of Funchal not provide a proper tourist office?
