reviews/0/text: This is a very beautiful setting in Seizal. You have the black sand and coastline and natural tidal pool called Praia de Seixal. Plenty of parking and restaurants. Just a warning that the public toilets are disgusting.
reviews/0/title: Stunning tidal pools and black sand beach.
reviews/1/text:
As a volcanic island, Madeira’s beaches are mostly volcanic rocks and stones, but the black sand beach at Seixal has soft, fine sand to walk on. We enjoyed walking along the beach and dipping our toes in the water. Walk to the other end of the beach to stand under a small waterfall and discover small caves to explore. We didn't stay to relax on the beach as we had an action-packed touristy day ahead of us.

We visited to experience a black sand beach (which was great), but also we had read that there are sea caves at the Seixal natural pools that you can swim in. I read, "The natural pools are easily accessible via the concrete stairs and the pools are calm to swim in, even if the sea just outside is rough. Remember to bring towels to lie out on. Entrance is free."  Maybe it was low tide or something? but we totally did not experience anything like this!  The rock pool we saw is located just across the concrete walkway from the black send beach, yes there are concrete steps down but these just lead to an area with very large pebbles/stones that is extremely difficult to walk on. The water is far away and so shallow you would have to wade out for a long long way, not at all feasible on the treacherous large pebbles/rocks. There was an archway that looked like it might be a sea cave but we couldn't get anywhere near it. (see photos)

That was the only disappointing part of our trip though. There is a mini viewpoint that just takes a couple of minutes to climb up to and from there you can see lovely views across the natural pool to the sea.

There are showers, toilets and a cafe next to the beach. Parking is free, but aim to arrive early before 11am as after that it gets very busy.

Note: when driving to/from Seixel, visit the nearby Miradouro do Véu da Noiva to see a waterfall that leads straight into the ocean. This viewpoint is beautiful and extremely easy to reach as only a few seconds walk from the nearby parking lot.
reviews/1/title: The black sand beach is great and we recommend, but the 'natural rock pools' is very misleading!!
reviews/2/text: Please be aware of how dangerous this place is. My sister almost drowned being swept into the sea by a huge wave, although she was more then 3metres from the edge! Later we heard this is called 'the pool of death' by locals and 7 people drowned recently by being swept into the sea. This place is unguarded so help is 20-30 minutes away. My sister barely made it. Its a beautiful place, but dont underestimate nature's force and stay away from the edge, meaning at least 4-5 meters! Be warned!
reviews/3/text: Lovely place!! Amazing view. I recommend to see this place, to get there you need to have a car, around 40 min from Funchal centre. The route is easy with nice surroundings. Really nice place to chill.
reviews/4/text:
The natural pools in Seixal are highly recommended. “Entrance” is free, just bring your bikini, maybe bathing shoes (not necessary) and a couple of towels to lie on.

The pools are easily accessible on the concrete stairs, and you can have a proper little swim - even if the sea just outside is rough.

We went here in December, temperature was 20 degrees Celsius, a sunny day perfect for a bit of tanning. You can lie on concrete decks - it’s better than it sounds!
reviews/4/title: Free swimming & tanning - also in December
reviews/5/text: This is the best black sand beach we went to on Madeira. The cliffs gave it a 'Jurassic Park' feel! We just went off a swim to cool down in October, during a 4x4 island tour, but the beach is shallow, so a great place for young kids.
reviews/5/title: best black sand beach we went to on Madeira
reviews/6/text: Good for a swim. Snorkeling is OK but visibility is a bit low, some fish. Go to the beach on the opposite side for some more action (waves)
reviews/7/text:
Wednesday 16th June we were driving around exploring the northwestern coast of the Island and we paid a visit to Seixal. 

It was a rather miserable day it was cloudy with rain showers which only enhanced and deepened the darkness of the pool. At times the water was nearly as dark as the volcanic rock. 

Perhaps it was due to the inclement weather there were hardly anybody there when we visited which added to the eerie feeling.
reviews/8/text: This is a nice place to be but quickly gets crowded and parking is difficult when many people there. The pool is ok as it is on rocks but pleasant swim.
reviews/9/text: Another must even for a day while visiting Madeira.A stoning beautiful nature with a nice waterfall, dark sandy beach and natural swimming pools. This combinating makes it worth visiting and Spenden some time.
reviews/10/text: Very natural place. Should go down with car very narrow but possible. A lot of stones and slippery. But in general is very spectacular to see natural lava stones. Have toilets clean and shower. Respect for cleanliness and free entrance.
reviews/11/text: One natural swimming pool but cold water there. There is also a restaurant, so it is good to go for coffee and then swim.
reviews/12/text: We swam there when local guide came and told us that some tourists just died when the wave sucked them to sea.
reviews/12/title: Dont swim there. It is dangerous
reviews/13/text: We absolutely loved swimming here, but was very lucky as we were the only ones.  We went in December and although the weather wasn't overly warm the sea/pools were.  Really stunning place.  We went back to try and swim again, but unfortunately the sea was so rough it would have been unsafe in the pools.
reviews/14/text: Very secluded location, hardly saw a few people, clean water, an extraordinary collaboration of nature and man.
reviews/15/text: This place is situated on the northern western coast of Madeira and is an oasis of relaxation. There were not many people around when we visited and so we were able to enjoy the village and area at our leisure. There are ample cafes, shops and restaurants in the area and some lovely pools and areas in which to bathe safely especially in the lava formed pools which shelter the swimmer from the more aggressive waves from the Atlantic Ocean.
reviews/16/text: Not too busy. Enough space for people (up to 20 approx) to lay down and enjoy the sunshine. Visited 3 times this month. It's got a shower, easy access by stairs and water is clean (can even see fish swimming).
reviews/17/text: The pool is great to wash off the black sand from the beach. You see lots of crabs and the waves make high splashes against the stones. The beach has a waterfall and perfect waves. You can rent a surfboard if the center is open. Free parking, restaurant, toilets, showers. Perfect spot!
reviews/18/text:
Breathtaking view, You will simply love it
I got goosebumps because of these view which feels strange to see irl but is so real it can be.
reviews/19/text: One of the best places I visited whilst in maderia. Free of charge, not full of tourists, clean and beautiful.

address: Caminho Levada da Serra Lombo das Raizes, Santo da Serra, Madeira 9200-155 Portugal
animal_welfare_tag/msg_body: Click below for expert advice on animal welfare in tourism.
description: CARE FOR NATURE; NATURE WILL CARE FOR YOU The “Parque Ribeira Primeira” (First Creek Park) main objective is to offer a close contact with Nature. Besides fishing Rainbow Trout and tasting your catch grilled on site, it is also possible to know their life cycle and understand how they live and reproduce. The entire Park is design and thought to be as Nature wisely is and allows, working with Nature, respecting Life and the Natural succession of seasons, with a constant and beautiful change in the landscape. The open air barbecue area is not a restaurant but a place where friends can gather to taste the freshest fish in Madeira. Everything is cooked with wood and in front of everybody. We can offer you: - Normal visit or Guided visit (30 to 45 minute walk “All about Nature and how we are also part of it” - minimum 8 people) - Trout fishing (we have all that is needed) - Explanation about all the lies fisherman truly say - Explanation about what is really fresh fish - Barbecue meals (your fresh trout or traditional “Espetada (beef) on a fresh laurel stick - Sandwiches, toasts, coffee, tea, scones and home made cakes - Special events on request. You can also experience a Levada Walk along the Levada da Serra do Faial (10 minutes walk from the Park) while we prepare your meal. Please come and visit us. This a magical place where children act as children and adults become children.

You can get to know the artists by visiting the page ART RESIDENTS and our BLOG. See the CURRENT STOCK section for collections and works available now. address: Rua Dom Carlos I 27-29, Funchal, Madeira 9060-051 Portugal
description: The Madeira Story Centre is a Museum situated in Funchal's Old Town centre where you can learn about Madeira's history in such a way, that you will feel that you are a part of it! The contents of the Museum are rigorous and detailed in order to give the the best information about the History and Culture of Madeira, from the island's volcanic origins to hydroplanes, its discovery and attacks by ferocious pirates, all described with the precision that you require. The Madeira Story Centre includes a large handcraft and souvenir shop with regional products, as well as a typical restaurant situated on the panoramic terrace with capacity for 200 people promoting Madeiran gastronomy. There are also thematic gardens where you can see the typical plants and flowers of Madeira, overlooking a magnificent view of the historical centre of Funchal. Madeira Story Centre Be a part of Madeira's history
